es: I

en: Mr. Jones, of the Manor Farm, had locked the hen-houses for the night, but was too drunk to remember to shut the pop-holes. With the ring of light from his lantern dancing from side to side, he lurched across the yard, kicked off his boots at the back door, drew himself a last glass of beer from the barrel in the scullery, and made his way up to bed, where Mrs. Jones was already snoring.
vi: Phạm Minh Ngọc translated from the original English version, with reference to the Russian version by Лара Беспалова -2001г. Mr. Jones, the owner of the Manor Farm, closed the chicken coop, but because he was too drunk, he forgot to close the pigsty. With a hurricane lamp in hand, swaying, sometimes to the right, sometimes to the left, he staggered across the yard, kicked off his boots at the back door, and stepped into the kitchen to finish the last mug of beer of the day before climbing into bed, where his wife, Mrs. Jones, was already snoring.
tr: Mr. Jones, the owner of Manor Farm, had closed the henhouse door as he did every night, but because he was very drunk, he had forgotten to close the holes through which the chickens went in and out. As he stumbled and staggered across the yard, the light from the lantern in his hand was swaying this way and that. At the back door, he took off his boots and threw them aside, filled one last glass of beer from the barrel in the pantry and drank it in one gulp, then went upstairs to his bedroom. Mrs. Jones was snoring loudly.
es: Mr. Jones, owner of Manor Farm, closed the henhouses for the night, but he was too drunk to remember that he had left the windows open. With the light of the lantern dancing from side to side, he crossed the yard, took off his boots at the back door, poured himself a final glass of beer from the barrel in the kitchen, and went straight to bed, where Mrs. Jones was already snoring.

en: As soon as the light in the bedroom went out there was a stirring and a fluttering all through the farm buildings. Word had gone round during the day that old Major, the prize Middle White boar, had had a strange dream on the previous night and wished to communicate it to the other animals. It had been agreed that they should all meet in the big barn as soon as Mr. Jones was safely out of the way. Old Major (so he was always called, though the name under which he had been exhibited was Willingdon Beauty) was so highly regarded on the farm that everyone was quite ready to lose an hour’s sleep in order to hear what he had to say.
vi: As soon as the light in the bedroom went out, rustling and whispering sounds suddenly arose here and there. That day, there was a rumor that the Leader, a white boar who had once won a medal at an exhibition, had a strange dream the night before and wanted to share it with all the animals. They agreed that as soon as Mr. Jones went to sleep, they would gather in the big barn. All the animals on the farm respected the Leader (they called him that, although at the exhibition he was known as Willingdon Handsome) and were willing to sacrifice their sleep to hear him speak.
tr: As soon as the light in the bedroom went out, a commotion and a rush began in all the buildings of the farm. It had been announced during the day: Old Major, the boar who had once won a prize, wanted to tell all the animals about a strange dream he had the night before. As soon as Mr. Jones was out of the way, it was decided that everyone would gather in the big barn. Old Major (he had entered the competition under the name Willingdon Beauty, but everyone called him Old Major) was so highly respected on the farm that everyone was willing to lose sleep to hear what he had to say.
es: As soon as the light went out in the bedroom, the commotion began throughout the farm. During the day, word had spread that Old Major, the prize boar, had had a strange dream the previous night and wanted to share it with the other animals. They had agreed to all meet in the main barn once Mr. Jones retired. Old Major (that was always his name, although he had been exhibited under the name Willingdon Beauty) was so highly regarded on the farm that everyone was willing to lose an hour of sleep to hear what he had to say.

en: At one end of the big barn, on a sort of raised platform, Major was already ensconced on his bed of straw, under a lantern which hung from a beam. He was twelve years old and had lately grown rather stout, but he was still a majestic-looking pig, with a wise and benevolent appearance in spite of the fact that his tushes had never been cut. Before long the other animals began to arrive and make themselves comfortable after their different fashions. First came the three dogs, Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher, and then the pigs, who settled down in the straw immediately in front of the platform. The hens perched themselves on the window-sills, the pigeons fluttered up to the rafters, the sheep and cows lay down behind the pigs and began to chew the cud. The two cart-horses, Boxer and Clover, came in together, walking very slowly and setting down their vast hairy hoofs with great care lest there should be some small animal concealed in the straw. Clover was a stout motherly mare approaching middle life, who had never quite got her figure back after her fourth foal. Boxer was an enormous beast, nearly eighteen hands high, and as strong as any two ordinary horses put together. A white stripe down his nose gave him a somewhat stupid appearance, and in fact he was not of first-rate intelligence, but he was universally respected for his steadiness of character and tremendous powers of work. After the horses came Muriel, the white goat, and Benjamin, the donkey. Benjamin was the oldest animal on the farm, and the worst tempered. He seldom talked, and when he did, it was usually to make some cynical remark — for instance, he would say that God had given him a tail to keep the flies off, but that he would sooner have had no tail and no flies. Alone among the animals on the farm he never laughed. If asked why, he would say that he saw nothing to laugh at. Nevertheless, without openly admitting it, he was devoted to Boxer; the two of them usually spent their Sundays together in the small paddock beyond the orchard, grazing side by side and never speaking.
vi: The Leader sat on a straw-cushioned platform at the far end of the barn, under the light of a hurricane lamp hanging from the rafters. It was twelve years old, and although it had recently gained some weight, with its protruding canine teeth, it still looked dignified and benevolent. The other animals began to arrive one by one, each finding a favorable spot to sit. First came the three dogs, Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher, followed by the pigs; they sat on the straw pile in front of the platform. The hens perched on the window sills, the pigeons settled on the rafters, and the cows and sheep lay behind the pigs and began their cud-chewing. Two cart horses named Boxer and Clover also came in, slowly approaching the platform, carefully watching each step to avoid crushing any small animals beneath the straw. Clover, a gentle middle-aged mare, had become somewhat stout after giving birth four times. Boxer, a majestic horse nearly two meters tall and as strong as two ordinary horses. Because of a white stripe down his nose, he looked somewhat stupid, and indeed he was not very intelligent, but he was respected by the other animals for his steadiness and hard work. Next came a white goat named Muriel and a donkey named Benjamin. Benjamin was the oldest animal among them, but also the most ill-tempered. Benjamin spoke little, but whenever he did, it was always to make a sarcastic remark, such as once declaring that God had given him a tail to swat flies, but he would have preferred to have neither tail nor flies. He was the only animal that never laughed. If asked why, he would say: there was nothing to laugh about. Despite this, and although he never spoke of it, he was very loyal to Boxer; every Sunday, the two of them would quietly graze together in the paddock behind the orchard.
tr: The leader had already settled on a straw mattress laid on a platform illuminated by a lantern hanging from one of the beams in the ceiling, in a corner of the large barn. He was twelve years old, had recently put on a bit of weight; despite his long, sharp canine teeth never having been cut, he was an imposing pig who looked wise and fatherly. Soon, the other animals also began to arrive one after another and started to take their places in an orderly manner. First appeared three dogs named Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher; then the pigs came and settled on the straw right in front of the platform. The hens perched on the window sills, the pigeons settled on the roof beams, and the sheep and cows lay down behind the pigs and began to chew cud. Two cart horses named Boxer and Clover entered together; they walked slowly, carefully placing their large, hairy feet on the ground, worried that there might be a small animal among the straw that they couldn't see. Clover was a large, motherly mare who could be considered middle-aged; she had never quite regained her former shape after giving birth to her fourth foal. Boxer, on the other hand, was a very large animal, nearly two meters tall, with the strength of two horses. A white stripe down his forehead to his nose made him look somewhat stupid; indeed, he was not considered the smartest animal on the farm, but he had earned everyone's respect with his solid character and astonishing work ethic. After the horses, a white goat named Muriel and a donkey named Benjamin appeared. Benjamin was the oldest and most cantankerous animal on the farm. It couldn't be said that honey dripped from his mouth, but he spoke little and to the point: "God gave me a tail to shoo away flies; but I wish there were no flies and no tail either." He was the only animal on the farm who never laughed. To those who asked why he didn't laugh, he would reply, "What's there to laugh at?" But despite not showing it openly, he admired Boxer; the two of them would spend their Sundays together, usually grazing side by side in silence in the meadow behind the orchard.
es: At one end of the main barn, on a sort of raised platform, Major was already settled comfortably in his straw bed, under a lantern hanging from a beam. He was twelve years old and had recently become quite fat, but he was still a majestic pig with a wise and good-natured appearance, despite his tusks never having been cut. After a short while, the other animals began to arrive and settle down comfortably, each in their own way. First came the three dogs, Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher, and then the pigs, who settled down in the straw in front of the platform. The hens perched on the windowsills, the pigeons fluttered up to the rafters, the sheep and cows lay down behind the pigs and began to chew the cud. The two cart-horses, Boxer and Clover, entered together, walking slowly and placing their large hairy hooves with great care, fearing that some small animal might be hidden in the straw. Clover was a sturdy mare, getting on in years and with a maternal appearance, who had not managed to regain her figure after her fourth foal. Boxer was an enormous beast, nearly eighteen hands high and as strong as two ordinary horses put together. A white stripe down his nose gave him a somewhat stupid appearance, and indeed he was not very intelligent, but he was respected by all for his steadiness of character and tremendous powers of work. After the horses came Muriel, the white goat, and Benjamin, the donkey. Benjamin was the oldest and the worst-tempered animal on the farm. He rarely spoke, and when he did, it was usually to make some cynical remark; for example, he would say that "God had given him a tail to keep the flies off, but that he would rather have had no tail and no flies." He was the only animal on the farm that never laughed. If asked why, he would say that he saw nothing to laugh at. However, without openly admitting it, he was devoted to Boxer; the two of them usually spent their Sundays together in the small paddock beyond the orchard, grazing side by side without speaking.

en: The two horses had just lain down when a brood of ducklings, which had lost their mother, filed into the barn, cheeping feebly and wandering from side to side to find some place where they would not be trodden on. Clover made a sort of wall round them with her great foreleg, and the ducklings nestled down inside it and promptly fell asleep. At the last moment Mollie, the foolish, pretty white mare who drew Mr. Jones’s trap, came mincing daintily in, chewing at a lump of sugar. She took a place near the front and began flirting her white mane, hoping to draw attention to the red ribbons it was plaited with. Last of all came the cat, who looked round, as usual, for the warmest place, and finally squeezed herself in between Boxer and Clover; there she purred contentedly throughout Major’s speech without listening to a word of what he was saying.
vi: As soon as the two horses lay down, the orphaned ducklings rushed into the barn, chirping softly as they scurried around, hoping to find a safe spot. Mrs. Fat used her front legs to create an enclosure for them, and the ducklings quickly nestled inside and fell asleep without realizing it. Just before the meeting began, Mollie, a foolish white mare who usually pulled Mr. Jones's small cart, sashayed in while chewing on a lump of sugar. She immediately took a spot in front of the platform and shook her mane, hoping the others would notice the red ribbon adorning it. Finally, there was a cat, which looked around and, as usual, sought out a warm place for itself. It squeezed in between Boxer and Mrs. Fat, purring contentedly, indifferent to whatever the Leader had to say.
tr: Just as the two horses had lain down, the orphaned ducklings, chirping loudly, entered the barn in a single file; waddling around, they were looking for a place where they wouldn't get trampled. Clover built a wall around the ducklings with her large foreleg; they huddled there and immediately fell asleep. At the last moment, Mollie, the white mare with long hair but short on brains, who pulled Mr. Jones's two-wheeled cart, arrived; with a lump of sugar in her mouth, she gracefully entered. She chose a spot at the front; hoping to draw attention, she began to sway her white mane, braided with red ribbons, from side to side. Finally, the cat appeared; true to its nature, it immediately began to look for the warmest spot and eventually nestled between Boxer and Clover; it purred contentedly throughout Old Major's speech –without listening to a single word he said.
es: As soon as the two horses lay down, a group of ducklings that had lost their mother entered the barn, chirping weakly and wandering from side to side in search of a place where they wouldn't be in danger of being stepped on. Clover formed a sort of wall with her enormous front hoof, and the ducklings nestled there, falling asleep immediately. At the last moment, Mollie, the pretty and silly white mare that pulled Mr. Jones's cart, entered affectedly, chewing on a sugar lump. She positioned herself in front, flirting with her white mane to draw attention to the red ribbons with which it had been braided. The last to appear was the cat, who, as usual, sought the warmest place, finally settling between Boxer and Clover; there she purred contentedly during Major's speech, without hearing a single word of what he was saying.

en: All the animals were now present except Moses, the tame raven, who slept on a perch behind the back door. When Major saw that they had all made themselves comfortable and were waiting attentively, he cleared his throat and began:
vi: So all the animals in the Manor Farm were present, except for the raven Moses, who was sleeping on the fence just outside the back door. When the Leader saw that everyone was settled and ready to listen, he cleared his throat and began:
tr: Except for the pet raven Moses, who was sleeping on the perch near the back door, all the animals had arrived. The leader, seeing that everyone had taken their place and was waiting in silence, cleared his throat and began to speak:
es: All the animals were already present —except for Moses, the tame raven, who was sleeping on a perch behind the back door—. When Major saw that they were all settled and waiting attentively, he cleared his throat and began:

en: “Comrades, you have heard already about the strange dream that I had last night. But I will come to the dream later. I have something else to say first. I do not think, comrades, that I shall be with you for many months longer, and before I die, I feel it my duty to pass on to you such wisdom as I have acquired. I have had a long life, I have had much time for thought as I lay alone in my stall, and I think I may say that I understand the nature of life on this earth as well as any animal now living. It is about this that I wish to speak to you.
vi: "Comrades! As you all know, last night I had a strange dream. But I will talk about that later. First, I want to discuss with you some entirely different matters. Comrades, I think that I won't be able to stay with you much longer, so I believe that before I die, I have a responsibility to share with you the experiences I have accumulated throughout my life. I have had what can be called a long life, and I have thought a lot while lying alone in the barn. I think I can say that I understand life as well as any animal in this world. That is what I want to tell you, comrades.
tr: "Comrades, you all know that I had a strange dream last night. I will come to the dream later. I want to tell you something else first. Comrades, I don't think I have much time left. Therefore, I consider it my duty to pass on to you the knowledge and experiences I have gained so far. I have lived a long life, and while lying alone in my stall, I had much time to think; I can say that I have understood the order of this world as much as any living animal. What I want to talk to you about today is precisely this.
es: —Comrades: you have already heard about the strange dream I had last night. But I will talk about that later. First, I have to say something else. I do not believe, comrades, that I will be with you for many more months, and before I die, I feel it is my duty to pass on to you the wisdom I have acquired. I have lived many years, had plenty of time to meditate while I have been alone in my sty, and I believe I can say that I understand the meaning of life in this world as well as any other living animal. It is about this that I wish to speak to you.

en: “Now, comrades, what is the nature of this life of ours? Let us face it: our lives are miserable, laborious, and short. We are born, we are given just so much food as will keep the breath in our bodies, and those of us who are capable of it are forced to work to the last atom of our strength; and the very instant that our usefulness has come to an end we are slaughtered with hideous cruelty. No animal in England knows the meaning of happiness or leisure after he is a year old. No animal in England is free. The life of an animal is misery and slavery: that is the plain truth.
vi: Now, comrades, what is the true nature of our lives? We must look straight at the truth. Our lives are toil, misery, and short-lived. We are born, we are given just enough food to keep us from starving, those who can work must work until they are exhausted, and when we can no longer work, we are slaughtered in a most brutal and savage manner. No animal in England knows the meaning of happiness and joy from the moment they are one year old. No animal in England is free. The life of an animal is one of misery and slavery: that is the plain truth.
tr: "Yes comrades, what kind of life are we living? Let's not be afraid to say it openly: Our short lives pass by in poverty, struggling and toiling from morning till night. After coming into the world, they give us just enough food to survive; they make those of us who remain standing work until we drop; and when we become useless to them, they slaughter us with terrible cruelty. In England, after reaching one year of age, no animal knows what happiness is, no animal can rest or have fun. In England, no animal is free. What is our life but misery and slavery! This, in all its starkness, is the truth.
es: "Let's see, comrades: What is the reality of this life of ours? Let's face it: our lives are sad, laborious, and short. We are born, we are given the necessary food to sustain ourselves, and those of us who are able to work are forced to do so until the last ounce of our strength; and the very moment we are no longer useful, we are killed with appalling cruelty. No animal in England knows the meaning of happiness or leisure after reaching one year of age. There is no free animal in England. The life of an animal is only misery and slavery; this is the plain truth.

en: “But is this simply part of the order of nature? Is it because this land of ours is so poor that it cannot afford a decent life to those who dwell upon it? No, comrades, a thousand times no! The soil of England is fertile, its climate is good, it is capable of affording food in abundance to an enormously greater number of animals than now inhabit it. This single farm of ours would support a dozen horses, twenty cows, hundreds of sheep — and all of them living in a comfort and a dignity that are now almost beyond our imagining. Why then do we continue in this miserable condition? Because nearly the whole of the produce of our labour is stolen from us by human beings. There, comrades, is the answer to all our problems. It is summed up in a single word — Man. Man is the only real enemy we have. Remove Man from the scene, and the root cause of hunger and overwork is abolished for ever.
vi: But is that the law of nature? Could it be that our country is so poor that it cannot support the animals living here? No, a thousand times no, comrades. Our land is fertile, the weather is favorable, and it can easily provide food for a much larger number of animals than it currently does. Just our farm alone could support a dozen horses, twenty cows, hundreds of sheep, and all of them could live in comfort and dignity that we cannot even imagine now. So why do we continue to live in such miserable conditions? Because almost everything we produce is taken by humans. That is the cause of all our problems. In short, in one word: Man. Man is our enemy. If there were no humans, we would never be hungry again, and we would no longer have to do hard labor.
tr: "So, is this situation a law of Nature? Is our country so poor that it cannot offer a decent life to those living on its land? No, comrades, never! The lands of England are fertile; the air and water of our homeland are good; today, it can provide plenty of food for many more animals than those living in this country. Even just our farm alone can feed a dozen horses, twenty cows, hundreds of sheep; not just feed, but can give them a life of comfort and dignity that we cannot even dream of today. So, why should we submit to this misery? Humans are stealing almost all of what we produce with our labor. Here, comrades, the answer to all our problems lies here. It can be summarized in a single word: Man. Our only real enemy is Man. Remove Man, and the root cause of hunger and overwork will be abolished forever from the earth.
es: "But, does this really form part of the order of nature?" "Is it perhaps because this land of ours is so poor that it cannot provide a decent life for all its inhabitants?" "No, comrades; a thousand times no." "The soil of England is fertile, its climate is good, it is capable of providing abundant food for a much larger number of animals than currently inhabit it." "Our farm alone can support a dozen horses, twenty cows, hundreds of sheep; and all of them living with a comfort and dignity that at this moment is almost beyond our imagination." "Why, then, do we continue in this miserable condition?" "Because human beings take away almost all the fruit of our labor." "There it is, comrades, the answer to all our problems." "Everything is explained in a single word: Man." "Man is the only real enemy we have." "Remove man from the scene and the root cause of our hunger and overwork will be abolished forever."

en: “Man is the only creature that consumes without producing. He does not give milk, he does not lay eggs, he is too weak to pull the plough, he cannot run fast enough to catch rabbits. Yet he is lord of all the animals. He sets them to work, he gives back to them the bare minimum that will prevent them from starving, and the rest he keeps for himself. Our labour tills the soil, our dung fertilises it, and yet there is not one of us that owns more than his bare skin. You cows that I see before me, how many thousands of gallons of milk have you given during this last year? And what has happened to that milk which should have been breeding up sturdy calves? Every drop of it has gone down the throats of our enemies. And you hens, how many eggs have you laid in this last year, and how many of those eggs ever hatched into chickens? The rest have all gone to market to bring in money for Jones and his men. And you, Clover, where are those four foals you bore, who should have been the support and pleasure of your old age? Each was sold at a year old — you will never see one of them again. In return for your four confinements and all your labour in the fields, what have you ever had except your bare rations and a stall?
vi: Humans are the only creatures that eat without working. Humans do not produce milk, do not lay eggs, cannot pull a plow, and do not run as fast as a rabbit. Yet they are the masters of all of us. They make us work, take away all the fruits of our labor, and only feed us enough to keep us from starving. We plow the fields, fertilize them with our dung, but what do we get? Nothing but skin and bones. Comrades cows sitting in front of me, how many liters of milk did you produce last year? And where did the milk that was supposed to nourish your calves go? Our enemy drank every last drop. And you, hens, how many eggs did you lay last year, and how many of those hatched into chicks? Old Jones and his men took them all to the market to sell for money. Mrs. Fat, where are your four children, your joy and support in your old age? They were sold when they were just a year old, and you will never see them again. A starvation diet and a shed, that's all your four labors and your farm work have earned you!
tr: "Man is the only creature that consumes without producing. He does not give milk, he does not lay eggs, he is not strong enough to pull the plow, he cannot run fast enough to catch a rabbit. Yet, he is the lord of all the animals. He sets them to work, he gives them just enough food to keep them from starving, and the rest he keeps for himself. We plow the fields with our labor, we enrich the soil with our manure; yet none of us has anything except our bare skin. You, cows sitting before me; how many thousands of liters of milk did you give this year? Where did the milk that was necessary to raise sturdy calves go? Every drop of it has gone down the throats of our enemies. You, hens; how many eggs did you lay this year, how many of those eggs hatched into chicks? Almost all of them were sold at the market, bringing money to Jones and his men. And you, Clover, where are those four foals you bore; where are those foals you would lean on and enjoy when you grow old? All four were sold when they reached a year old; you will never see them again. What did you get in return for those four foals you gave to the humans and your labor in the fields, other than a handful of feed and a cold barn?
es: »Man is the only creature that consumes without producing. He does not give milk, he does not lay eggs, he is too weak to pull the plow, and his speed does not even allow him to catch rabbits. Yet he is lord and master of all the animals. He makes them work, gives them the bare minimum to keep them alive, and keeps the rest for himself. Our labor tills the soil, our manure fertilizes it, and yet there is not one of us that owns more than his skin. You, cows, who are here, how many thousands of liters of milk have you given this last year? And what has become of that milk which should have been used to raise sturdy calves? Every last drop has gone down the throats of our enemies. And you, hens, how many eggs have you laid this year and how many chicks have hatched from those eggs? All the rest has gone to the market to produce money for Jones and his people. And you, Clover, where are those four foals you bore, that should have been the support and joy of your old age? All were sold at a year old; you will never see them again. As a reward for your four offspring and all your work in the fields, what have you had except for your meager rations and a stall?

en: “And even the miserable lives we lead are not allowed to reach their natural span. For myself I do not grumble, for I am one of the lucky ones. I am twelve years old and have had over four hundred children. Such is the natural life of a pig. But no animal escapes the cruel knife in the end. You young porkers who are sitting in front of me, every one of you will scream your lives out at the block within a year. To that horror we all must come — cows, pigs, hens, sheep, everyone. Even the horses and the dogs have no better fate. You, Boxer, the very day that those great muscles of yours lose their power, Jones will sell you to the knacker, who will cut your throat and boil you down for the foxhounds. As for the dogs, when they grow old and toothless, Jones ties a brick round their necks and drowns them in the nearest pond.
vi: But even though we are in such a miserable state, we don't get to live our full lifespan. As for me, I have nothing to complain about, because in reality, I have been lucky. This year, I am twelve years old, and I have more than four hundred children. That's how the heavens created the pig species. But in the end, no animal can escape the cruel blade. All of you meat pigs sitting in front of me here, within a year, all of you will have to bid farewell to life on the slaughter table. All of us, cows, pigs, chickens, sheep, none of us can escape that terrible fate. The fate of horses and dogs is no better. Comrade Warrior too, as soon as your muscles weaken, old Jones will sell you to the horse butcher, who will slit your throat and boil you down for the hunting dogs to eat. The old, toothless dogs will have a brick tied to their necks by old Jones and be thrown into the lake.
tr: "Moreover, they don't even allow this wretched life we live to reach its natural end. I'm considered lucky, so I'm not complaining too much. I'm twelve years old, and I've had more than four hundred children. Quite natural for a pig. But no animal can escape that cruel knife in the end. You, young pigs sitting in front of me; within a year, you'll die squealing under the knife. Cows, pigs, chickens, sheep; this horrible end awaits all of us, all of us. The fate of horses and dogs is not much different from ours. You, Boxer, as soon as those big muscles of yours lose their strength, Jones will sell you to the butcher who buys crippled and old horses. The butcher will slit your throat, boil you in a pot, and make dog food out of you. As for the dogs; once they grow old and lose their teeth, Jones ties a stone around their necks and throws them into the nearest lake.
es: "They don't even allow us to reach the natural end of our miserable lives." "I don't complain for myself, because I have been one of the fortunate ones." "I am twelve years old and I have had more than four hundred offspring." "Such is the natural fate of a pig." "But in the end, no animal escapes the cruel knife." "You, young pigs sitting in front of me, each one of you will be squealing for your life within a year." "We will all come to that horror: cows, pigs, chickens, sheep; all of us." "Not even the horses and dogs have a better fate." "You, Boxer, the very day your great muscles lose their strength, Jones will sell you to the knacker, who will cut your throat and boil you down for the hunting dogs." "As for the dogs, when they are old and toothless, Jones ties a brick around their neck and drowns them in the nearest pond."

en: “Is it not crystal clear, then, comrades, that all the evils of this life of ours spring from the tyranny of human beings? Only get rid of Man, and the produce of our labour would be our own. Almost overnight we could become rich and free. What then must we do? Why, work night and day, body and soul, for the overthrow of the human race! That is my message to you, comrades: Rebellion! I do not know when that Rebellion will come, it might be in a week or in a hundred years, but I know, as surely as I see this straw beneath my feet, that sooner or later justice will be done. Fix your eyes on that, comrades, throughout the short remainder of your lives! And above all, pass on this message of mine to those who come after you, so that future generations shall carry on the struggle until it is victorious.
vi: Comrades, don't you see that all the suffering in our lives is caused by humans? If we eliminate humans, all the fruits of our labor will belong to us. If we achieve this, in just one night we will become rich and free. So what must we do? Work tirelessly, day and night, using both strength and talent to overthrow the human oppressors! Revolt! Comrades - that is my message. I don't know when the Revolt will happen, it could be next week, or it could be a hundred years from now, but I know for sure, as clearly as I see the straw beneath my feet, that sooner or later justice will be established. Comrades, think about this for the rest of your short lives! Moreover, pass my message to future generations, so that they may continue the struggle until the final victory.
tr: "So then, comrades, isn't it as clear as day that all the evils that befall us in this life stem from human tyranny? Let's get rid of Mankind, and the fruits of our labor will be ours. Only then will we be rich and free. So, what should we do? Day and night, with all our might, we must strive to overthrow the human race! So, I tell you comrades: Rise up! I don't know when this Uprising will happen, it could be in a week, it could be in a hundred years; but as surely as I see the straw beneath my feet, I see that justice will eventually prevail. Comrades, in this short life of yours, do not forget this! And most importantly, pass on this advice to those who come after you, so that future generations may fight until victory.
es: Isn't it then of the utmost clarity, comrades, that all the evils of our lives stem from the tyranny of human beings? Eliminate Man, and the product of our labor will belong to us. Almost overnight, we would become rich and free. So, what must we do? Work night and day, with body and soul, to overthrow the human race! That is my message, comrades: Rebellion! I do not know when that rebellion will come; perhaps in a week or in a hundred years; but I do know, as surely as I see this straw beneath my feet, that sooner or later justice will be done. Keep your eyes fixed on that, comrades, during the few years you have left to live! And, above all, pass on my message to those who come after, so that future generations may continue the struggle until victory is achieved.

en: “And remember, comrades, your resolution must never falter. No argument must lead you astray. Never listen when they tell you that Man and the animals have a common interest, that the prosperity of the one is the prosperity of the others. It is all lies. Man serves the interests of no creature except himself. And among us animals let there be perfect unity, perfect comradeship in the struggle. All men are enemies. All animals are comrades.”
vi: Comrades, be steadfast. Do not waver. Do not listen to the propaganda that Man and animals have common interests, that the prosperity of one is the prosperity of the other. It's all deceit. Man does not care about anyone's interests; he only cares about himself. We animals must unite and have a spirit of comradeship in this struggle. All humans are enemies. All animals are comrades.
tr: "And comrades, your determination must never, but never waver. No argument should divert you from your path. There may be those who say that humans and animals have a common interest, that the well-being of one is the well-being of the others. Do not listen to them. It is all lies. Mankind does not consider the interests of any creature other than itself. In this struggle, establish complete unity among animals, ensure perfect comradeship. All humans are enemies! All animals are comrades!"
es: "And remember, comrades: your will must never waver. No argument should sway you. Never pay attention when they tell you that Man and animals have common interests, that the prosperity of one is also that of the others. They are lies. Man serves the interests of no being except his own. And among us animals, let there be perfect unity, perfect comradeship in the struggle. All men are enemies. All animals are comrades.

en: At this moment there was a tremendous uproar. While Major was speaking four large rats had crept out of their holes and were sitting on their hindquarters, listening to him. The dogs had suddenly caught sight of them, and it was only by a swift dash for their holes that the rats saved their lives. Major raised his trotter for silence.
vi: At that moment, a commotion arose. It turned out that while the Leader was speaking, four sewer rats had crawled out of their hole and also came to listen. The dogs saw them, and luckily the rats managed to run back into their hole, otherwise they would have lost their lives. The Leader had to raise his paw to request silence.
tr: At that moment, a tremendous noise erupted. While Koca Reis was speaking, four large rats that had slipped out of their holes sat on their hind legs and began listening to him. The dogs, as soon as they saw them, launched an attack; the rats quickly escaped into their holes, barely saving their lives. Reis raised his front paw and silenced everyone:
es: At that moment, a tremendous commotion occurred. While Major was speaking, four large rats had come out of their hiding places and had sat on their haunches, listening to him. The dogs suddenly spotted them and only by a swift dash to their refuges did the rats manage to save their lives. Major raised his paw to impose silence.

en: “Comrades,” he said, “here is a point that must be settled. The wild creatures, such as rats and rabbits — are they our friends or our enemies? Let us put it to the vote. I propose this question to the meeting: Are rats comrades?”
vi: "Comrades," it said, "there is a problem that needs to be addressed. Wild animals like rats and rabbits, are they our friends or our enemies? Let's put it to a vote. I would like to pose the question to the assembly as follows: Are rats comrades?"
tr: "Comrades. We have a problem to solve. Are wild animals like rats and rabbits our friends or our enemies? Let's put it to a vote. I ask this question: Are rats our comrades?"
es: —Comrades —he said—, there is a point here that must be clarified. Wild animals, like mice and rabbits, are they our friends or our enemies? Let's put it to a vote. "I pose this question to the assembly: Are the rats comrades?"

en: The vote was taken at once, and it was agreed by an overwhelming majority that rats were comrades. There were only four dissentients, the three dogs and the cat, who was afterwards discovered to have voted on both sides. Major continued:
vi: The vote was conducted immediately, with the majority agreeing to consider the rats as comrades. There were only four votes against, which came from three dogs and one cat, but it was later discovered that the cat had cast both a for and against vote. The Leader continued:
tr: The vote was taken immediately; it was decided by a very large majority that the rats were comrades. Only four votes were against, and they came from three dogs and a cat. Later, it was understood that the cat had voted both yes and no. The Big Chief continued his speech:
es: It was put to a vote immediately, and it was decided by an overwhelming majority that the rats were comrades. There were only four dissenters: the three dogs and the cat, who, as was later discovered, had voted on both sides. Major continued:

en: “I have little more to say. I merely repeat, remember always your duty of enmity towards Man and all his ways. Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. And remember also that in fighting against Man, we must not come to resemble him. Even when you have conquered him, do not adopt his vices. No animal must ever live in a house, or sleep in a bed, or wear clothes, or drink alcohol, or smoke tobacco, or touch money, or engage in trade. All the habits of Man are evil. And, above all, no animal must ever tyrannise over his own kind. Weak or strong, clever or simple, we are all brothers. No animal must ever kill any other animal. All animals are equal.
vi: "I would like to add a little more. I just want to reiterate that your duty is to always fight against Man and everything created by him. All two-legged creatures are enemies. All four-legged creatures or those with wings are friends. Comrades, you must always remember that we must not imitate humans in our struggle against them. Even when victorious, we must not adopt their vices. No animal must live in a house, sleep in a bed, wear clothes, drink alcohol, smoke, use money, or engage in trade. All human customs are harmful. Most importantly, no animal must oppress another. Strong or weak, intelligent or ordinary, we are all brothers. We must not kill one another. All animals are born equal.
tr: "I am not going to say anything more. There is only one point I want to repeat: Never forget that it is your duty to act hostile towards Man and all the misfortunes that come from him. Two-legged creatures are our enemies. Four-legged creatures and winged creatures are our friends. Also, remember that while fighting against Man, we must not end up resembling him. Even when you have defeated him, do not try to adopt his bad habits. No animal should ever live in a house, sleep in a bed, wear clothes, drink alcohol, smoke, touch money, or engage in trade. All of Man's habits are evil. And most importantly, no animal should ever tyrannize over its own kind. The strong, the weak, the intelligent, the foolish, we are all brothers. No animal should kill another animal. All animals are equal.
es: —I have little left to tell you. I simply insist: always remember your duty of enmity towards Man and his ways. Anything that walks on two legs is an enemy. Anything that walks on four legs, or has wings, is a friend. And also remember that in the struggle against Man, we must not come to resemble him. Even when you have defeated him, do not adopt his vices. No animal must live in a house, sleep in a bed, wear clothes, drink alcohol, smoke tobacco, handle money, or engage in trade. All the habits of Man are evil. And, above all things, no animal must tyrannize over his own kind. Weak or strong, clever or simple, we are all brothers. No animal must kill another animal. All animals are equal.

en: “And now, comrades, I will tell you about my dream of last night. I cannot describe that dream to you. It was a dream of the earth as it will be when Man has vanished. But it reminded me of something that I had long forgotten. Many years ago, when I was a little pig, my mother and the other sows used to sing an old song of which they knew only the tune and the first three words. I had known that tune in my infancy, but it had long since passed out of my mind. Last night, however, it came back to me in my dream. And what is more, the words of the song also came back-words, I am certain, which were sung by the animals of long ago and have been lost to memory for generations. I will sing you that song now, comrades. I am old and my voice is hoarse, but when I have taught you the tune, you can sing it better for yourselves. It is called ‘Beasts of England’.”
vi: And now, comrades, I will tell you about my dream from last night. I cannot describe it. I dreamed of the Earth when humans had already disappeared. This dream revived in my mind the following event: "A long time ago, when I was still a little pig, my mother along with other pigs used to sing a song from the old days: they only remembered the melody and the first three words. When I was young, I also knew the melody, but I had forgotten it long ago. However, last night, in a dream, I remembered everything, and more than that, I also recalled the lyrics of the song. I am certain that in the past, animals used to sing it, but later they forgot, and in recent generations, they completely lost the ability to sing. Now I will sing it for you comrades. I am old, my voice is no longer clear, but when I teach you the melody, you will sing it better. The song is called: Beasts of England."
tr: "Comrades, I can now speak about the dream I had last night. I cannot describe it exactly, but I can say that I saw what the world would be like after Man has vanished. I remembered something I had long forgotten. Years ago, when I was a little pig, my mother and the other sows used to sing an old song of which they only knew the tune and the first three words. I had learned the tune as a child, but it had long since slipped my mind. Last night, in my dream, the tune of the song came back to me. Moreover, I remembered the words of the song. I have no doubt that these were the words of a song that animals sang in ancient times, forgotten for generations. Now, comrades, I will sing this song to you. I am old, my voice is hoarse, but once I teach you the tune, you can sing it much better. The name of the song is, 'Beasts of England.'"
es: "And now, comrades, I will tell you about my dream from last night." "I am not in a position to describe it to you." "It was a vision of how the earth will be when Man has been outlawed." "But it brought to my memory something that I had long forgotten." "Many years ago, when I was a little piglet, my mother and the other sows used to sing an old song of which they only knew the tune and the first three words." "I learned that song in my childhood, but I had long since forgotten it." "Last night, however, it came back to me in the dream." "And more than that, the words of the song as well; words that, I am certain, were sung by animals of long ago and then forgotten for many generations." "I will sing that song to you now, comrades." "I am old and my voice is hoarse, but when I have taught you the tune you will be able to sing it better than I can." "It is called 'Beasts of England.'"

en: The singing of this song threw the animals into the wildest excitement. Almost before Major had reached the end, they had begun singing it for themselves. Even the stupidest of them had already picked up the tune and a few of the words, and as for the clever ones, such as the pigs and dogs, they had the entire song by heart within a few minutes. And then, after a few preliminary tries, the whole farm burst out into ‘Beasts of England’ in tremendous unison. The cows lowed it, the dogs whined it, the sheep bleated it, the horses whinnied it, the ducks quacked it. They were so delighted with the song that they sang it right through five times in succession, and might have continued singing it all night if they had not been interrupted.
vi: The song had made the animals extremely excited. Some of them managed to join in even before the Leader finished singing. Even the most ignorant ones grasped the melody and learned a few words, while the smarter ones, like the dogs and pigs, memorized the entire song within the first few minutes. After a few practice sessions, the whole farm could sing the "Beasts of England" in unison. Each species sang in its own voice: cows bellowed, dogs barked, sheep bleated, horses neighed, and ducks quacked. They enjoyed the song so much that they sang it five times in a row and could have kept singing it all night if they hadn't been interrupted.
tr: The song had stirred a wild excitement in the hearts of the animals. Before the Leader even reached the end, they had all begun to sing together. Even the most foolish had picked up the tune and a few words of the song; those as intelligent as the pigs and dogs had memorized the entire song in a few minutes. After a few attempts, the farm echoed with the sound of "Animals of England" sung in unison. The cows were mooing, the dogs were barking, the sheep were bleating, the horses were neighing, and the ducks were quacking. They enjoyed it so much that they sang the song from beginning to end five times; if Mr. Jones hadn't woken up, they might have sung it until morning.
es: The rehearsal of this song put all the animals in the wildest excitement. Shortly before Major had finished, they had all started singing it. Even the most stupid had retained the melody and part of the lyrics, while the more intelligent ones, like the pigs and the dogs, learned the song in a few minutes. Shortly afterwards, with the help of several previous rehearsals, the entire farm broke into singing "Beasts of England" in unison. The cows mooed it, the dogs howled it, the sheep bleated it, the horses neighed it, the ducks quacked it. They were so pleased with the song that they repeated it five times in a row and would have continued all night if they hadn't been interrupted.

en: Unfortunately, the uproar awoke Mr. Jones, who sprang out of bed, making sure that there was a fox in the yard. He seized the gun which always stood in a corner of his bedroom, and let fly a charge of number 6 shot into the darkness. The pellets buried themselves in the wall of the barn and the meeting broke up hurriedly. Everyone fled to his own sleeping-place. The birds jumped on to their perches, the animals settled down in the straw, and the whole farm was asleep in a moment.
vi: Unfortunately, the loud noise woke Mr. Jones, who got out of bed convinced that a fox had entered the yard. He grabbed the gun that was always kept in the corner of the room and fired a series of shots into the air. Some pellets embedded themselves in the wall of the barn, and the meeting quickly came to an end. Each animal returned to its sleeping place. The poultry jumped onto their perches, while the livestock lay down on the straw, and soon the entire farm was asleep.
tr: But unfortunately, Mr. Jones woke up from the noise; thinking a fox had entered the yard, he jumped out of bed. As he grabbed the rifle that always stood in the corner of his bedroom, he fired into the darkness. As soon as the large pellets embedded themselves in the wall of the barn, the animals at the meeting scattered like chicks. Everyone ran to where they slept. The birds jumped to their perches, and the animals lay down on their straw beds. Soon, the entire farm fell asleep.
es: Unfortunately, the armed commotion woke up Mr. Jones, who jumped out of bed believing there was a fox prowling around the pens. He took the shotgun, which was permanently in a corner of the bedroom, and fired a shot into the darkness. The pellets embedded themselves in the barn wall and the meeting broke up hastily. Everyone fled to their sleeping places. The birds jumped onto their perches, the animals lay down in the straw, and in an instant, the whole farm was asleep.

en: Three nights later old Major died peacefully in his sleep. His body was buried at the foot of the orchard.
vi: Three nights later, the old Leader peacefully passed away. His body was buried at the end of the garden.

es: THREE nights later, Old Major died peacefully in his sleep. His body was buried at the foot of the orchard.

en: This was early in March. During the next three months there was much secret activity. Major’s speech had given to the more intelligent animals on the farm a completely new outlook on life. They did not know when the Rebellion predicted by Major would take place, they had no reason for thinking that it would be within their own lifetime, but they saw clearly that it was their duty to prepare for it. The work of teaching and organising the others fell naturally upon the pigs, who were generally recognised as being the cleverest of the animals. Pre-eminent among the pigs were two young boars named Snowball and Napoleon, whom Mr. Jones was breeding up for sale. Napoleon was a large, rather fierce-looking Berkshire boar, the only Berkshire on the farm, not much of a talker, but with a reputation for getting his own way. Snowball was a more vivacious pig than Napoleon, quicker in speech and more inventive, but was not considered to have the same depth of character. All the other male pigs on the farm were porkers. The best known among them was a small fat pig named Squealer, with very round cheeks, twinkling eyes, nimble movements, and a shrill voice. He was a brilliant talker, and when he was arguing some difficult point he had a way of skipping from side to side and whisking his tail which was somehow very persuasive. The others said of Squealer that he could turn black into white.
vi: That incident happened at the beginning of March. The animals intensified their underground activities continuously for the next three months. The Leader's speech had created an entirely new way of life for the intelligent ones. They didn't know when the Rebellion that the Leader predicted would happen, nor did they think they would witness it, but they knew one thing clearly: they had the responsibility to carry out the preparations. Of course, the task of education and organization was assigned to the pigs because they were considered the most intelligent species. Two young male pigs named Snowball and Napoleon, who were being fattened by Mr. Jones for sale, were the most famous. Napoleon was a fierce-looking boar, the only Berkshire on the Manor Farm; he was known for being taciturn but reputedly patient. Snowball was more lively, more articulate, and had more ideas, but most believed his character was not as deep as Napoleon's. The rest were all meat pigs. The most prominent among them was named Squealer, a small, rather fat but nimble pig with chubby cheeks, darting eyes, and a shrill voice. He was an excellent speaker; when he needed to prove a difficult point, he would skip around and wag his tail, looking very persuasive. It was rumored that he could turn black into white with ease.
tr: It was the early days of March when the Leader died. During the following three months, a lot of secret activities were carried out. The Leader's speech had made the smarter animals on the farm look at life with a completely new perspective. No one knew when the Rebellion he had predicted would occur; they also didn't know if they would live long enough to see such an uprising; but they could clearly see that their duty was to prepare for that day. The task of educating and organizing the others was naturally given to the pigs, who were generally considered the smartest of the animals. The most talented of the pigs were two young male pigs named Snowball and Napoleon, whom Mr. Jones had raised for sale. Napoleon was a large, fierce-looking Berkshire boar; in fact, he was the only Berkshire on the farm. He wasn't much of a talker, but he was known for getting his way by force. Snowball was a more lively, more spirited pig than Napoleon; he was also more eloquent and more inventive; but it was said that his character was not as strong as Napoleon's. All the male pigs on the farm were fattening pigs. The most famous among them was a plump pig named Squealer, with very round cheeks, constantly blinking eyes, a shrill voice, and a restless nature. He was a brilliant speaker; when discussing a difficult topic, he would jump from side to side and wag his tail rapidly; for some reason, these actions made him very persuasive. They used to say about Squealer, "He could turn black into white."
es: That happened in early March. During the following three months, there was a great deal of secret activity. To the most intelligent animals on the farm, Major's speech had made them see life from a completely new perspective. They did not know when the Rebellion that Major had predicted would occur; they had no reason to believe it would happen during their own lifetimes, but they clearly saw that their duty was to prepare for it. The work of teaching and organizing the others naturally fell upon the pigs, who were generally recognized as the most intelligent of the animals. Prominent among them were two young pigs named Snowball and Napoleon, whom Mr. Jones was raising to sell. Napoleon was a large, fierce-looking boar, the only Berkshire pig on the farm; he was known for being taciturn and always getting his way. Snowball was more lively than Napoleon, had greater ease of speech, and was more inventive, but he was considered to have a weaker character. The other male pigs on the farm were very young. The best known among them was a small, fat pig named Squealer, with very round cheeks, bright eyes, nimble movements, and a shrill voice. He was a brilliant orator, and when discussing a difficult matter, he had a way of skipping from side to side and wagging his tail that made him very persuasive. It was said of Squealer that he could turn black into white.

en: These three had elaborated old Major’s teachings into a complete system of thought, to which they gave the name of Animalism. Several nights a week, after Mr. Jones was asleep, they held secret meetings in the barn and expounded the principles of Animalism to the others. At the beginning they met with much stupidity and apathy. Some of the animals talked of the duty of loyalty to Mr. Jones, whom they referred to as “Master,” or made elementary remarks such as “Mr. Jones feeds us. If he were gone, we should starve to death.” Others asked such questions as “Why should we care what happens after we are dead?” or “If this Rebellion is to happen anyway, what difference does it make whether we work for it or not?”, and the pigs had great difficulty in making them see that this was contrary to the spirit of Animalism. The stupidest questions of all were asked by Mollie, the white mare. The very first question she asked Snowball was: “Will there still be sugar after the Rebellion?”
vi: These three had developed the old Leader's doctrine into a complete philosophical system which they called Animalism. Every night, after Mr. Jones went to bed, they would secretly gather in the barn to explain the main principles of Animalism to the other animals. At first, it was quite difficult because the animals were indifferent and very ignorant. Some said they had a duty of loyalty to Mr. Jones, whom they called their master, and some even naively remarked, "Mr. Jones feeds us. Without him, we would starve to death." Some even asked questions like, "Why should we care about what happens after we die?" or "The rebellion is going to happen anyway, whether we do anything or not." The pigs had a hard time convincing them that such arguments were completely contrary to the spirit of Animalism. But the most foolish questions came from a white mare named Mollie. First, she asked Snowball:
tr: These three had developed Old Major's thoughts into a complete doctrine, which they named "Animalism." Several nights a week, after Mr. Jones had gone to sleep, they held secret meetings in the barn, explaining the principles of Animalism to the other animals. At first, they encountered great stupidity and indifference. Some animals talked about their duty of loyalty to Mr. Jones, whom they called "Master"; others said, "Mr. Jones feeds us. If it weren't for him, we would starve to death," uttering such foolish remarks. Some asked questions like, "What good will it do us after we are dead?" or "If this Rebellion is going to happen anyway, what difference does it make whether we work for it or not?" The pigs had a hard time making them understand that such talk was contrary to the spirit of Animalism. The most foolish question came from the white mare Mollie; her first question to Snowball was, "Will there still be sugar after the Rebellion?"
es: These three had developed, based on the teachings of Old Major, a complete system of ideas which they named Animalism. Several nights a week, when Mr. Jones was already asleep, they held secret meetings in the barn, during which they explained the principles of Animalism to the others. At the beginning, they encountered much stupidity and apathy. Some animals spoke of the duty of loyalty towards Mr. Jones, whom they called "Master," or made elementary remarks such as: "Mr. Jones feeds us"; "If he were not here, we would starve to death." Others asked questions like: "What do we care about what will happen when we are dead?" or "If the rebellion is going to happen anyway, what difference does it make whether we work for it or not?" and the pigs had great difficulty making them see that this was contrary to the spirit of Animalism. The most foolish questions were asked by Mollie, the white mare. The first one she directed at Snowball was the following: —Will there be sugar after the rebellion?

en: “No,” said Snowball firmly. “We have no means of making sugar on this farm. Besides, you do not need sugar. You will have all the oats and hay you want.”
vi: "So, after the uprising, is there a way?" "No," Tuyết Tròn interrupted, "We do not produce sugar." In fact, comrade, you will not need sugar. You will have enough oats and straw that you need."
tr: Snowball cut in, "No," he said. "We cannot produce sugar on this farm. Besides, sugar will not be necessary. You will be able to eat as much oats and hay as you want."
es: —No —replied Snowball firmly—. We have no means to produce sugar on this farm. Besides, you don't need sugar. You will have all the oats and hay you need.

en: “And shall I still be allowed to wear ribbons in my mane?” asked Mollie.
vi: "So, can I still wear the ribbon?"
tr: This time, Mollie had asked, "Well, will I still be able to put ribbons in my mane?"
es: —And will I be allowed to keep using ribbons in my mane? —insisted Mollie.

en: “Comrade,” said Snowball, “those ribbons that you are so devoted to are the badge of slavery. Can you not understand that liberty is worth more than ribbons?”
vi: "Comrade," Tuyết Tròn said, "The ribbon that you love so much is actually a symbol of the spirit of slavery." "Don't you see that freedom is more precious than the ribbon?"
tr: Snowball said, "Come on, comrade." "The ribbon you can't do without is a symbol of slavery. Don't you get that freedom is worth more than ribbons?"
es: —Comrade —said Snowball—, those ribbons you like so much are the symbol of slavery. Don't you understand that freedom is worth more than those ribbons?

en: Mollie agreed, but she did not sound very convinced.
vi: Mollie agreed, but she didn't seem very trusting.
tr: Mollie didn't seem very convinced when she said "Kabul."
es: Mollie nodded, but it seemed that she was not very convinced.

en: The pigs had an even harder struggle to counteract the lies put about by Moses, the tame raven. Moses, who was Mr. Jones’s especial pet, was a spy and a tale-bearer, but he was also a clever talker. He claimed to know of the existence of a mysterious country called Sugarcandy Mountain, to which all animals went when they died. It was situated somewhere up in the sky, a little distance beyond the clouds, Moses said. In Sugarcandy Mountain it was Sunday seven days a week, clover was in season all the year round, and lump sugar and linseed cake grew on the hedges. The animals hated Moses because he told tales and did no work, but some of them believed in Sugarcandy Mountain, and the pigs had to argue very hard to persuade them that there was no such place.
vi: The pigs had an even harder time refuting the arguments put forth by the raven Moses. Moses was Mr. Jones's pet, he specialized in sneaking around but remembered many fairy tales and was also a skilled orator. He claimed to know of a mythical kingdom called Sugarcandy Mountain, where the souls of animals would go after they died. Moses said that this place was not far away, just beyond the clouds. There, all seven days of the week were Sundays, the clover was green all year round, and rock candy and dry bread grew right on the hedges. The animals hated Moses because he only talked and did no work, but some of them believed in his Sugarcandy Mountain, so the pigs had to work very hard to convince them that no such place existed.
tr: The pigs had to fight an even tougher battle to curb the lies spread by the pet raven Moses. Moses, who was Mr. Jones's favorite, was a tattler and a gossip, but he was a smooth talker. He had made up another tale: supposedly, there was a mysterious country called the Land of Sugarcandy, where all animals went when they died. According to Moses, this country was somewhere in the sky, just beyond the clouds. In the Land of Sugarcandy, every day was Sunday; clover grew in all seasons, and trees and bushes were laden with sugar lumps and linseed cakes. Although the animals hated Moses because he spent his days telling tales and never worked, there were still some who believed in the tale of the Land of Sugarcandy. The pigs talked at length to convince them that such a place did not exist.
es: The pigs had an even greater struggle to counteract the lies spread by Moses, the tamed raven. Moses, who was Mr. Jones's favorite, was a spy and a gossip, but also a very skilled orator. He claimed to know of the existence of a mysterious country called Sugarcandy Mountain, to which all animals went when they died. It was located somewhere in the sky, "just a little beyond the clouds," Moses said. There it was Sunday seven times a week, clover was in season all year round, and lumps of sugar and linseed cakes grew in the hedges. The animals hated Moses because he was a gossip and did no work, but some believed in Sugarcandy Mountain, and the pigs had to argue a lot to persuade them of the nonexistence of such a place.

en: Their most faithful disciples were the two cart-horses, Boxer and Clover. These two had great difficulty in thinking anything out for themselves, but having once accepted the pigs as their teachers, they absorbed everything that they were told, and passed it on to the other animals by simple arguments. They were unfailing in their attendance at the secret meetings in the barn, and led the singing of ‘Beasts of England’, with which the meetings always ended.
vi: The most trusted apostles of theirs were the two cart horses, Boxer and Clover. These two were originally slow to understand, but once they regarded the pigs as their masters, they absorbed every teaching and then explained it to the others in a more comprehensible language. These two never missed a single meeting and were often the ones leading the singing of "Beasts of England" at the end of each meeting.
tr: The most loyal disciples were the two cart horses, Boxer and Clover. These two horses, who had considerable difficulty thinking for themselves, had unquestioningly adopted everything the pigs said after deeming them as teachers and conveyed it exactly to the other animals. They never missed the secret meetings in the barn; they led the singing of the "Beasts of England" song at the end of each meeting.
es: The most loyal disciples were the draft horses Boxer and Clover. Both had great difficulty in forming their own judgment, but since they accepted the pigs as teachers, they absorbed everything they were told and conveyed it to the other animals through simple arguments. They never missed the secret meetings in the barn and led the singing of "Beasts of England" with which the meetings always ended.

en: Now, as it turned out, the Rebellion was achieved much earlier and more easily than anyone had expected. In past years Mr. Jones, although a hard master, had been a capable farmer, but of late he had fallen on evil days. He had become much disheartened after losing money in a lawsuit, and had taken to drinking more than was good for him. For whole days at a time he would lounge in his Windsor chair in the kitchen, reading the newspapers, drinking, and occasionally feeding Moses on crusts of bread soaked in beer. His men were idle and dishonest, the fields were full of weeds, the buildings wanted roofing, the hedges were neglected, and the animals were underfed.
vi: The Uprising happened much earlier and more easily than they had anticipated. In recent years, Mr. Jones, who had been a good and strict landlord, encountered many troubles. After losing a lot of money in lawsuits, he became gloomy and drank more than usual. He often sat all day in the kitchen armchair, reading the newspaper and drinking beer, occasionally giving Moses some beer-soaked bread crumbs. The servants became a bunch of lazy thieves, the fields turned into wastelands, the houses were dilapidated, the fences were leaning and collapsing, and the animals were frequently left starving.
tr: Then, the Rebellion happened much earlier and much more easily than anyone had expected. Although Mr. Jones was a skilled farmer, he had been treating the animals very harshly, and recently his affairs had taken a turn for the worse. Especially after losing money in a lawsuit, he had lost hope completely and had taken to drinking excessively, to the point of ruining his health. Sometimes he would sit idly for days in his kitchen armchair, reading the newspaper and drinking, occasionally feeding Moses with pieces of bread soaked in beer. The workers he employed were lazy and dishonest; the fields were overrun with weeds; the roofs of the buildings needed repair; the fences were neglected; and the animals were not being properly fed.
es: The fact was that the rebellion took place much earlier and more easily than they expected. In previous years Mr. Jones, despite being a harsh master, had been a capable farmer, but lately he had acquired some vices. He had become very discouraged after losing quite a bit of money in a lawsuit, and began to drink more than he should. For entire days he would remain in his kitchen chair, reading newspapers, drinking, and occasionally giving Moses crusts of bread soaked in beer. His men had become lazy and careless, the fields were full of weeds, the buildings needed repairs, the fences were neglected, and the animals were poorly fed.

en: June came and the hay was almost ready for cutting. On Midsummer’s Eve, which was a Saturday, Mr. Jones went into Willingdon and got so drunk at the Red Lion that he did not come back till midday on Sunday. The men had milked the cows in the early morning and then had gone out rabbiting, without bothering to feed the animals. When Mr. Jones got back he immediately went to sleep on the drawing-room sofa with the News of the World over his face, so that when evening came, the animals were still unfed. At last they could stand it no longer. One of the cows broke in the door of the store-shed with her horn and all the animals began to help themselves from the bins. It was just then that Mr. Jones woke up. The next moment he and his four men were in the store-shed with whips in their hands, lashing out in all directions. This was more than the hungry animals could bear. With one accord, though nothing of the kind had been planned beforehand, they flung themselves upon their tormentors. Jones and his men suddenly found themselves being butted and kicked from all sides. The situation was quite out of their control. They had never seen animals behave like this before, and this sudden uprising of creatures whom they were used to thrashing and maltreating just as they chose, frightened them almost out of their wits. After only a moment or two they gave up trying to defend themselves and took to their heels. A minute later all five of them were in full flight down the cart-track that led to the main road, with the animals pursuing them in triumph.
vi: June has come, this is the season for cutting grass. Before the Summer Solstice, that day was a Saturday, Mr. Jones went to Willingdon and got drunk at the Red Lion tavern, returning only by noon on Sunday. The farmhands hurriedly milked the cows early in the morning and then went rabbit hunting without bothering to feed the animals at all. Upon returning home, Mr. Jones immediately climbed onto the sofa in the living room, covered his face with a copy of "News of the World," and fell asleep, leaving the animals unfed until late evening. Finally, they couldn't stand it any longer. A cow broke down the door of the storage shed, and all the animals rushed to the grain bins. At that moment, Mr. Jones woke up. He and the four farmhands immediately grabbed whips and rushed into the shed, relentlessly lashing the poor animals. The starving animals could no longer endure it. Without any prior agreement, they charged forward and attacked their oppressors. Mr. Jones and the farmhands were suddenly kicked and butted from all directions. The situation became uncontrollable. They had never encountered anything like this before; the sudden rebellion of the animals, which they had previously beaten and mistreated at will, threw them into a panic. They could only hold out for a few minutes before having to flee. All five of them hurriedly rushed down the small path to the village road, while the animals enthusiastically chased after them.
tr: June had arrived, and the grass was almost ready to be mowed. Mr. Jones, having gone to Willingdon just before the summer solstice, which fell on a Saturday, and gotten dead drunk at the Red Lion tavern, could only return to the farm by noon on Sunday. The workers had milked the cows early in the morning and had gone rabbit hunting without feeding the animals. As soon as Mr. Jones returned home, he lay down on the couch in the living room and fell asleep while glancing at the News of the World newspaper. When night fell, the still-hungry animals could no longer bear it. One of the cows broke open the barn door with its horn; the animals rushed in and began to fill their bellies from the feed buckets. Just then, Mr. Jones woke up, grabbed his four workers, and ran to the barn; together, they started whipping the animals. This was the last straw for the animals. Despite not having planned anything beforehand, they collectively charged at the oppressors. They were butting and kicking Jones and his workers from all sides. The men, who had never seen the animals like this before, were bewildered; they were terrified by this unexpected rebellion from the animals they had beaten and tormented at will until that day. Seeing that things were not going well, they gave up trying to defend themselves and took to their heels. As they ran down the path towards the main road, the animals chased them with triumphant shouts.
es: June arrived and the hay was almost ready to be harvested. On the night of Saint John, which was a Saturday, Mr. Jones went to Willingdon and got so drunk at "The Red Lion" that he didn't return to the farm until midday on Sunday. The farmhands had milked the cows at dawn and then went off to hunt rabbits, without bothering to feed the animals. Upon his return, Mr. Jones immediately fell asleep on the living room sofa, covering his face with the newspaper, so that by nightfall the animals were still unfed. Hunger stirred the animals, who could no longer endure it. One of the cows broke down the door of the feed store with a butt of her horns, and the animals began to help themselves from the stores. At that moment, Mr. Jones woke up. Immediately, he and his four farmhands appeared with whips, lashing out in all directions. This was more than the hungry animals could bear. Unanimously, though nothing had been planned in advance, they pounced on their tormentors. Suddenly, Jones and his farmhands found themselves being pushed and kicked from all sides. They were losing control of the situation because they had never seen the animals behave in this way. That unexpected insurrection of beasts they were used to beating and mistreating at will terrified them almost to the point of losing their minds. Soon, they abandoned their attempt at defense and fled. A minute later, the five of them were running at full speed down the path that led to the main road with the animals triumphantly chasing them.

en: Mrs. Jones looked out of the bedroom window, saw what was happening, hurriedly flung a few possessions into a carpet bag, and slipped out of the farm by another way. Moses sprang off his perch and flapped after her, croaking loudly. Meanwhile the animals had chased Jones and his men out on to the road and slammed the five-barred gate behind them. And so, almost before they knew what was happening, the Rebellion had been successfully carried through: Jones was expelled, and the Manor Farm was theirs.
vi: Through the bedroom window, Mrs. Jones had seen everything; she hurriedly put a few things into a cloth bag and slipped out the back door to escape the Manor Farm. Moses also managed to fly out of his nest, cawing and following his mistress. After successfully chasing away the intruders, the animals returned and closed the gate. Thus, the Rebellion was completely victorious, Mr. Jones was driven away, and the Manor Farm belonged to the animals before they even had time to understand everything.
tr: Bayan Jones had seen what was happening from the window of her bedroom. She quickly gathered a few pieces of belongings, stuffed them into a saddlebag, and slipped away through the back road of the farm. Moses also jumped from his perch, flapping his wings and screaming at the top of his lungs as he followed the woman. Meanwhile, the animals had chased Jones and his men to the road, slamming the five-bar gate of the farm shut behind them. Thus, before they even realized what had happened, the Rebellion had succeeded, Jones had been expelled from the farm, and Manor Farm belonged to them.
es: Mrs. Jones looked out the bedroom window, saw what was happening, hastily put some things in a bag, and slipped away from the farm by another path. Moses jumped from his perch and flapped after her, cawing loudly. Meanwhile, the animals had chased Jones and his hands to the road and, as soon as they were out, slammed the gate shut behind them. And so, almost without realizing what had happened, the rebellion had been triumphantly carried out: Jones was expelled and "Manor Farm" was theirs.

en: For the first few minutes the animals could hardly believe in their good fortune. Their first act was to gallop in a body right round the boundaries of the farm, as though to make quite sure that no human being was hiding anywhere upon it; then they raced back to the farm buildings to wipe out the last traces of Jones’s hated reign. The harness-room at the end of the stables was broken open; the bits, the nose-rings, the dog-chains, the cruel knives with which Mr. Jones had been used to castrate the pigs and lambs, were all flung down the well. The reins, the halters, the blinkers, the degrading nosebags, were thrown on to the rubbish fire which was burning in the yard. So were the whips. All the animals capered with joy when they saw the whips going up in flames.
