Snowball also threw on to the fire the ribbons with which the horses’ manes and tails had usually been decorated on market days.
vi: At first, they did not believe that fate had smiled upon them. Their first action was to gather together and run around the compound to see if anyone was left inside, then they rushed into the buildings to destroy the remnants of Mr. Jones's dictatorial regime. The tool shed at the end of the stable was smashed, and all the horse bits, cattle nose rings, dog chains, and castration knives for pigs and sheep were thrown down the well. As for the reins, nooses, horse blinders, and old feed baskets usually hung around the horses' necks, they were thrown into the fire in the middle of the yard. The whips met the same fate. All the animals jumped up and down when they saw the whips catch fire. Snowball even threw the ribbons that were usually tied to the horses' manes and tails during fairs into the fire.
tr: The animals could not believe their luck for a while. First, they gathered together and circled the farm to see if there was a human hiding somewhere. Then, they ran to the farm buildings and began to destroy the last traces of Jones' sinister reign. The door of the room at the end of the stables, where the harnesses were kept, was broken; bits, nose rings, dog chains, and the cruel knives Mr. Jones used to castrate the pigs and lambs were thrown to the bottom of the well. Reins, halters, leather blinkers, humiliating feed bags were thrown into the fire where the trash in the yard was burned. Whips too. Seeing the whips engulfed in flames, all the animals were jumping with joy. Snowball also threw the ribbons that decorated the horses' manes and tails on market days into the fire.
es: During the first few minutes, the animals could hardly believe their victory. Their first action was to run all together around the boundaries of the farm, as if to make sure that no human being was hiding within it; then they galloped back to the buildings to erase the last traces of Jones's ominous reign. They burst into the harness-room that was at one end of the stable; the bits, the rings, the dog chains, the cruel knives with which Mr. Jones used to castrate the pigs and lambs, all were thrown down the well. The reins, the halters, the blinkers, the degrading nosebags were thrown into the fire in the yard, where at that moment the rubbish was burning. The whips met the same fate. All the animals leaped with joy when they saw the whips burning. Snowball also threw into the fire the ribbons that usually adorned the tails and manes of the horses on market days.

en: “Ribbons,” he said, “should be considered as clothes, which are the mark of a human being. All animals should go naked.”
vi: "Ribbons," it declared, "must be considered clothing, as well as a symbol of humanity." "All animals must be naked."
tr: "Clothing resembles humankind," he said. "A ribbon is also considered clothing. All animals should roam naked."
es: —The ribbons —he said— should be considered as clothing, which is the distinctive mark of a human being. All animals must go naked.

en: When Boxer heard this he fetched the small straw hat which he wore in summer to keep the flies out of his ears, and flung it on to the fire with the rest.
vi: Hearing that, the Warrior hurriedly took off the straw hat that it usually wore in the summer to prevent flies from getting into its ears and threw it into the fire.
tr: Upon hearing Snowball's words, Boxer grabbed the small straw hat he wore in the summer to protect his ears from flies and threw it into the fire.
es: When Boxer heard this, he took the little straw hat he used in the summer to keep flies from getting into his ears and threw it into the fire with the rest.

en: In a very little while the animals had destroyed everything that reminded them of Mr. Jones. Napoleon then led them back to the store-shed and served out a double ration of corn to everybody, with two biscuits for each dog. Then they sang ‘Beasts of England’ from end to end seven times running, and after that they settled down for the night and slept as they had never slept before.
vi: It wasn't long before the animals had destroyed everything related to Mr. Jones. Napoleon led the group into the storehouse and doubled the daily rations, giving each dog two butter biscuits. After that, they sang "Beasts of England" seven times in a row, then everyone went to sleep, never having slept as well as they did that night.
tr: Shortly after, the animals had destroyed everything that reminded them of Mr. Jones. Napoleon took them all back to the barn, distributed two rations of corn to everyone, and gave two biscuits each to the dogs. Then, they sang the song "Beasts of England" from start to finish exactly seven times; as night fell, everyone retreated to their corners and fell asleep. They had never slept so comfortably since they were born.
es: In a very short time, the animals had destroyed everything that could remind them of Mr. Jones's rule. Then Napoleon led them back to the feed store and served each one a double ration of corn, with two biscuits for each dog. Then they sang "Beasts of England" from beginning to end seven times in a row, and after that, they settled down for the night and slept like they had never done before.

en: But they woke at dawn as usual, and suddenly remembering the glorious thing that had happened, they all raced out into the pasture together. A little way down the pasture there was a knoll that commanded a view of most of the farm. The animals rushed to the top of it and gazed round them in the clear morning light. Yes, it was theirs — everything that they could see was theirs! In the ecstasy of that thought they gambolled round and round, they hurled themselves into the air in great leaps of excitement. They rolled in the dew, they cropped mouthfuls of the sweet summer grass, they kicked up clods of the black earth and snuffed its rich scent. Then they made a tour of inspection of the whole farm and surveyed with speechless admiration the ploughland, the hayfield, the orchard, the pool, the spinney. It was as though they had never seen these things before, and even now they could hardly believe that it was all their own.
vi: As usual, they woke up just as dawn was breaking, but they immediately remembered the glorious event that had just happened, and so they all rushed out to the meadow. On the meadow, there was a small hill, from which most of the farm could be seen. The animals ran up there and gazed at the scene in the rosy light of a new day. Everything, everything before their eyes now belonged to them! In a state of euphoria, they kept running around, running around endlessly, occasionally jumping up in joy! They rolled on the wet dew, filled their mouths with sweet summer grass, tossed up clumps of black soil, and inhaled its warm, rich scent. Then they went to inspect the entire farm, silently observing the fields of grain, the meadows, the orchard, the fish pond, and the grove. They looked at them as if they had never seen them before, and even now they could not believe that all those things were theirs.
tr: But as usual, when they woke up at dawn and remembered the magnificent uprising they had carried out the day before, they all ran to the meadow together. A little down the meadow, there was a small hill that overlooked a large part of the farm. They immediately climbed the hill and began to gaze at the surroundings in the clear light of the morning. Yes, it was theirs now; everything that stretched out before them as far as the eye could see was theirs! Overcome with this thought, they began to hop and jump, leaping into the air with great enthusiasm. They rolled on the dew-covered grass, plucked and devoured the sweet summer herbs, dug up the black soil and tossed it into the air, inhaling the beautiful scent of the earth. Then, they toured the entire farm and inspected it; they couldn't help but watch the field, the pasture, the orchard, the pond, and the grove in awe, as if they were struck dumb. It was as if they had never seen these places before; they still couldn't believe that all of this was now theirs.
es: But they woke up at dawn, as usual, and, suddenly remembering the glorious event, they all went together to the meadow. A short distance away, there was a hill from which almost the entire farm could be seen. The animals hurried to reach the summit and looked around in the clear morning light. Yes, it was theirs; everything they could see was theirs! Possessed by this thought, they jumped everywhere, leaping into the air with great jumps of joy. They rolled in the dew, bit the sweet summer grass, kicked up clods of black earth, and inhaled its strong aroma. Then they made an inspection tour of the entire farm and looked with silent admiration at the plowed land, the hayfield, the orchard, the pond, the grove. It was as if they had never seen those things before, and they could hardly believe that everything was theirs.

en: Then they filed back to the farm buildings and halted in silence outside the door of the farmhouse. That was theirs too, but they were frightened to go inside. After a moment, however, Snowball and Napoleon butted the door open with their shoulders and the animals entered in single file, walking with the utmost care for fear of disturbing anything. They tiptoed from room to room, afraid to speak above a whisper and gazing with a kind of awe at the unbelievable luxury, at the beds with their feather mattresses, the looking-glasses, the horsehair sofa, the Brussels carpet, the lithograph of Queen Victoria over the drawing-room mantelpiece. They were lust coming down the stairs when Mollie was discovered to be missing. Going back, the others found that she had remained behind in the best bedroom. She had taken a piece of blue ribbon from Mrs. Jones’s dressing-table, and was holding it against her shoulder and admiring herself in the glass in a very foolish manner. The others reproached her sharply, and they went outside. Some hams hanging in the kitchen were taken out for burial, and the barrel of beer in the scullery was stove in with a kick from Boxer’s hoof, otherwise nothing in the house was touched. A unanimous resolution was passed on the spot that the farmhouse should be preserved as a museum. All were agreed that no animal must ever live there.
vi: Then the whole group returned together and quietly gathered in front of the main house. Although this house now belonged to them, they were still hesitant and did not dare to enter immediately. But Snowball and Napoleon quickly regained their composure and used their shoulders to break open the door, then each one cautiously stepped inside, careful not to disturb the items within. They tiptoed from room to room, whispering, nervously admiring the unbelievable luxury before their eyes: feather beds, mirrors, horsehair-stuffed chairs, velvet carpets, and a portrait of Queen Victoria hanging above the fireplace in the living room. But when they reached the bottom of the stairs, they suddenly realized that Mollie was missing. They turned back and found Mollie still standing in the most beautiful bedroom in the house. It turned out she had taken a blue ribbon from Mrs. Jones's dressing table, draped it over her shoulder, and was gazing at herself in the mirror. The others immediately grabbed her and dragged her out of the house. The hams hanging in the kitchen were buried, the beer barrel in the scullery was kicked open by Boxer, and almost everything else was left in its place. A resolution to keep the main house as a museum was unanimously passed on the spot. All agreed that no animal should ever live in this house.
tr: Then, they lined up and returned to the farm buildings; when they reached the front door of the farmhouse, they held their breath and stopped. This house was theirs now, but they were afraid to go inside. Then, with Snowball and Napoleon shouldering the door and breaking it down, the animals entered in single file. They took great care with their steps to avoid making a mess; as they tiptoed from room to room, they whispered as if afraid their voices would be heard; they looked at the splendor inside, the feather mattresses, the mirrors, the horsehair-covered settee, the Brussels carpet, and the lithograph portrait of Queen Victoria above the fireplace in the sitting room with a mix of awe and fear. Just as they were descending the stairs, they noticed that Mollie was missing. A few of them rushed upstairs and began checking the rooms one by one. When they opened the door to the most elegant bedroom, what did they see! Wasn't Mollie admiring herself foolishly in the mirror, holding a blue ribbon, which seemed to have been taken from Mrs. Jones's dressing table, over her shoulder! They scolded Mollie severely and left the house. The hams hanging in the kitchen were taken out and buried, and the beer barrel in the pantry was smashed by Boxer with a kick, that's all; nothing else in the house was touched. Right then and there, they made a unanimous decision: The farmhouse would be preserved as a museum. There was not the slightest disagreement among them: No animal should live in this house.
es: They returned afterward to the farm buildings and, hesitantly, stopped in silence before the door of the house. It was theirs too, but they were afraid to enter. A moment later, however, Snowball and Napoleon pushed the door with their shoulders and the animals entered in single file, walking with the utmost care for fear of spoiling something. They tiptoed from one room to another, afraid to raise their voices, gazing with a kind of reverent awe at the incredible luxury there: the beds with their feather mattresses, the mirrors, the horsehair sofa, the Brussels carpet, the lithograph of Queen Victoria hanging above the mantelpiece in the drawing-room. They were coming down the stairs when they realized that Mollie was missing. Retracing their steps, they discovered that the mare had stayed in the best bedroom. She had taken a piece of blue ribbon from Mrs. Jones's dressing table and, holding it against her shoulder, was admiring herself foolishly in the mirror. The others reproached her sharply and went out. They took out some hams that were hanging in the kitchen and buried them; the barrel of beer was smashed with a kick from Boxer, and nothing else in the house was touched. It was unanimously resolved then and there that the house would be preserved as a museum. They all agreed that no animal should ever live there.

en: The animals had their breakfast, and then Snowball and Napoleon called them together again.
vi: They went to have breakfast and then Snowball and Napoleon invited everyone to gather.
tr: Snowball and Napoleon called the animals to a meeting again after breakfast.
es: The animals had breakfast, and then Snowball and Napoleon gathered them all again.

en: “Comrades,” said Snowball, “it is half-past six and we have a long day before us. Today we begin the hay harvest. But there is another matter that must be attended to first.”
vi: "Comrades," Tuyết Tròn said, "It is now seven-thirty, we still have the whole day ahead of us. Today we will start cutting grass, but we have one task to do first."
tr: "Comrades," said Snowball. "It is only half past six, a long day awaits us. Today we start mowing the hay. But first, we have a task to take care of."
es: —Comrades —said Snowball—, it is half-past six and we have a long day ahead of us. Today we must begin the hay harvest. But there is another matter we must resolve first.

en: The pigs now revealed that during the past three months they had taught themselves to read and write from an old spelling book which had belonged to Mr. Jones’s children and which had been thrown on the rubbish heap. Napoleon sent for pots of black and white paint and led the way down to the five-barred gate that gave on to the main road. Then Snowball (for it was Snowball who was best at writing) took a brush between the two knuckles of his trotter, painted out MANOR FARM from the top bar of the gate and in its place painted ANIMAL FARM. This was to be the name of the farm from now onwards. After this they went back to the farm buildings, where Snowball and Napoleon sent for a ladder which they caused to be set against the end wall of the big barn. They explained that by their studies of the past three months the pigs had succeeded in reducing the principles of Animalism to Seven Commandments. These Seven Commandments would now be inscribed on the wall; they would form an unalterable law by which all the animals on Animal Farm must live for ever after. With some difficulty (for it is not easy for a pig to balance himself on a ladder) Snowball climbed up and set to work, with Squealer a few rungs below him holding the paint-pot. The Commandments were written on the tarred wall in great white letters that could be read thirty yards away. They ran thus:
vi: So the two pigs said that thanks to the elementary books Mr. Jones found in the trash, they had been studying for the past three months and now they could read and write. Napoleon ordered to fetch a can of red paint, a can of white paint, and then led the group to the main gate. Snowball (because he had the best handwriting) held the paintbrush between his two hooves, erased the words Manor Farm, and wrote Animal Farm on the top plank of the gate. From now on, that would be the official name of the farm. After that, the group returned to the house, and Snowball and Napoleon ordered to find a ladder and set it up against the end wall of the barn. They explained that after a period of diligent research, in the past three months, they had distilled the principles of Animalism into Seven Commandments. The Seven Commandments would be inscribed on the wall and would be the unalterable law for all members of Animal Farm. Snowball climbed the ladder with difficulty (because pigs have trouble balancing on ladders) and began to write, while Squealer held the paint can below a few rungs. The commandments were written in white paint on the tarred wall, clearly readable from thirty meters away. The content was as follows:
tr: In the end, it was understood that two pigs had found a reading book among the trash belonging to Mr. Jones's children, and over the past three months, they had learned to read and write from this book. Napoleon had the black and white paint cans brought over, and leading the animals, he took them to the farm gate that opened onto the main road. Snowball (he was the best at writing) took the brush between his two hooves and scribbled out the name MANOR FARM written on the top bar of the gate, replacing it with ANIMAL FARM. From now on, the farm would be known by this name. Afterwards, they returned to the farm buildings; Snowball and Napoleon had a ladder brought and leaned it against the wall of the big barn. As a result of their three months of work, the pigs had managed to condense the fundamental principles of Animalism into seven commandments. Now these seven commandments would be written on the wall, and from now on, all the animals on Animal Farm would adhere to these unchanging laws for the rest of their lives. Snowball climbed the ladder with great difficulty (it is not easy for a pig to balance on a ladder) and set to work; Squealer was holding the paint can a few steps below. The seven commandments were written on the tarred wall in large white letters that could be read from twenty or thirty meters away:
es: The pigs then revealed that, over the past three months, they had learned to read and write using an elementary book that had belonged to Mr. Jones's children and had later been thrown away. Napoleon ordered some cans of white and black paint to be brought and took them to the gate that led to the main road. Then Snowball (who was the best at writing) took a brush between the two knuckles of his front hoof, crossed out "Manor Farm" from the top rail of the gate, and in its place painted "Animal Farm." That was going to be the name of the farm from now on. Afterwards, they returned to the buildings, where Snowball and Napoleon ordered a ladder to be brought and placed it against the back wall of the main barn. They then explained that, through their studies over the past three months, they had succeeded in reducing the principles of Animalism to seven Commandments. Those seven Commandments would be inscribed on the wall; they would form an unalterable law by which all the animals of "Animal Farm" should henceforth govern themselves. With some difficulty (because it is not easy for a pig to maintain balance on a ladder), Snowball climbed up and got to work with the help of Squealer who, a few rungs below, was holding the paint can for him. The Commandments were written on the tarred wall in white letters, so large that they could be read from thirty yards away. The inscription read as follows:

en: THE SEVEN COMMANDMENTS
vi: THE SEVEN COMMANDMENTS
tr: SEVEN COMMANDS
es: THE SEVEN COMMANDMENTS

en: Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy.
vi: All two-legged creatures are enemies.
tr: 1. You will consider everyone who walks on two legs an enemy.
es: 1. Everything that walks on two legs is an enemy.

en: Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend.
vi: All four-legged creatures or those with wings are friends.
tr: 2. You will consider everyone who walks on four legs or has wings as a friend.
es: 2. Everything that walks on four legs, or has wings, is a friend.

en: No animal shall wear clothes.
vi: No animal shall wear clothes.
tr: 3. No animal shall wear clothes.
es: 3. No animal shall wear clothes.

en: No animal shall sleep in a bed.
vi: No animal shall sleep in a bed.
tr: 4. No animal shall sleep in a bed.
es: 4. No animal shall sleep in a bed.

en: No animal shall drink alcohol.
vi: No animal shall drink alcohol.
tr: 5. No animal shall drink alcohol.
es: 5. No animal shall drink alcohol.

en: No animal shall kill any other animal.
vi: Animals must not kill each other.
tr: 6. No animal shall kill any other animal.
es: 6. No animal shall kill another animal.

en: All animals are equal.
vi: All animals are born equal.
tr: 7. All animals are equal.
es: 7. All animals are equal.

en: It was very neatly written, and except that “friend” was written “freind” and one of the “S’s” was the wrong way round, the spelling was correct all the way through. Snowball read it aloud for the benefit of the others. All the animals nodded in complete agreement, and the cleverer ones at once began to learn the Commandments by heart.
vi: All the letters were written clearly and the entire passage had only two spelling mistakes: the word "giường" was written as "gưìơng" and one letter S was written backwards. Tuyết Tròn read it aloud for everyone to hear. Everyone nodded in agreement, and the smarter ones immediately memorized the Commandments.
tr: The commands were written with great care; except for "friend" being written as "toast" and one of the 's' letters being reversed, there were no spelling mistakes. Snowball read the commands aloud from start to finish so that everyone could understand. All the animals nodded their heads, indicating their complete submission to the commands. The smartest ones immediately began to memorize them.
es: It was written very clearly, and except for where it should have said "friend," it read "imago," and one of the "S" letters was reversed, the wording was correct. Snowball read it aloud to the others. All the animals nodded in agreement, showing their total approval, and the more intelligent ones immediately began to memorize the Commandments.

en: “Now, comrades,” cried Snowball, throwing down the paint-brush, “to the hayfield! Let us make it a point of honour to get in the harvest more quickly than Jones and his men could do.”
vi: "Now, comrades," Tuyết Tròn shouted as she threw the paintbrush to the ground, "everyone to the fields to cut grass! We must harvest faster than old Jones and his servants.
tr: Snowball threw the paintbrush to the ground and shouted, "Come on, comrades!" "To the field! Let's have the honor of harvesting the crop faster than Jones and his men."
es: —Now, comrades —shouted Snowball, throwing away the brush—, to the hayfield! Let us impose upon ourselves the honor of finishing the harvest in less time than it took Jones and his men.

en: But at this moment the three cows, who had seemed uneasy for some time past, set up a loud lowing. They had not been milked for twenty-four hours, and their udders were almost bursting. After a little thought, the pigs sent for buckets and milked the cows fairly successfully, their trotters being well adapted to this task. Soon there were five buckets of frothing creamy milk at which many of the animals looked with considerable interest.
vi: At that moment, the three cows, who had been feeling uncomfortable for some time, suddenly bellowed. For the past twenty-four hours, they had not been milked, and their udders were so full they seemed about to burst. After a moment of hesitation, the pigs ordered buckets to be brought and performed the task quite skillfully, their legs proving suitable for the job. Before long, they had filled five buckets with rich milk, and some curious animals came to watch.
tr: But at that moment, three cows that had been looking tense for a while started to moo. Their udders were about to burst because they hadn't been milked for twenty-four hours. After thinking for a bit, the pigs brought the buckets, and since their forelegs were suited for the task, they expertly milked the cows. Soon, the buckets were filled with frothy, creamy milk; many of the animals were looking at the milk with watering mouths.
es: At that moment, the three cows, which had seemed restless for a while, began to moo very loudly. It had been twenty-four hours since they had been milked, and their udders were about to burst. After thinking about it for a moment, the pigs ordered some buckets to be brought and milked the cows with reasonable success, as their hooves adapted quite well to the task. Quickly, there were five buckets of creamy and frothy milk, which many of the animals looked at with great interest.

en: “What is going to happen to all that milk?” said someone.
vi: "What should we do with this milk?" the child asked.
tr: One of them asked, "What will happen to all this milk?"
es: —What will be done with all that milk? —someone asked.

en: “Jones used sometimes to mix some of it in our mash,” said one of the hens.
vi: "Old Jones occasionally mixes milk into our food," a hen spoke up.
tr: "Jones sometimes added milk to our feed," said one of the chickens.
es: —Jones sometimes used a part of it by mixing it into our food —said one of the hens.

en: “Never mind the milk, comrades!” cried Napoleon, placing himself in front of the buckets. “That will be attended to. The harvest is more important. Comrade Snowball will lead the way. I shall follow in a few minutes. Forward, comrades! The hay is waiting.”
vi: "Comrades, why bother about the milk!" Napoleon shouted as he stepped in front of the milk pails, "Leave it for now and we'll deal with it later. The harvest is more important. Comrade Snowball will lead the way. I will follow shortly. Comrades, move forward! The harvest needs us.
tr: Thereupon, Napoleon stepped in front of the buckets and shouted, "Don't worry about the milk, comrades!" "It will be taken care of, don't worry. The harvest is more important. Comrade Snowball will take the lead. I'll be there shortly. Forward, comrades! The harvest awaits us."
es: —Don't worry about the milk, comrades! —said Napoleon, positioning himself in front of the buckets—. That will be sorted out. The harvest is more important. Comrade Snowball will guide you. I will join you in a few minutes. Forward, comrades! The hay awaits you.

en: So the animals trooped down to the hayfield to begin the harvest, and when they came back in the evening it was noticed that the milk had disappeared.
vi: The animals went out to the field and started cutting grass, but by the afternoon they couldn't find the buckets of milk anymore. George Orwell Animal Farm
tr: The animals arrived at the field in a herd and started to harvest. When they returned in the evening, they would notice that the milk had disappeared.
es: The animals went in a rush to the hayfield to start the harvest, and when they returned at dusk, they noticed that the milk had disappeared.

en: Chapter 3
vi: Chapter 3
tr: Chapter Three
es: III

en: How they toiled and sweated to get the hay in! But their efforts were rewarded, for the harvest was an even bigger success than they had hoped.
vi: It must be acknowledged that they work very diligently, regardless of fatigue, just to finish the harvest! Their hard work has been rewarded, they have harvested more than expected.
tr: They worked like laborers until the harvest was done, drenched in sweat from head to toe! But their efforts were not in vain; the harvest was more bountiful than they had hoped.
es: HOW hard they worked and sweated to bring in the hay! But their efforts were rewarded, as the harvest turned out even better than they expected.

en: Sometimes the work was hard; the implements had been designed for human beings and not for animals, and it was a great drawback that no animal was able to use any tool that involved standing on his hind legs. But the pigs were so clever that they could think of a way round every difficulty. As for the horses, they knew every inch of the field, and in fact understood the business of mowing and raking far better than Jones and his men had ever done. The pigs did not actually work, but directed and supervised the others. With their superior knowledge it was natural that they should assume the leadership. Boxer and Clover would harness themselves to the cutter or the horse-rake (no bits or reins were needed in these days, of course) and tramp steadily round and round the field with a pig walking behind and calling out “Gee up, comrade!” or “Whoa back, comrade!” as the case might be. And every animal down to the humblest worked at turning the hay and gathering it. Even the ducks and hens toiled to and fro all day in the sun, carrying tiny wisps of hay in their beaks. In the end they finished the harvest in two days’ less time than it had usually taken Jones and his men. Moreover, it was the biggest harvest that the farm had ever seen. There was no wastage whatever; the hens and ducks with their sharp eyes had gathered up the very last stalk. And not an animal on the farm had stolen so much as a mouthful.
vi: Sometimes they also encountered some difficulties because all the tools were made for humans, not for animals, and to use those tools, one had to stand on two hind legs. But it must be said that pigs are an intelligent breed - no matter how difficult, they always find a way. As for the horses, they understood each plot of land well, and they were much better at cutting and piling grass than Mr. Jones and his men. The pigs did not work but only guided and supervised the others. With such knowledge, it was natural for them to take on the leadership role. Boxer and Clover harnessed themselves to the cutter or the harrow (of course, without needing bits or reins) and patiently walked around the fields, while a pig followed behind, occasionally shouting "Straight ahead, comrade!" or "Turn back, comrade!". All the animals, regardless of size, participated in cutting and stacking the grass. Even the chickens and ducks exposed themselves to the sun all day to help transport small bundles of grass with their beaks. They completed the work quickly, faster than humans, as it would have taken Mr. Jones and his men two more days to finish. Moreover, it was the most productive harvest ever. There was no wastage because the chickens and ducks, with their keen eyes, picked up every single blade. And no animal stole even a single bite.
tr: From time to time, the milk they had sucked from their mothers came out of their noses; the tools were made for humans, not animals; not being able to use the tools that required them to stand on their hind legs was causing great difficulty. But the pigs were so smart that they found a way to overcome every difficulty. As for the horses; they knew the field inch by inch, and they understood the work of harvesting and gathering crops much better than Jones and his men. The pigs did not work directly; they managed and supervised the others. With their superior knowledge, it was natural for them to take on the leadership. Boxer and Clover harnessed themselves to the horse-drawn harrow (of course, bridles and reins were no longer used), slowly circling around the field; the pig following them would occasionally call out, "Gee, comrade!" or "Haw, comrade!" All the animals, from the largest to the smallest, worked in the harvesting and gathering of the crops. Even the ducks and chickens, running around from morning till night under the sun, carried bits of grass with their beaks. In the end, they harvested it in about two days less than Jones and his men would have. Moreover, it was the largest harvest the farm had ever seen. Furthermore, nothing was wasted; the sharp-eyed chickens and ducks gathered everything down to the smallest blade of grass. Not a single farm animal attempted to steal.
es: Sometimes the work was hard; the implements had been designed for human beings and not for animals, and it was a great disadvantage that no animal could use the tools that required standing on their hind legs. But the pigs were so clever that they found a solution to every problem. As for the horses, they knew every inch of the land and, in fact, understood the work of mowing and raking better than Jones and his men. The pigs did not really work, but they directed and supervised the others. Because of their superior knowledge, it was natural for them to assume command. Boxer and Clover would harness themselves to the mower or the rake (in those days, of course, there was no need for brakes or reins) and resolutely marched across the field with a pig walking behind them and saying: "Gee, comrade" or "Haw, comrade," as the case might be. And all the animals, even the humblest, worked to toss the hay and pile it up. Even the ducks and hens worked, going back and forth all day long in the blazing sun, carrying little bundles of hay in their beaks. In the end, they finished the harvest two days less than it usually took Jones and his men. Moreover, it was the largest harvest that had ever been seen on the farm. There was no waste; the hens and ducks with their keen eyesight had picked up every last stalk. And no animal on the farm had stolen so much as a mouthful.

en: All through that summer the work of the farm went like clockwork. The animals were happy as they had never conceived it possible to be. Every mouthful of food was an acute positive pleasure, now that it was truly their own food, produced by themselves and for themselves, not doled out to them by a grudging master. With the worthless parasitical human beings gone, there was more for everyone to eat. There was more leisure too, inexperienced though the animals were. They met with many difficulties — for instance, later in the year, when they harvested the corn, they had to tread it out in the ancient style and blow away the chaff with their breath, since the farm possessed no threshing machine — but the pigs with their cleverness and Boxer with his tremendous muscles always pulled them through. Boxer was the admiration of everybody. He had been a hard worker even in Jones’s time, but now he seemed more like three horses than one; there were days when the entire work of the farm seemed to rest on his mighty shoulders. From morning to night he was pushing and pulling, always at the spot where the work was hardest. He had made an arrangement with one of the cockerels to call him in the mornings half an hour earlier than anyone else, and would put in some volunteer labour at whatever seemed to be most needed, before the regular day’s work began. His answer to every problem, every setback, was “I will work harder!”— which he had adopted as his personal motto.
vi: The farm work went smoothly throughout that summer. The animals felt extremely happy; they had never thought that such a thing could happen. Eating was a joy, because now the food was theirs, made by them and for them, not something begrudgingly given by a stingy master anymore. After they had driven away the useless parasitic humans, each animal's portion naturally increased. And although they lacked experience, they still had more leisure time. They did encounter some difficulties, for example, when harvesting grain they had to use their strength to blow away the chaff because the farm didn't have a threshing machine, but with the intelligence of the pigs and the strength of Boxer, there was nothing they couldn't accomplish. Boxer was highly respected. Even when Mr. Jones was still around, he was already diligent, but now he worked three times as hard, sometimes it seemed like the entire farm's work fell on his shoulders. He pulled and pushed from dawn till dusk and was always present at the most difficult spots. He asked a rooster to wake him up half an hour earlier and voluntarily did some of the most urgent tasks before the official workday began. In the face of any difficulty or obstacle, he would say, "I will work harder!" This phrase had become his personal motto.
tr: That summer, everything was going well on the farm. The animals were happier than they could ever have imagined. They were no longer dependent on the meager food given by their stingy owners; they were eating food produced by themselves and for themselves, and they savored every bite. Since the worthless, parasitic humans had disappeared, there was more food for everyone. Despite their lack of experience, they were able to find more free time. They faced many difficulties; for example, as the season progressed and harvest time came, they had to thresh the grain with their feet and winnow it by blowing it into the air, just like in ancient times, because there was no threshing machine on the farm; but with the intelligence of the pigs and the strong muscles of Boxer, they were able to overcome every challenge. Everyone admired Boxer. Boxer, who had been an indefatigable animal even during Jones's time, was now working with the strength of nearly three horses; there were days when the entire burden of the farm's work fell on his strong shoulders. He was always there where the work was hardest; from morning till night, he worked tirelessly. He had made an arrangement with one of the young roosters to wake him up half an hour earlier than the others in the mornings; before the daily tasks began, he would rush to the place where he was most needed and work there voluntarily. It was as if he had made work a law for himself: If a problem or a setback arose, he would immediately say, "I will work even harder!" and get to work.
es: Throughout the entire summer, work on the farm went smoothly. The animals were as happy as they had never imagined they could be. Every bite of food was a delicious treat, as it was truly their own food, produced by them and for them, and not doled out in small portions and grudgingly by a grumpy master. Since the useless and parasitic human beings were no longer there, there was more food for everyone. They also had more free hours, despite the animals' inexperience. Of course, they encountered many difficulties, for example: when they harvested the corn, they had to tread it in the old-fashioned way and remove the waste by blowing, since the farm did not have a threshing machine, but the pigs with their intelligence and Boxer with his powerful muscles always got them out of trouble. Everyone admired Boxer. He had been a great worker even in Jones's time, but now he resembled three horses rather than one; on certain days it seemed that all the work rested on his strong shoulders. He pulled and dragged from morning till night and always where the work was hardest. He had agreed with a rooster that it would wake him half an hour earlier than the others, and he would do some voluntary work where it was most needed before starting the normal daily tasks. His response to every problem, to every setback, was: "I will work harder!"; it was like a personal refrain.

en: But everyone worked according to his capacity. The hens and ducks, for instance, saved five bushels of corn at the harvest by gathering up the stray grains. Nobody stole, nobody grumbled over his rations, the quarrelling and biting and jealousy which had been normal features of life in the old days had almost disappeared. Nobody shirked — or almost nobody. Mollie, it was true, was not good at getting up in the mornings, and had a way of leaving work early on the ground that there was a stone in her hoof. And the behaviour of the cat was somewhat peculiar. It was soon noticed that when there was work to be done the cat could never be found. She would vanish for hours on end, and then reappear at meal-times, or in the evening after work was over, as though nothing had happened. But she always made such excellent excuses, and purred so affectionately, that it was impossible not to believe in her good intentions. Old Benjamin, the donkey, seemed quite unchanged since the Rebellion. He did his work in the same slow obstinate way as he had done it in Jones’s time, never shirking and never volunteering for extra work either. About the Rebellion and its results he would express no opinion. When asked whether he was not happier now that Jones was gone, he would say only “Donkeys live a long time. None of you has ever seen a dead donkey,” and the others had to be content with this cryptic answer.
vi: The other animals also worked with all their might. For example, the chickens and ducks managed to gather up to two quintals of grain. Petty theft; complaints about food and drink; quarrels and fights; jealousy - those bad habits of the past had completely disappeared. No animal shirked work - or rather, almost no animal. Mollie didn't like getting up early and tried to slip away, claiming that a small stone had gotten into her hoof. The cat's attitude was also suspicious. Whenever needed, it invariably disappeared beforehand. She often went off somewhere for a long time and only appeared, as if nothing had happened, right before meals or in the afternoon when the work was done. But she always found a way to explain and purred so charmingly that it was hard to doubt her goodwill. Only the old donkey Benjamin remained the same. He still did his work with the same slow pace as in Mr. Jones's time, never shirking but never doing more either. He said nothing about the Rebellion or the changes that followed. If asked whether he felt happier than in Mr. Jones's time, he would say: "Donkey's life is long. You have never seen a dead donkey" - he always said such a cryptic sentence.
tr: Actually, everyone was working well according to their own strength and ability. For instance, the chickens and ducks had saved nearly twenty bushels of grain by collecting the scattered grains. No one was stealing, no one was grumbling about their assigned rations; fights, bites, and jealousies, which were once considered normal features of life on the farm, had almost entirely disappeared. No one was shirking work, except for one person. Yes, Mollie had a problem with not being able to get up early in the mornings; moreover, she would sometimes leave work early, using a stone in her hoof as an excuse. In truth, the cat was also peculiar. After a while, it was understood that she never appeared when there was work to be done. She would disappear for hours, but when it was time to eat or when the work was finished in the late afternoon, she would appear as if nothing had happened. But each time, she would come up with such good excuses and purr so affectionately that she managed to convince everyone of her good intentions. The old donkey Benjamin seemed unchanged since the Rebellion. Just like in Mr. Jones's time, he was still sluggish and stubborn; he neither shirked work nor was he eager to work too hard. He did not express the slightest opinion about the Rebellion and its consequences. When asked if he was happier after Jones left the farm, he would simply say, "Donkeys live a long time. Have you ever seen a dead donkey in your life?" and leave everyone to settle for this ambiguous answer.
es: But each one acted according to their ability. The hens and ducks, for example, recovered five bushels of corn during the harvest by picking up the lost grains. Nobody stole, nobody complained about their ration; the arguments, fights, and envies that were a natural component of daily life in the old days had almost completely disappeared. Nobody shirked work, or almost nobody. Mollie, in truth, was not very diligent about getting up in the morning, and she had the habit of leaving work early, claiming that a stone had gotten into her hoof. And the behavior of the cat was somewhat strange. Soon it was noticed that when there was work, she was nowhere to be found. She would disappear for entire hours, and then show up at mealtime or at dusk, when the work was over, as if nothing had happened. But she always presented such excellent excuses and purred so affectionately that it was impossible to doubt her good intentions. Old Benjamin, the donkey, seemed not to have changed since the rebellion. He did his work with the same stubbornness and slowness as before, never shirking it and never volunteering for any extra task either. He did not give his opinion on the rebellion or its results. When asked if he was not happier now that Jones was gone, he would simply answer: "Donkeys live a long time. None of you has ever seen a dead donkey." And the others had to be content with such a mysterious response.

en: On Sundays there was no work. Breakfast was an hour later than usual, and after breakfast there was a ceremony which was observed every week without fail. First came the hoisting of the flag. Snowball had found in the harness-room an old green tablecloth of Mrs. Jones’s and had painted on it a hoof and a horn in white. This was run up the flagstaff in the farmhouse garden every Sunday morning. The flag was green, Snowball explained, to represent the green fields of England, while the hoof and horn signified the future Republic of the Animals which would arise when the human race had been finally overthrown. After the hoisting of the flag all the animals trooped into the big barn for a general assembly which was known as the Meeting. Here the work of the coming week was planned out and resolutions were put forward and debated. It was always the pigs who put forward the resolutions. The other animals understood how to vote, but could never think of any resolutions of their own. Snowball and Napoleon were by far the most active in the debates. But it was noticed that these two were never in agreement: whatever suggestion either of them made, the other could be counted on to oppose it. Even when it was resolved — a thing no one could object to in itself — to set aside the small paddock behind the orchard as a home of rest for animals who were past work, there was a stormy debate over the correct retiring age for each class of animal. The Meeting always ended with the singing of ‘Beasts of England’, and the afternoon was given up to recreation.
vi: Sunday is a day off. Breakfast is an hour later, and after that, there is always a solemn gathering. First is the flag-raising ceremony. Snowball found an old green tablecloth of Mrs. Jones in the tool shed and drew a hoof and a horn in white on it. And so, every Sunday morning, the tablecloth would flutter on the flagpole in the garden. Snowball explained that the green color symbolized the fields of England, while the hoof and horn were symbols of the future Animal Republic, once the humans were completely overthrown. After the flag-raising, all the animals would gather in the big barn, which they called the Meeting. They would plan the coming week and discuss and pass resolutions on various proposals there. Only the pigs made proposals. The other animals only voted but never proposed anything. Snowball and Napoleon were the most active in discussions. But these two always opposed each other: whenever one proposed an idea, the other would immediately counter it. Even when a matter had been decided, such as setting aside a small piece of land behind the orchard for retirement, which no one could oppose, these two would still argue fiercely over which species and at what age they should retire. The Meetings always ended with the singing of "Beasts of England," and in the afternoon, they were free to rest.
tr: Sundays were not for working. After a breakfast that was an hour later than usual, a ceremony was held every Sunday, starting with the raising of the flag. In the room where the harnesses were kept, Snowball had found an old tablecloth of Mrs. Jones's, and had painted a hoof and a horn in white on the green cloth. The flag was raised on the flagpole in the farmhouse garden every Sunday morning. According to Snowball's explanation, the green background of the flag represented the lush fields of England, while the hoof and horn symbolized the future Animal Republic that would be born when the human race was finally overthrown. After the flag was raised, all the animals would gather in the large barn to attend the general assembly known as the Meeting. At the Meeting, the work for the coming week was planned, and decisions were discussed. The decisions to be made were always proposed by the pigs. The other animals knew how to vote, but they could never come up with any resolutions on their own. The most fervent debaters at the Meetings were Snowball and Napoleon. But these two never agreed: Whatever one proposed, the other was sure to oppose. Even when a decision was reached that no one could dispute, they found a way to quarrel with each other. For example, after it was decided that the pasture behind the orchard would be set aside as a grazing area for animals no longer able to work, they argued over what the retirement age for the different types of animals should be. At the end of every Meeting, the song "Beasts of England" was sung, and the afternoons were devoted to recreation.
es: Sundays were not for working. Breakfast was taken an hour later than usual, and afterwards, a ceremony took place that was carried out every week without exception. First, the flag was raised. Snowball had found an old green tablecloth of Mrs. Jones in the harness-room and had painted a hoof and a horn in white on its surface. And this emblem was hoisted on the flagpole in the garden every Sunday morning. The flag was green, explained Snowball, to represent the green fields of England, while the hoof and the horn signified the future Republic of the Animals, which would arise when they finally overthrew the human race. After raising the flag, all the animals would head in a rush to the main barn where a general assembly, known as the Meeting, took place. There, the work for the following week was planned, and decisions to be adopted were raised and debated. The pigs were the ones who always proposed the resolutions. The other animals understood how they should vote, but they never came up with their own ideas. Snowball and Napoleon were, without a doubt, the most active in the debates. But it was noted that the two of them never agreed; for any suggestion made by one, it could be expected that the other would be against it. Even when it was decided to reserve the small field behind the orchard as a retirement home for animals no longer fit to work, there was a stormy debate regarding the retirement age for each class of animal. The Meeting always ended with the song "Beasts of England," and the afternoon was devoted to leisure.

en: The pigs had set aside the harness-room as a headquarters for themselves. Here, in the evenings, they studied blacksmithing, carpentering, and other necessary arts from books which they had brought out of the farmhouse. Snowball also busied himself with organising the other animals into what he called Animal Committees. He was indefatigable at this. He formed the Egg Production Committee for the hens, the Clean Tails League for the cows, the Wild Comrades’ Re-education Committee (the object of this was to tame the rats and rabbits), the Whiter Wool Movement for the sheep, and various others, besides instituting classes in reading and writing. On the whole, these projects were a failure. The attempt to tame the wild creatures, for instance, broke down almost immediately. They continued to behave very much as before, and when treated with generosity, simply took advantage of it. The cat joined the Re-education Committee and was very active in it for some days. She was seen one day sitting on a roof and talking to some sparrows who were just out of her reach. She was telling them that all animals were now comrades and that any sparrow who chose could come and perch on her paw; but the sparrows kept their distance.
vi: The pigs used the old harness-room as their headquarters. In the evenings, they studied carpentry, blacksmithing, and other trades through books they found in the main house. Snowball also organized the other animals into what he called Animal Committees. He worked on this enthusiastically, never tiring. He had established the Egg Production Committee for the hens, the Clean Tails League for the cows, the Wild Comrades' Re-education Committee (the aim of which was to tame the rats and rabbits); the Whiter Wool Movement for the sheep, and so on, not to mention the literacy classes. In general, Snowball's projects were not very successful. The attempt to tame the wild creatures failed almost immediately. Their behavior did not change at all, and if anything, they became even more unruly. The cat was also a member of the Re-education Committee and was very active for a few days. Once, it even climbed onto the roof to talk to some sparrows that were out of its reach. It told them that now all animals were comrades and that any sparrow who wished could perch on its paw; but the sparrows kept their distance.
tr: The pigs had established their headquarters in the room where the harnesses were kept. In the evenings, they would read and learn necessary trades like blacksmithing and carpentry from the books they had brought from the farmhouse. Snowball was also busy organizing the other animals into Animal Committees, tirelessly putting in effort for this task. In addition to literacy classes, he had established the Egg Production Committee for the hens, the Clean Tails League for the cows, the Wild Comrades' Re-education Committee for the domestication of rats and rabbits, and the Whiter Wool Movement for the sheep. Most of these initiatives did not yield results. For instance, the attempt to domesticate wild animals failed from the start. The wild animals continued to behave as they always had, immediately taking advantage of the leniency shown to them. The cat had joined the Re-education Committee and worked diligently for a while. One day, they found her sitting on the roof, talking to sparrows that were out of her reach; she was telling them that all animals were now comrades and that they could come and perch on her paw without any fear if they wished. But the sparrows did not even come close to the cat.
es: The pigs made the harness-room their headquarters. Every night, they studied blacksmithing, carpentry, and other necessary trades from the books they had brought from the house. Snowball also took charge of organizing the others into what he called Animal Committees. For this, he was tireless. He formed the Egg Production Committee for the hens, the Clean Tails League for the cows, the Committee for the Re-education of Wild Comrades (whose purpose was to domesticate the rats and rabbits), the Whiter Wool Movement for the sheep, and many others, in addition to organizing reading and writing classes. In general, these projects turned out to be failures. The attempt to domesticate the wild animals, for example, failed almost immediately. They continued behaving practically the same as before, and when treated generously, they took advantage of it. The cat joined the Re-education Committee and was very active in it for a few days. Once, she was seen sitting on the roof chatting with some sparrows that were out of her reach. She was telling them that all animals were now comrades and that any sparrow who wished could perch on her paw; but the sparrows preferred to abstain.

en: The reading and writing classes, however, were a great success. By the autumn almost every animal on the farm was literate in some degree.
vi: The reading and writing classes achieved positive results. Before autumn arrived, most of the animals on the farm had escaped illiteracy to a certain extent.
tr: On the other hand, the literacy classes had been very successful. By the time autumn came, almost every animal on the farm knew how to read and write to some extent.
es: The reading and writing classes, on the contrary, were very successful. By autumn, almost all the animals, to a greater or lesser degree, had some education.

en: As for the pigs, they could already read and write perfectly. The dogs learned to read fairly well, but were not interested in reading anything except the Seven Commandments. Muriel, the goat, could read somewhat better than the dogs, and sometimes used to read to the others in the evenings from scraps of newspaper which she found on the rubbish heap. Benjamin could read as well as any pig, but never exercised his faculty. So far as he knew, he said, there was nothing worth reading. Clover learnt the whole alphabet, but could not put words together. Boxer could not get beyond the letter D. He would trace out A, B, C, D, in the dust with his great hoof, and then would stand staring at the letters with his ears back, sometimes shaking his forelock, trying with all his might to remember what came next and never succeeding. On several occasions, indeed, he did learn E, F, G, H, but by the time he knew them, it was always discovered that he had forgotten A, B, C, and D. Finally he decided to be content with the first four letters, and used to write them out once or twice every day to refresh his memory. Mollie refused to learn any but the six letters which spelt her own name. She would form these very neatly out of pieces of twig, and would then decorate them with a flower or two and walk round them admiring them.
vi: The pigs could read and write fluently. The dogs could also read, but they only read the Seven Commandments. The goat named Muriel could read better than the dogs, so in the evenings, she would often read to the others from scraps of newspaper she found in the trash heap. The donkey Benjamin could read as quickly as the pigs, but he never read anything. He said there was nothing worth reading. Mrs. Fatty memorized the entire alphabet but couldn't spell words. Warrior couldn't get past the letter D. He would often use his large hooves to write the letters A, B, C, D in the sand and then stand back to look at them, ears folded back, occasionally flicking his mane, trying to remember what came next, but he never could. Sometimes he would manage to remember the letters E, F, G, H, but it was always the same: if he remembered those letters, he would forget A, B, C, D. In the end, he settled for those four letters and practiced writing them once or twice a day to train his memory. Mollie only learned the five letters that spelled her name. She would often use a small twig to arrange those letters and then decorate them with a few flowers, after which she would walk around to admire them.
tr: The pigs' literacy was flawless. The dogs had learned to read very well, but they read nothing other than the Seven Commandments. Muriel the goat read even better than the dogs; some evenings, she would bring pieces of newspaper she found in the garbage and read them to the other animals. Benjamin, who could read as well as the pigs, was rarely seen using this ability. "I don't see anything worth reading," he would say. Clover had learned the alphabet from start to finish, but she couldn't make out the words. As for Boxer, he couldn't get past D. He would write the letters A, B, C, D on the ground with his large hoof, then he would lay his ears back, shake his mane, and stare blankly at the letters, trying to figure out the letter that came after D, but he could never manage it. A few times, he had learned E, F, G, H, but as soon as he learned them, he realized he had forgotten A, B, C, D, and finally decided to settle for the first four letters of the alphabet; to avoid forgetting them, he would write these four letters once or twice every day. As for Mollie, she stubbornly refused to learn any letter other than the six letters in her name. She would arrange thin branches to spell out her name, decorate them with a few flowers, and then circle around them admiringly.
es: The pigs already knew how to read and write perfectly. The dogs learned to read quite well, but they were only interested in reading the seven commandments. Muriel, the goat, read a little better than the dogs, and sometimes, at night, she would read to the others from newspaper clippings she found in the trash. Benjamin read as well as any of the pigs, but he never exercised his abilities. As far as he knew, he said, there was nothing worth reading. Clover learned the entire alphabet, but she couldn't form the words. Boxer couldn't get past the letter D. He could trace A, B, C, D in the dirt with his enormous hoof, and then he would stand staring at the letters with his ears back, sometimes moving his mane, trying to remember what came next, but never succeeding. On several occasions, it's true, he managed to learn E, F, G, H, but when he did, he found that he had forgotten A, B, C, and D. Finally, he decided to settle for these four letters, and he would write them once or twice a day to refresh his memory. Mollie refused to learn more than the six letters that made up her name. She would form them very neatly with pieces of branches, and then she would decorate them with a flower or two and walk around them admiring them.

en: None of the other animals on the farm could get further than the letter A. It was also found that the stupider animals, such as the sheep, hens, and ducks, were unable to learn the Seven Commandments by heart. After much thought Snowball declared that the Seven Commandments could in effect be reduced to a single maxim, namely: “Four legs good, two legs bad.” This, he said, contained the essential principle of Animalism. Whoever had thoroughly grasped it would be safe from human influences. The birds at first objected, since it seemed to them that they also had two legs, but Snowball proved to them that this was not so.
vi: The others did not get past the letter A. Less intelligent species like sheep, chickens, and ducks could not memorize the Seven Commandments. After some thought, Snowball declared that the Seven Commandments could be reduced to a single maxim: "Four legs good, two legs bad." He said that this was the fundamental principle of Animalism. As long as they grasped this maxim, they would no longer fear the influence of humans. The chickens and ducks protested, arguing that they only had two legs, but Snowball proved that this was not the case.
tr: None of the other animals on the farm could get beyond the letter A; it was observed that the most foolish animals like sheep, chickens, and ducks could never memorize the Seven Commandments. Snowball, who put a lot of thought into solving this problem, finally announced that the Seven Commandments could actually be reduced to a single maxim. The Seven Commandments could easily be reduced to the maxim, "four legs good, two legs bad." According to Snowball, this maxim contained the fundamental principle of animalism. Anyone who thoroughly understood this fundamental principle could be protected from the harmful effects of mankind. At first, the birds objected to this maxim on the grounds that they too had two legs; but Snowball was quick to prove them wrong.
es: No other animal on the farm could get past the letter A. It was also discovered that the most stupid ones, like the sheep, the hens, and the ducks, were incapable of memorizing the seven commandments. After much thought, Snowball declared that the seven commandments could be reduced to a single maxim expressed as: "Four legs good, two legs bad!" This, he said, contained the essential principle of Animalism. Anyone who fully understood it would be safeguarded against human influences. At first, the birds made certain objections because it seemed to them that they also had only two legs; but Snowball demonstrated to them that this was not the case.

en: “A bird’s wing, comrades,” he said, “is an organ of propulsion and not of manipulation. It should therefore be regarded as a leg. The distinguishing mark of man is the HAND, the instrument with which he does all his mischief.”
vi: "The wings, comrades," Tuyết Tròn said, "are organs for movement, not for grasping. Wings are just like legs. The distinguishing feature from Humans is the hands; all the evil deeds are done by their hands."
tr: "Comrades," he said. "The wing of a bird is an organ used not for work, but for movement. Therefore, the wing should be considered as a foot. The difference of mankind lies in the hand, the tool with which all devilry is done."
es: —The wings of a bird —he explained— are propulsion organs and not for manipulation. Therefore, they should be considered as legs. The characteristic that distinguishes man is the "hand," a tool with which he commits all his excesses.

en: The birds did not understand Snowball’s long words, but they accepted his explanation, and all the humbler animals set to work to learn the new maxim by heart. FOUR LEGS GOOD, TWO LEGS BAD, was inscribed on the end wall of the barn, above the Seven Commandments and in bigger letters. When they had once got it by heart, the sheep developed a great liking for this maxim, and often as they lay in the field they would all start bleating “Four legs good, two legs bad! Four legs good, two legs bad!” and keep it up for hours on end, never growing tired of it.
vi: The chickens and ducks did not fully understand the lengthy sermon, but they agreed with Snowball's explanation, and all the more foolish animals had to memorize the new maxim. FOUR LEGS GOOD, TWO LEGS BAD was written larger, above the Seven Commandments. Once they had memorized it, the sheep showed great enthusiasm for this maxim, and whenever they were resting, they would chant in unison, "Four legs good, two legs bad! Four legs good, two legs bad!" tirelessly for hours on end.
tr: Despite not understanding anything from Snowball's words, the birds accepted his explanation. All the animals began to memorize the new maxim. On the wall of the barn, above the Seven Commandments, it was written in even larger letters: FOUR LEGS GOOD, TWO LEGS BAD. After memorizing these words, the sheep loved the maxim so much that while lounging in the meadow, they would habitually bleat together, "Four legs good, two legs bad! Four legs good, two legs bad!" tirelessly for hours.
es: The birds did not fully understand Snowball's lengthy harangue, but they accepted his explanations, and even the most insignificant animals began to learn the new maxim by heart. "Four legs good, two legs bad!" was inscribed on the back wall of the barn, above the seven commandments and in larger letters. The sheep loved it, and once they had memorized it, they bleated it over and over again, even while resting on the field, and their "Four legs good, two legs bad!" could be heard for hours on end, repeated tirelessly.

en: Napoleon took no interest in Snowball’s committees. He said that the education of the young was more important than anything that could be done for those who were already grown up. It happened that Jessie and Bluebell had both whelped soon after the hay harvest, giving birth between them to nine sturdy puppies. As soon as they were weaned, Napoleon took them away from their mothers, saying that he would make himself responsible for their education. He took them up into a loft which could only be reached by a ladder from the harness-room, and there kept them in such seclusion that the rest of the farm soon forgot their existence.
vi: Napoleon did not care about Snowball's committees. He said that educating the younger generation was more important than mobilizing the already grown animals. The two female dogs, Jessie and Bluebell, gave birth to nine healthy puppies right after the harvest. Napoleon took the puppies as soon as they were weaned, saying he would take responsibility for their education. He hid the puppies in the attic, above the tool shed, which could only be reached by ladder, and kept them there so secretly that gradually no one remembered the puppies anymore.
tr: Napoleon had never been interested in Snowball's committees. He believed that educating the young was far more important than anything that could be done for those who were already grown up. Jessie and Bluebell had given birth to nine sturdy puppies immediately after the harvest. As soon as they were weaned, Napoleon took them away from their mothers, saying that he would be responsible for their education. He then secluded them in a loft which could only be reached by a ladder from the harness-room, keeping them so out of sight that the rest of the farm soon forgot their existence.
es: Napoleon did not take an interest in the committees created by Snowball. He said that the education of the young was more important than anything that could be done for the adults. Meanwhile, it happened that Jessie and Bluebell had given birth shortly after the hay was harvested. Between the two of them, they had given the farm nine sturdy puppies. As soon as they were weaned, Napoleon separated them from their mothers, saying that he would take charge of their education. He took them to an attic, which could only be reached by a ladder from the harness room, and there he kept them in such a degree of seclusion that the rest of the farm soon forgot about their existence.

en: The mystery of where the milk went to was soon cleared up. It was mixed every day into the pigs’ mash. The early apples were now ripening, and the grass of the orchard was littered with windfalls. The animals had assumed as a matter of course that these would be shared out equally; one day, however, the order went forth that all the windfalls were to be collected and brought to the harness-room for the use of the pigs. At this some of the other animals murmured, but it was no use. All the pigs were in full agreement on this point, even Snowball and Napoleon. Squealer was sent to make the necessary explanations to the others.
vi: The issue of milk loss is no longer a secret. The pigs mixed it into the daily feed. The early-season apples have ripened, and every day some fall onto the grass in the garden. All the animals thought they would be shared equally, but one day there was an order to collect the fallen apples and store them in the tool shed exclusively for the pigs. Some animals complained about this, but it led nowhere. On this matter, the pigs, including Snowball and Napoleon, were in complete agreement. Squealer was assigned to carry out the propaganda work.
tr: It was soon understood where the milk had gone. The milk was being mixed into the pigs' mash every day. The apples were now starting to ripen; the grass of the orchard was covered with apples fallen by the wind. The animals naturally hoped that the apples would be shared equally; however, one day it was ordered that all the apples fallen from the trees be collected and delivered to the pigs in the room where the harnesses were kept. Some animals grumbled, but it was of no use. All the pigs, even Snowball and Napoleon, were of the same mind on this matter. Squealer, who was tasked with making the necessary explanations to the other animals, shouted, "Comrades!" "I hope you do not think that we pigs are doing this out of selfishness or a love for privilege.
es: The mystery of the fate of the milk was soon clarified: it was mixed every day into the pigs' food. The first apples were already ripening, and the grass in the orchard was covered with fruit fallen from the trees. The animals naturally believed that this fruit would be distributed equitably; one day, however, the order was given that all fallen apples should be collected and taken to the harness-room for the pigs' consumption. Shortly after this happened, some animals began to murmur, but in vain. All the pigs agreed on this point, even Snowball and Napoleon. Squealer was sent to give the necessary explanations.

en: “Comrades!” he cried. “You do not imagine, I hope, that we pigs are doing this in a spirit of selfishness and privilege? Many of us actually dislike milk and apples. I dislike them myself. Our sole object in taking these things is to preserve our health. Milk and apples (this has been proved by Science, comrades) contain substances absolutely necessary to the well-being of a pig. We pigs are brainworkers. The whole management and organisation of this farm depend on us. Day and night we are watching over your welfare. It is for YOUR sake that we drink that milk and eat those apples. Do you know what would happen if we pigs failed in our duty? Jones would come back! Yes, Jones would come back! Surely, comrades,” cried Squealer almost pleadingly, skipping from side to side and whisking his tail, “surely there is no one among you who wants to see Jones come back?”
vi: "Comrades," it said, "I hope you don't think that we pigs are doing this out of selfishness and privilege, do you? Many pig comrades are also sick of milk and apples. I don't like those two things either. Our purpose in eating those things is solely to protect our health. Milk and apples (Comrades, science has proven) contain many substances that are extremely necessary for the health of pigs. We pigs do intellectual work. We handle all the organization and management of this farm. For your prosperity, we have to work day and night. We drink milk and eat apples for your own benefit. Can you imagine what would happen if we pigs couldn't handle our duties? Mr. Jones would come back! Yes, Mr. Jones would come back! Surely none of us want Mr. Jones to come back, do we?" it pleaded loudly, shouting and jumping from right to left, its tail wagging furiously, "Surely none of us want Mr. Jones to come back, right?"
tr: Squealer, who was tasked with making the necessary explanations to the other animals, shouted, "Comrades!" "I hope you do not think that we pigs are doing this out of selfishness or a love for privilege. In fact, most of us do not like milk and apples. I do not like them either. The only reason we are taking these apples is to preserve our health. There are certain substances in milk and apples that are absolutely necessary for the health of pigs. Science has proven this, comrades. We pigs are the brainworkers. We are responsible for the management and organization of this farm. We work day and night to safeguard your well-being. We drink this milk and eat these apples for your sake. Do you know what would happen if we pigs failed to perform our duty properly? Jones would come back! Yes, Jones would come back! Have no doubt about that, comrades." Then, jumping from side to side and wagging his tail, he shouted: "I believe there is not a single animal among you who wants Jones to come back!"
es: —Comrades —he shouted—, I imagine you don't suppose that we pigs are doing this with a spirit of selfishness and privilege. Many of us, in fact, have an aversion to milk and apples. Personally, I don't like them. Our only purpose in eating these foods is to preserve our health. Milk and apples (this has been proven by Science, comrades) contain substances absolutely necessary for the health of a pig. We pigs work with our brains. The entire administration and organization of this farm depend on us. Day and night we are watching over your happiness. For your sake, we take that milk and eat those apples. Do you know what would happen if we pigs failed in our duty? Jones would come back! Yes, Jones would come back! Surely, comrades —exclaimed Squealer almost pleadingly, dancing from side to side and wagging his tail—, surely there is no one among you who wants Jones to return.

en: Now if there was one thing that the animals were completely certain of, it was that they did not want Jones back. When it was put to them in this light, they had no more to say. The importance of keeping the pigs in good health was all too obvious. So it was agreed without further argument that the milk and the windfall apples (and also the main crop of apples when they ripened) should be reserved for the pigs alone.
vi: Surely no animal wanted Mr. Jones to come back. When put that way, no animal dared to speak up anymore. The health of the pigs was of utmost importance, that was unquestionable. So they unanimously agreed without further discussion that the milk and fallen apples (when in season, all of them) were to be reserved exclusively for the pigs. George Orwell Animal Farm
tr: If there was one thing the animals had no doubt about, it was that they did not want Jones to return. The importance of keeping the pigs healthy was very clear. Thus, before the argument grew, it was agreed by everyone that all the milk and the apples that fell from the trees due to the wind (naturally, also the apples picked from the trees when they ripened) would be allocated to the pigs.
es: Certainly, if there was one thing the animals were completely sure of, it was that they did not want Jones back. When it was presented to them in this way, they didn't know what to say. The importance of preserving the health of the pigs was too obvious. So it was decided without any discussion that the milk and the apples that had fallen from the trees (and also the main harvest of apples when they ripened) should be reserved exclusively for the pigs.
