en: By the late summer the news of what had happened on Animal Farm had spread across half the county. Every day Snowball and Napoleon sent out flights of pigeons whose instructions were to mingle with the animals on neighbouring farms, tell them the story of the Rebellion, and teach them the tune of ‘Beasts of England’.
vi: By the end of summer, news about Animal Farm had spread across half the country. Every day, Snowball and Napoleon sent flocks of pigeons to infiltrate other farms to propagate the Rebellion and teach the song "Beasts of England."
tr: By the end of summer, almost the entire country had heard about what was happening at Animal Farm. The carrier pigeons that Snowball and Napoleon sent out every day were making friends with the animals on neighboring farms, telling them the story of the Rebellion, and teaching them the song "Beasts of England."
es: BY the end of summer, the news of what had happened at "Animal Farm" had spread almost throughout the entire county. Every day, Snowball and Napoleon sent flocks of pigeons with instructions to mingle with the animals of the neighboring farms, tell them the story of the Rebellion, and teach them the tune of "Beasts of England."

en: Most of this time Mr. Jones had spent sitting in the taproom of the Red Lion at Willingdon, complaining to anyone who would listen of the monstrous injustice he had suffered in being turned out of his property by a pack of good-for-nothing animals. The other farmers sympathised in principle, but they did not at first give him much help. At heart, each of them was secretly wondering whether he could not somehow turn Jones’s misfortune to his own advantage. It was lucky that the owners of the two farms which adjoined Animal Farm were on permanently bad terms. One of them, which was named Foxwood, was a large, neglected, old-fashioned farm, much overgrown by woodland, with all its pastures worn out and its hedges in a disgraceful condition. Its owner, Mr. Pilkington, was an easy-going gentleman farmer who spent most of his time in fishing or hunting according to the season. The other farm, which was called Pinchfield, was smaller and better kept. Its owner was a Mr. Frederick, a tough, shrewd man, perpetually involved in lawsuits and with a name for driving hard bargains. These two disliked each other so much that it was difficult for them to come to any agreement, even in defence of their own interests.
vi: Meanwhile, Mr. Jones almost every day sat in the Red Lion restaurant in Willingdon, lamenting to anyone who would listen about being robbed of his property by the useless animals. The other farm owners were sympathetic, but they didn't offer any help. Moreover, deep down, they were looking for ways to take advantage of his misfortune. Fortunately, the owners of the two farms adjacent to Animal Farm were always at odds with each other. One farm was called Foxwood, a large but neglected farm, cultivated in the old-fashioned way, with overgrown areas, trampled grazing grounds, and dilapidated fences. The owner of this farm, Mr. Pilkington, was an easygoing man who spent most of his time hunting and fishing. The second farm was called Pinchfield, smaller but better maintained. The owner of this farm, Mr. Frederick, was a tough, shrewd man, constantly involved in lawsuits and notorious as a cunning swindler. These two men hated each other so much that they couldn't find common ground even in protecting their own interests.
tr: Meanwhile, Mr. Jones spent most of his time lounging at the Red Lion tavern in Willingdon; whenever he found someone to listen to him, he would immediately start complaining, saying he had been terribly wronged and driven out of his farm by a bunch of lowly animals. The other farmers had met him with understanding, but initially, they were not very inclined to help. Each of them was secretly thinking about how they could benefit from Jones's misfortune. Fortunately, the owners of the two farms neighboring Animal Farm could never get along with each other. Foxwood was a large, neglected, and run-down farm; it was overgrown with bushes, its pastures had withered, and its fences were in tatters. The owner of Foxwood, Mr. Pilkington, spent most of his time fishing during the fishing season and hunting during the hunting season; he was a laid-back, gentlemanly man. Pinchfield Farm, on the other hand, was smaller but better maintained. The owner of Pinchfield, Mr. Frederick, was a bully and a cunning man; he was constantly involved in lawsuits; money was his religion, and once he got his hands on something, he wouldn't let go. These two hated each other so much that they couldn't agree even on matters that were in their mutual interest.
es: For most of that time, Jones stayed at the "Red Lion" tavern in Willingdon, complaining to anyone who would listen about the monstrous injustice he had suffered by being thrown off his property by a band of useless animals. The other farmers sympathized with him, although they did not give him much help. Inwardly, each one secretly wondered if they could somehow turn Jones's misfortune to their own advantage. It was fortunate that the owners of the two farms adjoining "Animal Farm" were always at odds. One of them, called Foxwood, was a large, old-fashioned, and neglected farm, covered with woodland, with its grazing fields exhausted and its fences in a lamentable state. Its owner, Mr. Pilkington, was a gentlemanly and lazy farmer who spent most of his time fishing or hunting, depending on the season. The other farm, called Pinchfield, was smaller and better kept. Its owner, one Frederick, was a tough, shrewd man who was always involved in lawsuits and had a reputation as a skilled negotiator. The two hated each other so much that it was difficult for them to agree, even in defense of their own interests.

en: Nevertheless, they were both thoroughly frightened by the rebellion on Animal Farm, and very anxious to prevent their own animals from learning too much about it. At first they pretended to laugh to scorn the idea of animals managing a farm for themselves. The whole thing would be over in a fortnight, they said. They put it about that the animals on the Manor Farm (they insisted on calling it the Manor Farm; they would not tolerate the name “Animal Farm”) were perpetually fighting among themselves and were also rapidly starving to death. When time passed and the animals had evidently not starved to death, Frederick and Pilkington changed their tune and began to talk of the terrible wickedness that now flourished on Animal Farm. It was given out that the animals there practised cannibalism, tortured one another with red-hot horseshoes, and had their females in common. This was what came of rebelling against the laws of Nature, Frederick and Pilkington said.
vi: But the Rebellion at Animal Farm had frightened both of them, and they tried everything to prevent the news from reaching their own farms. At first, they pretended to ridicule the idea of animals running a farm by themselves. "It won't last more than a fortnight," they said. They spread rumors that the animals at Manor Farm (they insisted on calling it Manor Farm and refused to acknowledge the name Animal Farm) were constantly fighting among themselves and would soon starve to death. After some time, seeing that the animals were not starving, Frederick and Pilkington changed their tune and began talking about unimaginable immoral scenes taking place at Animal Farm. They claimed that the animals were eating each other, torturing each other with red-hot horseshoes, and that the females had become communal property. "That's what happens when you go against the laws of Nature," Frederick and Pilkington said.
tr: However, both of them were very afraid of the Rebellion at Animal Farm; they were doing everything they could to prevent the animals on their own farms from getting detailed information about the rebellion. In fact, at first, they had laughed a lot at the idea that animals could run a farm on their own; they thought that this would collapse in ten or fifteen days at most. They had spread rumors that the animals at Manor Farm (they insisted on referring to the farm as Manor Farm, they couldn't tolerate the name "Animal Farm") were constantly quarreling with each other and would soon die of starvation. But when it turned out after a while that the animals were not dying of starvation, they changed their tune and started talking about the mind-boggling devilry at Animal Farm. According to these two farmers, cannibalism had taken hold at Animal Farm; the animals were torturing each other with hot horseshoes and sharing their females communally. Frederick and Pilkington said that all of this was the natural consequence of rebelling against the laws of nature.
es: Nevertheless, both were completely frightened by the rebellion at "Animal Farm" and very anxious to prevent their animals from learning too much about the event. At first, they pretended to laugh and scorn the idea of animals managing their own farm. "This whole thing will be over by tomorrow," they said to each other. They claimed that the animals at "Manor Farm" (they insisted on calling it "Manor Farm" because they could not tolerate the name "Animal Farm") were constantly fighting among themselves and would end up starving to death. After some time, and when the animals evidently did not starve, Frederick and Pilkington changed their tune and began to talk about the terrible wickedness flourishing at "Animal Farm." They spread the rumor that the animals practiced cannibalism, tortured each other with red-hot horseshoes, and practiced free love. "That is the result of rebelling against the laws of Nature," Frederick and Pilkington maintained.

en: However, these stories were never fully believed. Rumours of a wonderful farm, where the human beings had been turned out and the animals managed their own affairs, continued to circulate in vague and distorted forms, and throughout that year a wave of rebelliousness ran through the countryside. Bulls which had always been tractable suddenly turned savage, sheep broke down hedges and devoured the clover, cows kicked the pail over, hunters refused their fences and shot their riders on to the other side. Above all, the tune and even the words of ‘Beasts of England’ were known everywhere. It had spread with astonishing speed. The human beings could not contain their rage when they heard this song, though they pretended to think it merely ridiculous. They could not understand, they said, how even animals could bring themselves to sing such contemptible rubbish. Any animal caught singing it was given a flogging on the spot. And yet the song was irrepressible. The blackbirds whistled it in the hedges, the pigeons cooed it in the elms, it got into the din of the smithies and the tune of the church bells. And when the human beings listened to it, they secretly trembled, hearing in it a prophecy of their future doom.
vi: But not many people believed that story. The rumor about a strange farm, where humans were driven away and the animals managed the work themselves, continued to be passed around in a vague and distorted manner, and throughout that year, waves of unrest spread across the countryside. Oxen that were usually docile suddenly became aggressive, sheep broke down fences and trampled the pastures, cows knocked over milk pails, and racehorses refused to jump over fences, throwing their riders high into the air. The melody and lyrics of the song "Beasts of England" spread to every nook and cranny. It was disseminated at an unprecedented speed. The song drove people mad, but they pretended it was just a ridiculous joke. Even animals couldn't possibly sing such vile rubbish, they said. Any animal caught singing that song was immediately beaten on the spot. Yet it still couldn't be completely banned. Birds sang it on the fences, pigeons cooed it in the trees, the song entered the chirping of crickets, and even the church bells. Humans shivered every time they heard it, as if they were hearing a forewarning of their own doom.
tr: But these stories did not seem credible to anyone. It was said that there was an extraordinary farm where animals drove out humans and managed everything themselves, and rumors about this continued with all their uncertainty and distortion. A wave of rebellion rose throughout the year on the surrounding farms. Bulls known to be docile suddenly went wild, sheep broke through fences and devoured clover, cows kicked over buckets, horses disobeyed orders, and suddenly stopped, throwing their riders over the fences to the other side. Most importantly, the tune and lyrics of the song "Animals of England" were now known everywhere. It had spread with unexpected speed. Although people claimed to find it very ridiculous, they couldn't help but feel great anger when they heard this song. They argued that they couldn't even comprehend how such a disgraceful and absurd song could be sung by animals. Animals caught singing the song were whipped on the spot, yet the spread of the song could not be prevented. While blackbirds whistled among the bushes and pigeons cooed in the trees, they were always singing this song; the melodies of the song mingled with the hammer blows of blacksmiths and the chimes of church bells.
es: However, these tales were never given much credit. Rumors about a wonderful farm from which humans had been expelled and where the animals managed their own affairs continued to circulate vaguely and falsely, and throughout that year a wave of rebellion spread across the region. Bulls that had always been docile suddenly turned wild; there were sheep that broke through fences and devoured the clover; cows that knocked over the buckets when being milked; hunting horses that refused to jump the hedges and threw their riders over their ears. Despite everything, the tune and even the lyrics of "Beasts of England" were known everywhere. They had spread with astonishing speed. Humans could not contain their fury when they heard this song, although they pretended to consider it simply ridiculous. They could not understand, they said, how even the animals themselves dared to sing something so despicable. Any animal caught singing it was whipped on the spot. However, the song proved irrepressible: blackbirds whistled it in the hedges, pigeons cooed it in the poplars, and it could even be recognized in the noise of the forges and the ringing of church bells. And when humans heard it, they secretly trembled, for they sensed in it a forewarning of their future doom.

en: Early in October, when the corn was cut and stacked and some of it was already threshed, a flight of pigeons came whirling through the air and alighted in the yard of Animal Farm in the wildest excitement. Jones and all his men, with half a dozen others from Foxwood and Pinchfield, had entered the five-barred gate and were coming up the cart-track that led to the farm. They were all carrying sticks, except Jones, who was marching ahead with a gun in his hands. Obviously they were going to attempt the recapture of the farm.
vi: At the beginning of October, after harvesting and storing all the grain, with some already threshed, a flock of pigeons suddenly tore through the air and landed in the farmyard, looking extremely agitated. Mr. Jones, along with his servants and about half a dozen young men from Foxwood and Pinchfield farms, had passed through the main gate and were advancing into the farm. Mr. Jones was brandishing a loaded gun, while the others were armed with sticks. There was no doubt about it, they intended to recapture the farm.
tr: It was early October; the crops had been harvested and stacked, and the threshing was largely completed. One day, suddenly, carrier pigeons came circling swiftly and landed in the courtyard of Animal Farm, flapping anxiously. According to the news they brought, Jones and his men, along with half a dozen men from the Foxwood and Pinchfield farms, had entered through the barred gate and were coming up the driveway to the farm. Jones, with a rifle in hand, was walking at the front; the men with sticks were following him. Obviously, they had made up their minds to take back the farm.
es: In early October, when the corn had been cut and stacked and some of it had already been threshed, a flock of pigeons sped across and landed, very excited, in the yard of "Animal Farm." Jones and all his men, with half a dozen more men from Foxwood and Pinchfield, had crossed the gate and were approaching the house along the path. They were all wielding sticks, except for Jones, who marched ahead with a shotgun in his hand. Evidently, they were going to try to recapture the farm.

en: This had long been expected, and all preparations had been made. Snowball, who had studied an old book of Julius Caesar’s campaigns which he had found in the farmhouse, was in charge of the defensive operations. He gave his orders quickly, and in a couple of minutes every animal was at his post.
vi: But the animals were not caught off guard; on the contrary, they had been preparing for this event for a long time. Snowball, who had previously studied the book on Julius Caesar's campaigns [2] thoroughly, which it found in the main house, was assigned to organize the defense. It immediately issued orders, and the animals quickly took up their assigned positions.
tr: In fact, since such an attempt had been expected for a long time, all precautions had been taken, and all necessary preparations had been made. Snowball, who had gained extensive knowledge about Julius Caesar's campaigns by reading an old book he found in the farmhouse, was appointed to the command of the defense operation. He immediately gave his orders; all the animals took their positions within a few minutes.
es: This eventuality had long been anticipated and, consequently, the necessary precautions had been taken. Snowball, who had studied Julius Caesar's campaigns in an old book found in the house, was in charge of the defensive operations. He gave the orders quickly and within a few minutes, each animal was in its combat position.

en: As the human beings approached the farm buildings, Snowball launched his first attack. All the pigeons, to the number of thirty-five, flew to and fro over the men’s heads and muted upon them from mid-air; and while the men were dealing with this, the geese, who had been hiding behind the hedge, rushed out and pecked viciously at the calves of their legs. However, this was only a light skirmishing manoeuvre, intended to create a little disorder, and the men easily drove the geese off with their sticks. Snowball now launched his second line of attack. Muriel, Benjamin, and all the sheep, with Snowball at the head of them, rushed forward and prodded and butted the men from every side, while Benjamin turned around and lashed at them with his small hoofs. But once again the men, with their sticks and their hobnailed boots, were too strong for them; and suddenly, at a squeal from Snowball, which was the signal for retreat, all the animals turned and fled through the gateway into the yard.
vi: Tuyet Tron ordered an attack as soon as the group of people approached the row of houses in the farm. Thirty-five pigeons were dispatched, flying back and forth and defecating on the heads of the people below. While they were busy dodging and brushing off, the geese, ambushed behind the fence, rushed out and bit their legs. But that was just a tactical move to disrupt the enemy's ranks because it was easy for people to use sticks to drive the geese away. The second wave of attack was launched. Muriel, Benjamin, and the entire flock of sheep, led by Tuyet Tron himself, charged forward, surrounding the people and butting them while Benjamin turned his back on them and kicked wildly. But this time, the animals did not win either; the sticks and spiked shoes used by the humans were too strong for them. Seeing the unfavorable situation, Tuyet Tron neighed loudly, which was the signal to temporarily retreat, and the animals quickly fled into the yard.
tr: As the people approached the farm buildings, Snowball initiated the first attack. Exactly thirty-five pigeons flew over the men's heads, defecating on them. While the men tried to chase away the pigeons, the geese, hidden behind the fence, suddenly rushed forward and began savagely pecking at their calves. However, this was merely a feint to cause some confusion; indeed, the men easily drove the geese back with their sticks. This time, Snowball initiated the second attack. Muriel, Benjamin, and all the sheep, led by Snowball, charged forward, butting and horn-thrusting the men from all sides; meanwhile, Benjamin kept kicking back. But with their sticks in hand and hobnailed boots on their feet, the men were still stronger than the animals. When Snowball suddenly squealed, signaling a retreat, all the animals turned back, dashed through the passage, and plunged into the yard.
es: When the human beings approached the farm buildings, Snowball launched his first attack. All the pigeons—there were about thirty-five of them—flew over the men's heads and soiled them from above; and while the men were busy dodging what was falling on them, the geese, hidden behind the hedge, attacked them by furiously pecking at their calves. But that was a mere skirmish intended to create a bit of disorder, and the men easily drove the geese away with their sticks. Snowball launched the second line of attack: Muriel, Benjamin, and all the sheep, with Snowball at the head, advanced, charging and shoving the men from all sides, while Benjamin turned around and began kicking with his hind legs. But again, the men, with their sticks and hobnailed boots, were too strong for them, and suddenly, upon hearing Snowball's squeal, which was the signal to retreat, all the animals turned around and went through the gate into the yard.

en: The men gave a shout of triumph. They saw, as they imagined, their enemies in flight, and they rushed after them in disorder. This was just what Snowball had intended. As soon as they were well inside the yard, the three horses, the three cows, and the rest of the pigs, who had been lying in ambush in the cowshed, suddenly emerged in their rear, cutting them off. Snowball now gave the signal for the charge. He himself dashed straight for Jones. Jones saw him coming, raised his gun and fired. The pellets scored bloody streaks along Snowball’s back, and a sheep dropped dead. Without halting for an instant, Snowball flung his fifteen stone against Jones’s legs. Jones was hurled into a pile of dung and his gun flew out of his hands. But the most terrifying spectacle of all was Boxer, rearing up on his hind legs and striking out with his great iron-shod hoofs like a stallion. His very first blow took a stable-lad from Foxwood on the skull and stretched him lifeless in the mud. At the sight, several men dropped their sticks and tried to run. Panic overtook them, and the next moment all the animals together were chasing them round and round the yard. They were gored, kicked, bitten, trampled on. There was not an animal on the farm that did not take vengeance on them after his own fashion. Even the cat suddenly leapt off a roof onto a cowman’s shoulders and sank her claws in his neck, at which he yelled horribly. At a moment when the opening was clear, the men were glad enough to rush out of the yard and make a bolt for the main road. And so within five minutes of their invasion they were in ignominious retreat by the same way as they had come, with a flock of geese hissing after them and pecking at their calves all the way.
vi: The victorious cheers echoed. The attackers saw that the enemy had fled as expected, so without needing to reorganize their ranks, they hurriedly rushed forward to pursue. Just as Snowball had anticipated. When everyone had entered the yard, three horses, three cows, and all the remaining pigs that had been lying in ambush in the cow shed rushed out to cut off the retreat. Snowball ordered a full assault. He charged straight at Mr. Jones. Mr. Jones saw him coming and pulled the trigger. The shotgun blast wounded Snowball along his back, blood streaming out, and killed a sheep. Without hesitating for a second, Snowball continued to thrust his hefty body into Mr. Jones's legs. He fell sprawling into a pile of dung, his gun flying far away. But the most terrifying was Boxer, who stood on his hind legs and brought down his iron-shod hooves on the man's head. His first blow knocked the Foxwood farmhand to the ground, unconscious. Several people threw down their sticks and fled. Not missing the opportunity, the animals chased them around the yard. They butted them up, then bit, kicked, and trampled. There wasn't a single animal on the farm that didn't take part in the revenge in its own way. Even the cat leapt from the roof of the cow shed onto a cowherd's shoulders, biting his neck and screeching as if in a fit. As soon as they saw an opening to retreat, everyone hurriedly ran out of the yard to the main road. Thus, having penetrated for less than five minutes, they had to flee, with the geese biting their legs and honking as they chased them.
tr: The men shouting victory cries, thinking their enemies were fleeing, ran chaotically after them. This was exactly what Snowball wanted. Once they all entered the yard, the three horses, three cows, and the other pigs who were lying in ambush in the barn suddenly appeared and cut off the men's retreat. It was at that moment that Snowball gave the signal to attack and charged straight at Jones. Seeing Snowball coming at him, Jones aimed his rifle and fired. The pellets opened bloody furrows on Snowball's back; one of the sheep died on the spot. Without a moment's hesitation, Snowball, with his hundred-kilo body, lunged at Jones's legs. As Jones tumbled onto a manure pile, his rifle flew out of his hand. But the most terrifying was Boxer; rearing up on his hind legs, he fought like a stallion, swinging his massive iron-shod hooves. The first blow landed on the head of a stable boy from Foxwood Farm, who collapsed into the mud and died on the spot. Seeing this, many of the men dropped their sticks and tried to flee. They were seized with panic. At that moment, all the animals chased after the men, pursuing them around the yard. They gored, kicked, bit, and trampled anyone who lagged behind. Not a single animal on the farm failed to take its revenge on the men. Even the cat suddenly leaped from the roof onto a cowherd's back, digging its claws into his neck and making him scream in pain. The men, finding an opportunity, bolted out of the yard and started running full speed towards the main road. It had been less than five minutes since they had raided the farm, yet they were retreating in disgrace, just as they had come. A flock of geese, hissing as they followed, pecked at their legs all the way down the road.
es: The men let out a cry of triumph. They saw —or so they imagined— their enemies in flight and ran after them in disarray. That was precisely what Snowball had been expecting. As soon as they were inside the yard, the three horses, the three cows, and the other pigs, who had been lying in wait in the cowshed, suddenly appeared behind them, cutting off their retreat. Snowball gave the signal to charge. He himself attacked Jones. Jones saw him coming, aimed his shotgun, and fired. The pellets left their bloody mark on Snowball's back, and a sheep fell dead. Without hesitating for an instant, Snowball hurled his fifteen stone against Jones's legs, who fell onto a pile of manure as the shotgun slipped from his hands. But the most terrifying sight was Boxer, rearing up on his hind legs and kicking like a stallion with his enormous iron-shod hooves. His first blow struck a stable boy from Foxwood on the head, leaving him lying lifeless in the mud. Seeing this scene, several men dropped their sticks and tried to escape. But panic seized them, and in an instant, the animals were running after them all over the yard. They were gored, kicked, bitten, trampled. There was not a single animal on the farm that did not take revenge in its own way. Even the cat suddenly leaped from a rooftop onto a cowboy's back and sank its claws into his neck, making him scream horribly. When the exit was clear, the men were glad to escape the yard and flee like lightning to the main road. And so, five minutes after their invasion, they were in shameful retreat along the same access route, with a flock of geese pecking at their calves all the way.

en: All the men were gone except one. Back in the yard Boxer was pawing with his hoof at the stable-lad who lay face down in the mud, trying to turn him over. The boy did not stir.
vi: There was one person who did not escape. In the yard, the Soldier was trying to turn over the stable cleaner who was still lying face down in the mud. The man did not move at all.
tr: They had all escaped, except for one. Boxer was nudging the stable boy who was lying face down in the mud in the yard with his front hoof, trying to turn him over, but the boy wasn't moving.
es: All the men had left, except one. Out in the yard, Boxer was pushing with his hoof at the stable boy who lay face down in the mud, trying to turn him over. The boy did not move.

en: “He is dead,” said Boxer sorrowfully. “I had no intention of doing that. I forgot that I was wearing iron shoes. Who will believe that I did not do this on purpose?”
vi: "He's dead!", the Warrior exclaimed sadly, "I didn't mean to do that. I forgot that I was wearing iron claws. Who would believe now that I didn't do it on purpose?"
tr: Boxer said sadly, "He's dead." "I had no intention of killing him. I forgot that I had iron shoes on my feet. Who will believe now that I didn't do it on purpose?"
es: —He is dead —said Boxer sadly—. I didn't mean to do it. I forgot that I had horseshoes. Who is going to believe that I didn't do this on purpose?

en: “No sentimentality, comrade!” cried Snowball from whose wounds the blood was still dripping. “War is war. The only good human being is a dead one.”
vi: "Stop being sentimental, comrade!" Tuyết Tròn said, blood still oozing from his back at times, "War is war. Good people are those who have died."
tr: With his wounds still bleeding, Snowball shouted, "No need for sentimentality, comrade!" "War is war. The best human is a dead human."
es: —No sentimentality, comrade —shouted Snowball, from whose wounds blood was still flowing—. War is war. The only good human is a dead one.

en: “I have no wish to take life, not even human life,” repeated Boxer, and his eyes were full of tears.
vi: "I did not mean to kill, not even to kill a person," the Warrior kept repeating, eyes filled with tears.
tr: "I don't want to take anyone's life," said Boxer. His eyes were filled with tears.
es: —I do not wish to take a life, not even a human one —repeated Boxer with his eyes full of tears.

en: “Where is Mollie?” exclaimed somebody.
vi: "Where's Mollie?", someone asked.
tr: At that moment, someone shouted, "Where is Mollie?"
es: —Where is Mollie? —someone inquired.

en: Mollie in fact was missing. For a moment there was great alarm; it was feared that the men might have harmed her in some way, or even carried her off with them. In the end, however, she was found hiding in her stall with her head buried among the hay in the manger. She had taken to flight as soon as the gun went off. And when the others came back from looking for her, it was to find that the stable-lad, who in fact was only stunned, had already recovered and made off.
vi: Indeed, Mollie was nowhere to be seen. At first, they were very worried, fearing that Mollie might have been injured or captured by the humans. Eventually, she was found hiding in the horse stable, her head buried in a pile of straw. She had fled as soon as she heard the gunshots. While the animals were searching for Mollie, the stable boy regained consciousness and escaped.
tr: Indeed, Mollie was missing. Suddenly, there was chaos. Had something happened to her? Could the men have kidnapped Mollie? After a long search, they found Mollie in the barn; she had hidden in her stall, burying her head in the hay in the manger. She had bolted as soon as the guns went off. When those who went to look for Mollie returned to the yard, they saw that the groom was nowhere to be found. Apparently, the young man they thought was dead had only fainted; he had come to later and made a run for it.
es: Indeed, Mollie was missing. For a moment there was great alarm; it was feared that the men had harmed her in some way, or perhaps had taken her with them. In the end, they found her hiding in her stall, in the stable, with her head buried in the hay of the manger. She had run away as soon as the gunshot was fired. And, when the others returned from their search, they found that the stable boy, who was actually only stunned, had recovered and fled.

en: The animals had now reassembled in the wildest excitement, each recounting his own exploits in the battle at the top of his voice. An impromptu celebration of the victory was held immediately. The flag was run up and ‘Beasts of England’ was sung a number of times, then the sheep who had been killed was given a solemn funeral, a hawthorn bush being planted on her grave. At the graveside Snowball made a little speech, emphasising the need for all animals to be ready to die for Animal Farm if need be.
vi: The animals had gathered in full, they were extremely excited, and competed to speak. The victory celebration was organized immediately. The flag was raised and they sang "Beasts of England" several times, then they held a funeral for the fallen sheep and planted a hawthorn bush on its grave. Snowball gave a speech right next to the fallen warrior's grave, emphasizing that every animal must be ready to sacrifice for Animal Farm when needed.
tr: The animals had reunited with wild enthusiasm, shouting at the top of their lungs as they recounted to each other the heroics they had shown in the battle. They immediately organized a ceremony right then and there to celebrate the victory. They hoisted the flag and sang "Beasts of England" several times. Then, they held a solemn burial ceremony for the sheep they had lost in the battle, planting a hawthorn sapling over its grave. Snowball, giving a short speech at the grave, emphasized that if necessary, all animals should be ready to die for Animal Farm.
es: The animals gathered very excitedly, each one loudly recounting their exploits in the battle. Immediately, an impromptu celebration of the victory took place. The flag was raised and "Beasts of England" was sung several times, and then a solemn burial was given to the sheep that died in the action, with a hawthorn branch planted over its grave. At this event, Snowball gave a speech, emphasizing the need for all animals to be willing to die for "Animal Farm," if necessary.

en: The animals decided unanimously to create a military decoration, “Animal Hero, First Class,” which was conferred there and then on Snowball and Boxer. It consisted of a brass medal (they were really some old horse-brasses which had been found in the harness-room), to be worn on Sundays and holidays. There was also “Animal Hero, Second Class,” which was conferred posthumously on the dead sheep.
vi: The animals unanimously decided to establish a reward for the recent feats, which was the title of First Class Animal Hero. This title was immediately awarded to Snowball and Boxer. The reward was a bronze medal (which was actually a piece of brass found in the harness room) to be worn on holidays and Sundays. The title of Second Class Animal Hero was awarded to the sheep that had sacrificed itself.
tr: The animals unanimously decided to establish a military decoration. The "First Class Hero Animal" medal was immediately awarded to Snowball and Boxer right there. These brass medals (actually, old horse trappings they found in the room where the harnesses were kept) were to be worn on Sundays and holidays. The sheep that had lost its life in the battle was deemed worthy of the "Second Class Hero Animal" medal.
es: The animals unanimously decided to create a military decoration: "Animal Hero, First Class," which was immediately awarded to Snowball and Boxer. It consisted of a bronze medal (in reality, some bronze horse trappings found in the harness-room), which was to be worn on Sundays and holidays. They also created the "Animal Hero, Second Class," which was posthumously awarded to the dead sheep.

en: There was much discussion as to what the battle should be called. In the end, it was named the Battle of the Cowshed, since that was where the ambush had been sprung. Mr. Jones’s gun had been found lying in the mud, and it was known that there was a supply of cartridges in the farmhouse. It was decided to set the gun up at the foot of the Flagstaff, like a piece of artillery, and to fire it twice a year — once on October the twelfth, the anniversary of the Battle of the Cowshed, and once on Midsummer Day, the anniversary of the Rebellion.
vi: They argued for a long time about what to name the victory. Finally, they decided to call it the Cow Shed Campaign because the ambush took place in a cow shed. They found Mr. Jones's gun in the mud, and there were still bullets available in the camp. The gun was placed at the foot of the flagpole, as if it were a cannon in other places, and they would fire it twice a year, once on the summer solstice to celebrate the Uprising, and again on the twentieth of October to celebrate the Victory. George Orwell Animal Farm
tr: The name of the war was discussed at length. In the end, it was decided to call it the "Battle of the Cowshed"; the ambushing animals had launched their attack from there. Mr. Jones's gun was found in the mud. They knew there were a few boxes of cartridges in the farmhouse. It was decided that the gun, like a cannon, would be placed at the base of the flagpole and that a ceremonial shot would be fired twice a year, once on October 12th, the anniversary of the Battle of the Cowshed, and the other on Midsummer Day, the anniversary of the Rebellion.
es: There was much discussion about the name that should be given to the battle. In the end, it was called the "Battle of the Cow Shed," as it was there where the ambush took place. Mr. Jones's shotgun was found in the mud, and it was known that there were shells in the house. It was decided to place the shotgun at the foot of the flagpole, as if it were a piece of artillery, and to fire it twice a year; once on October fourth, the anniversary of the "Battle of the Cow Shed," and the other on Midsummer Day, the anniversary of the Rebellion.

en: As winter drew on, Mollie became more and more troublesome. She was late for work every morning and excused herself by saying that she had overslept, and she complained of mysterious pains, although her appetite was excellent. On every kind of pretext she would run away from work and go to the drinking pool, where she would stand foolishly gazing at her own reflection in the water. But there were also rumours of something more serious. One day, as Mollie strolled blithely into the yard, flirting her long tail and chewing at a stalk of hay, Clover took her aside.
vi: The closer it got to winter, the more irritable Mollie became. Every morning she was late for work, claiming she overslept; in addition, she complained of strange illnesses, although she ate like a horse. She often found ways to shirk work and run to the pond, standing there gazing at her reflection. But according to rumors, she had much more serious flaws. One day, as she was strolling in the yard, casually wagging her long tail and chewing a mouthful of grass, Mrs. Fat pulled her aside and said:
tr: As winter approached, Mollie was acting even stranger. Every morning she came to work late, apologizing by saying she had overslept, and despite having a good appetite, she complained of some inexplicable pains. She would make up an excuse to avoid work, go to the trough, and watch her reflection in the water foolishly. But there were also more serious rumors circulating around. One day, when Mollie entered the yard cheerfully with a straw in her mouth, wagging her tail, Clover pulled her aside.
es: As winter approached, Mollie became more and more troublesome. She arrived late to work in the mornings with the excuse that she had overslept, complaining of mysterious ailments, even though her appetite was excellent. With any excuse, she would escape from work to go to the drinking pool, where she would stand staring at her reflection in the water like a fool. But there were also rumors of something more serious. One day, as Mollie was cheerfully entering the yard, swishing her long tail and chewing on a stalk of hay, Clover called her aside.

en: “Mollie,” she said, “I have something very serious to say to you. This morning I saw you looking over the hedge that divides Animal Farm from Foxwood. One of Mr. Pilkington’s men was standing on the other side of the hedge. And — I was a long way away, but I am almost certain I saw this — he was talking to you and you were allowing him to stroke your nose. What does that mean, Mollie?”
vi: "Mollie, I have a few things to say to you. This morning I saw you standing by the fence between Animal Farm and Foxwood Farm. On the other side of the fence was someone from Pilkington's farm. Even though I was very far away, I am certain that he was talking to you, I saw it clearly, and you let him stroke your cheeks. Mollie, what is the meaning of this?"
tr: "Look, Mollie," he said, "I have something very serious to tell you. This morning, I saw you looking over the fence that separates Animal Farm from Foxwood Farm. On the other side of the fence, there was one of Mr. Pilkington's men. Although I was very far away, I am almost certain that I saw him talking to you and you didn't object to him stroking your nose. What does this mean, Mollie?"
es: —Mollie —he said to her—, I have something very serious to tell you. This morning I saw you looking over the hedge that separates "Animal Farm" from Foxwood. One of Mr. Pilkington's men was on the other side of the hedge. And I was at a certain distance, but I am almost sure I saw you: he was talking to you and you were allowing him to pet you. What does that mean, Mollie?

en: “He didn’t! I wasn’t! It isn’t true!” cried Mollie, beginning to prance about and paw the ground.
vi: "He didn't clap!" "You weren't standing there! That didn't happen!" - Mollie screamed, her legs jumping up and pounding loudly on the ground.
tr: "No! He didn't stroke my nose or anything!" shouted Mollie. "I didn't do such a thing!" "Lies!" She was stamping her feet and scratching the ground with them.
es: —He did nothing! I wasn't there! It's not true! —shouted Mollie, prancing and kicking the ground.

en: “Mollie! Look me in the face. Do you give me your word of honour that that man was not stroking your nose?”
vi: "Mollie, look straight into my eyes! Do you dare swear to me that guy has never patted your cheek?"
tr: "Mollie! Look at my face. Do you swear on your honor that man didn't stroke your nose?"
es: —Mollie! Look me in the face. Can you give me your word of honor that that man was not petting your snout?

en: “It isn’t true!” repeated Mollie, but she could not look Clover in the face, and the next moment she took to her heels and galloped away into the field.

tr: Mollie, "Lies! Nothing like that happened!" she repeated, but she avoided Clover's eyes and galloped away towards the field.
es: —It's not true! —repeated Mollie, but she couldn't look Clover in the face, and instantly she ran away, galloping towards the field.

en: A thought struck Clover. Without saying anything to the others, she went to Mollie’s stall and turned over the straw with her hoof. Hidden under the straw was a little pile of lump sugar and several bunches of ribbon of different colours.
vi: A thought suddenly flashed in Mrs. Fat's mind. Without telling any of the others, she slowly approached Mollie's stall and used her hoof to turn over the pile of straw in the stall. Under the pile of straw was a lump of sugar and several colorful ribbons.

es: A thought occurred to Clover. Without saying anything to anyone, she went to Mollie's stall and stirred the straw with her hoof. Hidden under the straw, there was a small pile of sugar lumps and several strips of ribbons of different colors.

en: Three days later Mollie disappeared. For some weeks nothing was known of her whereabouts, then the pigeons reported that they had seen her on the other side of Willingdon. She was between the shafts of a smart dogcart painted red and black, which was standing outside a public-house. A fat red-faced man in check breeches and gaiters, who looked like a publican, was stroking her nose and feeding her with sugar. Her coat was newly clipped and she wore a scarlet ribbon round her forelock. She appeared to be enjoying herself, so the pigeons said. None of the animals ever mentioned Mollie again.
vi: Three days later, Mollie disappeared. Weeks went by without any news, but then the pigeons reported that they had seen Mollie outside Willingdon. She was pulling a small cart, splendidly painted in black and red, resting near a tavern. A stout man with a red face, wearing checkered trousers and gaiters, who seemed to be the tavern owner, was petting her and feeding her a piece of sugar. Her mane had been carefully trimmed and groomed, with a bright red ribbon tied to the tuft on her forehead. According to the pigeons, she looked satisfied. From then on, no one mentioned her again.
tr: Three days later, Mollie disappeared. For a long time, no information could be obtained about where she was, until the pigeons reported that they had seen her in Willingdon. She was harnessed to a small, stylish, red-and-black cart standing in front of a tavern. A fat, rosy-cheeked man, who looked like a tavern keeper, wearing checkered pants and gaiters, was stroking Mollie's nose and feeding her sugar. A red ribbon was tied to the forelock of Mollie, whose coat had been freshly clipped. According to the pigeons, she seemed to be in good spirits. From that day on, the animals never mentioned Mollie's name again.
es: Three days later, Mollie disappeared. For several weeks, nothing was known about her whereabouts; then the pigeons reported that they had seen her on the other side of Willingdon. She was harnessed between the shafts of a smart red and black painted carriage, which was standing outside a tavern. A fat man, with a red face, wearing checkered breeches and gaiters, who looked like a publican, was stroking her nose and feeding her sugar. Mollie's coat was freshly clipped, and she wore a scarlet ribbon in her mane. “She appeared to be enjoying herself,” said the pigeons. None of the animals ever mentioned Mollie again.

en: In January there came bitterly hard weather. The earth was like iron, and nothing could be done in the fields. Many meetings were held in the big barn, and the pigs occupied themselves with planning out the work of the coming season. It had come to be accepted that the pigs, who were manifestly cleverer than the other animals, should decide all questions of farm policy, though their decisions had to be ratified by a majority vote. This arrangement would have worked well enough if it had not been for the disputes between Snowball and Napoleon. These two disagreed at every point where disagreement was possible. If one of them suggested sowing a bigger acreage with barley, the other was certain to demand a bigger acreage of oats, and if one of them said that such and such a field was just right for cabbages, the other would declare that it was useless for anything except roots. Each had his own following, and there were some violent debates. At the Meetings Snowball often won over the majority by his brilliant speeches, but Napoleon was better at canvassing support for himself in between times. He was especially successful with the sheep. Of late the sheep had taken to bleating “Four legs good, two legs bad” both in and out of season, and they often interrupted the Meeting with this. It was noticed that they were especially liable to break into “Four legs good, two legs bad” at crucial moments in Snowball’s speeches. Snowball had made a close study of some back numbers of the ‘Farmer and Stockbreeder’ which he had found in the farmhouse, and was full of plans for innovations and improvements. He talked learnedly about field drains, silage, and basic slag, and had worked out a complicated scheme for all the animals to drop their dung directly in the fields, at a different spot every day, to save the labour of cartage. Napoleon produced no schemes of his own, but said quietly that Snowball’s would come to nothing, and seemed to be biding his time. But of all their controversies, none was so bitter as the one that took place over the windmill.
vi: As January arrived, the weather became extremely harsh. The ground was as hard as rock, making it impossible to do any work. Meetings were moved to the large barn, and the pigs focused on planning for the next season. They agreed that since the pigs were the smartest, they would be responsible for the overall direction of the farm, but their decisions had to be approved by an absolute majority. Everything would have been perfect if Snowball and Napoleon didn't constantly oppose each other. The two disagreed on every issue whenever they had the chance. If one said more barley should be sown, the other would insist on sowing more oats; if one said a certain field was suitable for cabbages, the other would argue that only turnips could be grown there. Each had a number of supporters, so the debates were often very intense. Thanks to his eloquence, Snowball usually won the majority in the Meetings, while outside, the majority supported Napoleon. The most loyal to Napoleon were the sheep. Recently, the sheep often chanted "Four legs good, two legs bad" for any reason or no reason at all, frequently interrupting the Meetings. Especially during the most important parts of Snowball's speeches, the sheep would invariably shout "Four legs good, two legs bad". Snowball had studied the "Agriculture and Livestock" magazine found in the main house thoroughly, and his head was full of plans for reforming and modernizing production. He talked about drainage systems for the fields, silage pits, and phosphate fertilizers for the entire farm; he even drafted a sanitation schedule so that each animal would "go" in a different place each time to save on transportation later. Napoleon, on the other hand, didn't draft anything but whispered to the others that Snowball was just talking nonsense and seemed to be waiting for the right moment to act. But the fiercest dispute between the two was over the construction of the windmill.

Meeting after meeting was being held in the large barn, and the pigs were trying to plan the work for the coming season. The authority to make decisions on all matters related to farm politics was given to the pigs, who were clearly more intelligent than the other animals; although their decisions had to be approved by a majority vote. If it weren't for the constant quarrels between Snowball and Napoleon, who clashed on almost every issue, this system would have worked quite well. If one proposed to expand the area planted with barley, the other would argue that the area planted with oats should be expanded; if one said a field was suitable for growing cabbages, the other would claim that nothing but root crops could be grown there. Both had their supporters; sometimes fierce arguments would break out. With his brilliant speeches, Snowball often managed to win the majority of votes at meetings; but Napoleon was no less skilled at garnering support through behind-the-scenes work. He was particularly good at influencing the sheep. The sheep, who had recently developed the habit of bleating "Four legs good, two legs bad!" at every opportunity, were frequently disrupting the meetings. It was particularly noticeable that they would start bleating "Four legs good, two legs bad!" at the most crucial points of Snowball's speeches. Snowball had read and studied old issues of a magazine called Farmer and Stockbreeder, which he found in the farmhouse, and had come up with a lot of plans for the renovation and improvement of the farm. He gave speeches demonstrating how well he knew topics such as opening water channels in the fields, preserving fodder in silos, and how to make use of manure. He had developed a complex plan for all the animals to defecate directly in the fields, in a different spot each day; this way, they would also save the labor and time spent transporting manure to the fields by cart. Napoleon, on the other hand, did not come up with a single original idea, quietly spreading the notion that Snowball's plans were useless, as if he were waiting for the right moment. But the fiercest argument between them would break out over the windmill.
