en: In the long pasture, not far from the farm buildings, there was a small knoll which was the highest point on the farm. After surveying the ground, Snowball declared that this was just the place for a windmill, which could be made to operate a dynamo and supply the farm with electrical power. This would light the stalls and warm them in winter, and would also run a circular saw, a chaff-cutter, a mangel-slicer, and an electric milking machine. The animals had never heard of anything of this kind before (for the farm was an old-fashioned one and had only the most primitive machinery), and they listened in astonishment while Snowball conjured up pictures of fantastic machines which would do their work for them while they grazed at their ease in the fields or improved their minds with reading and conversation.
vi: On the grass field, not far from the rows of houses of the farm, there was a small mound, which was also the highest point in the farm. After surveying, Snowball declared that this was the best area to build a windmill, and they would install a generator on it to supply electricity to the entire farm. The barns would then have electric lights, and in winter, there would be heaters, not to mention using electricity to run the saw, the grass cutter, the red beet slicer, and the milking machine. The animals had never heard of such things before (this farm was quite backward, only having the simplest machines), and they listened in amazement as Snowball enthusiastically talked about the wonderful machines that would do the work for them while they could leisurely graze in the fields or sit reading books and debating to gradually improve their minds.
tr: There was a small hill in the meadow that stretched out just beyond the farm buildings. This was the highest point of the farm. After carefully examining the ground, Snowball declared that this was the most suitable place for a windmill. The windmill could operate a dynamo and provide electrical power to the entire farm. Thus, the barns could be illuminated and heated in winter; tools such as a circular saw, hay and straw cutter, beet slicer, and electric milking machine could be used. The animals had never heard of such a thing before (Beilik Farm, being an ancient farm, only had the most primitive tools); they listened to Snowball in astonishment as he conjured up those fantastical devices before their eyes. According to Snowball's descriptions, these incredible devices would handle all the farm's work, and they would lounge in the fields, enjoying themselves, reading books, and engaging in conversations to improve themselves.
es: In the long prairie, near the buildings, there was a small hill that was the highest point of the farm. After studying the terrain, Snowball declared that this was the ideal place for a windmill, which could be used to run a dynamo and supply electricity to the farm. This would provide light for the animals' stalls and heat them in winter, and it would also run a circular saw, a thresher, a cutter, an electric milker, etc. The animals had never heard of such things (because the farm was old-fashioned and had the most primitive machinery), and they listened in astonishment to Snowball as he described to them pictures of fantastic machinery that would work for them, while they grazed peacefully in the fields or improved their minds through reading and conversation.

en: Within a few weeks Snowball’s plans for the windmill were fully worked out. The mechanical details came mostly from three books which had belonged to Mr. Jones —‘One Thousand Useful Things to Do About the House’, ‘Every Man His Own Bricklayer’, and ‘Electricity for Beginners’. Snowball used as his study a shed which had once been used for incubators and had a smooth wooden floor, suitable for drawing on. He was closeted there for hours at a time. With his books held open by a stone, and with a piece of chalk gripped between the knuckles of his trotter, he would move rapidly to and fro, drawing in line after line and uttering little whimpers of excitement. Gradually the plans grew into a complicated mass of cranks and cog-wheels, covering more than half the floor, which the other animals found completely unintelligible but very impressive. All of them came to look at Snowball’s drawings at least once a day. Even the hens and ducks came, and were at pains not to tread on the chalk marks. Only Napoleon held aloof. He had declared himself against the windmill from the start. One day, however, he arrived unexpectedly to examine the plans. He walked heavily round the shed, looked closely at every detail of the plans and snuffed at them once or twice, then stood for a little while contemplating them out of the corner of his eye; then suddenly he lifted his leg, urinated over the plans, and walked out without uttering a word.
vi: Just a few weeks later, Tuyet Tron had completed the technical documents for the windmill project. The detailed mechanical drawings were drafted based on three of Mr. Jones's books: "A Thousand Useful Household Items," "Do-It-Yourself Masonry," and "What a Beginner Electrician Needs to Know."Tuyet Tron used the shed, which was previously an incubation area, as an office because it had a flat wooden floor that was very suitable for technical drawing. Tuyet Tron sat in there for hours on end. It placed a stone on the necessary book page, held a piece of chalk with one foot; it hopped back and forth, drawing as it hopped, sometimes squealing softly in delight. Gradually, the drawings, consisting of numerous interlocking shafts and gears, covered nearly half of the shed, and although the other animals didn't understand them, they were extremely impressed. Every day, the animals came to look at Tuyet Tron's drawings at least once. Even the chickens and ducks came, but they stood at a distance to avoid stepping on the chalk drawings. Only Napoleon didn't care at all. He opposed it from the beginning. Nevertheless, one day he came to inspect the project without informing any of the animals beforehand. He walked around the shed, then went in to scrutinize the drawings, sniffing here and there, then lifted his leg and urinated on them, after which he calmly walked out without saying a word.
tr: Snowball's plans for the windmill were finalized in a few weeks. A large portion of the mechanical details were obtained from Mr. Jones's three books: A Thousand and One Tips for Your Home, Do It Yourself Wall Building, and Electricity in Ten Lessons. Snowball was using the shed, where the incubators once stood and which had a smooth wooden floor suitable for drawing, as his study room. Sometimes he would lock himself in the shed for hours. He placed weights on the pages of the books he laid on the ground, held a piece of chalk between the hooves of his front foot, and as he quickly made the drawings, he would get so excited that he was out of breath, making short, gasping sounds from his throat. Snowball's drawings gradually turned into a complex heap of levers and gears, covering more than half of the shed. The other animals did not understand any of this, but they found it very impressive. They came to look at Snowball's drawings at least once a day. The chickens and ducks also came, struggling not to step on the chalk-drawn lines. Only Napoleon, who had declared his opposition to the windmill from the very beginning, stayed away from there. But he couldn't resist; one day, out of the blue, he came to see the drawings. He slowly wandered inside the shed, examined every detail of the drawings at length, sniffed and prodded them several times, stood there for a while watching out of the corner of his eye, then suddenly lifted his leg and urinated on the drawings, and left without saying a single word.
es: In a few weeks, Snowball's plans for the windmill were completed. The technical details came mainly from three books that had belonged to Mr. Jones: "A Thousand Useful Things to Do Around the House," "Every Man His Own Bricklayer," and "Electricity for Beginners." As a study, Snowball used a shed that had once been used for incubators and had a smooth wooden floor, suitable for drawing. He would lock himself in there for hours on end. He kept his books open with a stone and, wielding a piece of chalk, moved quickly from side to side, drawing line after line and uttering small squeals of enthusiasm. Gradually, his plans transformed into a complicated mass of cranks and gears that covered more than half of the floor, which the other animals found completely indecipherable but very impressive. Everyone went to look at Snowball's plans at least once a day. Even the hens and ducks did so and took great care not to step on the chalk marks. Only Napoleon kept his distance. He had declared himself against the windmill from the beginning. One day, however, he unexpectedly came with the purpose of examining the plans. He walked heavily around, carefully observed every detail, and even sniffed once or twice; then he stood for a while, glancing at them sideways; then, suddenly, he lifted his leg, urinated on the plans, and walked away without saying a word.

en: The whole farm was deeply divided on the subject of the windmill. Snowball did not deny that to build it would be a difficult business. Stone would have to be carried and built up into walls, then the sails would have to be made and after that there would be need for dynamos and cables. (How these were to be procured, Snowball did not say.) But he maintained that it could all be done in a year. And thereafter, he declared, so much labour would be saved that the animals would only need to work three days a week. Napoleon, on the other hand, argued that the great need of the moment was to increase food production, and that if they wasted time on the windmill they would all starve to death. The animals formed themselves into two factions under the slogan, “Vote for Snowball and the three-day week” and “Vote for Napoleon and the full manger.” Benjamin was the only animal who did not side with either faction. He refused to believe either that food would become more plentiful or that the windmill would save work. Windmill or no windmill, he said, life would go on as it had always gone on — that is, badly.
vi: Due to the construction of the windmill, the farm was divided into two opposing factions. Snowball did not hide the fact that building the windmill would require a great sacrifice. They would have to quarry and transport stone to the site, then build, and only after that install the blades, motor, and electrical wiring (how to obtain those things, Snowball did not say). But he still asserted that the project could be completed within a year. After that, he declared, the workload would decrease significantly, and they would only have to work three days a week. On the other hand, Napoleon argued that the most important task at present was food production, and if they wasted time on building the windmill, they would starve. The animals divided into two factions; one faction adopted the slogan: "Support Snowball and three days of work a week"; the other adopted the slogan: "Support Napoleon and a full belly." Only Benjamin did not join any faction. He did not believe that food would become abundant, nor did he believe that the windmill would help reduce manual labor. With or without the windmill, it would be the same; they had lived as they did and would continue to live that way, meaning they would still suffer.
tr: The windmill issue had led to a deep division on the farm. Snowball did not deny that building the windmill would be very difficult. Stones would have to be carried from the quarry, walls built, the windmill's blades made, and then dynamos and cables would need to be found. (Snowball never mentioned how all these tasks would be accomplished) He merely claimed that all the work would be completed within a year. According to him, once the windmill was completed, work would become so easy that the animals would only need to work three days a week. In contrast, Napoleon argued that their greatest need was to increase food production and that if time was wasted on the windmill, everyone would die of starvation. The animals had split into two factions under the slogans "Vote for Snowball and work three days a week!" and "Vote for Napoleon and never go hungry!" The only animal who remained outside the factions was Benjamin. He believed neither in the coming of abundance nor that the windmill would make things easier. "Whether there is a windmill or not, nothing will change in our miserable lives," he said.
es: The entire farm was very divided on the matter of the windmill. Snowball did not deny that the construction would mean difficult work. They would have to extract stones from the quarry and with them build walls, then construct the blades, and after all that, they would need dynamos and cables (how they would obtain those things, Snowball did not say). But he maintained that everything could be done in a year. And henceforth, he declared, so much work would be saved that the animals would only have three working days per week. Napoleon, on the other hand, maintained that the great need of the moment was to increase food production, and that if they wasted time on the windmill, they would all starve to death. The animals grouped into two factions under the slogans: "Vote for Snowball and the three-day week" and "Vote for Napoleon and the full manger." Benjamin was the only animal who did not enlist in either of the two sides. He refused to believe that there would be more abundance of food or that the windmill would save work. "With windmill or without windmill," he said, "life will go on as it always has, that is, a disaster."

en: Apart from the disputes over the windmill, there was the question of the defence of the farm. It was fully realised that though the human beings had been defeated in the Battle of the Cowshed they might make another and more determined attempt to recapture the farm and reinstate Mr. Jones. They had all the more reason for doing so because the news of their defeat had spread across the countryside and made the animals on the neighbouring farms more restive than ever. As usual, Snowball and Napoleon were in disagreement. According to Napoleon, what the animals must do was to procure firearms and train themselves in the use of them. According to Snowball, they must send out more and more pigeons and stir up rebellion among the animals on the other farms. The one argued that if they could not defend themselves they were bound to be conquered, the other argued that if rebellions happened everywhere they would have no need to defend themselves. The animals listened first to Napoleon, then to Snowball, and could not make up their minds which was right; indeed, they always found themselves in agreement with the one who was speaking at the moment.
vi: Besides the windmill, they also argued about defense. Everyone understood that although humans were defeated in the Battle of the Cowshed, they would certainly fight another battle, this one fiercer, to reclaim the farm for Mr. Jones. People were bound to do so because rumors of the humans' great defeat had spread throughout the countryside, and the animals in other farms had now become more rebellious than ever. As always, Snowball and Napoleon could not find common ground. According to Napoleon, the first thing to do was to purchase and learn to use firearms. According to Snowball, the urgent task now was to send flocks of pigeons to other farms to incite rebellions there. One believed that if they could not defend themselves, they would certainly be conquered by humans, while the other argued that if rebellions broke out everywhere, there would be no need for defense. The animals listened to Napoleon and then to Snowball, but could not decide who was right; in fact, whoever was speaking at the moment seemed right to them, as they had no firm opinions of their own.
tr: While the windmill debates continued, there was also the issue of defending the farm. Despite having been defeated in the Battle of the Cowshed, it was now understood by all the animals that the humans might make a second, more determined attempt to recapture the farm and return it to Mr. Jones. The news of their defeat had spread to all the villages, causing the animals on neighboring farms to become even more rebellious; thus, the likelihood of the humans launching another attack had increased. Snowball and Napoleon, as with everything else, could not agree on this matter either. According to Napoleon, the animals needed to find firearms from somewhere and learn how to use them. Snowball, on the other hand, believed that they should send more pigeons to the other farms and incite the animals to rebel. One argued that if they couldn't defend themselves, they would inevitably be defeated in the end; the other said that if uprisings broke out everywhere, there would be no need to defend themselves. The animals listened to Napoleon and Snowball in turn, but they couldn't decide who was right. More precisely, they agreed with whoever was speaking at the time.
es: Apart from the discussions regarding the windmill, there was the issue of the farm's defense. It was perfectly understood that although the humans had been defeated in the "Battle of the Cowshed," they might make another attempt, more determined than the previous one, to reclaim the farm and restore Mr. Jones. They had even greater reasons to do so, as the news of the defeat spread around and had made the animals more discontented than ever. As usual, Snowball and Napoleon were in disagreement. According to Napoleon, what the animals should do was procure firearms and train themselves in their use. Snowball believed they should send more and more pigeons and incite rebellion among the animals on the other farms. One argued that if they couldn't defend themselves, they were destined to be conquered; the other argued that if there were rebellions everywhere, they wouldn't need to defend themselves. The animals listened first to Napoleon, then to Snowball, and couldn't decide who was right; to be honest, they always agreed with whoever was speaking to them at the moment.

en: At last the day came when Snowball’s plans were completed. At the Meeting on the following Sunday the question of whether or not to begin work on the windmill was to be put to the vote. When the animals had assembled in the big barn, Snowball stood up and, though occasionally interrupted by bleating from the sheep, set forth his reasons for advocating the building of the windmill. Then Napoleon stood up to reply. He said very quietly that the windmill was nonsense and that he advised nobody to vote for it, and promptly sat down again; he had spoken for barely thirty seconds, and seemed almost indifferent as to the effect he produced. At this Snowball sprang to his feet, and shouting down the sheep, who had begun bleating again, broke into a passionate appeal in favour of the windmill. Until now the animals had been about equally divided in their sympathies, but in a moment Snowball’s eloquence had carried them away. In glowing sentences he painted a picture of Animal Farm as it might be when sordid labour was lifted from the animals’ backs. His imagination had now run far beyond chaff-cutters and turnip-slicers. Electricity, he said, could operate threshing machines, ploughs, harrows, rollers, and reapers and binders, besides supplying every stall with its own electric light, hot and cold water, and an electric heater. By the time he had finished speaking, there was no doubt as to which way the vote would go. But just at this moment Napoleon stood up and, casting a peculiar sidelong look at Snowball, uttered a high-pitched whimper of a kind no one had ever heard him utter before.
vi: Finally, Snowball completed all the drawings for his project. In the meeting on Sunday, the issue of building the windmill was put to a vote. All the animals gathered in the large barn, Snowball spoke first and although he was occasionally interrupted by the sheep, he convincingly presented the benefits of the windmill. Then it was Napoleon's turn. He calmly declared that the windmill was nonsense and advised everyone not to support the project; he spoke for only about thirty seconds and then sat down calmly, seemingly indifferent to the effect he had on the audience. Snowball stood up on his hind legs and immediately delivered a passionate speech to persuade the others to vote for the construction of the windmill, speaking so loudly that he drowned out the sheep. Previously, the farm was divided into two equal factions, but this time Snowball had convinced the majority to support him. He spoke about the future of Animal Farm, a very bright future where manual labor would no longer weigh heavily on their backs. His imagination went beyond straw cutters and beet slicers. Electricity, he said, could power threshers, plows, harrows, rollers; it could also provide lighting, hot water, cold water, and heating for all the stalls. The result of the vote was clear even before Snowball finished his speech. But just at that moment, Napoleon stood up, glanced sharply at Snowball, and let out a high-pitched squeal like a whistle, a sound none of them had ever heard before.
tr: In the end, Snowball's plans came true. In the Meeting to be held next Sunday, the proposal to start the construction of the windmill would be put to a vote. When the animals gathered in the big barn, Snowball stood up and, despite his speech being interrupted by the bleating of the sheep, he listed the reasons why the windmill should be built. Then, Napoleon stood up to respond. In a very calm voice, he said that the windmill was nothing but nonsense, that he could not advise anyone to vote for the windmill, and immediately sat down. His speech had not even lasted half a minute; he seemed unaware of the impact of his words. Upon this, Snowball jumped up, silencing the sheep who had started bleating again, and delivered a passionate speech about the benefits of the windmill. Until that moment, the number of animals in favor of the windmill and those against it seemed roughly equal, but Snowball's eloquence quickly broke the tie. With brilliant words, Snowball painted a picture of an Animal Farm where the animals would be freed from working like slaves, and his imagination now extended far beyond chaff cutters and beet slicers. He said that threshing machines, plows, harrows, rollers, reapers, and binders would all be powered by electricity, and that every barn would have its own light, hot and cold water, and its own electric heater. When he finished his speech, there was no doubt left about where the votes would go. But just at that moment, Napoleon stood up, glanced sideways at Snowball, and let out a high-pitched scream that no one had ever heard before.
es: Finally, the day arrived when Snowball completed his plans. At the next Sunday Meeting, it would be put to a vote whether or not to start building the windmill. When the animals were gathered in the main barn, Snowball stood up and, although he was occasionally interrupted by the sheep's bleating, he laid out his reasons for defending the construction of the windmill. Then Napoleon stood up to respond. He calmly said that the windmill was nonsense and that he advised no one to vote for it. And he sat down immediately; he had spoken for barely thirty seconds, and he seemed indifferent to the effect he had produced. Next, Snowball jumped to his feet, and shouting to be heard despite the sheep, who had started bleating again, he launched into a passionate argument in favor of the windmill. Until then, the animals were more or less equally divided in their sympathies, but in an instant, Snowball's eloquence had convinced them. With fiery phrases, he painted a picture of what "Animal Farm" could be like when the vile labor was lifted from the animals' backs. His imagination had gone far beyond threshers and reapers. "Electricity," he said, "could power the threshers, plows, harrows, rollers, reapers, and binders, as well as provide each stall with its own electric light, cold and hot water, and an electric heater." When he finished speaking, there was no doubt about the outcome of the vote. But immediately Napoleon stood up and, casting a strange sidelong glance at Snowball, let out a high-pitched, shrill squeal that had never been heard from him before.

en: At this there was a terrible baying sound outside, and nine enormous dogs wearing brass-studded collars came bounding into the barn. They dashed straight for Snowball, who only sprang from his place just in time to escape their snapping jaws. In a moment he was out of the door and they were after him. Too amazed and frightened to speak, all the animals crowded through the door to watch the chase. Snowball was racing across the long pasture that led to the road. He was running as only a pig can run, but the dogs were close on his heels. Suddenly he slipped and it seemed certain that they had him. Then he was up again, running faster than ever, then the dogs were gaining on him again. One of them all but closed his jaws on Snowball’s tail, but Snowball whisked it free just in time. Then he put on an extra spurt and, with a few inches to spare, slipped through a hole in the hedge and was seen no more.
vi: There was a loud barking outside, then a pack of nine extremely large dogs with brass collars charged into the barn. They rushed straight at Snowball, but luckily he dodged their snapping jaws. Snowball hurriedly ran outside with the pack of dogs chasing after him. The remaining animals were extremely surprised and frightened, and they all rushed to the door to watch the chase. Snowball ran across the meadow towards the main road. He ran for his life while the pack of dogs kept right on his heels. Suddenly, he slipped, and it seemed like the dogs would catch him any moment. But he managed to get back up, this time running even faster with the dogs still in close pursuit. It seemed as if one of the dogs had caught Snowball's tail, but he managed to flick it to the side just in time. He sped up again, this time gaining some distance from the dogs, and then he squeezed through a hole in the fence. None of the dogs could see Snowball anymore.
tr: At that moment, terrifying barks were heard from outside, and soon nine large dogs with spiked collars burst in like a spear. They lunged straight at Snowball. If Snowball hadn't leaped out of the way just in time, he would have been devoured by the ferociously attacking dogs. He immediately threw himself outside, with the dogs in pursuit. The animals, struck dumb with astonishment and fear, crowded at the door and began to watch the chase. Snowball was running as fast as a pig could run, trying to cross the meadow and reach the main road. But the dogs were right on his heels. Suddenly, he slipped and fell; just when everyone thought he was surely caught, he got back up and started running even faster. The dogs were like a storm, they were about to catch their prey. One of them was just about to grab his tail, but Snowball pulled it away just in time. With the dogs nearly an inch away from him, he made one last effort and dashed forward, escaping through one of the holes in the fence. Snowball was never seen again.
es: Immediately afterwards, terrible barking was heard coming from outside, and nine enormous dogs wearing collars studded with nails burst into the barn. And they went straight for Snowball, who jumped from his spot just in time to dodge their ferocious fangs. In an instant, he was on the other side of the door with the dogs after him. Too astonished and scared to say anything, all the animals crowded at the door to watch the chase. Snowball was running at full speed across the long meadow that led to the road. He ran as only a pig can, but the dogs were hot on his heels. Suddenly, he slipped and seemed to be easy prey for the dogs, but as soon as he regained his balance, he kept running faster than ever, though the hounds were gaining on him again. One of them was about to close its jaws on Snowball's tail, but he managed to dodge the bite just in time. And with a supreme effort, he managed to slip through a hole in the hedge, thus putting himself out of danger.

en: Silent and terrified, the animals crept back into the barn. In a moment the dogs came bounding back. At first no one had been able to imagine where these creatures came from, but the problem was soon solved: they were the puppies whom Napoleon had taken away from their mothers and reared privately. Though not yet full-grown, they were huge dogs, and as fierce-looking as wolves. They kept close to Napoleon. It was noticed that they wagged their tails to him in the same way as the other dogs had been used to do to Mr. Jones.
vi: Extremely frightened, the animals silently turned back to the barn. The hunting dogs also returned shortly after. At first, each one wondered: where did those dogs come from? But then it was no longer a secret: these dogs had been taken by Napoleon when they were young and raised separately. Though not fully grown, they looked big and fierce like wolves. They stood right next to Napoleon. They also wagged their tails at Napoleon just like the others used to do for Mr. Jones.
tr: The animals, silent and cowed, returned to the barn. Soon after, the dogs came running. At first, no one could understand where these monsters had come from, but the truth soon emerged. These were the pups that Napoleon had separated from their mothers and specially trained. Although they were not fully grown, they were quite large; they looked as wild as wolves. They never left Napoleon's side. Just as the other dogs had fawned over Mr. Jones, it did not escape anyone's notice that they wagged their tails at Napoleon.
es: Silent and terrified, the animals stealthily returned to the barn. The dogs also returned, leaping about. At first, no one could imagine where those beasts had come from, but the problem was quickly clarified; they were the puppies that Napoleon had taken from their mothers and raised in seclusion. Although they were not yet fully grown, they were immense dogs, fierce as wolves. They never strayed far from Napoleon. And it was observed that they wagged their tails before him as the other dogs used to do with Mr. Jones.

en: Napoleon, with the dogs following him, now mounted on to the raised portion of the floor where Major had previously stood to deliver his speech. He announced that from now on the Sunday-morning Meetings would come to an end. They were unnecessary, he said, and wasted time. In future all questions relating to the working of the farm would be settled by a special committee of pigs, presided over by himself. These would meet in private and afterwards communicate their decisions to the others. The animals would still assemble on Sunday mornings to salute the flag, sing ‘Beasts of England’, and receive their orders for the week; but there would be no more debates.
vi: Napoleon, escorted by the dogs, stepped onto the platform where the Leader used to speak. He declared that from now on, the weekly Sunday Meetings would be abolished. He said that those Meetings were pointless and only a waste of time. From now on, matters related to the farm's work would be resolved by a committee of pigs with Napoleon as the chairman. These would be closed Meetings, and the resolutions would be announced to the entire farm afterward. The animals would still gather on Sunday mornings to salute the flag, sing "Beasts of England," and receive their work assignments for the following week, but there would be no more discussions.
tr: Napoleon, with his dogs behind him, climbed to the elevation where once the Great Leader had given speeches and announced that the Sunday morning meetings would be discontinued: These unnecessary meetings were nothing but a waste of time. Henceforth, all issues regarding the operation of the farm would be resolved by a special committee of pigs, presided over by himself. The committee would discuss the issues in closed sessions and later communicate the decisions to the other animals. The animals would still gather on Sunday mornings to salute the flag, sing the "Beasts of England" song, and receive weekly orders, but debates would no longer be permitted.
es: Napoleon, with the dogs behind him, climbed onto the platform that Major had occupied when he delivered his historic speech. He announced that from that moment on, the Sunday morning meetings were over. They were unnecessary, he said, and wasted time. In the future, all matters related to the governance of the farm would be resolved by a special committee of pigs, presided over by him. They would meet in council and then communicate their decisions to the others. The animals would gather on Sunday mornings to salute the flag, sing "Beasts of England," and receive their orders for the week; but there would be no more debates.

en: In spite of the shock that Snowball’s expulsion had given them, the animals were dismayed by this announcement. Several of them would have protested if they could have found the right arguments. Even Boxer was vaguely troubled. He set his ears back, shook his forelock several times, and tried hard to marshal his thoughts; but in the end he could not think of anything to say. Some of the pigs themselves, however, were more articulate. Four young porkers in the front row uttered shrill squeals of disapproval, and all four of them sprang to their feet and began speaking at once. But suddenly the dogs sitting round Napoleon let out deep, menacing growls, and the pigs fell silent and sat down again. Then the sheep broke out into a tremendous bleating of “Four legs good, two legs bad!” which went on for nearly a quarter of an hour and put an end to any chance of discussion.
vi: Although shocked by Tuyet Tron’s expulsion, the decision to cancel the discussions left everyone completely disappointed. Some of them would certainly protest if they could find a plausible argument. Even Vo Si felt uneasy. He pricked up his ears, shook his mane a few times, thoughts jumping around, and despite trying very hard, he still didn't know what to say. But the pigs were more articulate. The four porkers in the front row shouted in protest, then all four jumped up and spoke in unison. But the dogs surrounding Napoleon barked loudly, and those pigs had to shut their mouths and quietly return to their places. Then the sheep started their chant of "Four legs good, two legs bad," which lasted about fifteen minutes, ending all discussions.
tr: The animals, who had not yet recovered from the shock of Snowball's expulsion, fell into even deeper despair at this explanation. Some of them would have protested if they could find a proper reason. Even Boxer was uneasy. He laid his ears back, shook his mane, and tried to gather his thoughts; but he couldn't find anything to say. Some of the pigs, however, did not hesitate to express their thoughts openly. The four young pigs in the front row all stood up together and loudly declared that they did not approve of what was happening. But when the dogs lying at Napoleon's feet suddenly growled in a frightening manner, they had to fall silent and sit back down. At that moment, the sheep also began to bleat, "Four legs good, two legs bad!" in a deafening chorus. The demonstration went on so long that there was no opportunity to discuss the matter.
es: If the expulsion of Snowball had made a great impression on them, this announcement dismayed the animals. Some of them would have protested if they had the appropriate arguments. Even Boxer was a bit stunned. He pricked his ears back, shook his mane several times, and tried hard to organize his thoughts; but in the end, he couldn't think of anything to say. Some pigs, however, were more expressive. Four young pigs in the front row emitted sharp cries of disapproval, and they all stood up abruptly and began to speak at the same time. But suddenly, the dogs sitting around Napoleon let out deep, threatening growls, and the pigs fell silent, sitting back down. Then the sheep burst out with a tremendous bleating of "Four legs good, two legs bad!" which continued for almost a quarter of an hour and ended all attempts at discussion.

en: Afterwards Squealer was sent round the farm to explain the new arrangement to the others.
vi: Chỉ Điểm was sent to explain to the others.
tr: After a while, Squealer was given the task of touring the farm and explaining the new order to the other animals.
es: Then Squealer was sent all over the farm to explain the new decisions to the others.

en: “Comrades,” he said, “I trust that every animal here appreciates the sacrifice that Comrade Napoleon has made in taking this extra labour upon himself. Do not imagine, comrades, that leadership is a pleasure! On the contrary, it is a deep and heavy responsibility. No one believes more firmly than Comrade Napoleon that all animals are equal. He would be only too happy to let you make your decisions for yourselves. But sometimes you might make the wrong decisions, comrades, and then where should we be? Suppose you had decided to follow Snowball, with his moonshine of windmills — Snowball, who, as we now know, was no better than a criminal?”
vi: "Comrades," said Chỉ Điểm, "I hope that all of you appreciate the sacrifice of Comrade Napoleon when he took on the responsibility of leading the farm. Do not think that leadership is an easy task! On the contrary, it is an extremely heavy and difficult responsibility. None of us believe as deeply as Comrade Napoleon that all animals are born equal. He would be very happy if you could decide your own fate. But who can guarantee that sometimes you will not make the wrong decision, and what will happen to our farm then? For example, what if you follow Snowball with his fanciful windmill, follow someone whose actions are no different from a criminal?"
tr: "Comrades," said Squealer, "I have no doubt that all the animals here understand very well the great sacrifice Comrade Napoleon has made by taking on such a duty. Comrades, do not think that leadership is about lying back and enjoying oneself. On the contrary, leadership imposes a very heavy responsibility. Among us, it is Comrade Napoleon who most believes that all animals are equal. He would be very happy to allow you to make decisions on your own. But comrades, sometimes you might make wrong decisions, and then what would become of us? For example, if you had decided to follow Snowball, who advocated that windmill nonsense, what would we have done? Hasn't it now become clear that Snowball is nothing but a traitor?"
es: —Comrades —he said—, I hope that all the animals present will realize and appreciate the sacrifice that Comrade Napoleon has made by taking on this additional work. Do not think, comrades, that being a leader is a pleasure! On the contrary, it is a deep and heavy responsibility. No one believes more firmly than Comrade Napoleon in the principle that all animals are equal. He would be very happy to let you make your own decisions. But sometimes you might make the wrong decisions, comrades. And where would we be then? Suppose you had decided to follow Snowball, with his ridiculous windmills; Snowball, who, as we now know, was nothing more than a criminal…

en: “He fought bravely at the Battle of the Cowshed,” said somebody.
vi: "He fought bravely in the Cow Shed Campaign," someone spoke up.
tr: One of the animals said, "Snowball fought bravely in the Battle of the Cowshed."
es: —He fought valiantly in the "Battle of the Cow Shed" —someone said.

en: “Bravery is not enough,” said Squealer. “Loyalty and obedience are more important. And as to the Battle of the Cowshed, I believe the time will come when we shall find that Snowball’s part in it was much exaggerated. Discipline, comrades, iron discipline! That is the watchword for today. One false step, and our enemies would be upon us. Surely, comrades, you do not want Jones back?”
vi: "Courage alone is not enough," Chỉ Điểm said, "Loyalty and obedience are even more important. Speaking of the Cow Shed Campaign, I believe there will come a time when we see that Tuyết Tròn's role has been grossly exaggerated. Discipline, comrades, iron discipline! That is our slogan in the current phase. Just one misstep and the enemy will attack immediately. Surely you don't want old Jones to come back, do you?"
tr: "Bravery is not enough," replied Squealer. "Loyalty and obedience are more important. As for the Battle of the Cowshed; I believe that one day you will understand that Snowball's role in this battle has been greatly exaggerated. Discipline, comrades, iron discipline! Today, this should be our motto. If we take a single wrong step, our enemies will be upon us immediately. Comrades, surely you do not want Jones to come back!"
es: —Bravery is not enough —affirmed Squealer—. Loyalty and obedience are more important. And as for the "Battle of the Cowshed," I believe that the day will come when we will prove that the role played by Snowball has been greatly exaggerated. Discipline, comrades, iron discipline! That is the watchword for today. One misstep, and our enemies would fall upon us. Surely, comrades, you do not want the return of Jones, do you?

en: Once again this argument was unanswerable. Certainly the animals did not want Jones back; if the holding of debates on Sunday mornings was liable to bring him back, then the debates must stop. Boxer, who had now had time to think things over, voiced the general feeling by saying: “If Comrade Napoleon says it, it must be right.” And from then on he adopted the maxim, “Napoleon is always right,” in addition to his private motto of “I will work harder.”
vi: Its argument was indeed hard to refute. Surely, none of them wanted Mr. Jones to come back, and if the Sunday debates gave him an excuse to return, they would stop arguing. Boxer thought it over carefully and spoke on behalf of everyone: "Comrade Napoleon is always right. Comrade Napoleon is never wrong." From then on, besides "I will try harder", Chiến Sĩ also had a new slogan: "Comrade Napoleon is always right".
tr: This question also remained unanswered. Of course, they did not want Jones to come back; if the meetings held on Sunday mornings had the potential to lead to Jones's return, the discussions undoubtedly had to be stopped. Boxer, who was turning over the events in his mind, expressed everyone's thoughts: "If Comrade Napoleon says so, then it is so." From that day on, in addition to the motto he adopted for himself, "I will work harder," he also took up the saying, "Napoleon is always right."
es: Once again, this argument proved irrefutable. It was clear that the animals did not want Jones to return; if holding debates on Sunday mornings could imply his return, then the debates had to be abolished. Boxer, who had had time to coordinate his thoughts, expressed the general opinion by saying: "If Comrade Napoleon says it, it must be right." And from that moment on, he adopted the slogan: "Napoleon is always right," in addition to his personal motto: "I will work harder."

en: By this time the weather had broken and the spring ploughing had begun. The shed where Snowball had drawn his plans of the windmill had been shut up and it was assumed that the plans had been rubbed off the floor. Every Sunday morning at ten o’clock the animals assembled in the big barn to receive their orders for the week. The skull of old Major, now clean of flesh, had been disinterred from the orchard and set up on a stump at the foot of the flagstaff, beside the gun. After the hoisting of the flag, the animals were required to file past the skull in a reverent manner before entering the barn. Nowadays they did not sit all together as they had done in the past. Napoleon, with Squealer and another pig named Minimus, who had a remarkable gift for composing songs and poems, sat on the front of the raised platform, with the nine young dogs forming a semicircle round them, and the other pigs sitting behind. The rest of the animals sat facing them in the main body of the barn. Napoleon read out the orders for the week in a gruff soldierly style, and after a single singing of ‘Beasts of England’, all the animals dispersed.
vi: The weather has gradually warmed up, marking the start of a new plowing season. The warehouse, where Tuyet Tron designed the windmill, has been closed, and perhaps the drawings have also been erased. Every Sunday at ten in the morning, the animals gather in the large barn to receive production tasks for the following week. The Leader's skull, now just bones, was dug up and placed on a tree stump, next to the gun, at the foot of the flagpole. After attending the flag-raising ceremony, the animals must solemnly march past the Leader's skull before entering the barn. Now they no longer sit mixed together as they used to. Napoleon, Chỉ Điểm, and Kế Tục, a pig with a talent for composing songs and poems, sat on the wooden platform, nine dogs forming a semicircle around them, with the other pigs sitting behind. The remaining animals sat on the floor. Napoleon read out the work assignments for the following week, then they sang "Beasts of England" once and dispersed.
tr: With the arrival of spring, the weather had warmed up, and the fields had begun to be plowed. The shed where Snowball had made the windmill drawings was closed, and if the rumors were true, the drawings on the ground had also been erased. The animals gathered in the big barn every Sunday morning at ten o'clock to receive the weekly orders. The skull of Old Major, now completely dried out, had been dug up from where it was buried in the orchard and placed on a stump next to the flagpole, beside the gun. After the flag was hoisted, the animals had to pass respectfully in front of the skull before entering the barn. In the barn, they no longer sat together as they used to. Napoleon sat in front of the raised platform; a pig named Minimus, who had an extraordinary talent for writing poetry and composing songs, and Squealer sat on either side of him. Nine young dogs formed a semicircle around them, while the other pigs sat further back. All the remaining animals lined up facing them, opposite the raised platform. Napoleon read the weekly orders in a stern, military-like voice, the song "Beasts of England" was sung once, and then everyone dispersed.
es: By then the weather had changed and the spring plowing had begun. The shed where Snowball had drawn the plans for the windmill was closed, and it was assumed that the plans had been erased from the floor. Every Sunday at ten in the morning, the animals gathered in the main barn to receive their orders for the week. The skull of Old Major, now devoid of flesh, had been unearthed from the orchard and placed on a post at the foot of the flagpole, next to the shotgun. After raising the flag, the animals had to parade reverently past the skull before entering the barn. They no longer sat all together as they used to. Napoleon, with Squealer and another pig named Minimus, who had an extraordinary gift for composing songs and poems, sat on the platform, with the nine dogs forming a semicircle around them, and the other pigs positioned behind them. The other animals placed themselves in front, in the main body of the barn. Napoleon read them the orders for the week in a harsh military style, and after singing "Beasts of England" once, all the animals dispersed.

en: On the third Sunday after Snowball’s expulsion, the animals were somewhat surprised to hear Napoleon announce that the windmill was to be built after all. He did not give any reason for having changed his mind, but merely warned the animals that this extra task would mean very hard work, it might even be necessary to reduce their rations. The plans, however, had all been prepared, down to the last detail. A special committee of pigs had been at work upon them for the past three weeks. The building of the windmill, with various other improvements, was expected to take two years.
vi: On the third Sunday since Snowball's expulsion, the animals suddenly heard Napoleon declare that the windmill must be built. He did not explain why he changed his decision, but said that this task would require everyone to make great efforts and sacrifices, including the possibility of reducing daily rations. The project had been detailed to the last detail. A committee of pigs had been studying this project for the past three weeks. The construction of the windmill and other auxiliary works could take up to two years.
tr: It had only been three Sundays since Snowball was expelled from the farm. When Napoleon suddenly announced that the windmill had to be built, all the animals were stunned. Napoleon did not explain the reason for this sudden change of mind, he only warned everyone that this heavy task would require very hard work; even the reduction of rations might be in question. But the plans were prepared down to the finest details. A special committee of pigs had been brainstorming for three weeks. The construction of the windmill, with some modifications, could take two years.
es: On the third Sunday after Snowball's expulsion, the animals were somewhat surprised to hear Napoleon announce that, after all, the windmill would be built. He gave no explanation for this change of mind, but simply warned the animals that this extraordinary task would mean very hard work; it might be necessary to reduce their rations. The plans, however, had been prepared down to the smallest detail. A special committee of pigs had been working on them for the past three weeks. The construction of the windmill, along with other planned improvements, would require two years of work.

en: That evening Squealer explained privately to the other animals that Napoleon had never in reality been opposed to the windmill. On the contrary, it was he who had advocated it in the beginning, and the plan which Snowball had drawn on the floor of the incubator shed had actually been stolen from among Napoleon’s papers. The windmill was, in fact, Napoleon’s own creation. Why, then, asked somebody, had he spoken so strongly against it? Here Squealer looked very sly. That, he said, was Comrade Napoleon’s cunning. He had SEEMED to oppose the windmill, simply as a manoeuvre to get rid of Snowball, who was a dangerous character and a bad influence. Now that Snowball was out of the way, the plan could go forward without his interference. This, said Squealer, was something called tactics. He repeated a number of times, “Tactics, comrades, tactics!” skipping round and whisking his tail with a merry laugh. The animals were not certain what the word meant, but Squealer spoke so persuasively, and the three dogs who happened to be with him growled so threateningly, that they accepted his explanation without further questions.
vi: In the afternoon, Squealer came to explain to each animal that actually Napoleon was not opposed to the construction of the windmill. On the contrary, from the very beginning, he had supported the project, and the drawings they saw in the incubator were stolen by Snowball from Napoleon. The windmill was Napoleon's own initiative. Then why - some animals asked - was Napoleon so adamantly against it before? Squealer appeared very cunning. That - he explained - was the cleverness of Comrade Napoleon. He only pretended to be against it to get rid of Snowball, a dangerous enemy who could lead them astray at any moment. Now, with Snowball gone, they could proceed without fearing any more disturbances from him. That is called tactics, Squealer said. He repeated: "Tactics, comrades, it is all tactics," while smiling and jumping around, his tail wagging furiously. The animals did not understand anything, but Squealer spoke very eloquently, and the three dogs accompanying him suddenly barked loudly, so they accepted without further questions. George Orwell Animal Farm
tr: That evening, Squealer told the other animals that Napoleon had never actually opposed the windmill project. On the contrary, Napoleon was the first to advocate for this project; in fact, the designs that Snowball had drawn on the barn floor were actually stolen from Napoleon's files. The windmill had, in reality, originated from his idea. One of the animals couldn't help but ask: "If it was born from his idea, why did Napoleon oppose the windmill so fiercely?" A devilish expression appeared on Squealer's face: "Comrade Napoleon acted cunningly," he said. "Snowball was a dangerous one, setting a bad example for everyone. Comrade Napoleon appeared to be against the windmill to get rid of him." According to Squealer, now that Snowball was out of the picture, the windmill project could be easily implemented. This was what they called tactics. Squealer, hopping and skipping, laughing merrily and wagging his tail, repeated several times, "Tactics, comrades, tactics!" The animals didn't really understand much from the word "tactics"; but Squealer spoke so convincingly, and the three dogs that happened to be beside him by coincidence were growling so menacingly, that they accepted Squealer's explanation without further objection.
es: That very night, Squealer privately explained to the other animals that in reality, Napoleon had never been against the windmill. On the contrary, it was he who advocated for its construction, and the plan that Snowball had drawn on the floor of the incubator shed was actually stolen from Napoleon's papers. The windmill was truly a creation of Napoleon himself. “Why, then,” someone asked, “did he so firmly oppose the windmill?” Here Squealer put on a cunning face. “That,” he said, “was the sagacity of Comrade Napoleon.” He had pretended to oppose the windmill, but simply as a maneuver to get rid of Snowball, who was a dangerous and harmful influence. Now that Snowball had been eliminated, the plan could proceed without his interference. “This,” said Squealer, “is what is called tactics.” He repeated several times, “Tactics, comrades, tactics!” jumping and wagging his tail with a cheerful laugh. The animals were not certain about the meaning of the word, but Squealer spoke so persuasively, and three of the dogs that were with him growled so threateningly, that they accepted his explanation without further questions.
