en: All that year the animals worked like slaves. But they were happy in their work; they grudged no effort or sacrifice, well aware that everything that they did was for the benefit of themselves and those of their kind who would come after them, and not for a pack of idle, thieving human beings.
vi: Throughout that year, the animals had to work tirelessly, no different from slaves. But working was a joy for them; they spared no effort and were ready to accept any sacrifice because they knew they were working for themselves and their offspring, not for a bunch of lazy, thieving humans anymore.
tr: They worked like slaves for a whole year. But they were happy to work like this; because they were aware that whatever they were doing, they were doing it not for the benefit of a handful of idle and thieving people, but for their own benefit and for future generations, they were striving with all their might and silently enduring all kinds of sacrifices.
es: All that year, the animals worked like slaves. But they were happy in their task; they did not spare any effort or sacrifice, for they knew well that everything they did was for their own benefit and for those of their kind who would come after, and not for a few greedy and lazy human beings.

en: Throughout the spring and summer they worked a sixty-hour week, and in August Napoleon announced that there would be work on Sunday afternoons as well. This work was strictly voluntary, but any animal who absented himself from it would have his rations reduced by half. Even so, it was found necessary to leave certain tasks undone. The harvest was a little less successful than in the previous year, and two fields which should have been sown with roots in the early summer were not sown because the ploughing had not been completed early enough. It was possible to foresee that the coming winter would be a hard one.
vi: Throughout the spring and summer, they worked sixty-four hours a week, but by August, Napoleon declared that they would work Sunday afternoons as well. This work was completely voluntary, but any animal absent would have their rations cut by half. Despite this, they still could not complete the planned tasks. This year’s harvest was worse than last year’s, and they did not manage to plant turnips on two fields because the plowing was too slow. It could be foreseen that the coming winter would bring many difficulties.
tr: They had worked sixty hours a week throughout the spring and summer. When August came, Napoleon announced that they would also work on Sunday afternoons. This would be strictly voluntary work, but the ration of any animal who did not come to work would be cut in half. Despite this, some tasks had to be abandoned. The harvest was not as bountiful as the previous year; two fields had not been sown because they could not be plowed in time. One did not need to be a prophet to foresee that the approaching winter would be harsh.
es: Throughout the entire spring and summer, they worked sixty hours a week, and in August, Napoleon announced that they would also have to work on Sunday afternoons. This work was strictly voluntary, but any animal that did not show up would have their rations cut in half. Even so, it was necessary to leave several tasks undone. The harvest was somewhat less abundant than the previous year, and two plots that should have been planted with turnips at the beginning of the summer were not because they were not plowed in time. It was easy to foresee that the next winter would be harsh.

en: The windmill presented unexpected difficulties. There was a good quarry of limestone on the farm, and plenty of sand and cement had been found in one of the outhouses, so that all the materials for building were at hand. But the problem the animals could not at first solve was how to break up the stone into pieces of suitable size. There seemed no way of doing this except with picks and crowbars, which no animal could use, because no animal could stand on his hind legs. Only after weeks of vain effort did the right idea occur to somebody-namely, to utilise the force of gravity. Huge boulders, far too big to be used as they were, were lying all over the bed of the quarry. The animals lashed ropes round these, and then all together, cows, horses, sheep, any animal that could lay hold of the rope — even the pigs sometimes joined in at critical moments — they dragged them with desperate slowness up the slope to the top of the quarry, where they were toppled over the edge, to shatter to pieces below. Transporting the stone when it was once broken was comparatively simple. The horses carried it off in cart-loads, the sheep dragged single blocks, even Muriel and Benjamin yoked themselves into an old governess-cart and did their share. By late summer a sufficient store of stone had accumulated, and then the building began, under the superintendence of the pigs.
vi: The construction of the windmill encountered quite a few troubles. Right on the farm, there was a good limestone quarry, sand was also plentiful, and cement was readily available in the warehouse; all building materials were sufficient. But there was one problem that the animals couldn't solve immediately, which was how to break the stones into pieces of the desired size. It seemed that the only way was to use pickaxes and crowbars; but none of them knew how to use those tools because they couldn't stand on their hind legs. It took them several weeks of tinkering to figure out how to utilize the force of gravity. The large rocks, which couldn't be used, lay at the bottom of the limestone quarry. The animals wrapped ropes around the rocks, and then all of them, whether cows, horses, or sheep, any animal that could hold onto the rope was present, and in emergencies, even the pigs grabbed the rope and slowly pulled it up the slope, then they let the rock fall to the bottom to break into smaller pieces. Transporting the broken stones was not difficult. The horses transported them using small carts, the sheep carried them one by one, even Muriel and Benjamin harnessed themselves to a two-wheeled cart and participated in the transportation. By the end of the summer, they had gathered enough stones, the construction work began, and the pigs took on the roles of supervisors and foremen.
tr: The windmill was causing unexpected difficulties. There was a large limestone quarry on the farm; sand and cement were found in one of the small buildings; therefore, they had all kinds of construction materials at their disposal. But the problem the animals couldn't solve at first was how to break the stones into suitable sizes. Chisels and sledgehammers were needed, but the animals couldn't use these tools because they couldn't stand on their hind legs. They pondered for weeks and were about to lose hope when someone found a solution: They would take advantage of gravity. The quarry was filled with pieces of rock too large to be used without breaking. They tied these pieces of rock with ropes; then the cows, horses, sheep, all the animals that could hold the rope – even the pigs in difficult situations – slowly pulled the rocks up to the top of the quarry. The rocks they released from there would shatter into pieces below. It was easier to transport the stones. The carts pulled by the horses were very useful; the sheep dragged the stones one by one; even Muriel and Benjamin contributed by harnessing themselves to an old cart. Once enough stones were piled up by the end of summer, construction began under the supervision of the pigs.
es: The windmill presented unexpected difficulties. There was a good limestone quarry on the farm, and quite a bit of sand and cement was found in one of the outbuildings, so they had all the necessary materials for construction on hand. But the problem, which the animals could not solve at first, was how to break the stone into appropriately sized pieces. Apparently, there was no way to do it except with picks and iron levers, which they could not use because no animal was able to stand on its hind legs. After several weeks of futile efforts, one of them came up with the right idea, namely: to use the force of gravity. Immense stones, too large to use as they were, were found all over the bottom of the quarry. The animals tied them with ropes, and then all together, cows, horses, sheep, anyone who could pull the rope —even the pigs sometimes helped in critical moments— dragged them with exasperating slowness up the slope to the top of the quarry, from where they let them fall over the edge to break into pieces upon hitting the bottom. The work of transporting the stone once broken was relatively simple. The horses carried the pieces in carts, the sheep dragged them one by one, and even Muriel and Benjamin, pulling an old sulky, did their part. By the end of summer, they had accumulated a good supply of stone, and it was then that the construction of the windmill began, under the supervision of the pigs.

en: But it was a slow, laborious process. Frequently it took a whole day of exhausting effort to drag a single boulder to the top of the quarry, and sometimes when it was pushed over the edge it failed to break. Nothing could have been achieved without Boxer, whose strength seemed equal to that of all the rest of the animals put together. When the boulder began to slip and the animals cried out in despair at finding themselves dragged down the hill, it was always Boxer who strained himself against the rope and brought the boulder to a stop. To see him toiling up the slope inch by inch, his breath coming fast, the tips of his hoofs clawing at the ground, and his great sides matted with sweat, filled everyone with admiration. Clover warned him sometimes to be careful not to overstrain himself, but Boxer would never listen to her. His two slogans, “I will work harder” and “Napoleon is always right,” seemed to him a sufficient answer to all problems. He had made arrangements with the cockerel to call him three-quarters of an hour earlier in the mornings instead of half an hour. And in his spare moments, of which there were not many nowadays, he would go alone to the quarry, collect a load of broken stone, and drag it down to the site of the windmill unassisted.
vi: But the construction proceeded very slowly, consuming a lot of effort. They often took an entire day just to pull a stone to the top, but when they dropped it, it wouldn't break. Without Warrior, nothing would get done properly; it alone did the work of all the others combined. If the stone was too heavy and the whole group was dragged down, Warrior would always strive to pull it up. Everyone had to admire it when they saw it, feet firmly planted on the ground, breathing heavily, sides drenched in sweat, striving to pull the stones up step by step. Fatty occasionally reminded it not to overwork, but it wouldn't listen. It seemed that for it, the two slogans: "I will try harder" and "Comrade Napoleon is always right" were the answers to every problem. It even asked the rooster to wake it up forty-five minutes earlier instead of half an hour as before. In its spare time, which was now very limited, it would go alone to the quarry, arrange the broken stones, and pull them to the windmill construction site without any help.
tr: However, they had given a challenging effort that took a lot of time. Lifting a single rock to the top of the quarry often took their entire day and required extraordinary effort. Sometimes, the rock rolling down did not break apart. If it weren't for Boxer, whose strength was nearly equal to that of all the other animals combined, they might not have been able to manage this task. When the animals saw themselves being dragged along with the rock sliding down the hill, they would start to shout desperately, and Boxer would immediately come to the rescue, pulling the rope with all his might to stop the rock. The animals watched in admiration as he struggled breathlessly to prevent the rock from sliding, gripping the ground with his hooves, and his broad flanks drenched in sweat. Sometimes Clover would warn him not to push himself too hard, but Boxer never listened to her. "I will work harder" and "Napoleon is always right" were slogans that, in his eyes, were the cure for all problems. He had made an arrangement with the small rooster to wake him up not half an hour, but forty-five minutes early. As if all this were not enough, in his now greatly diminished free time, he would go to the quarry alone, collect broken stones, and drag them to the site where the windmill was to be built without any help from anyone.
es: It was a slow and laborious process. Frequently, it took them an entire day of exhausting effort to drag a single stone to the top of the quarry, and sometimes, when they threw it off the cliff, it wouldn't break. They wouldn't have been able to achieve anything without Boxer, whose strength seemed to equal that of all the other animals combined. When the stone started to slip and the animals cried out in desperation as they were dragged down the slope, it was always Boxer who, pulling on the rope like a convict, managed to stop the stone. Seeing him dragging it up the incline, inch by inch, panting, digging the tips of his hooves into the ground, and his enormous flanks sweaty, filled everyone with admiration. Clover sometimes warned him to be careful and not to overexert himself, but Boxer never paid attention. His two mottos: "I will work harder" and "Napoleon is always right," seemed to him a satisfactory answer to all problems. He had arranged with the rooster to wake him up three-quarters of an hour earlier in the morning, instead of half an hour. And in his free time, of which he had very little these days, he would go to the quarry, gather a pile of stone pieces, and drag it by himself to the site of the windmill.

en: The animals were not badly off throughout that summer, in spite of the hardness of their work. If they had no more food than they had had in Jones’s day, at least they did not have less. The advantage of only having to feed themselves, and not having to support five extravagant human beings as well, was so great that it would have taken a lot of failures to outweigh it. And in many ways the animal method of doing things was more efficient and saved labour. Such jobs as weeding, for instance, could be done with a thoroughness impossible to human beings. And again, since no animal now stole, it was unnecessary to fence off pasture from arable land, which saved a lot of labour on the upkeep of hedges and gates. Nevertheless, as the summer wore on, various unforeseen shortages began to make them selves felt. There was need of paraffin oil, nails, string, dog biscuits, and iron for the horses’ shoes, none of which could be produced on the farm. Later there would also be need for seeds and artificial manures, besides various tools and, finally, the machinery for the windmill. How these were to be procured, no one was able to imagine.
vi: Although they had to work hard, the animals' lives in the summer were not too bad. They did not eat more than they did during Mr. Jones's time, but they did not eat less either. In return, they only had to work to feed themselves; they did not have to feed the five greedy humans anymore, and this alone was enough to motivate them to overcome all the piled-up difficulties. Moreover, the animals' methods were often efficient and quick. For example, they weeded faster and more neatly than humans. Now that no animal was stealing, there was no need to repair the fences and gates between the pasture and the cultivated area anymore. But from that summer, shortages began to occur, now this thing, now that thing. They needed oil, nails, ropes, dog biscuits, iron for horseshoes, things that Animal Farm could not produce. Then there were seeds, chemical fertilizers, tools like hoes and shovels, and even equipment for the windmill. No animal knew how to buy those things.
tr: Despite the heaviness of the work, the animals did not have such a bad time that summer. Their rations were no more than they had been in Jones's time, but they were certainly no less. At the very least, they were no longer feeding five insatiable human beings; the pleasure of only having to feed themselves was so great that they willingly endured the hardships. Moreover, the animals' method of working was more efficient in many ways and prevented waste of labor. For instance, tasks like weeding were done with a proficiency that humans could never achieve. Since no animal now attempted to steal, there was no need to separate the pasture from the fields with fences; this saved the labor that would have been spent on maintaining and repairing the fences and barriers. However, as the summer progressed, some unforeseen shortages began to make themselves felt. There was a need for kerosene, nails, string, and dog biscuits; iron for horseshoes was also required; moreover, none of these could be produced on the farm. Later on, there would be a need for seeds and artificial fertilizers, various tools, and some machinery parts for the windmill. No one knew how these would be obtained.
es: The animals did not have such a hard time throughout that summer, despite the harshness of their work. If they did not have more food than they had during Jones's time, they did not have less either. The advantage of feeding themselves and not having to also support five useless human beings was so great that it would have taken countless failures to lose it. And in many situations, the animal method of doing things was more efficient than the human one and saved labor. Some tasks, such as weeding, could be done with an efficiency impossible for human beings. And besides, since no animal stole, it was not necessary to build fences to separate the pastures from the arable land, which saved a lot of work in maintaining the hedges and fences. However, as the summer progressed, an unforeseen shortage of various things began to be felt. There was a need for paraffin oil, nails, biscuits for the dogs, and iron for the horseshoes, none of which could be produced on the farm. Later on, there would also be a need for seeds and artificial fertilizers, as well as various tools and, finally, the most important thing: the machinery for the windmill. Nobody could imagine how all these items were going to be obtained.

en: One Sunday morning, when the animals assembled to receive their orders, Napoleon announced that he had decided upon a new policy. From now onwards Animal Farm would engage in trade with the neighbouring farms: not, of course, for any commercial purpose, but simply in order to obtain certain materials which were urgently necessary. The needs of the windmill must override everything else, he said. He was therefore making arrangements to sell a stack of hay and part of the current year’s wheat crop, and later on, if more money were needed, it would have to be made up by the sale of eggs, for which there was always a market in Willingdon. The hens, said Napoleon, should welcome this sacrifice as their own special contribution towards the building of the windmill.
vi: One Sunday morning, when the animals gathered to receive their tasks for the upcoming week, Napoleon suddenly announced that he had decided to implement a new policy. From now on, Animal Farm would trade with neighboring farms: of course, not for profit but only to purchase some truly necessary supplies. The task of building the windmill is of utmost importance to us, he said. Therefore, he had negotiated the sale of hay and part of the last wheat crop, and later, if more money was needed, they might have to sell eggs, as the demand for eggs in Willingdon was very high. Comrades, the hens, Napoleon said, should be proud to have made special contributions to the construction of the windmill.
tr: One Sunday morning, when they gathered to receive orders, Napoleon announced that he had determined a new policy. From now on, Animal Farm would engage in trade with neighboring farms. Undoubtedly, not for commercial purposes, but solely to acquire some urgently needed supplies. Napoleon said, "The needs of the windmill must be prioritized above everything else." Therefore, he was making arrangements to sell a large stack of hay and a portion of that year's wheat crop; later, if more money was needed, eggs, which always had a market in Willingdon, could also be sold. According to Napoleon, the hens should see this as their special contribution to the construction of the windmill and should not hesitate to make such a sacrifice.
es: One Sunday morning, when the animals gathered to receive orders, Napoleon announced that he had decided to adopt a new system. Henceforth, "Animal Farm" would negotiate with the neighboring farms; and not, of course, for any commercial purpose, but simply to obtain certain materials that were urgently needed. "The needs of the windmill are above everything else," he stated. Consequently, he was taking the necessary measures to sell a portion of the hay and another part of that year's wheat harvest, and later on, if they needed more money, they would have to obtain it by selling eggs, for which there was always a market in Willingdon. "The hens," said Napoleon, "should gladly accept this sacrifice as a special contribution to the construction of the windmill."

en: Once again the animals were conscious of a vague uneasiness. Never to have any dealings with human beings, never to engage in trade, never to make use of money — had not these been among the earliest resolutions passed at that first triumphant Meeting after Jones was expelled? All the animals remembered passing such resolutions: or at least they thought that they remembered it. The four young pigs who had protested when Napoleon abolished the Meetings raised their voices timidly, but they were promptly silenced by a tremendous growling from the dogs. Then, as usual, the sheep broke into “Four legs good, two legs bad!” and the momentary awkwardness was smoothed over. Finally Napoleon raised his trotter for silence and announced that he had already made all the arrangements. There would be no need for any of the animals to come in contact with human beings, which would clearly be most undesirable. He intended to take the whole burden upon his own shoulders. A Mr. Whymper, a solicitor living in Willingdon, had agreed to act as intermediary between Animal Farm and the outside world, and would visit the farm every Monday morning to receive his instructions. Napoleon ended his speech with his usual cry of “Long live Animal Farm!” and after the singing of ‘Beasts of England’ the animals were dismissed.
vi: Once again, the animals felt anxious. No dealings with humans, no engaging in trade, no use of money - weren't these the resolutions passed at the first Meeting celebrating the victory after driving out Mr. Jones? All the animals remembered that they had passed those resolutions, or at least they thought they remembered. The four pigs who had stood up to protest when Napoleon announced the cancellation of the weekend Meetings were about to speak again, but they quickly shut their mouths because the dogs had started barking loudly. As always, the sheep began chanting "Four legs good, two legs bad!" and everything settled down. Finally, Napoleon raised his hoof to call for order and declared that he had resolved everything satisfactorily. No animal would have to deal with humans, as it was not a pleasant task. He would take full responsibility for that heavy task. A lawyer currently living in Willingdon named Whymper had agreed to act as an intermediary between Animal Farm and the neighboring farms; he would take up his duties on Monday mornings each week. As usual, Napoleon ended his speech by shouting the slogan "Long live Animal Farm" and after singing "Beasts of England," the animals dispersed.
tr: The animals, once again, had become vaguely uneasy. Never do business with humans! Never engage in trade! Never use money! Weren't these the first decisions made at the Victory Meeting held after Jones was expelled from the farm? All the animals remembered these decisions being approved, or at least they thought they remembered. The four little pigs who had protested against Napoleon abolishing the meetings timidly raised their voices, but suddenly fell silent in the face of the dogs' terrifying growls. Immediately after, as usual, the sheep began to bleat "Four legs good, two legs bad!" and the tense atmosphere was diffused. Soon after, Napoleon raised his foreleg to silence everyone and announced that he had already arranged everything. Knowing that it would be extremely problematic for the farm animals to interact with humans, he had decided to create conditions where this would not be necessary. He would take all the responsibility himself. A lawyer named Mr. Whymper, who lived in Willingdon, had agreed to mediate in the dealings between Animal Farm and the outside world; he would come to the farm every Monday morning to receive instructions from Napoleon. After Napoleon, as always, concluded his speech with the cry "Long live Animal Farm!" the animals sang the Beasts of England song and dispersed.
es: Once again the animals felt themselves gripped by a vague unease. “Never to have any dealings with humans, never to engage in trade, never to use money,” weren’t those the first resolutions adopted at that triumphant meeting, after Jones had been expelled? All the animals remembered having approved such resolutions or, at least, they believed they remembered it. The four young pigs who had protested when Napoleon abolished the meetings timidly raised their voices, but were immediately silenced by the fierce growling of the dogs. Then, as usual, the sheep burst out with their “Four legs good, two legs bad!” and their chant prevailed. Finally, Napoleon raised his paw to impose silence and announced that he had already decided all the agreements. There would be no need for any of the animals to come into contact with human beings, which would be undesirable. He intended to take the full weight of the decisions upon his own shoulders. A certain Mr. Whymper, a broker who lived in Willingdon, had agreed to act as an intermediary between “Animal Farm” and the outside world, and would visit the farm every Monday morning to receive instructions. Napoleon ended his speech with his usual cry of “Long live Animal Farm!” and after singing “Beasts of England,” he dismissed the animals.

en: Afterwards Squealer made a round of the farm and set the animals’ minds at rest. He assured them that the resolution against engaging in trade and using money had never been passed, or even suggested. It was pure imagination, probably traceable in the beginning to lies circulated by Snowball. A few animals still felt faintly doubtful, but Squealer asked them shrewdly, “Are you certain that this is not something that you have dreamed, comrades? Have you any record of such a resolution? Is it written down anywhere?” And since it was certainly true that nothing of the kind existed in writing, the animals were satisfied that they had been mistaken.
vi: After that, Chỉ Điểm went around the camp to conduct ideological work. He assured that the decision not to trade and not to use money had never been put to a vote, let alone passed. That was just a fabrication, and if traced back to the beginning, it might have been made up by Tuyết Tròn. But some still did not believe, so Chỉ Điểm asked: "Comrade, are you sure you didn't imagine it? Do you have any documents confirming that? Where is that decision recorded?". Surely those decisions were not recorded anywhere, so in the end, the animals believed they were mistaken.
tr: Before long, Squealer set about touring the farm to dispel the doubts that had arisen in the animals' minds. With a convincing tone, he explained that no decision had ever been made regarding not engaging in trade or using money, and furthermore, that such a proposal had never even been suggested. All of this was most likely a figment of the imagination, stemming from the lies Snowball had spread in the early days. Noticing that some still harbored doubts, Squealer cunningly asked, "Could this be something you dreamed, comrades? Is there any document of such a decision? Is it written down anywhere?" Indeed, since there was no such written document to be found, the animals were forced to admit they were mistaken.
es: Then Squealer went around the farm and reassured them. He assured them that the resolution prohibiting trade and the use of money had never been passed, nor even suggested. It was pure imagination, probably attributable to lies spread by Snowball. Some animals still had certain doubts, but Squealer cunningly asked them: "Are you sure this isn't something you have dreamed, comrades? Do you have any record of such a resolution? Is it written down anywhere?" And since it was true that none of this was written down, the animals were convinced that they were mistaken.

en: Every Monday Mr. Whymper visited the farm as had been arranged. He was a sly-looking little man with side whiskers, a solicitor in a very small way of business, but sharp enough to have realised earlier than anyone else that Animal Farm would need a broker and that the commissions would be worth having. The animals watched his coming and going with a kind of dread, and avoided him as much as possible. Nevertheless, the sight of Napoleon, on all fours, delivering orders to Whymper, who stood on two legs, roused their pride and partly reconciled them to the new arrangement. Their relations with the human race were now not quite the same as they had been before. The human beings did not hate Animal Farm any less now that it was prospering; indeed, they hated it more than ever. Every human being held it as an article of faith that the farm would go bankrupt sooner or later, and, above all, that the windmill would be a failure. They would meet in the public-houses and prove to one another by means of diagrams that the windmill was bound to fall down, or that if it did stand up, then that it would never work. And yet, against their will, they had developed a certain respect for the efficiency with which the animals were managing their own affairs. One symptom of this was that they had begun to call Animal Farm by its proper name and ceased to pretend that it was called the Manor Farm. They had also dropped their championship of Jones, who had given up hope of getting his farm back and gone to live in another part of the county. Except through Whymper, there was as yet no contact between Animal Farm and the outside world, but there were constant rumours that Napoleon was about to enter into a definite business agreement either with Mr. Pilkington of Foxwood or with Mr. Frederick of Pinchfield — but never, it was noticed, with both simultaneously.
vi: Every Monday, Mr. Whymper came to the farm. He was a small-statured lawyer with long sideburns, just starting out in business, but quite shrewd, immediately recognizing that Animal Farm would definitely need a broker and that the commission would naturally be "substantial." The animals were afraid of Whymper and tried to avoid him as much as possible. Nevertheless, the fact that Napoleon, standing on four legs, gave orders to Whymper, who stood on two legs, instilled in them a legitimate sense of pride and somewhat mitigated their reaction to the new policy. Their relationship with humans was no longer the same as before. The humans' hatred for Animal Farm not only did not decrease but actually increased as it became more prosperous. Everyone believed that sooner or later the farm would go bankrupt, and the windmill was sure to fail. They often gathered in pubs and drew diagrams to prove that the windmill would definitely collapse, and even if it didn't, it would never work. But despite their dislike, they had to respect the animals because they managed the farm quite efficiently. The proof was that they had started calling it Animal Farm and had stopped pretending it was still named Manor Farm. They also no longer supported Mr. Jones, who had lost all hope of reclaiming the farm and had gone to work elsewhere. Although currently all relations between Animal Farm and the outside world were conducted through Whymper, there were rumors that Napoleon was about to sign a trade agreement either with Pilkington's Foxwood Farm or Frederick's Pinchfield Farm, but people also said that there would be no deal with both farms at the same time.
tr: Mr. Whymper, as previously arranged, visited the farm every Monday. Mr. Whymper, a lawyer who dealt with trivial matters, was a small man with sideburns and a mischievous look. But he was shrewd enough to realize long before that Animal Farm would eventually need a broker, and that this broker's share would not be insignificant. The animals watched his comings and goings with trepidation, avoiding encounters with him as much as possible. Nevertheless, seeing the four-legged Napoleon giving orders to the two-legged Whymper stroked their pride and helped them somewhat accept this new situation. Their relations with the human race were no longer quite the same. The humans' hatred for Animal Farm had not diminished; on the contrary, they hated it more than ever as they saw the farm prospering. They all wholeheartedly believed that the farm would eventually go bankrupt and, more importantly, that the windmill project would end in complete failure. They gathered in taverns, trying to prove to each other with drawings that the windmill could never be built, and even if it were, it would never work. On the other hand, they reluctantly admired the animals' skillful management of their own affairs. The fact that they had stopped insisting that the farm's real name was Manor Farm and had started using the name Animal Farm was an indication of this. They had also ceased defending Jones, who had lost hope of reclaiming his farm and had moved to another part of the country. There was no connection between Animal Farm and the outside world except for Whymper, but there were constant rumors that Napoleon was about to make a concrete business deal either with Mr. Pilkington of Foxwood Farm or Mr. Frederick of Pinchfield Farm, though it was said he would never make a deal with both at the same time.
es: Every Monday, Mr. Whymper visited the farm, as had been agreed. He was a short, cunning man with broad sideburns, a retail broker, but smart enough to realize, before anyone else, that "Animal Farm" was going to need an agent and that the commissions would be worth it. The animals watched his comings and goings with some fear, and avoided him as much as possible. However, the sight of Napoleon, on his four legs, giving orders to Whymper, who stood on his two feet, stirred their pride and partially reconciled them to the new situation. Their relations with the human race were not as they had been before. The humans, for their part, did not hate "Animal Farm" any less now that it was prospering; on the contrary, they hated it more than ever. Every human was certain that, sooner or later, the farm would go bankrupt, and above all, that the windmill would be a failure. They gathered in taverns and demonstrated to each other, through diagrams, that the windmill was destined to fall or, if it stood, that it would never work. And yet, against their wishes, they came to have a certain respect for the efficiency with which the animals were managing their own affairs. One of the signs of this was that they began to call "Animal Farm" by its real name and stopped pretending it was called "Manor Farm." They also ceased to support Jones, who had lost hope of regaining his farm and went to live elsewhere in the country. Except for Whymper, there was still no contact between "Animal Farm" and the outside world, but there were constant rumors that Napoleon was definitely going to make a trade agreement with Mr. Pilkington of Foxwood, or with Mr. Frederick of Pinchfield; but never — it was noted — with both simultaneously.

en: It was about this time that the pigs suddenly moved into the farmhouse and took up their residence there. Again the animals seemed to remember that a resolution against this had been passed in the early days, and again Squealer was able to convince them that this was not the case. It was absolutely necessary, he said, that the pigs, who were the brains of the farm, should have a quiet place to work in. It was also more suited to the dignity of the Leader (for of late he had taken to speaking of Napoleon under the title of “Leader”) to live in a house than in a mere sty. Nevertheless, some of the animals were disturbed when they heard that the pigs not only took their meals in the kitchen and used the drawing-room as a recreation room, but also slept in the beds. Boxer passed it off as usual with “Napoleon is always right!”, but Clover, who thought she remembered a definite ruling against beds, went to the end of the barn and tried to puzzle out the Seven Commandments which were inscribed there. Finding herself unable to read more than individual letters, she fetched Muriel.
vi: Around that time, the pigs suddenly moved into the main house. This time, the animals also believed that from the very beginning they had decided that no one was allowed to move into the main house. Squealer once again convinced them that they were mistaken. The pigs were the brains of the entire farm, he said, so they needed quiet places to work. The Leader (recently he had started calling Napoleon the Leader) had to live in a worthy place and couldn't just keep living in a pigsty. However, some were worried when they heard that the pigs not only ate in the kitchen and rested in the living room but also slept in beds. Boxer still said "Comrade Napoleon is always right," but Clover thought there surely was a rule against sleeping in beds, so she went to the end of the barn to check the Seven Commandments. But she could only recognize the letters and couldn't read the words, so she had to find Muriel.
tr: It was around that time that the pigs moved into the farmhouse and made it their residence. The animals vaguely remembered that there had been a resolution passed against such behavior, but Squealer once again managed to convince them that this was not the case at all. He said that it was absolutely necessary for the pigs, the brains of the farm, to work in a quiet and peaceful place. Moreover, for the Leader's (recently, they had started referring to Napoleon as "the Leader") dignity, it was more appropriate for him to live in a house rather than a simple shed. Nevertheless, some animals were quite disturbed when they heard that the pigs not only ate their meals in the kitchen and used the living room as a recreation room, but also slept in beds. Boxer, as usual, dismissed the situation by saying, "Napoleon is always right!" but Clover, who vaguely remembered a strict law against sleeping in beds, went to the wall of the big barn and tried to read the Seven Commandments written there. Seeing that she couldn't make out anything other than individual letters, she called Muriel.
es: It was around that time when the pigs suddenly moved into the farmhouse and established their residence there. Once again, the animals thought they remembered that in the early days a resolution had been passed against such a measure, and once again Squealer had to convince them that it was not so. It was absolutely necessary, he said, that the pigs, who were the brains of the farm, had a quiet place to work. It was also more appropriate for the dignity of the Leader (because lately they had begun to refer to Napoleon with the title of "Leader") that he lived in a house instead of a simple pigsty. However, some animals were upset to learn that the pigs not only ate in the kitchen and used the living room as a recreation area, but also slept in the beds. Boxer overlooked it, as usual, repeating "Napoleon is always right!", but Clover, who believed she remembered a specific provision against beds, went to the end of the barn and tried to decipher the seven commandments that were written there. Seeing that she could only read the letters one by one, she brought Muriel.

en: “Muriel,” she said, “read me the Fourth Commandment. Does it not say something about never sleeping in a bed?”
vi: "Muriel," Fatty said, "read me the Fourth Commandment. Is it that we should never sleep in a bed?"
tr: "Muriel," he said, "read me the Fourth Commandment. Does it say anything about never sleeping in a bed?"
es: —Muriel —he said—, read me the fourth commandment. Doesn't it say something about never sleeping in a bed?

en: With some difficulty Muriel spelt it out.
vi: Muriel had to spell it out for a long time before finishing.
tr: Muriel, who could barely read the writing, said, "No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets."
es: With a bit of difficulty, Muriel spelled it out.

en: “It says, ‘No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets,”’ she announced finally.
vi: "This Commandment reads: No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets," Muriel said.
tr: Muriel, who could barely read the writing, said, "No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets."
es: —He says: "No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets."

en: Curiously enough, Clover had not remembered that the Fourth Commandment mentioned sheets; but as it was there on the wall, it must have done so. And Squealer, who happened to be passing at this moment, attended by two or three dogs, was able to put the whole matter in its proper perspective.
vi: It's strange, Fat Lady remembered that the Fourth Commandment didn't mention bed sheets, but if it was clearly written on the wall like that, then it must be so. At that moment, Chỉ Điểm, along with two or three dogs, accidentally walked by.
tr: It was a bit strange; Clover did not remember any mention of sheets in the Fourth Commandment; but since it was written on the wall, there was nothing to be done. At that moment, Squealer, who was passing by with two or three dogs, did not delay in clarifying the matter.
es: The curious thing was that Clover did not remember the Fourth Commandment mentioning the sheets; but since it was written on the wall, it must have been so. And Squealer, who was passing by at that moment, accompanied by two or three dogs, was able to clarify the matter and set it straight.

en: “You have heard then, comrades,” he said, “that we pigs now sleep in the beds of the farmhouse? And why not? You did not suppose, surely, that there was ever a ruling against beds? A bed merely means a place to sleep in. A pile of straw in a stall is a bed, properly regarded. The rule was against sheets, which are a human invention. We have removed the sheets from the farmhouse beds, and sleep between blankets. And very comfortable beds they are too! But not more comfortable than we need, I can tell you, comrades, with all the brainwork we have to do nowadays. You would not rob us of our repose, would you, comrades? You would not have us too tired to carry out our duties? Surely none of you wishes to see Jones back?”
vi: "Comrades," it said, "I think you know that we pigs have been sleeping in beds already? Why not? Do you really think there is a rule against sleeping in beds? What is a bed, but a place to sleep? In fact, a pile of straw in a barn is also a bed. The rule is against sleeping with sheets, because those are a human invention. We have removed all the sheets, now we only use blankets. Beds are actually very convenient! But they are not too luxurious, I can tell you that they are exactly what we need for intellectual workers like us. Don't you want us to rest? Do you want us to be exhausted? Surely none of you want old Jones to come back, right?"
tr: "Comrades," he said. "It seems that you have heard that we pigs are sleeping in the beds of the farmhouse. Why shouldn't we? I hope you don't think there is a commandment that forbids beds! A bed is a place to lie down and sleep. In this sense, a pile of straw in the barn is also considered a bed. The commandment forbade sheets, which are a human invention. We removed the sheets from the beds in the farmhouse and are sleeping with blankets. Moreover, the beds are very comfortable! But believe me, for those of us who have to think hard about a lot of issues these days, a bed should not be begrudged. You wouldn't begrudge us this comfort, would you, comrades? Surely you don't want us to be too tired to fulfill our duties. I don't think any of you want Jones to come back!"
es: —You have heard, comrades —he said—, that we pigs now sleep in the beds of the house. And why not? Surely, you would not suppose that there was ever a ruling against beds. A bed simply means a place to sleep. For example: a pile of straw in a barn is a bed. The resolution was against the sheets, which are an invention of human beings. We have removed the sheets from the beds in the house and sleep between blankets. And indeed, they are very comfortable beds! But they are no more than what we need, I can assure you, comrades, considering all the brainwork we have these days. You wouldn't want to deprive us of our rest, would you, comrades? You wouldn't want us to be so tired that we can't fulfill our duties. Surely, none of you would want Jones to come back.

en: The animals reassured him on this point immediately, and no more was said about the pigs sleeping in the farmhouse beds. And when, some days afterwards, it was announced that from now on the pigs would get up an hour later in the mornings than the other animals, no complaint was made about that either.
vi: The animals assured it that they did not think so, and from then on, no one mentioned the pigs sleeping in beds anymore. A few days later, it was announced that from now on, the pigs would get up an hour later than the other animals; this time, no one complained at all.
tr: The animals immediately reassured Squealer on this matter and never brought up the issue of the pigs sleeping in the farmhouse beds again. A few days later, when it was announced that the pigs would now get up an hour later than the other animals in the mornings, no one said a word.
es: The animals immediately calmed him down and the matter of the pigs sleeping in the house beds was not discussed further. And when, days later, it was announced that from then on the pigs would get up an hour later in the morning than the other animals, there was no complaint about it either.

en: By the autumn the animals were tired but happy. They had had a hard year, and after the sale of part of the hay and corn, the stores of food for the winter were none too plentiful, but the windmill compensated for everything. It was almost half built now. After the harvest there was a stretch of clear dry weather, and the animals toiled harder than ever, thinking it well worth while to plod to and fro all day with blocks of stone if by doing so they could raise the walls another foot. Boxer would even come out at nights and work for an hour or two on his own by the light of the harvest moon. In their spare moments the animals would walk round and round the half-finished mill, admiring the strength and perpendicularity of its walls and marvelling that they should ever have been able to build anything so imposing. Only old Benjamin refused to grow enthusiastic about the windmill, though, as usual, he would utter nothing beyond the cryptic remark that donkeys live a long time.
vi: Autumn arrived, and although the animals were tired, they were happy. The past year had been a hard one; they had to sell some of the hay and grain, so the winter reserves were not very abundant, but the windmill compensated for all their efforts. The windmill was nearly halfway built. After the harvest, the weather was very favorable, and the animals worked harder than ever before, willing to move and carry things all day as long as the wall grew taller, even if just a little. At night, Boxer would even put in an extra hour or two under the moonlight. In their free time, the animals often strolled around the construction site, admiring the straight and sturdy walls; they wondered if they had really built such a magnificent structure. Only Benjamin remained unchanged; he said nothing except his usual remark that donkeys live a long time.
tr: When autumn came, the animals were tired but happy. They had left a difficult year behind. Although it couldn't be said that the stock of winter food was abundant after some of the hay and crops were sold, the windmill would make up for this shortfall. Nearly half of the construction was completed. After the harvest, the weather cleared up, and the animals were working harder than ever, thinking it was worth carrying stones from morning till night, as long as the walls of the windmill rose another inch. Boxer didn't even take nights off; he worked alone for an extra hour or two in the light of the full moon. In their free time, the animals wandered around the half-built windmill, admiring its solid, towering walls, and were amazed at how they had managed to create such a magnificent structure. The only animal who avoided getting enthusiastic about the windmill was old Benjamin; as always, he limited himself to saying cryptic things like, "Donkeys live a long time."
es: When autumn arrived, the animals were tired but happy. They had had a difficult year and after selling some of the hay and corn, the food supplies were not as abundant, but the windmill made up for everything. It was almost built. After the harvest, they had a season of dry and clear weather, and the animals worked harder than ever, thinking it was well worth running back and forth all day with stone blocks if by doing so they could raise the walls another foot in height. Boxer even sometimes went out at night and worked an hour or two on his own by moonlight. In their free time, the animals walked around and around the almost finished windmill, admiring the strength and verticality of its walls and marveling that they had ever been able to build something so imposing. Only old Benjamin refused to get excited about the windmill, although, as usual, he insisted on his enigmatic statement that donkeys lived a long time.

en: November came, with raging south-west winds. Building had to stop because it was now too wet to mix the cement. Finally there came a night when the gale was so violent that the farm buildings rocked on their foundations and several tiles were blown off the roof of the barn. The hens woke up squawking with terror because they had all dreamed simultaneously of hearing a gun go off in the distance. In the morning the animals came out of their stalls to find that the flagstaff had been blown down and an elm tree at the foot of the orchard had been plucked up like a radish. They had just noticed this when a cry of despair broke from every animal’s throat. A terrible sight had met their eyes. The windmill was in ruins.
vi: November begins with southwest winds. Construction work was halted because it was too damp to mix mortar. One night, the wind was so strong that the roof tiles were blown off, and the walls seemed on the verge of collapsing. The chickens woke up and clucked loudly because they all dreamt of hearing gunshots somewhere. In the morning, when the animals came out of the barn, they saw that the flagpole had fallen, and the elm tree at the end of the garden had been uprooted as if someone had pulled up a radish. But that was not all; in front of them was an even more terrifying sight. The windmill had completely collapsed.
tr: November came with strong winds blowing from the southwest. They had to stop the construction; it was impossible to mix cement because the weather was too rainy. Finally, one night, a storm broke out so violently that the farm buildings shook from their foundations, and tiles flew off the roof of the barn. The chickens woke up clucking in fear; they had all heard a gunshot in the distance in the dream they saw at the same time. In the morning, they saw that the flagpole had fallen, and one of the elm trees in the orchard had been uprooted like a radish. Before they could understand what was happening, all the animals started screaming in terror: The windmill had collapsed.
es: November arrived, with its furious southwest winds. They had to stop the construction because there was too much humidity to mix the cement. And then came a night when the gale was so violent that the farm buildings trembled on their foundations and several tiles were torn off the barn roof. The hens woke up clucking in terror because they all dreamed they had heard something like the boom of a cannon in the distance. In the morning, the animals came out of their stalls and found the flagpole knocked down and an elm tree, which was at the foot of the orchard, uprooted. They had barely seen this when a cry of despair burst from their throats. A terrible scene presented itself to their eyes. The windmill was in ruins.

en: With one accord they dashed down to the spot. Napoleon, who seldom moved out of a walk, raced ahead of them all. Yes, there it lay, the fruit of all their struggles, levelled to its foundations, the stones they had broken and carried so laboriously scattered all around. Unable at first to speak, they stood gazing mournfully at the litter of fallen stone. Napoleon paced to and fro in silence, occasionally snuffing at the ground. His tail had grown rigid and twitched sharply from side to side, a sign in him of intense mental activity. Suddenly he halted as though his mind were made up.
vi: They all cried out in unison in despair. They rushed towards the construction site. Napoleon, who always considered running to be beneath him, was now at the head of the group, running as fast as he could. It was all over; everything had gone to waste. The stones they had painstakingly broken and transported were now scattered everywhere. Speechless, they stood silently, painfully gazing at the pile of fallen stones. Napoleon walked back and forth in silence, occasionally sniffing the ground. His tail was stretched out, wagging vigorously, indicating that he was deep in thought. Suddenly, he stopped, which meant he had found a solution.
tr: They all rushed together to the windmill. Napoleon, who had never been seen even walking briskly, was at the forefront, kicking up dust. The windmill, which they had worked so hard to build, was completely destroyed, and the stones they had painstakingly broken and carried were scattered all around. They stood there as if struck dumb, staring at the stones scattered around. Napoleon was pacing silently, sniffing the ground every now and then, and judging by the rapid swishing of his erect tail, his mind was racing. Suddenly, as if he had made up his mind, he stopped.
es: All at once they rushed towards the place. Napoleon, who rarely hurried when walking, was running at the head of all of them. Yes, there lay the fruit of all their efforts, demolished to its foundations; the stones, which they had so diligently broken and moved, were scattered everywhere. Unable, at first, to utter a word, they could only look sadly at the fallen rubble in disarray. Napoleon walked back and forth in silence, occasionally sniffing the ground. His tail had gone stiff and was moving nervously from side to side, a sign of his intense mental activity. Suddenly he stopped as if he had clearly seen the origin of that disaster.

en: “Comrades,” he said quietly, “do you know who is responsible for this? Do you know the enemy who has come in the night and overthrown our windmill? SNOWBALL!” he suddenly roared in a voice of thunder. “Snowball has done this thing! In sheer malignity, thinking to set back our plans and avenge himself for his ignominious expulsion, this traitor has crept here under cover of night and destroyed our work of nearly a year. Comrades, here and now I pronounce the death sentence upon Snowball. ‘Animal Hero, Second Class,’ and half a bushel of apples to any animal who brings him to justice. A full bushel to anyone who captures him alive!”
vi: "Comrades," he calmly said, "do you know who is responsible for this? Who sabotaged, who destroyed our windmill last night? Snowball!" he suddenly shouted, "it was Snowball, no one else. That treacherous traitor has heartlessly sought to ruin us and take revenge for his humiliating expulsion; he took advantage of the darkness to sneak in and destroy the entire year's worth of our labor. Today, here, I declare a death sentence on Snowball. Whoever kills him will be awarded Animal Hero, Second Class, and half a barrel of apples. Whoever captures him alive will be rewarded with a full barrel of apples."
tr: Without raising his voice, he said, "Comrades." "Do you know who did this? Do you know who the enemy is that came here at night and destroyed our windmill?" Then he suddenly roared: "Snowball! This is Snowball's doing! This traitor, just to cause harm, to ruin our plans and take revenge for his disgraceful expulsion, came here under the cover of darkness and destroyed a year's worth of work. Comrades, I hereby sentence Snowball to death. To the animal who gives him the punishment he deserves, the 'Second Class Animal Hero' medal and half a bucket of apples. To the one who brings him back alive, a full bucket of apples!"
es: —Comrades —he said in a calm voice—, do you know who is responsible for all this? Do you know who the enemy is that came during the night and knocked down our windmill? Snowball! —he suddenly roared with a thunderous voice—. Snowball did this! Out of pure malice, believing that he was going to ruin our plans and take revenge for his ignominious expulsion, that traitor crawled here under the cover of darkness and destroyed our work of nearly a year. Comrades, at this moment and place, I sentence Snowball to death. I will reward and name "Animal Hero, Second Class" and give half a bushel of apples to the animal that brings him dead. A whole bushel to the one who captures him alive.

en: The animals were shocked beyond measure to learn that even Snowball could be guilty of such an action. There was a cry of indignation, and everyone began thinking out ways of catching Snowball if he should ever come back. Almost immediately the footprints of a pig were discovered in the grass at a little distance from the knoll. They could only be traced for a few yards, but appeared to lead to a hole in the hedge. Napoleon snuffed deeply at them and pronounced them to be Snowball’s. He gave it as his opinion that Snowball had probably come from the direction of Foxwood Farm.
vi: Every animal was extremely furious upon hearing the news that Snowball had committed such a heinous crime. Their anger erupted into screams, and each one thought of ways to capture Snowball alive if he was still lurking around. They also discovered pig tracks on the grass near the hill. The tracks extended for about ten meters, seemingly heading towards a hole in the fence. Napoleon sniffed the tracks deeply and then declared that they were Snowball's tracks. Napoleon said that Snowball might have come from the direction of Foxwood Farm.
tr: The animals, who had never even imagined that Snowball could commit such a crime until that day, were stunned. They were growling with anger, calculating how they would catch Snowball if he ever came back. Soon after, pig tracks were found among the grass a little further ahead of the small hill. The tracks continued for a few meters, apparently leading to a hole in the fence. After sniffing for a long time, Napoleon declared that the tracks belonged to Snowball. He guessed that Snowball had come from the direction of Foxwood Farm.
es: The animals were horrified to learn that Snowball could be guilty of such an action. There was a cry of indignation and everyone began to devise a way to catch Snowball, if they ever found him. Almost immediately, the footprints of a pig were discovered in the grass, a short distance from the hill. The tracks could be followed for a few meters, but they seemed to lead to a hole in the hedge. Napoleon sniffed them well and declared that they were Snowball's. He opined that Snowball had probably come from "Foxwood Farm."

en: “No more delays, comrades!” cried Napoleon when the footprints had been examined. “There is work to be done. This very morning we begin rebuilding the windmill, and we will build all through the winter, rain or shine. We will teach this miserable traitor that he cannot undo our work so easily. Remember, comrades, there must be no alteration in our plans: they shall be carried out to the day. Forward, comrades! Long live the windmill! Long live Animal Farm!”
vi: "Slow means death," Napoleon declared after examining the footprints, "we must continue the work, comrades! We will start rebuilding the windmill from this very morning, we will work throughout this winter, regardless of wind, rain, or cold. We will teach that treacherous scoundrel a lesson that he cannot stop us. Please remember, comrades: our plan remains unchanged. We are determined to complete the construction of the windmill on time. Comrades, forward! Long live the windmill! Long live Animal Farm!". George Orwell Animal Farm
tr: Napoleon, after examining the footprints, shouted, "Let's not waste time, comrades!" "We have a lot of work to do. Starting this morning, we will rebuild the windmill. We will work through the winter, regardless of snow and mud. We will show this lowly traitor that he cannot defeat us so easily. Keep in mind, comrades, there should not be the slightest disruption in our plans; all plans must be executed day by day. Come on, comrades! Long live the windmill! Long live Animal Farm!"
es: —There is no time to lose, comrades! —shouted Napoleon once he had examined the footprints—. There is much work to be done. This very morning we will start rebuilding the windmill and we will reconstruct it throughout the winter, come rain or shine. We will show that miserable traitor that he cannot undo our work so easily. Remember, comrades; there must be no alteration in our plans, which will be carried out no matter what. Forward, comrades! Long live the windmill! Long live "Animal Farm"!
