en: It was a bitter winter. The stormy weather was followed by sleet and snow, and then by a hard frost which did not break till well into February. The animals carried on as best they could with the rebuilding of the windmill, well knowing that the outside world was watching them and that the envious human beings would rejoice and triumph if the mill were not finished on time.
vi: The winter that year was very harsh. Storms followed by rain, then snow and frost; by February, the ice had not yet melted. Yet the animals diligently rebuilt the windmill, knowing that people were watching them and those wicked people would have a reason to rejoice if they did not complete the project on time.
tr: The winter was very harsh. After the storms, first came sleet, then snow, and later everything was covered in ice until February. The animals were working with all their might, knowing that the entire outside world had its eyes on Animal Farm, and that if the windmill was not completed on time, the envious humans would rejoice.
es: A harsh winter set in. The stormy weather was followed by hail and snow and then by a severe frost that lasted until mid-February. The animals managed as best they could to rebuild the windmill, for they knew well that the outside world was watching them and that the envious humans would rejoice and triumph over them if they did not finish the work on time.

en: Out of spite, the human beings pretended not to believe that it was Snowball who had destroyer the windmill: they said that it had fallen down because the walls were too thin. The animals knew that this was not the case. Still, it had been decided to build the walls three feet thick this time instead of eighteen inches as before, which meant collecting much larger quantities of stone. For a long time the quarry was full of snowdrifts and nothing could be done. Some progress was made in the dry frosty weather that followed, but it was cruel work, and the animals could not feel so hopeful about it as they had felt before. They were always cold, and usually hungry as well. Only Boxer and Clover never lost heart. Squealer made excellent speeches on the joy of service and the dignity of labour, but the other animals found more inspiration in Boxer’s strength and his never-failing cry of “I will work harder!”
vi: To provoke them, people even pretended not to believe that Snowball had destroyed the windmill; they claimed it collapsed because the walls were too thin. But the animals were convinced that wasn't the case. In any case, they decided to build the walls one meter thick instead of forty centimeters as before, which meant they needed to quarry more stone than before. The quarry had been buried under snow for a long time, so they couldn't start. After that, although the weather was cold, it was dry, but the work was truly dreadful, and the animals were no longer as enthusiastic as before. They were not only cold but also constantly hungry. Only Boxer and Clover remained enthusiastic. Squealer encouraged the movement with speeches, eloquently proving that labor was happiness and glory. But Squealer's speeches had no effect; it was Boxer's strength and his motto "I will work harder" that greatly motivated the others.
tr: It seems that people do not believe that Snowball destroyed the windmill out of sheer stubbornness; they were saying that the windmill collapsed because its walls were built too thin. Although the animals were not unaware that this was not true, it was decided that the walls, which were previously forty-five centimeters thick, would be built ninety centimeters thick this time; this required carrying much more stone. Since the quarry remained under snow for a long time, nothing could be done. Later, when the weather turned cold and frosty, they started working again, but they were facing great difficulties and were not as hopeful as before. They were freezing from the cold and often working on an empty stomach. Only Boxer and Clover had not lost their courage. Squealer was giving tremendous speeches about the happiness of serving the public and the honor of labor, and Boxer's strength and his constant cry of "I will work harder!" were inciting and motivating the animals.
es: Resentful, the humans pretended not to believe that it was Snowball who had destroyed the windmill; they claimed it collapsed because the walls were too thin. The animals knew that wasn't true. Despite this, they decided to build the walls one meter thick instead of half a meter as before, which meant gathering a much larger amount of stones. For a long time, the quarry was completely covered by a layer of snow and nothing could be done. Some progress was made during the dry and cold period that followed, but it was a cruel labor and the animals did not feel as optimistic as before. They were always cold and often hungry. Only Boxer and Clover never lost heart. Squealer gave magnificent speeches about the pride of service and the dignity of labor, but the other animals found more inspiration in Boxer's strength and his unfailing cry: "I will work harder!"

en: In January food fell short. The corn ration was drastically reduced, and it was announced that an extra potato ration would be issued to make up for it. Then it was discovered that the greater part of the potato crop had been frosted in the clamps, which had not been covered thickly enough. The potatoes had become soft and discoloured, and only a few were edible. For days at a time the animals had nothing to eat but chaff and mangels. Starvation seemed to stare them in the face.
vi: Food supplies began to run out in January. Rations of grain were reduced, replaced by potatoes. It was then discovered that most of the piled-up potatoes had rotted due to improper covering, leaving very few edible ones. Many days, they only had grass and turnips to eat. Famine began to threaten.
tr: In January, the food supplies began to run out. Grain rations were significantly reduced, and it was announced that extra potatoes would be given to make up for the shortfall. But soon it was discovered that the potatoes had frozen because they were not sufficiently covered. Very few of the potatoes, which had softened and spoiled, were edible. For days, they ate nothing but peelings and beets. They were now on the brink of starvation.
es: In January, food was scarce. The corn ration was drastically reduced, and it was announced that, in compensation, a supplementary ration of potatoes would be given. But then it was discovered that most of the potato harvest had frozen due to insufficient protection. The tubers had softened and discolored, and very few were edible. For entire days, the animals had nothing to eat except straw and beets. The specter of hunger seemed to stare them in the face.

en: It was vitally necessary to conceal this fact from the outside world. Emboldened by the collapse of the windmill, the human beings were inventing fresh lies about Animal Farm. Once again it was being put about that all the animals were dying of famine and disease, and that they were continually fighting among themselves and had resorted to cannibalism and infanticide. Napoleon was well aware of the bad results that might follow if the real facts of the food situation were known, and he decided to make use of Mr. Whymper to spread a contrary impression. Hitherto the animals had had little or no contact with Whymper on his weekly visits: now, however, a few selected animals, mostly sheep, were instructed to remark casually in his hearing that rations had been increased. In addition, Napoleon ordered the almost empty bins in the store-shed to be filled nearly to the brim with sand, which was then covered up with what remained of the grain and meal. On some suitable pretext Whymper was led through the store-shed and allowed to catch a glimpse of the bins. He was deceived, and continued to report to the outside world that there was no food shortage on Animal Farm.
vi: This information must be kept strictly confidential, not to be disclosed to those around. Excited by the collapse of the windmill, people spread even more false rumors about Animal Farm. They gossiped that the animals were on the verge of dying from hunger and disease, that they fought all day, that they were eating each other, and even killing the young ones. Napoleon understood that there would be many troubles if outsiders knew the farm was facing food shortages, so he decided to use Whymper as a tool for counter-propaganda. Previously, the animals usually stood at a distance whenever Whymper visited the farm, but now some selected ones, mainly sheep, were allowed to come closer and, as if by chance, mention that rations had increased lately. Additionally, Napoleon ordered sand to be poured almost to the brim of the bins in the storehouse and then covered it with grain and flour. Whenever there was an opportunity, they would lead Whymper past the storehouse so he could see the food stored there. Whymper was deceived and often told everyone that Animal Farm still had enough food.
tr: This situation absolutely had to be kept hidden from the outside world. Emboldened by the destruction of the windmill, people were inventing new lies about Animal Farm. Again, rumors spread that all the animals were being decimated by famine and disease, constantly fighting with each other, that cannibalism was rampant, and that newborns were being slaughtered. Napoleon, very well aware of the bad consequences that could arise if the truth about the food situation were known, decided to use Mr. Whymper to create the opposite effect. Until that day, the animals either rarely encountered Whymper, who came to the farm every week, or did not encounter him at all. However, this time, a group of animals, mostly sheep, were instructed to loiter near Mr. Whymper and, pretending to talk among themselves but loud enough for him to hear, mention that the rations had been increased. Napoleon ordered that the nearly empty barrels in the barn be filled with sand and that the sand be covered with the remaining grain and feed. Whymper was taken to the barn under some pretext and made to see the barrels, seemingly full to the brim, even if only out of the corner of his eye. Falling for Napoleon's trick, Whymper began to spread the word everywhere he went that there was no food shortage at Animal Farm.
es: It was absolutely necessary to hide that from the outside world. Encouraged by the collapse of the windmill, humans were inventing new lies about "Animal Farm." Once again, it was being spread that all the animals were dying of hunger and disease, that they were constantly fighting among themselves, and had fallen into cannibalism and infanticide. Napoleon was well aware of the disastrous consequences that would result from the discovery of the true food situation, and decided to use Mr. Whymper to spread a contrary impression. Until then, the animals had little or no contact with Whymper during his weekly visits; now, however, a few selected beasts, mostly sheep, were instructed to casually comment within his hearing range that the rations had been increased. Moreover, Napoleon ordered that the nearly empty bins in the sheds be filled to the top with sand and then covered with what little grain and forage remained. Under an appropriate pretext, Whymper was led through those sheds and allowed to take a look at the bins. They managed to deceive him, and he continued to report to the outside world that there was no food shortage on "Animal Farm."

en: Nevertheless, towards the end of January it became obvious that it would be necessary to procure some more grain from somewhere. In these days Napoleon rarely appeared in public, but spent all his time in the farmhouse, which was guarded at each door by fierce-looking dogs. When he did emerge, it was in a ceremonial manner, with an escort of six dogs who closely surrounded him and growled if anyone came too near. Frequently he did not even appear on Sunday mornings, but issued his orders through one of the other pigs, usually Squealer.
vi: However, by the end of January, it became clear that they needed to find a way to buy more grain. These days, Napoleon rarely went outside; he stayed in the main house, with fierce dogs guarding all the entrances strictly. If he did go outside, he was always escorted by six dogs, who would immediately bare their teeth and growl threateningly if any other animals came near. He also no longer participated in the Sunday Meetings, delegating another pig, usually Squealer, to read the work assignments instead.
tr: By the end of January, it became inevitable to get some more grain from somewhere. In those days, Napoleon was rarely seen, not stepping outside the farmhouse guarded by ferocious dogs. When he did come out, he wandered around with six dogs acting as his bodyguards, not acknowledging anyone, and if anyone got too close, the dogs would immediately growl. Napoleon, who no longer attended the Sunday morning meetings, communicated his orders through one of the other pigs, usually Squealer.
es: However, by the end of January, it was evident that there was a need to obtain more grain from somewhere. During those days, Napoleon rarely appeared in public; he spent all his time inside the house, whose doors were guarded by fierce-looking dogs. When he did appear, it was in a ceremonious manner, with an escort of six dogs that closely surrounded him and growled if anyone came too close. He was no longer seen on Sunday mornings either, but gave his orders through another pig, who was usually Squealer.

en: One Sunday morning Squealer announced that the hens, who had just come in to lay again, must surrender their eggs. Napoleon had accepted, through Whymper, a contract for four hundred eggs a week. The price of these would pay for enough grain and meal to keep the farm going till summer came on and conditions were easier.
vi: One time, on a Sunday, Chỉ Điểm declared that the hens, who had just started laying eggs, must hand over their eggs. Through Whymper, Napoleon had signed a contract to supply four hundred eggs each week. The money from selling the eggs would be enough to buy food until summer, and by then everything would be easier.
tr: One Sunday morning, Squealer announced that the hens, who were just about to lay eggs, had to give their eggs to the farm management. Napoleon had signed a contract mediated by Whymper; according to the contract, they had to deliver four hundred eggs per week. With the money from the eggs, they would buy grain and feed to sustain the farm until summer came and things improved.
es: One Sunday morning, Squealer announced that the hens, who were starting to lay eggs again, had to deliver their eggs. Napoleon had signed, through Whymper, a contract to sell four hundred eggs weekly. The price of these would be enough to buy a sufficient amount of grain and food, and would allow the farm to subsist until summer arrived and conditions improved.

en: When the hens heard this, they raised a terrible outcry. They had been warned earlier that this sacrifice might be necessary, but had not believed that it would really happen. They were just getting their clutches ready for the spring sitting, and they protested that to take the eggs away now was murder. For the first time since the expulsion of Jones, there was something resembling a rebellion. Led by three young Black Minorca pullets, the hens made a determined effort to thwart Napoleon’s wishes. Their method was to fly up to the rafters and there lay their eggs, which smashed to pieces on the floor. Napoleon acted swiftly and ruthlessly. He ordered the hens’ rations to be stopped, and decreed that any animal giving so much as a grain of corn to a hen should be punished by death. The dogs saw to it that these orders were carried out. For five days the hens held out, then they capitulated and went back to their nesting boxes. Nine hens had died in the meantime. Their bodies were buried in the orchard, and it was given out that they had died of coccidiosis. Whymper heard nothing of this affair, and the eggs were duly delivered, a grocer’s van driving up to the farm once a week to take them away.
vi: The hens squawked loudly. Previously, they had been reminded that they needed to sacrifice, but they did not expect things to be this bad. They had prepared nests for the spring hatching, declaring that taking the eggs now was akin to murder. Since the expulsion of Mr. Jones, this was the first time there had been a gathering resembling a riot. Three young Minorca hens led the uprising against Napoleon's plan. Their tactic was to fly up to the rafters and lay their eggs so they would break. Napoleon acted swiftly and decisively. He ordered that the hens were not to be fed and declared that anyone giving them even a grain of corn would be executed immediately. The dogs were assigned to monitor them. The hens held out for five days, but eventually had to surrender and return to laying in their nests as before. Nine hens died. They were considered to have died from coccidiosis and were buried in the garden. Whymper knew nothing of this and a cart came weekly to collect the eggs.
tr: As soon as the chickens heard the news, they caused a commotion. Although they had been warned before that such a sacrifice might be necessary, they honestly never believed it would actually happen one day. What else could it be but murder to take the eggs just when they were preparing for the spring hatching? For the first time since Jones was expelled from the farm, something resembling a rebellion occurred. The chickens, led by three Black Minorca pullets, resolutely opposed Napoleon's command. They perched on the roof beams and laid their eggs there, which then fell and broke on the ground. Napoleon, undoubtedly, did not delay in taking swift and ruthless measures. He not only ordered the chickens' rations to be cut off, but also issued a decree that any animal attempting to give even a bit of food to the chickens would be sentenced to death. The dogs would ensure compliance with the orders. Although the chickens resisted for about five days, they eventually surrendered and returned to their nests. Meanwhile, nine chickens that died were buried in the orchard, and it was said that they had died of bloody diarrhea. Whymper was not even aware of what had happened; the eggs were delivered on time, and a cart that came to the farm once a week took the eggs away.
es: When the hens heard this, they raised a great clamor. They had been warned beforehand that this sacrifice would be necessary, but they did not believe that this reality would come to pass. They were preparing their nests to brood in the spring and protested, saying that taking their eggs was a crime. For the first time since Jones's expulsion, there was something resembling a rebellion. Led by three young Black Minorca hens, the hens made a determined attempt to thwart Napoleon's wishes. Their protest was to fly up to the rafters and lay their eggs there, which shattered upon hitting the ground. Napoleon acted quickly and mercilessly. He ordered that the hens' rations be suspended and decreed that any animal giving even a grain of corn to a hen would be punished with death. The dogs ensured that the orders were carried out. The hens held out for five days, then capitulated and returned to their nests. Nine hens died in the meantime. Their bodies were buried in the orchard and it was reported that they had died of coccidiosis. Whymper did not find out about this matter and the eggs were duly delivered; the grocer's van came to the farm weekly to collect them.

en: All this while no more had been seen of Snowball. He was rumoured to be hiding on one of the neighbouring farms, either Foxwood or Pinchfield. Napoleon was by this time on slightly better terms with the other farmers than before. It happened that there was in the yard a pile of timber which had been stacked there ten years earlier when a beech spinney was cleared. It was well seasoned, and Whymper had advised Napoleon to sell it; both Mr. Pilkington and Mr. Frederick were anxious to buy it. Napoleon was hesitating between the two, unable to make up his mind. It was noticed that whenever he seemed on the point of coming to an agreement with Frederick, Snowball was declared to be in hiding at Foxwood, while, when he inclined toward Pilkington, Snowball was said to be at Pinchfield.
vi: Snowball was nowhere to be seen. There were rumors that he was hiding in Foxwood or Pinchfield. Relations between Napoleon and the surrounding farms had somewhat improved. At that time, they suddenly discovered a pile of timber in the yard, which had been felled about ten years ago. The timber was found at just the right time, and Whymper advised Napoleon to sell it; both Pilkington and Frederick wanted to buy it. Napoleon hesitated, not knowing whom to sell it to. Whenever he decided to sell to Frederick, there would be news that Snowball was hiding in Foxwood, but when he leaned towards Pilkington, there would be news that Snowball was in Pinchfield.
tr: Meanwhile, Snowball had not been seen around; rumors had spread that he was hiding in one of the neighboring farms, either at Foxwood or Pinchfield. Napoleon's relations with the other farmers had somewhat improved. In the yard, there was a large pile of timber that had dried out completely because it had been cut down when a grove of hornbeam trees was cleared about ten years ago. Whymper had advised Napoleon to sell them; both Mr. Pilkington and Mr. Frederick were eager to buy the timber, but Napoleon couldn't decide to whom he should sell it. When he seemed to be making a deal with Frederick, news would come that Snowball was hiding at Foxwood Farm, and when he seemed to be leaning towards Pilkington, rumors would spread that Snowball was concealed at Pinchfield Farm.
es: During all this time there were no signs of Snowball. It was rumored that he was hiding in one of the neighboring farms: Foxwood or Pinchfield. Napoleon maintained better relations than before with the other farmers. And it happened that in the yard there was a pile of timber for construction, which had been there for ten years, since a beech forest was felled. It was well maintained and Whymper advised Napoleon to sell it; both Mr. Pilkington and Mr. Frederick were eager to buy it. Napoleon was undecided between the two, unable to make a resolution. It was noted that when he seemed about to reach an agreement with Frederick, it was said that Snowball was hiding in Foxwood, and when he leaned towards Pilkington, it was claimed that Snowball was in Pinchfield.

en: Suddenly, early in the spring, an alarming thing was discovered. Snowball was secretly frequenting the farm by night! The animals were so disturbed that they could hardly sleep in their stalls. Every night, it was said, he came creeping in under cover of darkness and performed all kinds of mischief. He stole the corn, he upset the milk-pails, he broke the eggs, he trampled the seedbeds, he gnawed the bark off the fruit trees. Whenever anything went wrong it became usual to attribute it to Snowball. If a window was broken or a drain was blocked up, someone was certain to say that Snowball had come in the night and done it, and when the key of the store-shed was lost, the whole farm was convinced that Snowball had thrown it down the well. Curiously enough, they went on believing this even after the mislaid key was found under a sack of meal. The cows declared unanimously that Snowball crept into their stalls and milked them in their sleep. The rats, which had been troublesome that winter, were also said to be in league with Snowball.
vi: At the beginning of January, the entire camp suddenly became agitated because of an unexpected piece of news, like a bolt from the blue. It turned out that Snowball had been secretly infiltrating the camp at night! The animals were so worried that they lost sleep. It was rumored that every night Snowball would sneak in to cause havoc. He stole food, knocked over milk pails, broke eggs, trampled the seedlings, and chewed the bark of the trees in the garden. Any difficulty or failure was blamed on Snowball. If a window was broken or a drain was clogged, someone would say it was Snowball's doing, and even when the warehouse key was lost, the whole camp believed Snowball had thrown it down the well. The strange thing was that even after the key was found under a sack of flour, the whole camp still believed it was Snowball's fault. The cows insisted that at night Snowball would sneak into the barn and steal milk while they slept. It was rumored that the rats, which had caused a lot of trouble last winter, were also in league with Snowball.
tr: It was the early days of spring; suddenly, a piece of news caused a commotion: Snowball was secretly coming to the farm after dark! The animals were so anxious that they couldn't sleep at night. According to the rumors, Snowball was sneaking into the farm every night under the cover of darkness, causing all sorts of mischief. He was stealing the grain, knocking over the milk pails, breaking the eggs, trampling and crushing the seedlings, and gnawing the bark off the fruit trees. From then on, whenever something went wrong on the farm, Snowball was immediately blamed. If a window broke or a gutter got clogged, it was said that Snowball had come to the farm again at night and done it. One day, when the key to the storehouse was lost, the entire farm believed the rumor that Snowball had thrown the key into the well. Strangely enough, even when the lost key was found under a sack of flour, the animals did not stop believing in this rumor. The cows even claimed that Snowball had secretly entered their barn and milked them in their sleep. It was also said that the rats, which had caused a lot of damage to the farm that winter, were in collaboration with Snowball.
es: Suddenly, at the beginning of spring, something alarming was discovered. Snowball was secretly frequenting the farm at night! The animals were so disturbed that they could barely sleep in their stables. Every night, it was said, he would sneak in under the cover of darkness and cause all sorts of damage. He would steal the corn, overturn the milk pails, break the eggs, trample the seedlings, gnaw the bark of the fruit trees. Whenever something went wrong, it became customary to always attribute it to Snowball. If a window was broken or a drain was clogged, it was a sure thing that someone would say Snowball had done it during the night, and when the key to the food shed was lost, the entire farm was convinced that Snowball had thrown it down the well. Curiously enough, they continued to believe this even after the lost key was found under a sack of flour. The cows unanimously declared that Snowball had slipped into their stalls and milked them while they slept. It was also said that the mice, which had been quite troublesome that winter, were in league with Snowball.

en: Napoleon decreed that there should be a full investigation into Snowball’s activities. With his dogs in attendance he set out and made a careful tour of inspection of the farm buildings, the other animals following at a respectful distance. At every few steps Napoleon stopped and snuffed the ground for traces of Snowball’s footsteps, which, he said, he could detect by the smell. He snuffed in every corner, in the barn, in the cow-shed, in the henhouses, in the vegetable garden, and found traces of Snowball almost everywhere. He would put his snout to the ground, give several deep sniffs, ad exclaim in a terrible voice, “Snowball! He has been here! I can smell him distinctly!” and at the word “Snowball” all the dogs let out blood-curdling growls and showed their side teeth.
vi: Napoleon ordered a thorough investigation into the activities of Snowball. Napoleon, escorted by a few dogs, surveyed all the buildings in the farm, while others followed at a distance. He claimed he could smell Snowball, so he would stop every few steps to sniff the ground for traces. He sniffed every corner, including the warehouse, the cow shed, the chicken coop, the vegetable garden, and found traces of Snowball everywhere. He pressed his nose to the ground several times, inhaled deeply, and then declared in a chilling voice: "Snowball! He has been here! I have recognized his scent!" Every time the word "Snowball" was mentioned, the dogs would bare their teeth and bark in agreement.
tr: Deciding that a thorough investigation into Snowball's schemes was necessary, Napoleon took his dogs and began to tour the farm buildings, probing and examining every nook and cranny; the other animals followed him at a respectful distance. Claiming that he could find Snowball's trail by scent, Napoleon would stop every few steps to sniff the ground. He left no corner of the barn, the cow shed, the henhouses, or the vegetable garden unsniffed and found traces of Snowball almost everywhere. Pressing his long snout to the ground and sniffing rapidly, he would then shout in a terrifying voice, "Snowball! He's been here! This is his scent!" Every time Napoleon shouted "Snowball!", the dogs would bare their teeth and emit blood-curdling growls.
es: Napoleon ordered a thorough investigation of Snowball's activities. With his entourage of dogs, he went out to inspect the farm buildings, followed at a prudent distance by the other animals. Every few steps, Napoleon would stop and sniff the ground, searching for traces of Snowball's footprints, which he claimed he could recognize by scent. He sniffed in every corner, in the barn, in the cow shed, in the henhouses, in the vegetable garden, and found traces of Snowball almost everywhere. Pressing his snout to the ground, he would sniff deeply several times and then exclaim in a terrible voice: "Snowball! He has been here! I can smell him perfectly!" and upon hearing the word "Snowball," all the dogs would let out horrible growls and bare their fangs.

en: The animals were thoroughly frightened. It seemed to them as though Snowball were some kind of invisible influence, pervading the air about them and menacing them with all kinds of dangers. In the evening Squealer called them together, and with an alarmed expression on his face told them that he had some serious news to report.
vi: Everyone trembled with fear. It felt as if the mysterious and powerful Tuyet Tron was lurking somewhere nearby, ready to unleash disaster upon them. That night, Chi Diem called everyone together and with a serious face, said that there was some urgent news to announce.
tr: The animals were like they were possessed by a demon. Snowball seemed to have become invisible, constantly lurking around them, and it was impossible to predict what mischief he might cause next. In the evening, Squealer gathered all the animals together and, with a worried tone, said that he had important news.
es: The animals were completely terrified. It seemed to them that Snowball was a kind of invisible curse that infested the breathable air and threatened them with all kinds of dangers. At dusk, Squealer gathered them all, and with a troubled face, announced that he had serious news to communicate to them.

en: “Comrades!” cried Squealer, making little nervous skips, “a most terrible thing has been discovered. Snowball has sold himself to Frederick of Pinchfield Farm, who is even now plotting to attack us and take our farm away from us! Snowball is to act as his guide when the attack begins. But there is worse than that. We had thought that Snowball’s rebellion was caused simply by his vanity and ambition. But we were wrong, comrades. Do you know what the real reason was? Snowball was in league with Jones from the very start! He was Jones’s secret agent all the time. It has all been proved by documents which he left behind him and which we have only just discovered. To my mind this explains a great deal, comrades. Did we not see for ourselves how he attempted — fortunately without success — to get us defeated and destroyed at the Battle of the Cowshed?”
vi: "Comrades!", he shouted, "we have discovered an unforgivable crime. Snowball has sold himself to Frederick of Pinchfield Farm, who is planning to attack and seize our farm! Once war breaks out, Snowball will act as a guide. But he is even more unscrupulous than that. Previously, we thought that Snowball's disruptions were due to his vanity and lust for power. But comrades, we were wrong. Do you know where the real reason lies? From the very beginning, he has been in league with Jones! He is Jones's undercover spy. The evidence is in the documents he left behind, which we have only recently discovered. Comrades, I believe that explains a lot. Haven't we realized that he tried, fortunately unsuccessfully, to make us lose and disband during the Battle of the Cowshed?"
tr: Jumping from place to place nervously, he shouted, "Comrades!" "We have received a terrifying piece of news. Traitor Snowball has allied with Frederick, the owner of Pinchfield Farm! Frederick is planning to attack us and take over our farm! When the attack begins, Snowball will guide them. There's more. We thought Snowball rebelled because of his arrogance and greed. But we were wrong, comrades. Do you know what the real reason was? Snowball was Jones' man from the very beginning! He was a secret agent of Jones all along. We just captured the documents he left behind, and everything has come to light. As far as I'm concerned, everything is as clear as day, comrades. Hadn't we already seen with our own eyes the schemes he plotted to defeat us in the Battle of the Cowshed? Fortunately, he failed."
es: —Comrades —shouted Squealer, making some nervous little jumps—, something terrible has been discovered! Snowball has sold himself to Frederick, from "Pinchfield Farm," and at this very moment he must be conspiring to attack us and take our farm! Snowball will act as a guide when the attack begins. But there is something even worse. We had believed that Snowball's rebellion was motivated simply by his vanity and ambition. But we were wrong, comrades. Do you know what the real reason was? Snowball was in agreement with Jones from the very beginning! He has always been Jones's secret agent. This has been proven by documents he left behind and that we have now discovered. To me, this explains many things, comrades: haven't we seen ourselves how he tried, fortunately without success, to provoke our defeat and annihilation in the "Battle of the Cowshed"?

en: The animals were stupefied. This was a wickedness far outdoing Snowball’s destruction of the windmill. But it was some minutes before they could fully take it in. They all remembered, or thought they remembered, how they had seen Snowball charging ahead of them at the Battle of the Cowshed, how he had rallied and encouraged them at every turn, and how he had not paused for an instant even when the pellets from Jones’s gun had wounded his back. At first it was a little difficult to see how this fitted in with his being on Jones’s side. Even Boxer, who seldom asked questions, was puzzled. He lay down, tucked his fore hoofs beneath him, shut his eyes, and with a hard effort managed to formulate his thoughts.
vi: Everyone was stunned. This crime was truly horrifying, far worse than the destruction of the windmill. It took them a while to fully grasp the severity of the situation. They all still remembered, or thought they remembered, the image of Snowball leading the charge in the Battle of the Cowshed, uniting and encouraging them, never giving up even after being wounded by Jones. It was hard to imagine how that could have happened if he had been Jones's spy. Even Boxer, usually so taciturn, felt confused. Boxer lay down, tucked his forelegs under his belly, closed his eyes, tried to concentrate, and finally said:
tr: The animals were dumbfounded. This was a betrayal much greater than destroying the windmill. But as soon as their initial shock passed, they remembered, or seemed to remember, how Snowball had fought bravely at the forefront during the Battle of the Cowshed, how he had rallied and encouraged them when they were about to retreat, and how he had charged forward even when he was wounded by the pellets from Jones's gun. It was indeed a bit difficult to reconcile Snowball's heroism in the battle with the idea of him being Jones's secret agent. Even Boxer, who rarely asked questions, was confused. He lay down, tucked his forelegs under him; he closed his eyes, trying to clear his head.
es: The animals were stunned. That was an evil much greater than the destruction of the windmill. But it took them several minutes to understand its meaning. They all remembered, or thought they remembered, how they had seen Snowball leading the attack in the "Battle of the Cowshed," how he had rallied and encouraged them at every setback, and how he had not hesitated for a single moment, even though Jones's shotgun pellets had wounded him in the back. At first, it was a bit difficult to understand how all this fit with the fact that he was on Jones's side. Even Boxer, who rarely asked questions, was perplexed. He lay down, tucked his front legs under his chest, closed his eyes, and with great effort managed to piece together his thoughts.

en: “I do not believe that,” he said. “Snowball fought bravely at the Battle of the Cowshed. I saw him myself. Did we not give him ‘Animal Hero, first Class,’ immediately afterwards?”
vi: "I don't believe it, during the Snowball Barn Campaign, he fought bravely. I saw it with my own eyes. Didn't we just honor him as a First Class Animal Hero right after the campaign?"
tr: "I don't believe this," he said. "Snowball fought like a lion in the Battle of the Cowshed. I saw it with my own eyes. Didn't we award him the 'Animal Hero, First Class' medal immediately after the battle ended?"
es: —I don't believe that —he said—, Snowball fought bravely in the "Battle of the Cowshed." I saw it myself. Didn't we immediately award him the "Animal Hero, First Class" right after?

en: “That was our mistake, comrade. For we know now — it is all written down in the secret documents that we have found — that in reality he was trying to lure us to our doom.”
vi: "Comrades, that is precisely our mistake." "Now we know that these matters are clearly documented in the secret files we have just found; it was intended to lure us into a trap for the others to eliminate us."
tr: Squealer replied, "We were mistaken, comrade." "In fact, he was trying to lead us to ruin; the secret documents we obtained explain everything."
es: —That was our mistake, comrade. Because now we know —it is all written in the secret documents we have found— that in reality, he was dragging us towards our ruin.

en: “But he was wounded,” said Boxer. “We all saw him running with blood.”
vi: "But it was also injured," said the Warrior, "we all saw the blood flowing as it was running."
tr: "But she was injured," said Boxer. "We all saw her running around covered in blood."
es: —But he was wounded —argued Boxer—. We all saw him bleeding.

en: “That was part of the arrangement!” cried Squealer. “Jones’s shot only grazed him. I could show you this in his own writing, if you were able to read it. The plot was for Snowball, at the critical moment, to give the signal for flight and leave the field to the enemy. And he very nearly succeeded — I will even say, comrades, he WOULD have succeeded if it had not been for our heroic Leader, Comrade Napoleon. Do you not remember how, just at the moment when Jones and his men had got inside the yard, Snowball suddenly turned and fled, and many animals followed him? And do you not remember, too, that it was just at that moment, when panic was spreading and all seemed lost, that Comrade Napoleon sprang forward with a cry of ‘Death to Humanity!’ and sank his teeth in Jones’s leg? Surely you remember THAT, comrades?” exclaimed Squealer, frisking from side to side.
vi: "It was all prearranged!", Squealer shouted, "Jones's shot only grazed him. If only you comrades could read, I could show you how Snowball wrote it all down in black and white. They had agreed that at the most critical moment, Snowball would order a retreat, leaving the battlefield to the enemy. And he almost succeeded, I can say he certainly would have succeeded if it weren't for our heroic Leader, Comrade Napoleon. Do you remember when Jones and his men entered the yard? Snowball turned tail and many of the animals followed him. Don't you remember that at that very moment, when chaos began to spread and it seemed the front was about to break, Comrade Napoleon charged forward and shouted "Kill!" and then dashed straight at Jones's legs? Comrades, surely you remember that detail!", Squealer said, hopping from side to side.
tr: "It was a staged fight!" shouted Squealer, jumping up and down. "The bullets actually just grazed him. If you could read, I would show you his own writing; then you would understand everything. All of Snowball's dirty laundry has come out: He was going to find an excuse to give the order to retreat and leave the field to the enemy, and we had no idea. He almost succeeded too. In fact, comrades, I have no doubt that if it weren't for our brave leader Comrade Napoleon, he would have definitely done it. Have you forgotten that when Jones and his men stormed into the yard, Snowball suddenly turned and started to run away, and many animals followed him? At that very moment, when we were all panicking and thought the battle was lost, don't you remember how Comrade Napoleon charged forward shouting 'Death to Humanity!' and sank his teeth into Jones' leg? You can't have forgotten that, comrades!"
es: —That was part of the agreement! —shouted Squealer—. Jones's shot only grazed him. I could prove this to you, which is written in his own handwriting, if you could read it. The plan was that Snowball, at the critical moment, would give the signal to retreat, leaving the field in the enemy's hands. And he almost succeeded: I will say more, comrades: he would have succeeded if it weren't for our heroic Leader, comrade Napoleon. Do you remember how, at the precise moment when Jones and his men reached the yard, Snowball suddenly turned and fled, and many animals followed him? And do you also remember that just at that moment, when panic spread and it seemed that all was lost, comrade Napoleon leaped forward with the cry of "Death to Humanity!" and sank his teeth into Jones's leg? Surely you have not forgotten this, comrades — exclaimed Squealer.

en: Now when Squealer described the scene so graphically, it seemed to the animals that they did remember it. At any rate, they remembered that at the critical moment of the battle Snowball had turned to flee. But Boxer was still a little uneasy.
vi: Now, when Chỉ Điểm described it so vividly, the animals seemed to remember. In any case, they clearly remembered that Tuyết Tròn had turned and run at the critical moment. But Chiến Sĩ still felt uneasy.
tr: When Squealer described the scene so vividly, the animals almost seemed to remember it. At the very least, they remembered Snowball turning tail and running at the critical moment of the battle. But there was still a sense of unease in Boxer.
es: As Squealer described the scene so graphically, it seemed to the animals that they remembered it. In any case, they knew that at the critical moment of the battle, Snowball had turned to flee. But Boxer was still somewhat undecided.

en: “I do not believe that Snowball was a traitor at the beginning,” he said finally. “What he has done since is different. But I believe that at the Battle of the Cowshed he was a good comrade.”
vi: "I don't believe that Snowball betrayed us from the beginning," he said, "later on, it was a different story." "I believe that during the Cowshed Campaign, Snowball was still a good comrade."
tr: He finally let the cat out of the bag: "I don't believe Snowball was a traitor from the beginning. I have nothing to say about what he did later. But I believe that Snowball acted like a true comrade during the Battle of the Cowshed."
es: —I don't believe that Snowball was a traitor at the beginning —he finally said—. What he may have done since then is different. But I believe that in the "Battle of the Cowshed" he was a good comrade.

en: “Our Leader, Comrade Napoleon,” announced Squealer, speaking very slowly and firmly, “has stated categorically — categorically, comrade — that Snowball was Jones’s agent from the very beginning — yes, and from long before the Rebellion was ever thought of.”
vi: "Our leader, Comrade Napoleon," Squealer said slowly and firmly, "has categorically declared, I repeat, comrades, categorically declared that from the very beginning Snowball has been a spy for Mr. Jones, even before we thought about the Rebellion."
tr: Squealer, in a low but determined voice, said, "Look, comrade." "Our leader Comrade Napoleon has unequivocally, yes unequivocally, revealed that Snowball has been Jones's agent from the very beginning, even before there was any talk of the Rebellion."
es: —Our Leader, Comrade Napoleon —announced Squealer, speaking slowly and firmly—, has categorically, categorically, comrades, stated that Snowball was Jones's agent from the very beginning of everything and in any case, long before the Rebellion was even thought of.

en: “Ah, that is different!” said Boxer. “If Comrade Napoleon says it, it must be right.”
vi: "That's different!", Chiến Sỹ said, "Comrade Napoleon has spoken, so it must be right."
tr: Upon this, "Ah, then that's different!" said Boxer. "If Comrade Napoleon says so, then it must be so."
es: —Ah, that's different! —shouted Boxer—. If Comrade Napoleon says so, it must be true.

en: “That is the true spirit, comrade!” cried Squealer, but it was noticed he cast a very ugly look at Boxer with his little twinkling eyes. He turned to go, then paused and added impressively: “I warn every animal on this farm to keep his eyes very wide open. For we have reason to think that some of Snowball’s secret agents are lurking among us at this moment!”
vi: "That is a truly constructive attitude, comrades!", Chỉ Điểm exclaimed, but everyone could see its narrow, shifty, resentful eyes glaring straight at Chiến Sĩ. It was about to leave, but added menacingly, "I must warn you all to be vigilant. There is ample reason to believe that there are still agents of Tuyết Tròn in this camp!"
tr: Squealer shouted, "Now, this is what I call the spirit of comradeship!" But it did not go unnoticed that he was glaring at Boxer with his tiny, constantly blinking eyes. Just as he was about to leave, he suddenly stopped and added in an impressive voice: "I warn all the animals on this farm, keep your eyes wide open. It is obvious that Snowball's agents are already walking among us freely!"
es: —That's the true spirit, comrade! —shouted Squealer, but it was noticeable that he cast a sullen glance at Boxer with his flashing little eyes. He turned to leave, then stopped and added impressively—: I warn every animal on this farm to keep their eyes wide open, because we have reason to believe that some of Snowball's secret agents are among us and lurking at this very moment!

en: Four days later, in the late afternoon, Napoleon ordered all the animals to assemble in the yard. When they were all gathered together, Napoleon emerged from the farmhouse, wearing both his medals (for he had recently awarded himself “Animal Hero, First Class”, and “Animal Hero, Second Class”), with his nine huge dogs frisking round him and uttering growls that sent shivers down all the animals’ spines. They all cowered silently in their places, seeming to know in advance that some terrible thing was about to happen.
vi: Four days later, in the afternoon, Napoleon ordered everyone to be present in the yard. When everyone had gathered, Napoleon appeared, wearing two medals on his chest (he had recently awarded himself the titles of Animal Hero First Class and Animal Hero Second Class) with nine large dogs, running around and barking so loudly that the animals were terrified to the point of getting goosebumps. They sat silently, huddled together, as if awaiting a fierce storm.
tr: Four days later, towards evening, Napoleon ordered all the animals to gather in the yard. When everyone had gathered, Napoleon appeared with his medals on his chest (some time ago, he had awarded himself both the "First Class Animal Hero" and the "Second Class Animal Hero" medals); nine large dogs were circling around him, growling every now and then, instilling fear in the hearts of all the animals. As if sensing that something very bad was going to happen, everyone quietly crouched down on the ground.
es: Four days later, at dusk, Napoleon ordered the animals to gather in the yard. When they were all assembled, Napoleon emerged from the house, wearing his two medals (because he had recently named himself "Animal Hero First Class" and "Animal Hero Second Class"), with his nine enormous dogs leaping around and emitting growls that sent chills down the other animals' spines. They all quietly took their places, seeming to know in advance that terrible things were about to happen.

en: Napoleon stood sternly surveying his audience; then he uttered a high-pitched whimper. Immediately the dogs bounded forward, seized four of the pigs by the ear and dragged them, squealing with pain and terror, to Napoleon’s feet. The pigs’ ears were bleeding, the dogs had tasted blood, and for a few moments they appeared to go quite mad. To the amazement of everybody, three of them flung themselves upon Boxer. Boxer saw them coming and put out his great hoof, caught a dog in mid-air, and pinned him to the ground. The dog shrieked for mercy and the other two fled with their tails between their legs. Boxer looked at Napoleon to know whether he should crush the dog to death or let it go. Napoleon appeared to change countenance, and sharply ordered Boxer to let the dog go, whereat Boxer lifted his hoof, and the dog slunk away, bruised and howling.
vi: Napoleon sternly looked at the crowd, then hissed sharply like a whistle. Immediately, the dogs rushed in to bite the ears of four pigs, some of which fainted from pain and fear, then dragged themselves to Napoleon's feet. Blood flowed from the pigs' ears, and the dogs went mad when they smelled the fresh blood. Everyone was even more surprised when three dogs charged at Boxer. Boxer quickly raised his leg to grab one and pinned it to the ground. That dog immediately cried out for mercy, while the other two tucked their tails and ran away. Boxer looked at Napoleon as if to ask whether to crush or release the captured dog. Napoleon changed his expression and ordered Boxer to release it, so Boxer lifted his leg, and the pitiful dog, bruised all over, limped away while whimpering.
tr: Napoleon stood there, scanning the crowd with a stern gaze; then suddenly let out a high-pitched scream. The dogs, as soon as they heard the scream, leapt forward and grabbed four of the pigs by their ears, dragging the squealing and terrified animals to Napoleon's feet. Blood was dripping from the pigs' ears, and the dogs, having tasted the blood, went wild. Suddenly, three of the dogs, to everyone's astonishment, leapt at Boxer. As soon as Boxer saw them coming, he raised his huge foreleg, caught one of the dogs in mid-air, and slammed it to the ground. The dog, pinned to the ground, screamed for mercy, while the other two tucked their tails between their legs and ran off. Boxer's eyes were on Napoleon; should he crush and kill the dog, or let it go? Napoleon's face was contorted; he ordered Boxer in a harsh voice to release the dog. Upon this, Boxer lifted his foot off the dog, which then slunk away, whimpering in pain.
es: Napoleon stood observing his audience sternly; then he let out a sharp growl. Immediately, the dogs leaped forward, grabbed four of the pigs by their ears, and dragged them, terrified and squealing in pain, to Napoleon's feet. The pigs' ears were bleeding; the dogs had tasted blood and for a few moments seemed crazed. To everyone's astonishment, three of them pounced on Boxer. He saw them coming and stretched out his enormous hoof, caught one in mid-air, and pinned it to the ground. The dog squealed for mercy and the others fled with their tails between their legs. Boxer looked at Napoleon to see if he should continue crushing the dog to death or if he should release it. Napoleon seemed to change his expression and brusquely ordered him to release the dog, to which Boxer lifted his hoof and the dog fled, battered and whimpering.

en: Presently the tumult died down. The four pigs waited, trembling, with guilt written on every line of their countenances. Napoleon now called upon them to confess their crimes. They were the same four pigs as had protested when Napoleon abolished the Sunday Meetings. Without any further prompting they confessed that they had been secretly in touch with Snowball ever since his expulsion, that they had collaborated with him in destroying the windmill, and that they had entered into an agreement with him to hand over Animal Farm to Mr. Frederick. They added that Snowball had privately admitted to them that he had been Jones’s secret agent for years past. When they had finished their confession, the dogs promptly tore their throats out, and in a terrible voice Napoleon demanded whether any other animal had anything to confess.
vi: Order was quickly restored. Four pigs lay awaiting their fate, trembling, guilt evident on every face. Napoleon ordered them to confess their crimes. These were the four pigs who had stood up to oppose Napoleon when he decided to abolish the Sunday Meetings. They immediately confessed to having secretly communicated with Snowball since his expulsion, helped him destroy the windmill, and conspired with him to sell Animal Farm to Frederick. They also added that Snowball had told them he had been Jones's spy for years. As soon as they finished speaking, the dogs leapt up and tore out their throats, after which Napoleon, in a menacing voice that sent chills down their spines, asked if any other animal felt the need to confess.
tr: Soon after, the place had calmed down. The four pigs, whose guilt was written all over their faces, were trembling and waiting. Napoleon turned to them and asked them to confess their crimes. These were the pigs who had opposed Napoleon's decision to abolish the Sunday meetings. Without much resistance, they confessed everything: They had secretly met with Snowball since the day he was expelled from the farm, collaborated in the destruction of the windmill, and had reached an agreement to transfer Animal Farm to Mr. Frederick. They also did not hesitate to say that Snowball had confessed to them that he had been Jones's secret agent for years. As soon as their confessions were complete, the dogs leapt upon them and tore their throats out. Then, Napoleon turned back to the assembly and said in a terrible voice, "If there are any other animals who wish to confess, let them come forward."
es: Soon the tumult ceased. The four pigs waited, trembling, with guilt written in every furrow of their faces. Napoleon demanded that they confess their crimes. They were the same four pigs who had protested when Napoleon abolished the Sunday meetings. Without further prompting, they confessed that they had been in clandestine contact with Snowball since his expulsion, collaborated with him in the destruction of the windmill, and agreed to hand over "Animal Farm" to Mr. Frederick. They added that Snowball had admitted, confidentially, that he had been Mr. Jones's secret agent for many years. When they finished their confession, the dogs, without wasting time, tore their throats out, and meanwhile, Napoleon, in a terrible voice, asked if any other animal had anything to confess.

en: The three hens who had been the ringleaders in the attempted rebellion over the eggs now came forward and stated that Snowball had appeared to them in a dream and incited them to disobey Napoleon’s orders. They, too, were slaughtered. Then a goose came forward and confessed to having secreted six ears of corn during the last year’s harvest and eaten them in the night. Then a sheep confessed to having urinated in the drinking pool — urged to do this, so she said, by Snowball — and two other sheep confessed to having murdered an old ram, an especially devoted follower of Napoleon, by chasing him round and round a bonfire when he was suffering from a cough. They were all slain on the spot. And so the tale of confessions and executions went on, until there was a pile of corpses lying before Napoleon’s feet and the air was heavy with the smell of blood, which had been unknown there since the expulsion of Jones.
vi: The three chickens who led the rebellion over the eggs stepped forward and declared that they had dreamt of Snowball inciting them to disobey Napoleon's orders. They were also executed. Then a goose stepped forward and confessed to having stolen six ears of corn from the last harvest to eat at night. Next, a ewe confessed that Snowball had incited her to urinate in the drinking water, and then two more sheep confessed to having tortured an old ram to death, a ram particularly loyal to Napoleon, by chasing it around the bonfire when it was coughing. All of these animals were executed on the spot. Thus, execution immediately followed confession. Soon, at Napoleon's feet lay a pile of corpses, and the air was thick with the smell of fresh blood, a scene unprecedented since the expulsion of Mr. Jones.
tr: The three hens who had tried to lead the egg rebellion stepped forward and declared that in their dreams, Snowball had urged them to disobey Napoleon's orders. And at that moment, they were throttled by the dogs. Then, a goose came forward and confessed that it had secretly eaten six ears of wheat that it had stolen and hidden during the last harvest. Next, one of the sheep declared that, at Snowball's request, it had urinated in the drinking water. Two other sheep confessed that they had chased and killed an old ram, known for his loyalty to Napoleon, around the fire while he was having a coughing fit. They were all slaughtered on the spot. The confessions and executions continued in this manner. In the end, they found themselves surrounded by corpses at Napoleon's feet. The smell of blood filled the air. Such a smell had not been sensed on the farm since the day Jones was expelled.
es: The three hens, who were the ringleaders of the attempted rebellion over the eggs, stepped forward and declared that Snowball had appeared to them in dreams, urging them to disobey Napoleon's orders. They too were slaughtered. Then a goose stepped forward and confessed that it had hidden six ears of corn during the previous year's harvest and had eaten them at night. Then a sheep admitted that it had urinated in the drinking pool, instigated to do so, it said, by Snowball, and two other sheep confessed that they had murdered an old ram, very loyal to Napoleon, by chasing him around a bonfire when he was coughing. All of them were executed on the spot. And so the series of confessions and executions continued until a pile of corpses lay at Napoleon's feet and the air was heavy with the smell of blood, a smell that had been unknown since Jones's expulsion.

en: When it was all over, the remaining animals, except for the pigs and dogs, crept away in a body. They were shaken and miserable. They did not know which was more shocking — the treachery of the animals who had leagued themselves with Snowball, or the cruel retribution they had just witnessed. In the old days there had often been scenes of bloodshed equally terrible, but it seemed to all of them that it was far worse now that it was happening among themselves. Since Jones had left the farm, until today, no animal had killed another animal. Not even a rat had been killed. They had made their way on to the little knoll where the half-finished windmill stood, and with one accord they all lay down as though huddling together for warmth — Clover, Muriel, Benjamin, the cows, the sheep, and a whole flock of geese and hens — everyone, indeed, except the cat, who had suddenly disappeared just before Napoleon ordered the animals to assemble. For some time nobody spoke. Only Boxer remained on his feet. He fidgeted to and fro, swishing his long black tail against his sides and occasionally uttering a little whinny of surprise. Finally he said:
vi: The remaining animals after the execution, of course excluding the dogs and pigs, gathered into a group and quietly crawled out of the yard. They looked so small and miserable. They couldn't understand whether the betrayal of those associated with Snowball or the brutal punishment they had just witnessed was more shocking. In the past, they had witnessed equally barbaric massacres, but this time it was clearly more terrifying because it was them killing each other. Since old Jones left, no animal had been killed. Not even a rat had been killed. They went up the hill and lay close together for warmth next to the half-built windmill: Fatty lay next to Mona, Benjamin, then the cows, sheep, chickens, and geese, with only the cat missing, as it had slipped away just before Napoleon summoned them. They lay silently. Only Boxer remained standing. He kept pacing back and forth, his tail continuously hitting his sides, occasionally neighing softly with anxiety. Finally, he said:
tr: After everything was over, all the animals except the pigs and dogs huddled together and moved away from there. They had tucked their tails in and were trembling with fear. They couldn't decide which was more terrifying: the betrayal of the animals who had sided with Snowball, or the ruthless reprisals they had just witnessed? They had witnessed such bloody massacres before, but at least they weren't slaughtering each other. Since Jones was expelled, it had never been seen that one animal killed another. Not even a rat had been killed. When they reached the small hill where the half-completed windmill stood, they lay down close to each other as if trying to warm up. Clover, Muriel, Benjamin, the cows, the sheep, the geese, the chickens, everyone was there. Only the cat, who had suddenly disappeared just before Napoleon ordered all the animals to gather, was not among them. For a while, no one spoke. Only Boxer was standing. He couldn't stay still, kept swaying his long black tail from side to side, and was neighing softly in confusion. Finally, he said:
es: When this was over, the remaining animals, except for the pigs and the dogs, walked away together. They were shaken and dismayed. They did not know what was more terrifying: the betrayal of the animals who conspired with Snowball or the cruel repression they had just witnessed. In the past, there had been many equally terrible scenes of slaughter, but this one seemed much worse to everyone because it had happened among themselves. Since Jones had left the farm, no animal had killed another animal. Not even a rat. They reached the small hill where the half-built windmill stood and, by common agreement, they all lay down, as if huddling together for warmth: Clover, Muriel, Benjamin, the cows, the sheep, and a whole flock of geese and hens: all, indeed, except for the cat, who had suddenly disappeared shortly before Napoleon ordered the animals to assemble. For some time, no one spoke. Only Boxer remained standing, flicking his long black tail against his sides and occasionally letting out a small neigh of bewilderment. Finally, he said: "I don't understand.

en: “I do not understand it. I would not have believed that such things could happen on our farm. It must be due to some fault in ourselves. The solution, as I see it, is to work harder. From now onwards I shall get up a full hour earlier in the mornings.”
vi: "I don't understand anything at all. It's unbelievable that such a thing could happen in our camp. Maybe we are also at fault. There is only one way out, and that is to work more. From now on, I will wake up an hour earlier."
tr: "I can't make sense of what's happening. Even if I thought for forty years, I wouldn't have imagined such things happening on our farm. We must have made a mistake. If you ask me, the only way out is to work harder. As for me, from now on, I will get up an hour earlier in the mornings."
es: Finally, he said: "I don't understand. I would never have believed that such things could happen on our farm. It must be due to some fault of ours. The solution, as I see it, is to work harder. From now on, I will get up an hour earlier every morning."

en: And he moved off at his lumbering trot and made for the quarry. Having got there, he collected two successive loads of stone and dragged them down to the windmill before retiring for the night.
vi: Then he sadly walked back to the quarry. The little guy filled up two carts and dragged them to the construction site before going to sleep.
tr: With all his laziness, he started trotting and headed towards the quarry. When he arrived there, he hauled two loads of stones to the windmill with the cart, and then went to bed.
es: And he walked away with his heavy trot towards the quarry. Once there, he gathered two cartloads of stones and pulled them to the mill before going to bed.

en: The animals huddled about Clover, not speaking. The knoll where they were lying gave them a wide prospect across the countryside. Most of Animal Farm was within their view — the long pasture stretching down to the main road, the hayfield, the spinney, the drinking pool, the ploughed fields where the young wheat was thick and green, and the red roofs of the farm buildings with the smoke curling from the chimneys. It was a clear spring evening. The grass and the bursting hedges were gilded by the level rays of the sun. Never had the farm — and with a kind of surprise they remembered that it was their own farm, every inch of it their own property — appeared to the animals so desirable a place. As Clover looked down the hillside her eyes filled with tears. If she could have spoken her thoughts, it would have been to say that this was not what they had aimed at when they had set themselves years ago to work for the overthrow of the human race. These scenes of terror and slaughter were not what they had looked forward to on that night when old Major first stirred them to rebellion. If she herself had had any picture of the future, it had been of a society of animals set free from hunger and the whip, all equal, each working according to his capacity, the strong protecting the weak, as she had protected the lost brood of ducklings with her foreleg on the night of Major’s speech. Instead — she did not know why — they had come to a time when no one dared speak his mind, when fierce, growling dogs roamed everywhere, and when you had to watch your comrades torn to pieces after confessing to shocking crimes. There was no thought of rebellion or disobedience in her mind. She knew that, even as things were, they were far better off than they had been in the days of Jones, and that before all else it was needful to prevent the return of the human beings. Whatever happened she would remain faithful, work hard, carry out the orders that were given to her, and accept the leadership of Napoleon. But still, it was not for this that she and all the other animals had hoped and toiled. It was not for this that they had built the windmill and faced the bullets of Jones’s gun. Such were her thoughts, though she lacked the words to express them.
vi: The group of animals huddled around Mrs. Fat but none of them spoke up. From the top of the hill, they could see the entire area. They could see almost the entire Animal Farm - the grazing fields stretching to the main road, the grass fields, the forest, the water basin, the cultivated fields with green wheat growing, and the tiled roofs of the farmhouses with winding trails of smoke. It was a spring afternoon, the sky clear and cloudless. The twilight cast a golden hue on the grass and the distant hedges. They were surprised to remember that this farm was theirs, every inch of land here was their property, every inch was so precious. Mrs. Fat looked into the distance, her eyes filled with tears. If she could express all her thoughts, she would surely say that this was not what they intended when they decided to overthrow human rule. On the night the old Leader called for their uprising, they could not have imagined the terror and mass killings of today. If she had thought about the future then, it would have been a society where animals were no longer hungry, no longer beaten, all were equal, all worked according to their ability, the strong protected the weak, just as she had protected the orphaned ducklings on the night the old Leader spoke. Yet, she could not understand why now no one dared to speak their true thoughts anymore, the fierce hunting dogs roamed everywhere, and all had to witness the killing of comrades after they confessed to heinous crimes. But in her mind, there was no thought of disobedience or rebellion. After all, they were still better off than under old Jones, and the main thing was to prevent humans from returning. No matter what, she remained loyal to the cause, continued to work tirelessly, completed all tasks, and followed the path that Napoleon had chosen. But was this really what they had longed for, what they had worked so hard to create? No, they built the windmill for a completely different purpose, the life-and-death struggle with old Jones was also to create a society completely different from what they had received today. These were the thoughts that flashed through Mrs. Fat's mind, but she could not put them into words.
tr: The animals had gathered around Clover, and no one could utter a word. From the hill they were on, they could see the fields stretching out all around. A large part of Animal Farm was within their view: the pasture extending to the main road, the mown and dried hay, the grove, the trough, the lush, green crops beginning to sprout in the plowed fields, the red roofs of the farm buildings, and the smoking chimneys... It was a bright spring evening. The grass and the leaf-budding hedges illuminated by the sun's rays were sparkling. The farm had never looked so beautiful to their eyes. Suddenly, they remembered that this was their own farm; every inch of this land was theirs. As Clover looked down from the hill, her eyes filled with tears. If she could express her thoughts, she would say that when they set out years ago to overthrow the human race, this was never their goal. Could the violence and slaughter they now witnessed be what they had envisioned on the night Old Major first called for the Rebellion? In the future she had imagined, there was a society where animals were free from hunger and the whip, where everyone was equal, everyone worked according to their ability, and the strong protected the weak just as Old Major had embraced the lost ducklings on the night he spoke. However, for some unknown reason, a society had emerged where no one dared to express their thoughts, wild, savage dogs roamed everywhere growling, and they were forced to watch their comrades being torn apart after confessing to horrific crimes. But thoughts of rebelling or rising up did not cross her mind. She knew that even their current situation was much better than it had been in Jones's time and that above all, it was necessary to prevent the humans from returning to the farm. No matter what, she would remain loyal to the administration, follow the orders given to her to the letter, and accept Napoleon's leadership. But still, this should not have been the result of so much hope and effort. Should this be the reward for building the windmill with such difficulty and braving the pellets from Jones's gun? She thought this way, but she could not put her thoughts into words and express them.
es: The animals huddled around Clover, without speaking. The hill where they were lying offered them a wide view across the countryside. Most of "Animal Farm" was in sight: the long meadow, stretching to the road, the hayfield, the drinking pool, the plowed fields where the new wheat was growing, thick and green, and the red roofs of the farm buildings, with smoke spiraling up from their chimneys. It was a clear spring evening. The grass and the blooming hedges were golden in the rays of the setting sun. The farm had never seemed to them—and with some surprise, they remembered that it was their own farm, and that every inch of it was their property—a place so desirable. As Clover looked down the hillside, her eyes filled with tears. If she could express her thoughts, it would have been to say that this was not what they had aspired to when they set out, years ago, to overthrow the human race. Those scenes of terror and slaughter were not what they had dreamed of that night when Old Major first stirred them to rebellion. If she herself had conceived a picture of the future, it would have been of a society of animals freed from hunger and the whip, all equal, each working according to their capacity, the strong protecting the weak, as she had protected those lost ducklings with her foreleg the night of Major's speech. Instead—she did not know why—they had come to a state where no one dared to say what they thought, where fierce, growling dogs roamed everywhere, and where one had to watch their comrades being torn to pieces after confessing to horrible crimes. There was no thought of rebellion or disobedience in her mind. She knew that, even as things were, they were much better off than in the days of Jones and that, above all, it was necessary to prevent the return of human beings. Whatever happened, she would remain loyal, work hard, follow the orders given to her, and accept Napoleon's directives. But even so, this was not what she and the other animals had yearned for and worked so hard for. It was not for this that they had built the windmill and faced Jones's bullets. Such were her thoughts, though she lacked the words to express them.

en: At last, feeling this to be in some way a substitute for the words she was unable to find, she began to sing ‘Beasts of England’. The other animals sitting round her took it up, and they sang it three times over — very tunefully, but slowly and mournfully, in a way they had never sung it before.
vi: Unable to find words to say, Mrs. Fat had to sing the song "Beasts of England," which was also a way to express the emotions surging in her heart. The other animals immediately sang along. They sang three times, their voices melodious, slow, and sad; they had never sung like that before.
tr: In the end, thinking it would take the place of the words she couldn't express, Clover began to sing the song of the Beasts of England. The other animals sitting around her also joined in the song. They sang the song three times in total, and very beautifully; but it had never been sung so slowly and sadly before.
es: In the end, sensing that perhaps it would be a substitute for the words she could not find, she began to sing "Beasts of England." The other animals around her imitated her and sang it three times, melodiously, though slowly and mournfully as they had never done before.

en: “It’s no longer needed, comrade,” said Squealer stiffly. “‘Beasts of England’ was the song of the Rebellion. But the Rebellion is now completed. The execution of the traitors this afternoon was the final act. The enemy both external and internal has been defeated. In ‘Beasts of England’ we expressed our longing for a better society in days to come. But that society has now been established. Clearly this song has no longer any purpose.”
vi: "Comrades, this song is outdated," Chỉ Điểm said coldly, "The song 'Beasts of England' is a call for insurrection. The insurrection has been completely victorious. This afternoon's execution was the final battle. The enemy, both internal and external, has been defeated. The song 'Beasts of England' expresses our dream of a better society in the future. That society has been built. This song is clearly no longer necessary."
tr: Squealer, fawningly, said, "There is no longer any need, comrade." 'Beasts of England' was the song of the Rebellion. The Rebellion is now complete. This afternoon's execution of the traitors was the final act. Both the internal and external enemies have been defeated. In the song 'Beasts of England,' we expressed our longing for a better society to be established in the future. Now that society has been established, this song no longer has any meaning."
es: —There is no longer any need, comrade —said Squealer dryly—. “Beasts of England” was the song of the Rebellion. But the Rebellion is now over. The execution of the traitors this afternoon was the final act. The enemy, both external and internal, has been defeated. In “Beasts of England” we expressed our longing for a better society in the future. But that society has now been established. Truly, this song no longer has a purpose.

tr: Despite being very frightened, some of the animals were preparing to resist, but as usual, the sheep's bleating of "Four legs good, two legs bad!" ended the discussion before it could start.
es: Although they were scared, some of the animals would have protested, but at that moment the sheep began their usual bleating of "Four legs good, two legs bad," which lasted several minutes and ended the discussion.
