en: A few days later, when the terror caused by the executions had died down, some of the animals remembered — or thought they remembered — that the Sixth Commandment decreed “No animal shall kill any other animal.” And though no one cared to mention it in the hearing of the pigs or the dogs, it was felt that the killings which had taken place did not square with this. Clover asked Benjamin to read her the Sixth Commandment, and when Benjamin, as usual, said that he refused to meddle in such matters, she fetched Muriel. Muriel read the Commandment for her. It ran: “No animal shall kill any other animal WITHOUT CAUSE.” Somehow or other, the last two words had slipped out of the animals’ memory. But they saw now that the Commandment had not been violated; for clearly there was good reason for killing the traitors who had leagued themselves with Snowball.
vi: A few days later, when the fear caused by the massacre had subsided, some of them remembered, or thought they remembered, that the Sixth Commandment said: "Animals shall not kill each other." Although they did not dare to speak up when near the dogs and pigs, they all believed that the recent killings were not in accordance with the Sixth Commandment. Mrs. Fat asked Benjamin to read the Sixth Commandment, but as always, Benjamin said he did not get involved in such matters. Mrs. Fat had to find Muriel to ask her to read it. It was written as follows: "Animals shall not kill each other without reason." It turned out they had forgotten the last few words. But this meant that the Commandment was still respected, and the traitors associated with Snowball deserved to be killed.
tr: A few days later, when the terror caused by the executions had subsided, some animals remembered or seemed to remember the Sixth Commandment: "No animal shall kill any other animal." Although no one dared to speak up in the presence of the pigs or the dogs, everyone was aware that the murders did not comply with this commandment. Clover asked Benjamin to read the Sixth Commandment to her, but Benjamin, as always, said he did not want to get involved in such matters. So Clover found Muriel. Muriel read the Sixth Commandment as follows: "No animal shall kill any other animal without cause." Apparently, the words without cause had somehow been erased from the animals' memories. Thus, the Sixth Commandment had not been violated; because the traitors who had conspired with Snowball had not been killed without cause.
es: DAYS later, when the terror produced by the executions had already disappeared, some animals remembered—or believed they remembered—that the sixth commandment decreed: "No animal shall kill another animal." And although no one wanted to mention it in the hearing of the pigs or the dogs, there was a sense that the killings that had taken place did not agree with that. Clover asked Benjamin to read the sixth commandment to her, and when Benjamin, as usual, said he refused to meddle in such matters, she went in search of Muriel. Muriel read the Commandment to her. It said: "No animal shall kill another animal without cause." For one reason or another, the last two words had slipped from the animals' memory. But they confirmed that the Commandment had not been violated; because, evidently, there was ample reason to kill the traitors who had conspired with Snowball.

en: Throughout the year the animals worked even harder than they had worked in the previous year. To rebuild the windmill, with walls twice as thick as before, and to finish it by the appointed date, together with the regular work of the farm, was a tremendous labour. There were times when it seemed to the animals that they worked longer hours and fed no better than they had done in Jones’s day. On Sunday mornings Squealer, holding down a long strip of paper with his trotter, would read out to them lists of figures proving that the production of every class of foodstuff had increased by two hundred per cent, three hundred per cent, or five hundred per cent, as the case might be. The animals saw no reason to disbelieve him, especially as they could no longer remember very clearly what conditions had been like before the Rebellion. All the same, there were days when they felt that they would sooner have had less figures and more food.
vi: This year they worked much harder than the previous year. Besides the usual farm tasks, they also had to rebuild the windmill with walls twice as thick, and they had to complete it on schedule. There were times when they felt they had to work more but were fed no better than during Mr. Jones's time. Every Sunday morning, Squealer would hold a long piece of paper and read out figures proving that the production of various foodstuffs had increased, sometimes by two hundred, sometimes by three hundred, sometimes by five hundred percent. They saw no reason to doubt it, especially since they had forgotten and no longer remembered anything from before the Rebellion. However, sometimes they felt it would be better if the figures were lower but the food was more.
tr: That year, the animals worked much harder than the previous year. On one hand, the reconstruction of the windmill with walls twice as thick and its completion by the predetermined date, and on the other hand, the daily operations of the farm required an extraordinary effort. From time to time, the animals began to notice that despite working more than they did during Jones's era, they were not better fed. On Sunday mornings, Squealer would read out some figures from a long piece of paper he held with his foot, explaining that the production of various foodstuffs had increased by two hundred percent, three hundred percent, five hundred percent. Since the animals no longer remembered the conditions before the Rebellion accurately, they saw no reason not to believe him. But still, there were days when they couldn't help but wonder when they would see the days where they listened to fewer numbers and ate more food.
es: During this year, the animals worked even harder than the previous year. Rebuilding the windmill, with walls twice as thick as before, and completing it by a set date, in addition to the daily farm work, was a tremendous task. Sometimes it seemed to them that they worked more and did not eat better than in Jones's time. On Sunday mornings, Squealer, holding a long paper with one paw, would read them long lists of figures, showing that the production of all kinds of foodstuffs had increased by 200 percent, 300 percent, or 500 percent, as the case might be. The animals saw no reason not to believe him, especially since they could not clearly remember how things were before the Rebellion. Even so, they sometimes preferred to have fewer figures and more food.

en: All orders were now issued through Squealer or one of the other pigs. Napoleon himself was not seen in public as often as once in a fortnight. When he did appear, he was attended not only by his retinue of dogs but by a black cockerel who marched in front of him and acted as a kind of trumpeter, letting out a loud “cock-a-doodle-doo” before Napoleon spoke. Even in the farmhouse, it was said, Napoleon inhabited separate apartments from the others. He took his meals alone, with two dogs to wait upon him, and always ate from the Crown Derby dinner service which had been in the glass cupboard in the drawing-room. It was also announced that the gun would be fired every year on Napoleon’s birthday, as well as on the other two anniversaries.
vi: All orders now were issued by Squealer or another pig. Napoleon appeared only once every fortnight. Each time he appeared, he was escorted by a pack of dogs and preceded by a black rooster, like a bugler in a cavalry regiment, which always crowed "Cock-a-doodle-doo" loudly before Napoleon cleared his throat to begin his speech. It was rumored that even in the main house, Napoleon had a separate room, distinct from the other pigs. He ate alone, always attended by two dogs, and used porcelain dishes that had previously been kept in the drawing-room cupboard and only brought out on special occasions during Mr. Jones's time. There was also a new decree that from now on, the gun would be fired three times: once on Napoleon's birthday and twice on other major holidays of the farm.
tr: From now on, all orders were conveyed by Squealer or one of the other pigs. Napoleon only appeared in public once every fortnight, and when he did, he was accompanied not only by his entourage of dogs but also by a black rooster. The rooster walked ahead and, like a bugler, crowed as loudly as he could, "Cock-a-doodle-doo!" whenever Napoleon was about to speak. It was said that Napoleon even stayed in separate rooms from the others in the farmhouse. While eating his meals alone, two dogs would stand guard beside him; he used the Crown Derby dinner service that once stood in the glass cabinet in the sitting room. Meanwhile, it was announced that, in addition to the other two anniversaries, Napoleon's birthday would also be celebrated with a ceremonial gunshot.
es: All orders were issued through Squealer or any of the other pigs. Napoleon was not seen in public, at most, once every fortnight. When he did appear, he was accompanied not only by his entourage of dogs but also by a black rooster that marched ahead and acted as a sort of herald, letting out a loud crow before Napoleon spoke. Even in the house, it was said, Napoleon occupied quarters separate from the others. He ate alone, with two dogs to serve him, and always used the tableware that had been in the glass cabinet in the living room. It was also announced that the shotgun would be fired every year on Napoleon's birthday, just like on the other two anniversaries.

en: Napoleon was now never spoken of simply as “Napoleon.” He was always referred to in formal style as “our Leader, Comrade Napoleon,” and this pigs liked to invent for him such titles as Father of All Animals, Terror of Mankind, Protector of the Sheep-fold, Ducklings’ Friend, and the like. In his speeches, Squealer would talk with the tears rolling down his cheeks of Napoleon’s wisdom the goodness of his heart, and the deep love he bore to all animals everywhere, even and especially the unhappy animals who still lived in ignorance and slavery on other farms. It had become usual to give Napoleon the credit for every successful achievement and every stroke of good fortune. You would often hear one hen remark to another, “Under the guidance of our Leader, Comrade Napoleon, I have laid five eggs in six days”; or two cows, enjoying a drink at the pool, would exclaim, “Thanks to the leadership of Comrade Napoleon, how excellent this water tastes!” The general feeling on the farm was well expressed in a poem entitled Comrade Napoleon, which was composed by Minimus and which ran as follows:
vi: Now they no longer address Napoleon as simply as before. His name always comes with titles like "Our Leader, Comrade Napoleon," and the pigs even try to invent new titles such as: Father of All Animals, Terror of Mankind, Protector of the Sheep, Friend of the Ducks, etc. Whenever they speak of Napoleon's wisdom, kindness, and love as deep as the ocean for the animals, especially those still living in the dark bondage of other farms, Snowball's tears would wet his cheeks. All achievements were attributed to Napoleon. You could hear two hens confiding: "Under the leadership of Comrade Napoleon, our Leader, I have laid five eggs in the past six days"; or two cows drinking water saying: "Thanks to Comrade Napoleon's wise leadership, the water tastes so sweet these days!" The general sentiment of the farm was expressed in a poem titled: "Comrade Napoleon" composed by Minimus: Comrade Napoleon!
tr: No one could simply refer to Napoleon as "Napoleon" anymore; it was required to formally address him as "Our Leader Comrade Napoleon." The pigs were competing with each other to come up with titles for him such as Father of All Animals, Terror of Humans, Protector Angel of the Sheep, and Dear Friend of the Ducklings. Squealer, with tears streaming from his eyes during his speeches, spoke of how wise and kind-hearted an animal Napoleon was, and how deeply he loved all the animals on earth, especially the unhappy animals still living like slaves in the darkness of ignorance on other farms. It had become a habit to attribute every success and every joyous event to Napoleon. It was even heard that a hen said to another hen, "If it weren't for Our Leader Comrade Napoleon, I wouldn't have been able to lay five eggs in six days," and that two cows drinking water from the lake shouted, "Would the lake's water be this sweet without Comrade Napoleon's leadership?" The feelings and thoughts of the animals on the farm about this were echoed in a poem titled "Comrade Napoleon," written by Minimus:

The general sentiment of the farm was well expressed in a poem titled "Comrade Napoleon," written by Minimus, which went like this:

en: Meanwhile, through the agency of Whymper, Napoleon was engaged in complicated negotiations with Frederick and Pilkington. The pile of timber was still unsold. Of the two, Frederick was the more anxious to get hold of it, but he would not offer a reasonable price. At the same time there were renewed rumours that Frederick and his men were plotting to attack Animal Farm and to destroy the windmill, the building of which had aroused furious jealousy in him. Snowball was known to be still skulking on Pinchfield Farm. In the middle of the summer the animals were alarmed to hear that three hens had come forward and confessed that, inspired by Snowball, they had entered into a plot to murder Napoleon. They were executed immediately, and fresh precautions for Napoleon’s safety were taken. Four dogs guarded his bed at night, one at each corner, and a young pig named Pinkeye was given the task of tasting all his food before he ate it, lest it should be poisoned.
vi: Meanwhile, Napoleon, through the intermediary Whymper, was conducting complicated negotiations with Frederick and Pilkington. The pile of wood still hadn't been sold. Frederick was very eager to buy it, but he offered too low a price. At the same time, there were rumors that Frederick and his men were plotting to attack Animal Farm to destroy the windmill because he hated this place bitterly. It was said that Snowball was still hiding at Pinchfield Farm. By mid-summer, the animals were once again thrown into a panic when they heard rumors that three hens had confessed to being incited by Snowball to plot Napoleon's assassination. They were executed immediately, and stricter security measures for Napoleon were implemented. From now on, at night, four dogs would guard each corner of Napoleon's bed, and to avoid being poisoned, a dog named Pinkeye was assigned to taste all his food before Napoleon ate it.
tr: Meanwhile, Napoleon had entered into complicated relations with Frederick and Pilkington through Whymper. The timber was still waiting to be sold. Although Frederick seemed more eager to buy, he was unwilling to offer a fair price. Moreover, according to rumors that had begun to circulate again, Frederick was planning to attack Animal Farm with his men and destroy the windmill he was very envious of. It was also known that Snowball was still hiding at Pinchfield Farm. In the middle of summer, the animals were struck with great fear upon hearing that three hens had confessed to participating in a plot to assassinate Napoleon. The hens were immediately executed, and new measures were taken for Napoleon's safety. At night, dogs stood guard around his bed, and every meal he ate was first tasted by a young pig named Pinkeye to check if it was poisoned.
es: Meanwhile, through Whymper, Napoleon was engaged in complicated negotiations with Frederick and Pilkington. The pile of timber was still unsold. Of the two, Frederick was the one most eager to obtain it, but he did not want to offer a reasonable price. At the same time, persistent rumors were circulating that Frederick and his men were plotting to attack "Animal Farm" and destroy the windmill, whose construction had provoked furious envy in him. It was known that Snowball was still lurking on Pinchfield Farm. In the middle of the summer, the animals were alarmed to hear that three hens had confessed to plotting, inspired by Snowball, a conspiracy to assassinate Napoleon. They were executed immediately, and new precautions were taken for the Leader's safety. Four dogs guarded his bed at night, one in each corner, and a young pig named Pinkeye was appointed to taste all his food before the Leader ate it, for fear it might be poisoned.

en: At about the same time it was given out that Napoleon had arranged to sell the pile of timber to Mr. Pilkington; he was also going to enter into a regular agreement for the exchange of certain products between Animal Farm and Foxwood. The relations between Napoleon and Pilkington, though they were only conducted through Whymper, were now almost friendly. The animals distrusted Pilkington, as a human being, but greatly preferred him to Frederick, whom they both feared and hated. As the summer wore on, and the windmill neared completion, the rumours of an impending treacherous attack grew stronger and stronger. Frederick, it was said, intended to bring against them twenty men all armed with guns, and he had already bribed the magistrates and police, so that if he could once get hold of the title-deeds of Animal Farm they would ask no questions. Moreover, terrible stories were leaking out from Pinchfield about the cruelties that Frederick practised upon his animals. He had flogged an old horse to death, he starved his cows, he had killed a dog by throwing it into the furnace, he amused himself in the evenings by making cocks fight with splinters of razor-blade tied to their spurs. The animals’ blood boiled with rage when they heard of these things beingdone to their comrades, and sometimes they clamoured to be allowed to go out in a body and attack Pinchfield Farm, drive out the humans, and set the animals free. But Squealer counselled them to avoid rash actions and trust in Comrade Napoleon’s strategy.
vi: Around that time, there was news that Napoleon had decided to sell timber to Pilkington; moreover, it was planned to establish regular product exchanges between Animal Farm and Foxwood Farm. The relationship between Napoleon and Pilkington, even though it was only through the intermediary Whymper, had become quite friendly. Pilkington, like everyone else, was never trusted by the animals, but they still preferred him over Frederick, whom they both hated and feared. As the end of summer approached, when the windmill was nearly completed, rumors of a treacherous attack increased. Some said that Frederick planned to attack with an army of twenty men fully armed and had bribed the government as well as the police to act freely. Additionally, news of his cruel deeds towards the animals at Pinchfield Farm was revealed. He beat an old horse to death, starved the cows, threw a dog into the furnace, and every evening he incited the roosters to fight each other, not just any fight, but he also tied razor blades to their spurs for extra thrill. When they heard that their comrades were being treated so barbarically, every animal's blood boiled with anger, and sometimes they shouted for an attack on Pinchfield Farm to drive out the humans and reclaim freedom for the animals there. But Squealer advised them to avoid hasty actions and to trust in Comrade Napoleon's strategic plan.
tr: In the same days, it was announced that Napoleon had decided to sell the timber to Mr. Pilkington; furthermore, a suitable agreement was to be made regarding the exchange of some products between Animal Farm and Foxwood Farm. The relations between Napoleon and Pilkington, although conducted only through Whymper, had now taken on an almost friendly nature. Although the animals did not trust Pilkington as a human being even a little, they still preferred him over Frederick, whom they both feared and hated. As summer progressed and the construction of the windmill neared completion, rumors of an imminent and relentless attack on the farm increased. According to what was said, Frederick had gathered twenty armed men and had already bribed judges and police so that they would not question him when he seized the deeds of Animal Farm. Moreover, from Pinchfield Farm, chilling information about how cruelly Frederick treated his animals was leaking out. If true, he had whipped an old horse to death, starved the cows for days, thrown one of the dogs into the furnace; in the evenings, he took pleasure in making roosters fight with sharp razors attached to their spurs. As the animals heard about what was done to their comrades, they were furious with rage, and from time to time, they asked for permission to attack Pinchfield Farm together and drive out the humans to set the animals free. Squealer, however, said that if they acted in anger, they would suffer losses, and advised them to trust in Comrade Napoleon's knowledge and experience.
es: More or less around that time, it was disclosed that Napoleon had agreed to sell the pile of wood to Mr. Pilkington; a formal agreement was also to be celebrated for the exchange of certain products between "Animal Farm" and Foxwood. The relations between Napoleon and Pilkington, although conducted solely through Whymper, were almost friendly. The animals distrusted Pilkington, as a human being, but they much preferred him over Frederick, whom they feared and hated at the same time. When the summer was ending and the construction of the windmill was nearing completion, rumors of an imminent treacherous attack were increasing. Frederick, it was said, intended to bring against them twenty men, all armed with shotguns, and had already bribed the magistrates and the police so that, in the event he could obtain the property titles of "Animal Farm," they would not investigate. Moreover, some terrible stories were leaking from Pinchfield regarding the cruelties Frederick inflicted on the animals. He had whipped a horse to death; starved his cows, killed a dog by throwing it into an oven, and entertained himself at night with cockfights, tying pieces of razor blades to the spurs. The animals' blood boiled with rage when they learned of the things being done to their comrades, and sometimes they clamored to be allowed to go out and attack "Pinchfield Farm" en masse, drive out the humans, and liberate the animals. But Squealer advised them to avoid rash actions and to trust in Napoleon's strategy.

en: Nevertheless, feeling against Frederick continued to run high. One Sunday morning Napoleon appeared in the barn and explained that he had never at any time contemplated selling the pile of timber to Frederick; he considered it beneath his dignity, he said, to have dealings with scoundrels of that description. The pigeons who were still sent out to spread tidings of the Rebellion were forbidden to set foot anywhere on Foxwood, and were also ordered to drop their former slogan of “Death to Humanity” in favour of “Death to Frederick.” In the late summer yet another of Snowball’s machinations was laid bare. The wheat crop was full of weeds, and it was discovered that on one of his nocturnal visits Snowball had mixed weed seeds with the seed corn. A gander who had been privy to the plot had confessed his guilt to Squealer and immediately committed suicide by swallowing deadly nightshade berries. The animals now also learned that Snowball had never — as many of them had believed hitherto — received the order of “Animal Hero, First Class.” This was merely a legend which had been spread some time after the Battle of the Cowshed by Snowball himself. So far from being decorated, he had been censured for showing cowardice in the battle. Once again some of the animals heard this with a certain bewilderment, but Squealer was soon able to convince them that their memories had been at fault.
vi: The hatred towards Frederick increased day by day. One day, on a Sunday, Napoleon appeared in the warehouse to explain to the animals that he had never thought of selling the wood to Frederick, saying that such types were not worthy of his dealings. The pigeons, which were still being sent to call on animals in other farms to rise up in rebellion, were forbidden from approaching Foxwood Farm, and the slogan "Death to Humanity!" was replaced with "Death to Frederick!". By the end of summer, another crime of Snowball was discovered. This time it was the wheat field full of weeds - after investigation, it was discovered that Snowball had sneaked into the farm at night and mixed weed seeds with the wheat seeds. A male goose, an accomplice in this affair, confessed his guilt to Squealer and then immediately swallowed a poisonous nightshade berry to commit suicide. The animals were also informed that, contrary to what many believed, Snowball had never been awarded the title of Animal Hero, First Class. That story was fabricated by Snowball himself right after the Battle of the Cowshed. Not only was he not rewarded, but he was also heavily criticized for showing cowardice during the battle. As always, this news confused some of the animals, but Squealer quickly convinced them that it was simply due to their poor memory.
tr: However, the hatred for Frederick was growing day by day. One Sunday morning, Napoleon came to the barn and declared that he had never even considered selling the timber to Frederick, as he could not bear the dishonor of dealing with such a vile creature. The pigeons, which were still being sent to neighboring farms to spread the idea of rebellion, were instructed not to set foot on Foxwood Farm, and they were ordered to abandon the slogan "Death to Humanity" and instead use the slogan "Death to Frederick." Towards the end of summer, another one of Snowball's schemes was uncovered. No one could solve the mystery of the weeds that had been plaguing the crops for some time; finally, it was discovered that Snowball had secretly entered the farm one night and mixed weed seeds with the wheat seeds. A male goose, who had been an accomplice to Snowball, confessed his crime to Squealer and then committed suicide by swallowing poisonous yew berries. Meanwhile, the animals learned that, contrary to what many had known until that day, Snowball had never received the "Animal Hero, First Class" medal. Snowball had fabricated this story himself some time after the Battle of the Cowshed. Far from being rewarded with a medal, he had been condemned for showing cowardice in the battle. When the animals heard all this, they reacted with great astonishment once again. But Squealer was quick to calm them down, saying that memory was deceptive.
es: However, the resentment against Frederick continued to grow. One Sunday morning, Napoleon appeared in the barn and explained that at no time had he intended to sell the pile of wood to Frederick; he considered it incompatible with his dignity to have dealings with scoundrels of that sort. The pigeons, who were still being sent to spread news about the Rebellion, were forbidden to set foot in Foxwood and were also forced to abandon their previous slogan of "Death to Humanity," replacing it with "Death to Frederick." At the end of summer, a new plot by Snowball was uncovered. The wheat fields were full of weeds, and it was discovered that, during one of his nocturnal visits, Snowball had mixed thistle seeds with the wheat seeds. A goose, an accomplice in the plot, had confessed its guilt to Squealer and immediately committed suicide by ingesting some toxic herbs. The animals also learned that Snowball had never—as many of them had believed until then—received the order of "Animal Hero, First Class." It was simply a legend spread shortly after the "Battle of the Cowshed" by Snowball himself. Far from being decorated, he was censured for showing cowardice in the battle. Once again, some animals listened to this with some perplexity, but Squealer managed to convince them that their memories were mistaken.

en: In the autumn, by a tremendous, exhausting effort — for the harvest had to be gathered at almost the same time — the windmill was finished. The machinery had still to be installed, and Whymper was negotiating the purchase of it, but the structure was completed. In the teeth of every difficulty, in spite of inexperience, of primitive implements, of bad luck and of Snowball’s treachery, the work had been finished punctually to the very day! Tired out but proud, the animals walked round and round their masterpiece, which appeared even more beautiful in their eyes than when it had been built the first time. Moreover, the walls were twice as thick as before. Nothing short of explosives would lay them low this time! And when they thought of how they had laboured, what discouragements they had overcome, and the enormous difference that would be made in their lives when the sails were turning and the dynamos running — when they thought of all this, their tiredness forsook them and they gambolled round and round the windmill, uttering cries of triumph. Napoleon himself, attended by his dogs and his cockerel, came down to inspect the completed work; he personally congratulated the animals on their achievement, and announced that the mill would be named Napoleon Mill.
vi: The windmill was completed in the fall, right at the time of the harvest, and they had to work until they were exhausted. Although the equipment still needed to be installed, which Whymper was negotiating to purchase, the main thing was that the workshop was already built. Despite numerous difficulties, lack of technology and experience, and even sabotage by Snowball, they still managed to complete the construction on the scheduled date! Even though they were very tired, the animals still tried to walk around the windmill many times, full of pride, and at this moment, it looked even more beautiful than the first time it was built. Not to mention, the walls this time were twice as thick as before. Now, it would be impossible to destroy it without explosives! And when they thought about the amount of work done, the difficulties overcome, the changes that would come when the windmill blades started to turn, when the generator started running; when they thought about those things, all their fatigue disappeared, and they ran around the windmill together, shouting loudly. Even Napoleon, escorted by a few dogs and a rooster, came to see it, congratulated everyone on the completion of the project, and declared that the project would be named the Napoleon Mill.
tr: The windmill was completed in the autumn; but since the harvest also needed to be gathered around the same time, they were exhausted from fatigue. The machines had not yet been installed, Whymper was conducting the purchase negotiations; but the construction work was finished. Despite inexperience, the primitiveness of the tools used, misfortunes, Snowball's betrayal, in short, despite all kinds of difficulties and obstacles, they managed to finish the work on the exact day specified! The animals, their bodies tired but their hearts full of pride, were circling around the masterpiece they had created, losing themselves as they watched the windmill, which they found much more beautiful than the first one built. Moreover, this time the walls of the windmill were twice as thick as before. Nothing but dynamite could destroy these walls! When they thought about how much effort they had put in, how many disappointments they had overcome, and how different their lives would be once the gears turned and the dynamos worked, their fatigue melted away; they began to hop and skip around the windmill, shouting victory cries. Shortly after, Napoleon arrived with his dogs and rooster, inspected the windmill, congratulated the animals on their success, and announced that the windmill would henceforth be known as Napoleon Mill.
es: In the autumn, through a tremendous and exhausting effort—because the harvest had to be done almost simultaneously—the windmill was completed. The machinery still needed to be installed and Whymper was still negotiating its purchase, but the construction was finished. Despite all the difficulties, despite the inexperience, the primitive tools, the bad luck, and the betrayal of Snowball, the work had been completed punctually on the set day! Very tired but proud, the animals circled around their masterpiece, which in their opinion appeared even more beautiful than when it was first erected. Moreover, the thickness of the walls was double what it had been before. Only with explosives would it be possible to bring it down this time! And when they remembered how they had worked, the discouragement they had overcome, and the change it would bring to their lives when the sails were turning and the dynamos were functioning, when they thought of all this, their fatigue disappeared and they jumped around the windmill, shouting triumphantly. Napoleon himself, accompanied by his dogs and his rooster, came to inspect the finished work; he personally congratulated the animals on their feat and announced that the windmill would be called "Napoleon Mill."

en: Two days later the animals were called together for a special meeting in the barn. They were struck dumb with surprise when Napoleon announced that he had sold the pile of timber to Frederick. Tomorrow Frederick’s wagons would arrive and begin carting it away. Throughout the whole period of his seeming friendship with Pilkington, Napoleon had really been in secret agreement with Frederick.
vi: Two days later, the animals were invited to attend a special meeting in the barn. They could not believe it when they heard Napoleon say that he had sold the timber to Frederick. Tomorrow, Frederick's truck would come to collect it. It turned out that all this time Napoleon had pretended to be friendly with Pilkington but was secretly negotiating with Frederick.
tr: Two days later, the animals were called to a special meeting to be held in the barn. At the meeting, they were stunned when Napoleon announced that he had sold all the timber to Frederick. The next day, Frederick's carts would come to the farm and start transporting the timber. Apparently, while Napoleon appeared to be friendly with Pilkington, he had actually already secretly made a deal with Frederick.
es: Two days later, the animals were summoned for a special meeting in the barn. They were stunned when Napoleon announced that he had sold the pile of wood to Frederick. Frederick's carts would start taking it away. Throughout the entire period of his apparent friendship with Pilkington, Napoleon had actually been secretly in agreement with Frederick.

en: All relations with Foxwood had been broken off; insulting messages had been sent to Pilkington. The pigeons had been told to avoid Pinchfield Farm and to alter their slogan from “Death to Frederick” to “Death to Pilkington.” At the same time Napoleon assured the animals that the stories of an impending attack on Animal Farm were completely untrue, and that the tales about Frederick’s cruelty to his own animals had been greatly exaggerated. All these rumours had probably originated with Snowball and his agents. It now appeared that Snowball was not, after all, hiding on Pinchfield Farm, and in fact had never been there in his life: he was living — in considerable luxury, so it was said — at Foxwood, and had in reality been a pensioner of Pilkington for years past.
vi: All relations with Foxwood Farm were cut off, and a note filled with insulting words was sent to Pilkington. The pigeons were ordered to avoid Pinchfield Farm and change the slogan "Death to Frederick" to "Death to Pilkington". At the same time, Napoleon assured the animals that the rumors about the attack on Animal Farm were completely unfounded, and that the reports of Frederick's mistreatment of livestock had been greatly exaggerated. It was likely that Snowball and his agents had spread these rumors. It turned out that Snowball not only was not hiding in Pinchfield Farm but had never been there at all; in fact, he was living quite comfortably, according to reports, in Foxwood Farm: he had sold himself to Pilkington long ago.
tr: All relations with Foxwood Farm had been cut off, and denunciatory messages were sent to Pilkington. The pigeons were instructed not to visit Pinchfield Farm and to replace the slogan "Death to Frederick" with "Death to Pilkington." Meanwhile, Napoleon told the animals that the rumors about an imminent attack on Animal Farm were completely fabricated and that the stories about Frederick mistreating his animals were greatly exaggerated. All these rumors were most likely spread by Snowball and his agents. Now everything was clear: Snowball was not hiding at Pinchfield Farm, he had never been there; according to reports, he was living in great luxury at Foxwood Farm and had been serving Pilkington for years.
es: All relations with Foxwood were cut off while insulting messages were sent to Pilkington. The pigeons were instructed to avoid "Pinchfield Farm" and to change their slogan from "Death to Frederick" to "Death to Pilkington." At the same time, Napoleon assured the animals that the rumors of an attack on "Animal Farm" were completely false and that the news regarding Frederick's cruelties to his animals had been greatly exaggerated. All those rumors had probably been spread by Snowball and his agents. It was now discovered that Snowball was not hiding at "Pinchfield Farm" and that, in fact, he had never been there in his life; he was residing in Foxwood —in extraordinary luxury, it was said— and apparently, he had been a protégé of Pilkington for many years.

en: The pigs were in ecstasies over Napoleon’s cunning. By seeming to be friendly with Pilkington he had forced Frederick to raise his price by twelve pounds. But the superior quality of Napoleon’s mind, said Squealer, was shown in the fact that he trusted nobody, not even Frederick. Frederick had wanted to pay for the timber with something called a cheque, which, it seemed, was a piece of paper with a promise to pay written upon it. But Napoleon was too clever for him. He had demanded payment in real five-pound notes, which were to be handed over before the timber was removed. Already Frederick had paid up; and the sum he had paid was just enough to buy the machinery for the windmill.
vi: The pigs took the opportunity to elevate Napoleon to cloud nine. Pretending to be friendly with Pilkington, he forced Frederick to pay an extra twenty pounds. Squealer even said that Napoleon was an extraordinary pig because he never trusted anyone, not any animal, not even Frederick. Frederick wanted to pay by check, meaning a piece of paper specifying the amount that could be received when needed. But Napoleon proved to be much smarter than him. He demanded payment in cash, in five-pound notes, and insisted that the full amount be paid before the wood could be taken away. Frederick had already paid in full, and this amount was enough to buy all the equipment for the windmill.
tr: The pigs tipped their hats to Napoleon's cunning, who, by appearing to advance his friendship with Pilkington, had managed to get Frederick to pay twelve pounds more for the timber. But according to Squealer, the real proof of Napoleon's superior intelligence was that he trusted no one, not even Frederick. Frederick had tried to pay for the timber with a check that was nothing more than a piece of paper promising payment; but Napoleon had outsmarted him, insisting that the payment be made in five-pound banknotes before the timber was moved. In the end, Frederick had indeed paid the money as demanded; the amount he paid was just enough to purchase the machinery needed for the windmill.
es: The pigs were astonished by Napoleon's cunning. Through his apparent friendship with Pilkington, he forced Frederick to increase his price by twelve pounds. But the superiority of Napoleon's mind, said Squealer, was demonstrated by the fact that he trusted no one, not even Frederick. Frederick had wanted to pay for the timber with something called a check, which, it seems, was a piece of paper with the promise to pay the amount written on it. But Napoleon was too smart for him. He had demanded payment in genuine five-pound notes, which had to be paid before the timber was removed. Frederick paid, and the amount paid was just enough to buy the machinery needed for the windmill.

en: Meanwhile the timber was being carted away at high speed. When it was all gone, another special meeting was held in the barn for the animals to inspect Frederick’s bank-notes. Smiling beatifically, and wearing both his decorations, Napoleon reposed on a bed of straw on the platform, with the money at his side, neatly piled on a china dish from the farmhouse kitchen. The animals filed slowly past, and each gazed his fill. And Boxer put out his nose to sniff at the bank-notes, and the flimsy white things stirred and rustled in his breath.
vi: The wood was transported quite quickly. When the wood in the yard had all been taken away, the animals were invited to a special meeting to inspect the money delivered by Frederick. Napoleon, wearing two medals on his chest and smiling broadly, reclined on a straw mattress, next to a porcelain dish filled with crisp new bills. The animals walked by one by one, freely admiring the sight. Boxer even sniffed at them, causing the new bills to rustle softly.
tr: Meanwhile, the timbers were being transported at great speed. After all of them were transported, another special meeting was held in the big barn so that the animals could see the banknotes given by Frederick with their own eyes. Napoleon, who was wearing both of his medals, was grinning carelessly; he was lying on the straw mattress on the elevation; the money, carefully placed in a porcelain bowl brought from the farmhouse kitchen, was right beside him. The animals slowly passed by and closely examined the money. When Boxer tried to sniff by extending his nose, the thin banknotes rustled and moved.
es: Meanwhile, the timber was being hurriedly transported. When it had been completely removed, another special meeting was held in the barn so that the animals could gaze upon Frederick's banknotes. Smiling beatifically and displaying his two decorations, Napoleon lay on his straw bed on the platform, with the money beside him, carefully stacked on a porcelain kitchen plate. The animals slowly paraded past him and gazed at him to their heart's content. Boxer stretched out his nose to sniff the bills, and the thin papers moved and rustled under his breath.

en: Three days later there was a terrible hullabaloo. Whymper, his face deadly pale, came racing up the path on his bicycle, flung it down in the yard and rushed straight into the farmhouse. The next moment a choking roar of rage sounded from Napoleon’s apartments. The news of what had happened sped round the farm like wildfire. The banknotes were forgeries! Frederick had got the timber for nothing!
vi: Three days later, a commotion occurred. That day, Whymper, his face as pale as someone about to die, rode his bicycle madly into the campyard, and as soon as he arrived, he threw his bike to the ground and hurriedly rushed into the main building. Almost immediately, a horrifying scream was heard from Napoleon's room. The news spread throughout the camp like wildfire. The money Frederick paid was all fake! He had taken the wood for free!
tr: It had not even been three days when the farm was thrown into chaos. Suddenly, Whymper appeared on his bicycle from down the road; his face was as white as chalk; when he entered the yard, he threw his bicycle aside and rushed into the farmhouse. Soon, angry roars were heard from the room where Napoleon was staying. The news spread throughout the farm like an uncontrollable wildfire. The banknotes had turned out to be fake! Frederick had swindled the timber!
es: Three days later, a terrible commotion was recorded. Whymper, extremely pale, arrived at full speed on his bicycle, threw it to the ground upon reaching the yard, and ran inside. Soon, a dull roar of rage was heard from Napoleon's room. The news of what had happened spread through the farm like wildfire. The banknotes were fake! Frederick had gotten the wood for free!

en: Napoleon called the animals together immediately and in a terrible voice pronounced the death sentence upon Frederick. When captured, he said, Frederick should be boiled alive. At the same time he warned them that after this treacherous deed the worst was to be expected. Frederick and his men might make their long-expected attack at any moment. Sentinels were placed at all the approaches to the farm. In addition, four pigeons were sent to Foxwood with a conciliatory message, which it was hoped might re-establish good relations with Pilkington.
vi: Napoleon immediately ordered a gathering and declared a death sentence for Frederick. That guy deserves to be burned alive - he said so. At the same time, he also stated that everyone must be prepared to deal with the worst situations. Frederick and his men could attack at any moment. Guards must be stationed on every road leading into the camp. Additionally, he sent four pigeons carrying messages of goodwill to Foxwood Farm in hopes of normalizing relations.
tr: Napoleon immediately gathered the animals; in a terrifying voice, he announced that he had sentenced Frederick to death and would have him thrown into a cauldron alive as soon as he was caught. On the other hand, he also warned the animals to be prepared for the worst situations after Frederick's treachery. Frederick and his men could launch their long-awaited attack at any moment. Guards were placed at every possible entry point to the farm. Four pigeons were also sent to Foxwood Farm with a letter of reconciliation, hoping to re-establish friendly relations with Pilkington.
es: Napoleon immediately gathered all the animals and with a terrible voice decreed a death sentence for Frederick. When captured, he said, Frederick was to be boiled alive. At the same time, he warned them that after this treacherous act, the worst should be expected. Frederick and his people could launch their long-awaited attack at any moment. Sentinels were posted at all access routes to the farm. Additionally, four pigeons were sent to Foxwood with a conciliatory message, hoping to restore good relations with Pilkington.

en: The very next morning the attack came. The animals were at breakfast when the look-outs came racing in with the news that Frederick and his followers had already come through the five-barred gate. Boldly enough the animals sallied forth to meet them, but this time they did not have the easy victory that they had had in the Battle of the Cowshed. There were fifteen men, with half a dozen guns between them, and they opened fire as soon as they got within fifty yards. The animals could not face the terrible explosions and the stinging pellets, and in spite of the efforts of Napoleon and Boxer to rally them, they were soon driven back. A number of them were already wounded. They took refuge in the farm buildings and peeped cautiously out from chinks and knot-holes. The whole of the big pasture, including the windmill, was in the hands of the enemy. For the moment even Napoleon seemed at a loss. He paced up and down without a word, his tail rigid and twitching. Wistful glances were sent in the direction of Foxwood. If Pilkington and his men would help them, the day might yet be won. But at this moment the four pigeons, who had been sent out on the day before, returned, one of them bearing a scrap of paper from Pilkington. On it was pencilled the words: “Serves you right.”
vi: Early the next morning, Frederick organized an attack. The animals were preparing to have breakfast when the guard ran in to report that Frederick and his men had crossed the main gate of the farm. Without hesitation, the animals immediately charged, but this time they had to fight much harder than in the Battle of the Cowshed. There were fifteen men with about half a dozen guns, and they started shooting from more than a hundred meters away. The gunfire was deafening, and the bullets sprayed like chaff; the animals did not expect the battle to be so fierce, so despite Napoleon and Boxer’s efforts to motivate them, they gradually retreated. Some of the animals were injured. They ran into the buildings and peered through the holes in the walls. The entire large pasture, including the windmill, had fallen into the hands of the enemy. Even Napoleon appeared confused. He paced silently, his twisted tail flicking from side to side. Occasionally, he looked towards Foxwood Farm. If Pilkington brought reinforcements, they might be able to drive the enemy away. But at that moment, the four pigeons sent out the day before returned. One of them held a piece of paper with the words "Serves you right."
tr: The attack began the next morning. The animals were just sitting down to breakfast when the scouts came rushing in, raising dust, and reported that Frederick and his men had entered through the main gate. The animals bravely rushed forward to meet the attackers; but this time, achieving victory did not seem as easy as it had in the Battle of the Cowshed. There were fifteen of them, six of whom had rifles; they opened fire when they were about fifty meters away. The animals, unable to withstand the terrible explosions and the pellets that burned their flesh, soon had to retreat. Napoleon and Boxer tried hard to rally them, but it was to no avail. There were wounded. They had taken refuge in the farm buildings, watching the outside through cracks and knot holes. The large pasture and the windmill had fallen into enemy hands. Even Napoleon was stunned, unsure of what to do. He was silent, pacing the room rapidly with his tail held high. All eyes were on the road to Foxwood Farm. If Pilkington and his men came to help, they might be saved. But just at that moment, the pigeons they had sent out the day before returned. One of them had a note from Pilkington in its beak. The note, written in pencil, read: "Serves you right!"
es: The attack occurred the next morning. The animals were having breakfast when the lookouts came running in with the announcement that Frederick and his forces had already passed through the access gate. The animals boldly went out to fight, but this time they did not achieve the easy victory they had obtained in the "Battle of the Cowshed." There were fifteen men, with half a dozen shotguns, and they opened fire as soon as they got within fifty meters of the animals. The animals could not withstand the terrible explosions with their scalding pellets, and despite the efforts of Napoleon and Boxer to regroup them, they were soon driven back. A few of them were wounded. They took refuge in the farm buildings and cautiously peered through the cracks and knot holes in the wood. The entire large meadow, including the windmill, was in the hands of the enemy. For the moment, even Napoleon was at a loss for what to do. He paced back and forth without saying a word, his tail stiff and twitching nervously. They cast eager glances in the direction of Foxwood. If Pilkington and his people helped them, they might still come out well. But at that moment the four pigeons that had been sent the day before returned, one of them carrying a piece of paper from Pilkington. On it were written the following words in pencil: "Serves you right."

en: Meanwhile Frederick and his men had halted about the windmill. The animals watched them, and a murmur of dismay went round. Two of the men had produced a crowbar and a sledge hammer. They were going to knock the windmill down.
vi: Meanwhile, Frederick and his men had approached the windmill. The animals watched intently, and anxious whispers began to rise. Two men were carrying hammers and crowbars. They were probably planning to destroy the windmill.
tr: In the meantime, Frederick and his men had gathered around the windmill. The animals, too, were watching them with helpless grumbles. They saw two men take out a crowbar and a sledgehammer. They were preparing to demolish the windmill.
es: Meanwhile, Frederick and his men stopped by the mill. The animals watched them, and a murmur of anguish escaped their lips. Two of the men wielded an iron crowbar and a hammer. They were going to tear down the windmill.

en: “Impossible!” cried Napoleon. “We have built the walls far too thick for that. They could not knock it down in a week. Courage, comrades!”
vi: "It's not going to work!", Napoleon shouted, "The windmill walls are very thick, they can't do anything. It will take at least a week. Stay calm, comrades!"
tr: "They can't do anything!" shouted Napoleon. "Their sledgehammers won't penetrate our thick walls. Even if they work for a week, they still won't be able to bring them down. Don't be afraid, comrades!"
es: —Impossible! —shouted Napoleon—. We have built the walls too thick for that. They won't be able to bring them down even in a week. Take heart, comrades!

en: But Benjamin was watching the movements of the men intently. The two with the hammer and the crowbar were drilling a hole near the base of the windmill. Slowly, and with an air almost of amusement, Benjamin nodded his long muzzle.
vi: But Benjamin did not take his eyes off all the movements. The two men were using hammers and crowbars to dig a hole right at the foot of the windmill wall. Benjamin nodded his long snout, seemingly finding it interesting.
tr: But Benjamin kept his eyes wide open, trying to understand what the men were doing. Then he saw that the two men were digging a hole near the base of the windmill with a crowbar and a sledgehammer. He slowly shook his long nose from side to side and smiled knowingly.
es: But Benjamin was intently observing the movements of the men. Those handling the hammer and the iron lever were opening a hole near the base of the mill. Slowly, and with an almost amused air, Benjamin shook his long snout.

en: “I thought so,” he said. “Do you not see what they are doing? In another moment they are going to pack blasting powder into that hole.”
vi: "I still think so, it said, do you know what they are doing? They are going to put explosives in the hole."
tr: "I knew it," he said. "Can't you see? Soon they will fill that hole with gunpowder."
es: —I thought so —he said—. Don't you see what you're doing? They're going to fill that hole with gunpowder right away.

en: Terrified, the animals waited. It was impossible now to venture out of the shelter of the buildings. After a few minutes the men were seen to be running in all directions. Then there was a deafening roar. The pigeons swirled into the air, and all the animals, except Napoleon, flung themselves flat on their bellies and hid their faces. When they got up again, a huge cloud of black smoke was hanging where the windmill had been. Slowly the breeze drifted it away. The windmill had ceased to exist!
vi: The animals waited in fear. None of them dared to risk rushing out. Then they saw the humans scattering in all directions. A deafening explosion rang out. The pigeons shot up into the air, while the other animals, except Napoleon, quickly lay flat on the ground, faces pressed to the earth. When they lifted their heads, they saw a cloud of black smoke still covering the area of the windmill. The smoke gradually cleared. The windmill had been completely destroyed!
tr: The animals were waiting in fear. It was now impossible for them to attempt to leave the buildings they had taken refuge in. A few minutes later, they saw the men fleeing from the mill. Immediately after, a deafening roar erupted. The pigeons flew into the air, and all the animals except Napoleon threw themselves face down on the ground and covered their faces. When they stood up, the place where the windmill had been was engulfed in thick black smoke. When the smoke dispersed with the wind, they saw that there was nothing left of the windmill!
es: The animals waited terrified. It was impossible to venture outside the shelter of the buildings. After several minutes, the men were seen running in all directions. Then a deafening roar was heard. The pigeons swirled in the air and all the animals, except for Napoleon, threw themselves to the ground face down and hid their faces. When they got up again, a huge cloud of black smoke was floating where the windmill had been. Slowly the breeze carried it away. The windmill had ceased to exist!

en: At this sight the animals’ courage returned to them. The fear and despair they had felt a moment earlier were drowned in their rage against this vile, contemptible act. A mighty cry for vengeance went up, and without waiting for further orders they charged forth in a body and made straight for the enemy. This time they did not heed the cruel pellets that swept over them like hail. It was a savage, bitter battle. The men fired again and again, and, when the animals got to close quarters, lashed out with their sticks and their heavy boots. A cow, three sheep, and two geese were killed, and nearly everyone was wounded. Even Napoleon, who was directing operations from the rear, had the tip of his tail chipped by a pellet. But the men did not go unscathed either. Three of them had their heads broken by blows from Boxer’s hoofs; another was gored in the belly by a cow’s horn; another had his trousers nearly torn off by Jessie and Bluebell. And when the nine dogs of Napoleon’s own bodyguard, whom he had instructed to make a detour under cover of the hedge, suddenly appeared on the men’s flank, baying ferociously, panic overtook them. They saw that they were in danger of being surrounded. Frederick shouted to his men to get out while the going was good, and the next moment the cowardly enemy was running for dear life. The animals chased them right down to the bottom of the field, and got in some last kicks at them as they forced their way through the thorn hedge.
vi: The scene immediately awakened the animals. The cruel and wicked actions made them extremely angry. Without any orders, they simultaneously charged forward, rushing straight at the enemy, roaring with cries of hatred demanding revenge. Even the buckshot raining down on their backs did not make them falter. They were ready to sacrifice everything. Frederick and his men fired continuously, and when the animals got close, they used sticks to hit and kicked them. One cow, three sheep, and two geese were killed, almost all of them were injured. Napoleon, commanding from behind, was also shot in the tail. But some of Frederick's men were also bruised and battered. Three men had their heads smashed by Boxer, one was gored in the belly by a cow, and another had his pants torn by a dog bite. When the nine dogs of Napoleon's guard were ordered to flank and attack while barking, the humans panicked. They realized they were about to be surrounded. Frederick ordered a retreat, and the enemy fled in panic. The animals chased them all the way to the border and continued to butt them in the rear as they crawled through the fence separating the two farms.
tr: The animals, seeing all their labor blown away, suddenly gained courage. The anger they felt in the face of this treachery made them forget their earlier fear and despair. A terrifying cry for revenge rose. Without waiting for anyone's orders, they all attacked the enemy together. They no longer cared about the bullets raining down like hail. A wild, relentless battle ensued. The men first fired repeatedly, and when the animals got very close, they started hitting them with sticks and thick boots. A cow, three sheep, and two geese died right there. Almost everyone was injured. Even Napoleon, who was directing the operation from behind, had the tip of his tail grazed by a bullet that reached him. But the men had also suffered significant losses. Boxer had smashed the heads of three men with his kicks, a cow had gored one in the stomach with its horns, and Jessie and Bluebell had torn another's pants to shreds with their teeth. The nine dogs who were Napoleon's bodyguards, following their orders, circled around from behind the fence and attacked from the flank with terrifying barks, causing the men to panic. They realized they were about to be surrounded. Frederick ordered his men to leave the farm before things got worse. Soon, the cowardly enemies were fleeing without looking back. The animals chased the men down to the lower fields; they didn't miss the chance to land a few more kicks as the men tried to get through the barbed wire fence.
es: Upon seeing this scene, the animals regained their courage. The fear and despair they felt moments before were drowned by their anger against such a vile and abominable act. They let out a powerful cry for vengeance, and without waiting for another order, they attacked en masse and pounced on the enemy. This time they paid no attention to the cruel pellets that passed over their heads like hail. It was a fierce and savage battle. The men fired again and again, and when the animals reached hand-to-hand combat, they beat them with their sticks and heavy boots. A cow, three sheep, and two geese died, and almost all were wounded. Even Napoleon, who was directing operations from the rear, was wounded on the tip of his tail by a pellet. But the men did not come out unscathed either. Three of them had their heads broken by Boxer's kicks; another was gored in the belly by a cow; one almost had his pants torn off by Jessie and Bluebell. And when Napoleon's nine guard dogs, whom he had ordered to circle around behind the fence, suddenly appeared on the flank barking fiercely, panic seized the men who saw the danger of being surrounded. Frederick shouted to his men to escape while they still could, and immediately the enemy fled cowardly and at full speed. The animals chased them to the end of the field and managed to give them the last kicks as they crossed the barbed wire fence at full speed.

en: They had won, but they were weary and bleeding. Slowly they began to limp back towards the farm. The sight of their dead comrades stretched upon the grass moved some of them to tears. And for a little while they halted in sorrowful silence at the place where the windmill had once stood. Yes, it was gone; almost the last trace of their labour was gone! Even the foundations were partially destroyed. And in rebuilding it they could not this time, as before, make use of the fallen stones. This time the stones had vanished too. The force of the explosion had flung them to distances of hundreds of yards. It was as though the windmill had never been.
vi: They had won, but they were also exhausted from fatigue and injuries. They slowly returned to the farm. The sight of their comrades' sacrifice moved them to tears. They stood silently beside the rubble of the windmill. The windmill was gone, all their efforts erased! Even the foundation was almost completely destroyed. Last time, when rebuilding, they could still use the old stones. Now, even the stones were gone. The explosion had scattered the stones everywhere, as far as a hundred meters away. When they were nearing the farm, Chỉ Điểm, whom none of them had seen during the battle, suddenly appeared from somewhere, wagging its tail vigorously, looking very pleased.
tr: They had won the war, but they were exhausted, covered in blood from head to toe. Limping, they headed back towards the farm. Some of them burst into tears upon seeing their fallen comrades lying on the grass. They stood in respectful silence for a moment where the windmill once stood. Yes, all their efforts had been in vain, not even a trace of the windmill remained! Even the foundation of the structure was partially destroyed. Even if they tried to rebuild, they couldn't gather the stones from the demolished walls. The explosion had scattered them hundreds of meters away. As they approached the farm, they saw Squealer, who had mysteriously disappeared during the war, hopping and skipping towards them.
es: They had won, but they were battered and bleeding. Slowly and limping, they returned to the farm. The sight of the dead comrades lying on the grass made some of them cry. And for a while, they stopped, disconsolate and silent, at the place where the windmill had once stood. Yes, it was gone; every last trace of their labor had vanished! Even the foundations were partially destroyed. And to rebuild it, they could not, this time, use the fallen stones as they had before. Even those had disappeared. The force of the explosion had hurled them hundreds of meters away. It was as if the windmill had never existed.

en: As they approached the farm Squealer, who had unaccountably been absent during the fighting, came skipping towards them, whisking his tail and beaming with satisfaction. And the animals heard, from the direction of the farm buildings, the solemn booming of a gun.
vi: When they were nearing the farm, Chỉ Điểm, whom none of them had seen during the battle, suddenly appeared from somewhere, wagging its tail vigorously, looking very pleased. The animals heard the sound of gunfire.
tr: He was wagging his tail happily, his face shining with joy. At that moment, a gunshot rang out from the direction of the farm buildings.
es: When they approached the farm, Squealer, who had been inexplicably absent during the fight, came skipping towards them, wagging his tail and brimming with joy. And the animals heard, coming from the farm buildings, the solemn boom of a shotgun.

en: “What is that gun firing for?” said Boxer.
vi: "Why are they shooting?", Chiến Sĩ asked
tr: Boxer asked, "What is this?"
es: —What was that shot for? —asked Boxer.

en: “To celebrate our victory!” cried Squealer.
vi: "To celebrate the victory," Chỉ Điểm shouted.
tr: "They are celebrating our victory!" shouted Squealer.
es: —To celebrate our victory! —shouted Squealer.

en: “What victory?” said Boxer. His knees were bleeding, he had lost a shoe and split his hoof, and a dozen pellets had lodged themselves in his hind leg.
vi: "Which victory?" the Warrior said again. Its knees were all torn, the iron claws were loose, its feet were injured, and its hind legs were still embedded with dozens of shrapnel pieces.
tr: "What victory?" said Boxer. His knees were bleeding, he had lost one of his shoes, his hoof was split, and a lot of buckshot had lodged in his hind leg.
es: —What victory? —exclaimed Boxer. His knees were bleeding, he had lost a horseshoe, one hoof was cracked, and a dozen pellets were embedded in a hind leg.

en: “What victory, comrade? Have we not driven the enemy off our soil — the sacred soil of Animal Farm?”
vi: "What victory, comrades? Did we not just liberate the land, the sacred land of our Animal Farm?"
tr: "What do you mean, what victory, comrade? Didn't we drive the enemy out of our lands, the sacred lands of Animal Farm?"
es: —What victory, comrade? Haven't we driven the enemy off our soil, the sacred soil of "Animal Farm"?

en: “But they have destroyed the windmill. And we had worked on it for two years!”
vi: "But they have knocked down the windmill, two years of construction is not a small thing!"
tr: "But they blew up the windmill. We had spent exactly two years building that windmill!"
es: —But they have destroyed the mill. And we have worked for two years to build it!

en: “What matter? We will build another windmill. We will build six windmills if we feel like it. You do not appreciate, comrade, the mighty thing that we have done. The enemy was in occupation of this very ground that we stand upon. And now — thanks to the leadership of Comrade Napoleon — we have won every inch of it back again!”
vi: "So what? We will build another one. If we want, we can build six at once. Perhaps you have not fully appreciated the great victory we just achieved. The enemy had taken the very land we are standing on now. Now, thanks to Comrade Napoleon's leadership, we have reclaimed every inch of our land."
tr: "Never mind, don't worry! We'll make a new one. If we feel like it, we'll build six more windmills. You don't seem to realize what a great achievement we've accomplished, comrade! The land we're standing on was in enemy hands just a moment ago. But now we've taken back every inch of it; thanks to the leadership of Comrade Napoleon, of course!"
es: —What does it matter? We will build another windmill. We will build six windmills if we want. You do not appreciate, comrades, the importance of what we have done. The enemy was occupying this ground we stand on. And now, thanks to the leadership of Comrade Napoleon, we have recaptured every inch of it!

en: “Then we have won back what we had before,” said Boxer.
vi: "We are reclaiming our own land," the Warrior said.
tr: "So, we have taken back what was already ours," said Boxer.
es: —So, have we regained what we had before? —asked Boxer.

en: “That is our victory,” said Squealer.
vi: "That's exactly the victory, isn't it?" Chỉ Điểm said.
tr: Squealer said, "This victory is ours."
es: —That is our victory —added Squealer.

en: They limped into the yard. The pellets under the skin of Boxer’s leg smarted painfully. He saw ahead of him the heavy labour of rebuilding the windmill from the foundations, and already in imagination he braced himself for the task. But for the first time it occurred to him that he was eleven years old and that perhaps his great muscles were not quite what they had once been.
vi: Finally, they managed to drag themselves back to the campyard. The shrapnel still embedded in Chiến Sĩ's leg throbbed unbearably. He had already envisioned the hardships and toil of rebuilding the windmill from scratch and was mentally prepared to dive into the work. But this was also the first time he realized that he was already eleven years old, and his strength was not what it used to be.
tr: They limped into the courtyard. The pellets in his leg were causing Boxer pain. As he thought about how arduous the task of rebuilding the windmill would be and how much responsibility would fall on him, he felt old for perhaps the first time; he realized that his massive muscles were no longer as strong as they used to be.
es: They limped into the yard. The pellets, embedded in Boxer's leg, burned him painfully. He saw before him the heavy task of rebuilding the windmill from the foundations and, in his imagination, he prepared for the task. But for the first time, it occurred to him that he was eleven years old and that perhaps his great muscles were no longer what they had been before.

en: But when the animals saw the green flag flying, and heard the gun firing again — seven times it was fired in all — and heard the speech that Napoleon made, congratulating them on their conduct, it did seem to them after all that they had won a great victory. The animals slain in the battle were given a solemn funeral. Boxer and Clover pulled the wagon which served as a hearse, and Napoleon himself walked at the head of the procession. Two whole days were given over to celebrations. There were songs, speeches, and more firing of the gun, and a special gift of an apple was bestowed on every animal, with two ounces of corn for each bird and three biscuits for each dog. It was announced that the battle would be called the Battle of the Windmill, and that Napoleon had created a new decoration, the Order of the Green Banner, which he had conferred upon himself. In the general rejoicings the unfortunate affair of the banknotes was forgotten.
vi: But when they saw the green flag flying, heard the salvo of gunfire—seven volleys that day—and especially after hearing Napoleon's thanks for their brave fighting, they truly felt they had achieved a great victory. The fallen were buried with care. The funeral procession was led by Napoleon himself, followed by a two-horse carriage used as a hearse, pulled by Warrior and Fatty. They took two days off to celebrate the victory. They organized singing, gave speeches, and fired guns; each livestock animal received an apple, each poultry animal received sixty grams of grain, and each dog received three biscuits. It was then announced that this battle would be called the Windmill Campaign, and Napoleon decided to establish a new title called the "Green Flag Medal," which he awarded to himself. In that overwhelming collective joy, none of them thought about the counterfeit money incident anymore.
tr: The other animals, after seeing the green flag waving, hearing the gun fired exactly seven times, and listening to Napoleon's speech congratulating them for their bravery in the battle, felt that they had indeed achieved a great victory. Those who died in the battle were buried with a solemn ceremony. The cart used as a hearse was pulled by Boxer and Clover, and Napoleon walked at the front of the funeral procession. The celebrations lasted for a full two days. Songs were sung, speeches were made, guns were fired; as a reward, each animal was given an apple, each bird fifty grams of millet, and each dog three biscuits. It was then announced that this last battle would henceforth be known as the "Battle of the Windmill," that Napoleon had decided to establish a new decoration called the "Green Flag," and that he had awarded the first decoration to himself. The euphoria of victory had made them forget the counterfeit banknotes.
es: But when the animals saw the green flag waving and heard the gun being fired again —seven times in total— and listened to the speech Napoleon gave, congratulating them on their conduct, it seemed to them that, after all, they had achieved a great victory. The dead in the battle received a solemn burial. Boxer and Clover pulled the cart that served as a hearse and Napoleon himself led the procession. For two whole days, celebrations took place. There were songs, speeches, and more gunfire, and a special gift of an apple was given to each animal, with two ounces of corn for each bird and three biscuits for each dog. It was announced that the battle would be called the Battle of the Windmill and that Napoleon had created a new decoration, the "Order of the Green Banner," which he awarded to himself. In the general rejoicing, the unfortunate incident of the banknotes was forgotten.

en: It was a few days later than this that the pigs came upon a case of whisky in the cellars of the farmhouse. It had been overlooked at the time when the house was first occupied. That night there came from the farmhouse the sound of loud singing, in which, to everyone’s surprise, the strains of ‘Beasts of England’ were mixed up. At about half past nine Napoleon, wearing an old bowler hat of Mr. Jones’s, was distinctly seen to emerge from the back door, gallop rapidly round the yard, and disappear indoors again. But in the morning a deep silence hung over the farmhouse. Not a pig appeared to be stirring. It was nearly nine o’clock when Squealer made his appearance, walking slowly and dejectedly, his eyes dull, his tail hanging limply behind him, and with every appearance of being seriously ill. He called the animals together and told them that he had a terrible piece of news to impart. Comrade Napoleon was dying!
vi: A few days later, the pigs discovered a barrel of whisky in the basement of the main house. That afternoon, the other animals suddenly heard singing coming from the main house, and what surprised them even more was that there were parts of the song "Beasts of England". Then, at around half-past nine, while it was still light, they saw Napoleon emerge from the back door, wearing Mr. Jones's old bowler hat, trotting around the yard once before going back inside. The next morning, a silence enveloped the entire main house. Not a single pig or any movement was seen around the house. It wasn't until around nine o'clock that Squealer appeared, his eyes looking glazed, tail drooping, and legs moving sluggishly, clearly very tired. He called everyone together and said there was an important announcement to make. Comrade Napoleon is dying!
tr: A few days later, the pigs found a case of whiskey in the cellar of the farmhouse. Apparently, they hadn't noticed it when they first entered the house. That night, songs rose from the farmhouse; moreover, everyone was very surprised that tunes from "Beasts of England" occasionally mixed in. Around half-past nine, Napoleon came out the back door wearing Mr. Jones's bowler hat, circled around the yard, and went back inside. By morning, a deep silence reigned in the farmhouse. Apparently, all the pigs were still sleeping. Around nine, Squealer appeared at the door; he moved slowly; he looked exhausted, his gaze was blank, his tail hung down; he seemed as if he had caught an incurable disease. He immediately gathered the animals. The news was bad: Comrade Napoleon was on his deathbed!
es: A few days later, the pigs found a case of whiskey in the basement of the house. It had been overlooked when the building was occupied. That night, loud songs were heard from the house, where, to everyone's surprise, the chords of "Beasts of England" were intermingled. Around half-past nine, Napoleon, wearing one of Mr. Jones's old bowler hats, was seen exiting through the back door, galloping around the yard, and re-entering. But, in the morning, a profound silence reigned in the house. Not a single pig was moving. It was almost nine when Squealer made his appearance, walking slowly and clumsily, his eyes dull, his tail hanging limply, and looking seriously ill. He gathered the animals and told them he had bad news to share. Comrade Napoleon was dying!

en: A cry of lamentation went up. Straw was laid down outside the doors of the farmhouse, and the animals walked on tiptoe. With tears in their eyes they asked one another what they should do if their Leader were taken away from them. A rumour went round that Snowball had after all contrived to introduce poison into Napoleon’s food. At eleven o’clock Squealer came out to make another announcement. As his last act upon earth, Comrade Napoleon had pronounced a solemn decree: the drinking of alcohol was to be punished by death.
vi: The cries and wails rose up. They hurriedly brought straw to spread in front of the main house's door, none of them dared to step heavily. Tears welling up, they whispered to each other about what they would do if the leader were to meet any misfortune. There were rumors that Snowball had poisoned Napoleon. At eleven o'clock, Squealer appeared again. Squealer said that before departing from this world, comrade Napoleon had signed a decree that from now on, any animal that drinks alcohol would be sentenced to death.
tr: A cry arose from the animals. Straw was spread in front of the doors of the farmhouse; everyone was walking on tiptoe. They were lamenting, saying, "What will become of us if we lose our leader?" There was a rumor going around that Snowball had finally managed to poison Napoleon's food. At eleven o'clock, Squealer came out in front of the door to make another announcement. Comrade Napoleon, on his deathbed, had issued one last decree: Those who drank alcohol would be sentenced to death.
es: Expressions of pain rose in a unified cry. Straw was placed at all the entrances of the house and the animals walked on tiptoe. With tears in their eyes, they asked each other what they would do if they lost their Leader. The rumor spread that Snowball, despite everything, had managed to introduce poison into Napoleon's food.
