At eleven, Squealer came out to make another announcement. As his last act on earth, comrade Napoleon issued a solemn decree: the act of drinking alcohol would be punished by death.

en: By the evening, however, Napoleon appeared to be somewhat better, and the following morning Squealer was able to tell them that he was well on the way to recovery. By the evening of that day Napoleon was back at work, and on the next day it was learned that he had instructed Whymper to purchase in Willingdon some booklets on brewing and distilling. A week later Napoleon gave orders that the small paddock beyond the orchard, which it had previously been intended to set aside as a grazing-ground for animals who were past work, was to be ploughed up. It was given out that the pasture was exhausted and needed re-seeding; but it soon became known that Napoleon intended to sow it with barley.
vi: By the afternoon, there was news that Napoleon had improved, and the next morning, Chỉ Điểm announced that the leader was recovering. That afternoon, Napoleon had gotten up to work, and the next morning, there was news that he had ordered Whymper to buy some books on brewing beer and wine in Willingdon. A week later, Napoleon ordered the plowing of the land that had previously been intended as a pasture for the retired animals. The animals were told that the land was too barren and needed to be cultivated for a while to regain its fertility, but it later became clear that Napoleon intended to plant barley there.
tr: However, Squealer, who reported that Napoleon seemed a bit better towards the evening, announced the next morning that the Leader's health had rapidly improved. It was learned that Napoleon, who returned to his duties that evening, sent Whymper to Willingdon Farm the next day to purchase some booklets on fermentation and distillation methods. About a week later, Napoleon ordered the plowing of the small meadow at the back of the orchard, which was intended to be set aside as pasture for animals that could no longer work. Although it was said that the meadow had deteriorated and needed to be reseeded with grass, it soon became clear that Napoleon intended to plant barley there.
es: At dusk, however, Napoleon seemed to be somewhat better and the next morning Squealer was able to tell them that he was on the way to a full recovery. That same night Napoleon was up and the next day it was known that he had ordered Whymper to buy some pamphlets on fermentation and distillation of beverages in Willingdon. A week later Napoleon ordered that the field behind the orchard be plowed, intended as a recreational area for animals retired from work. It was said that the field was exhausted and needed to be cultivated again, but it soon became known that Napoleon intended to sow it with barley.

en: About this time there occurred a strange incident which hardly anyone was able to understand. One night at about twelve o’clock there was a loud crash in the yard, and the animals rushed out of their stalls. It was a moonlit night. At the foot of the end wall of the big barn, where the Seven Commandments were written, there lay a ladder broken in two pieces. Squealer, temporarily stunned, was sprawling beside it, and near at hand there lay a lantern, a paint-brush, and an overturned pot of white paint. The dogs immediately made a ring round Squealer, and escorted him back to the farmhouse as soon as he was able to walk. None of the animals could form any idea as to what this meant, except old Benjamin, who nodded his muzzle with a knowing air, and seemed to understand, but would say nothing.
vi: Around this time, an event occurred that almost none of the animals understood. That night, it was nearly midnight when a loud noise echoed from the yard, causing everyone to rush out of their pens. The moon was very bright that night, and they all saw near the gable end of the large barn, where the "Seven Commandments" were inscribed, a ladder broken in two. Nearby was Squealer, who was unconscious at the time, with a hurricane lamp and a can of white paint lying beside him. The dogs immediately formed a circle around Squealer and helped him back to the main house as he struggled to get up. It seemed that apart from Benjamin, none of the animals understood what had happened, but he just shook his head and said nothing.
tr: It was precisely during those days that something strange, which no one could understand, happened. One night, around midnight, all the animals rushed outside upon hearing a crackling noise coming from the courtyard. It was a moonlit night. At the foot of the long wall of the large barn where the Seven Commandments were written, a ladder split into two pieces was lying. Squealer was also lying on the ground beside the ladder; he looked dazed. A little further away, a lantern, a paintbrush, and a knocked-over can of white paint were noticeable. The dogs immediately surrounded Squealer, and as soon as he was able to walk a little, they took him to the farmhouse. No one could make sense of this incident. Only old Benjamin, who was nodding his head wisely, seemed to understand everything, but he said nothing.
es: More or less around that time, a strange incident occurred that almost no one was able to understand. One night, around twelve, a loud crash was heard in the yard, and the animals came running out. It was a clear, moonlit night. At the foot of the main barn wall, where the seven commandments were inscribed, there was a ladder broken into two pieces. Squealer, momentarily stunned, was lying on the ground, and very close by were a lantern, a brush, and a spilled can of white paint. The dogs immediately formed a circle around Squealer and escorted him back to the house as soon as he could walk. None of the animals could understand what it meant, except old Benjamin, who moved his snout knowingly, pretending to understand, but said nothing.

en: But a few days later Muriel, reading over the Seven Commandments to herself, noticed that there was yet another of them which the animals had remembered wrong. They had thought the Fifth Commandment was “No animal shall drink alcohol,” but there were two words that they had forgotten. Actually the Commandment read: “No animal shall drink alcohol TO EXCESS.”
vi: A few days later, Muriel, while rereading the Seven Commandments, discovered that they had misremembered another one. They thought that the Fifth Commandment was "No animal shall drink alcohol," but they had forgotten three words. In fact, the Commandment was: "No animal shall drink alcohol to excess." George Orwell Animal Farm
tr: But a few days later, while Muriel was reading the Seven Commandments once again on her own, she noticed that the animals had misremembered another of the commandments. They knew the Fifth Commandment as "No animal shall drink alcohol!" which meant they had forgotten a word. The correct version was: "No animal shall drink alcohol to excess."
es: After a few days, when Muriel was reading the seven commandments, she noticed that there was another one that the animals remembered incorrectly. They believed that the fifth commandment said: "No animal shall drink alcohol," but they overlooked two words. Now the commandment indicated: "No animal shall drink alcohol to excess."

en: Chapter 9
vi: Chapter 9
tr: Ninth Chapter
es: IX

en: Boxer’s split hoof was a long time in healing. They had started the rebuilding of the windmill the day after the victory celebrations were ended. Boxer refused to take even a day off work, and made it a point of honour not to let it be seen that he was in pain. In the evenings he would admit privately to Clover that the hoof troubled him a great deal. Clover treated the hoof with poultices of herbs which she prepared by chewing them, and both she and Benjamin urged Boxer to work less hard. “A horse’s lungs do not last for ever,” she said to him. But Boxer would not listen. He had, he said, only one real ambition left — to see the windmill well under way before he reached the age for retirement.
vi: The injured hoof of Warrior took a long time to heal. Meanwhile, the animals proceeded to restore the windmill right after the victory celebration. Warrior did not take a single day off, and it was very proud that it did not let the others see it was in pain. Only in the evening did it tell Fatty that the wound was tormenting it. Fatty had to chew leaves and apply them to Warrior's wound. She, along with Benjamin, persuaded Warrior to take care of itself. "A horse's lungs are not very strong," it said. But Chiến Sĩ did not listen. He said that he had only one wish, which was to see the windmill completed before he retired.
tr: It took a long time for Boxer's split hoof to heal. They had started rebuilding the windmill the day after the victory celebrations ended. Boxer had not agreed to take a single day off; he saw it as a matter of honor not to show anyone that he was in pain, and he only confessed to Clover in the evenings that his hoof hurt a lot. Clover was trying to heal Boxer's wound with poultices she prepared by chewing various herbs. Clover and Benjamin were begging Boxer not to overexert himself. Clover would say, "Horses get tired too," but Boxer wouldn't listen: He now had only one goal left, and that was to see the windmill working before he retired.
es: Boxer's split hoof took a long time to heal. They had begun the reconstruction of the windmill the day after the victory celebrations ended. Boxer refused to take even a single day off and made it a point of honor not to show that he was in pain. At night, he would privately admit to Clover that his hoof bothered him a lot. Clover treated it with herbal poultices that she prepared by chewing them, and both she and Benjamin asked Boxer to work less. "A horse's lungs are not eternal," she would tell him. But Boxer paid no attention to her. He said he had only one true ambition left: to see the windmill well advanced before reaching retirement age.

en: At the beginning, when the laws of Animal Farm were first formulated, the retiring age had been fixed for horses and pigs at twelve, for cows at fourteen, for dogs at nine, for sheep at seven, and for hens and geese at five. Liberal old-age pensions had been agreed upon. As yet no animal had actually retired on pension, but of late the subject had been discussed more and more. Now that the small field beyond the orchard had been set aside for barley, it was rumoured that a corner of the large pasture was to be fenced off and turned into a grazing-ground for superannuated animals. For a horse, it was said, the pension would be five pounds of corn a day and, in winter, fifteen pounds of hay, with a carrot or possibly an apple on public holidays. Boxer’s twelfth birthday was due in the late summer of the following year.
vi: Right from the establishment of the Animal Farm's rules, it was stipulated that the retirement age for horses and pigs is twelve, for cows is fourteen, for dogs is nine, for sheep is seven, and for chickens is five. They also agreed that those who retire would not lack anything. In fact, until now, no animal has retired yet, but recently this issue has been frequently discussed. Now, with the plot of land next to the garden being used to grow barley, there is news that a corner of the long pasture will be fenced off for the elderly animals. There is also news that retired horses will receive two pounds of grain per day in the summer, and seven pounds of hay in the winter, with an additional carrot or apple on holidays. Next year, Boxer will turn twelve years old.
tr: In the beginning, when the laws of Animal Farm were first being drafted, the retirement age was set at twelve for horses and pigs, fourteen for cows, nine for dogs, seven for sheep, and five for chickens and geese. It was decided that the retirement pensions would be kept high. Although no animal had yet retired, this topic had recently become more and more discussed. After the small meadow at the back of the orchard was allocated for barley cultivation, there was a rumor that a corner of the large meadow would be fenced off and used as pasture for animals that were due to retire; it was said that retired horses should be given two and a half kilos of grain per day, seven and a half kilos of hay in winter, and on holidays, a carrot or, if possible, an apple. Boxer would turn twelve towards the end of next summer.
es: In the beginning, when the laws of "Animal Farm" were formulated, the following retirement ages were set: horses and pigs at twelve years, cows at fourteen, dogs at nine, sheep at seven, and chickens and geese at five. Generous pensions were established for old age. Until then, no animal had retired, but lately, the discussion of the matter was increasing. Now that the small field behind the orchard had been designated for barley, there was a rumor that a corner of the long pasture would be fenced off, turning it into a field where retired animals would graze. For horses, it was said, the pension would be five pounds of maize per day and in winter fifteen pounds of hay, with a carrot or possibly an apple on holidays. Boxer was going to turn twelve at the end of the summer of the following year.

en: Meanwhile life was hard. The winter was as cold as the last one had been, and food was even shorter. Once again all rations were reduced, except those of the pigs and the dogs. A too rigid equality in rations, Squealer explained, would have been contrary to the principles of Animalism. In any case he had no difficulty in proving to the other animals that they were NOT in reality short of food, whatever the appearances might be. For the time being, certainly, it had been found necessary to make a readjustment of rations (Squealer always spoke of it as a “readjustment,” never as a “reduction”), but in comparison with the days of Jones, the improvement was enormous. Reading out the figures in a shrill, rapid voice, he proved to them in detail that they had more oats, more hay, more turnips than they had had in Jones’s day, that they worked shorter hours, that their drinking water was of better quality, that they lived longer, that a larger proportion of their young ones survived infancy, and that they had more straw in their stalls and suffered less from fleas. The animals believed every word of it. Truth to tell, Jones and all he stood for had almost faded out of their memories. They knew that life nowadays was harsh and bare, that they were often hungry and often cold, and that they were usually working when they were not asleep. But doubtless it had been worse in the old days. They were glad to believe so. Besides, in those days they had been slaves and now they were free, and that made all the difference, as Squealer did not fail to point out.
vi: Currently, their lives must be said to be quite difficult. This winter is as cold as last year, but food is even scarcer. Rations, except for dogs and pigs, have all been reduced. Absolute equality, Squealer explained, is contrary to the principles of Animalism. He easily proved to the others that they actually had enough food, and that the food shortage was merely an illusion. Of course, certain adjustments were necessary at this time (Squealer said "adjustments" rather than "reductions"), but compared to the days of old Jones, the improvement was clear. In a rapid, shrill voice, he presented very specific figures, proving that they harvested more oats, more hay, more turnips than in Jones's time, the work was lighter, the water quality was better, they lived longer, the infant survival rate was higher, they had more straw for bedding, and fewer lice. All the animals believed this. In fact, they had almost forgotten all about the days of Mr. Jones. They only knew that life now was very hard, arduous, they were often hungry, cold, and as soon as they opened their eyes, they had to work. It must have been even harder before. They were happy to believe this. Moreover, more importantly, they were slaves before, but now they were free, Squealer always emphasized this.
tr: The hardships of life seemed never-ending. This winter was as cold as the previous one, and food supplies had dwindled even further. Except for the rations of the pigs and dogs, all other rations had been cut once. According to Squealer's explanation, very strict equality in rations was against the principles of Animalism; it might seem like there was a food shortage, but the reality was far from it. Squealer was very good at soothing hearts. Undoubtedly, for now, they had to readjust the rations (Squealer never used the word "cut," preferring to say "readjustment"), but compared to Jones's era, there was still a significant improvement. Reading the numbers in a high-pitched voice and quickly, he demonstrated that compared to Jones's era, they ate more oats, more hay, and more turnips, worked fewer hours, had better quality drinking water, lived longer, saw a significant reduction in the number of dead offspring, had more straw in the barns, and were less infested with fleas. The animals believed whatever he said. To be honest, what happened during Jones's time had almost entirely faded from their memories. They knew that nowadays they lived a poor and harsh life, often going hungry and freezing from the cold, spending every minute working except for sleeping. But they believed that the old days were even worse and took solace in that. Moreover, as Squealer constantly emphasized, although they were slaves in the past, they were now free; and that was the main difference.
es: Meanwhile, life continued to be hard. The winter was as cold as the previous one, and food even more scarce. Once again, all rations were reduced, except for those of the pigs and the dogs. “A too rigid equality in rations,” explained Squealer, “would be contrary to the principles of Animalism.” In any case, he had no difficulty in demonstrating to the others that, in reality, they were not short of food, whatever the appearances might be. Certainly, it was necessary to make an adjustment of the rations (Squealer always referred to this as an “adjustment,” never as a “reduction”), but compared to Jones's times, the improvement was enormous. Reading them the figures in a shrill and rapid voice, he demonstrated in detail that they had more oats, more hay, and more turnips than they had in Jones's times; that they worked fewer hours, that the water they drank was of better quality, that they lived longer, that a greater proportion of creatures survived infancy, and that they had more straw in their stalls and fewer fleas. The animals believed everything he said. In truth, Jones, and what he represented, had almost faded from their memories. They knew that life was hard and harsh, that many times they were hungry and cold, and generally they were working when they were not sleeping. But, without a doubt, it had been worse in the old days. They felt happy to believe it so. Besides, in those days they were slaves and now they were free, and that made a big difference, as Squealer never forgot to point out to them.

en: There were many more mouths to feed now. In the autumn the four sows had all littered about simultaneously, producing thirty-one young pigs between them. The young pigs were piebald, and as Napoleon was the only boar on the farm, it was possible to guess at their parentage. It was announced that later, when bricks and timber had been purchased, a schoolroom would be built in the farmhouse garden. For the time being, the young pigs were given their instruction by Napoleon himself in the farmhouse kitchen. They took their exercise in the garden, and were discouraged from playing with the other young animals. About this time, too, it was laid down as a rule that when a pig and any other animal met on the path, the other animal must stand aside: and also that all pigs, of whatever degree, were to have the privilege of wearing green ribbons on their tails on Sundays.
vi: The population is increasing day by day. Last autumn, four sows farrowed at the same time, giving birth to a total of thirty-one piglets. All of them were spotted pigs, and since Napoleon was the only boar on the farm, it was easy to guess whose offspring they were. The entire farm was informed that bricks and wood were being purchased, and once acquired, a schoolhouse would be built. In the meantime, the piglets would be taught by Napoleon in the kitchen area. The piglets were allowed to play in the garden but were forbidden to interact with other species' young. A new rule was also introduced around this time, stating that everyone must step aside to give way to pigs, and additionally, pigs, regardless of rank, were to wear a green ribbon on their tails on Sundays.
tr: The number of mouths to feed had also increased. In the fall, four sows had given birth to a total of thirty-one piglets around the same time. Since the only male pig on the farm was Napoleon, it was not hard to guess who the father of the spotted piglets was. It was announced that a classroom would be built in the garden of the farmhouse when bricks and timber were obtained in the future. But for now, Napoleon himself was teaching the young pigs in the kitchen of the farmhouse. They would go out to the garden for physical education and walks, but they were not allowed to play with the other animals' offspring. Around that time, new rules were introduced: When a pig and another animal met on the road, the other animal would step aside to let the pig pass, and all pigs would have the privilege of wearing green ribbons on their tails on Sundays.
es: There were many more mouths to feed. In the autumn, the four sows gave birth simultaneously, nursing a total of thirty-one piglets. The young pigs were spotted, and since Napoleon was the only boar on the farm, it was not difficult to guess their paternal origin. It was announced that later on, when bricks and wood were purchased, a school would be built in the garden. Meanwhile, the piglets were educated by Napoleon himself in the house's kitchen. They did their exercises in the garden, and were discouraged from playing with the other young animals. At that time, the rule was also established that when a pig and any other animal met on the path, the latter had to step aside; and likewise, that pigs of any category would have the privilege of adorning themselves with green ribbons on their tails on Sundays.

en: The farm had had a fairly successful year, but was still short of money. There were the bricks, sand, and lime for the schoolroom to be purchased, and it would also be necessary to begin saving up again for the machinery for the windmill. Then there were lamp oil and candles for the house, sugar for Napoleon’s own table (he forbade this to the other pigs, on the ground that it made them fat), and all the usual replacements such as tools, nails, string, coal, wire, scrap-iron, and dog biscuits. A stump of hay and part of the potato crop were sold off, and the contract for eggs was increased to six hundred a week, so that that year the hens barely hatched enough chicks to keep their numbers at the same level. Rations, reduced in December, were reduced again in February, and lanterns in the stalls were forbidden to save oil. But the pigs seemed comfortable enough, and in fact were putting on weight if anything. One afternoon in late February a warm, rich, appetising scent, such as the animals had never smelt before, wafted itself across the yard from the little brew-house, which had been disused in Jones’s time, and which stood beyond the kitchen. Someone said it was the smell of cooking barley. The animals sniffed the air hungrily and wondered whether a warm mash was being prepared for their supper. But no warm mash appeared, and on the following Sunday it was announced that from now onwards all barley would be reserved for the pigs. The field beyond the orchard had already been sown with barley. And the news soon leaked out that every pig was now receiving a ration of a pint of beer daily, with half a gallon for Napoleon himself, which was always served to him in the Crown Derby soup tureen.
vi: This year has been quite successful, but money is still lacking. We still have to buy bricks, lime, and sand to build the school; and we also have to save up to buy machinery for the windmill. Then we need to buy oil for lamps, candles, and sugar for Napoleon alone (he forbids the other pigs from eating sugar for fear they will gain weight) and many other things like tools, nails, ropes, coal, wire, roofing sheets, and biscuits for the dogs. We have to sell some hay and potatoes, the contract to sell eggs has increased to six hundred eggs per week, so the number of chickens has almost not increased, if not decreased, because the number of eggs they leave for hatching is too few. In December, the rations were reduced once, in February they were reduced again, and to save money, from now on, no lights are allowed to be lit in the barns at night. But the pigs seem to be living well, at least each one has gained weight. Once, on a February afternoon, a strong fragrance suddenly filled the farmyard, a smell the animals had never encountered before. It turned out the smell came from the house behind the kitchen, which in Jones's time was used for brewing beer, but had been abandoned for a long time. Someone said it was the smell of brewing barley. The animals sniffed the strong, spicy aroma and tried to guess if they would get to eat the "mash" that night. But that night there was no "mash", and on Sunday they were informed that from now on the barley would be reserved exclusively for the pigs. The plot of land next to the garden had already been sown with barley. Then there was news that from now on each pig would get half a liter of beer a day, while Napoleon would get two liters, and he had to drink it from a crystal goblet.
tr: That year, although things were going well on the farm, they were still experiencing financial difficulties. They had to buy bricks, sand, and lime for the classroom and save money for the windmill's machinery. Additionally, they needed to buy kerosene and candles for the house, and sugar for Napoleon's table (he had banned sugar for the other pigs to prevent them from getting fat); tools, nails, string, coal, wire, scrap iron, and dog biscuits were also necessary. Some of the hay and potatoes had been sold; since the number of eggs in the contract had been increased to six hundred per week, the hens had not been able to hatch enough chicks that year. In February, the rations, which had been reduced in December, were restricted again, and lanterns were banned in the barns to save kerosene. But the pigs were comfortable; in fact, it could even be said that they were getting fatter. Towards the end of February, one evening, a warm, delicious, appetizing smell that the animals had never smelled before spread into the yard from the small brewery behind the kitchen, which had never been used during Jones's time. One of the animals said that it was the smell of barley being cooked. The hungry animals, inhaling the smell, couldn't help but wonder if a hot mash was being prepared for dinner. But far from a hot mash, it was announced the next Sunday that all the barley would be reserved for the pigs. Barley had already been planted in the field behind the orchard. Soon, a rumor spread: Each pig was now being given half a liter of beer a day, and Napoleon was receiving four liters, drinking his beer from the soup bowl of the Crown Derby set.
es: The farm had a fairly prosperous year, but they were still short of money. They still needed to acquire the bricks, sand, and cement necessary for the school, and it was going to be necessary to save again for the mill machinery. Additionally, oil was required for the lamps, candles for the house, sugar for Napoleon's table (he prohibited this for the other pigs, claiming it made them fat), and all the usual supplies like tools, nails, threads, coal, wire, iron, and biscuits for the dogs. A stack of hay and part of the potato harvest were sold, and the egg sale contract was increased to six hundred per week, so that year the hens barely hatched enough chicks to keep the numbers at the same level. Rations, reduced in December, were decreased again in February, and lanterns in the stalls were banned to save oil. But the pigs seemed quite comfortable and, in fact, were gaining weight. One afternoon, at the end of February, a warm and appetizing aroma, like the animals had never smelled before, reached the yard, carried by the breeze and coming from the little house where beer was brewed in Jones's time, a house that was located beyond the kitchen. Someone said it was the smell of boiling barley. The animals sniffed hungrily and wondered if a hot mash was being prepared for their dinner. But no hot mash appeared, and the following Sunday it was announced that from that moment all the barley would be reserved for the pigs. The field behind the orchard had already been sown with barley. And soon it was known that all the pigs received a ration of one pint of beer per day, and half a gallon for Napoleon himself, which was always served to him in the soup tureen from the set kept in the glass cabinet.

en: But if there were hardships to be borne, they were partly offset by the fact that life nowadays had a greater dignity than it had had before. There were more songs, more speeches, more processions. Napoleon had commanded that once a week there should be held something called a Spontaneous Demonstration, the object of which was to celebrate the struggles and triumphs of Animal Farm. At the appointed time the animals would leave their work and march round the precincts of the farm in military formation, with the pigs leading, then the horses, then the cows, then the sheep, and then the poultry. The dogs flanked the procession and at the head of all marched Napoleon’s black cockerel. Boxer and Clover always carried between them a green banner marked with the hoof and the horn and the caption, “Long live Comrade Napoleon!” Afterwards there were recitations of poems composed in Napoleon’s honour, and a speech by Squealer giving particulars of the latest increases in the production of foodstuffs, and on occasion a shot was fired from the gun. The sheep were the greatest devotees of the Spontaneous Demonstration, and if anyone complained (as a few animals sometimes did, when no pigs or dogs were near) that they wasted time and meant a lot of standing about in the cold, the sheep were sure to silence him with a tremendous bleating of “Four legs good, two legs bad!” But by and large the animals enjoyed these celebrations. They found it comforting to be reminded that, after all, they were truly their own masters and that the work they did was for their own benefit. So that, what with the songs, the processions, Squealer’s lists of figures, the thunder of the gun, the crowing of the cockerel, and the fluttering of the flag, they were able to forget that their bellies were empty, at least part of the time.
vi: Although there are still many difficulties, life is much more worth living than before. Never before have they been able to sing, listen to talks, attend rallies, and protest as much as they do now. Napoleon ordered that there must be a Parade every week, which he called Spontaneous, with the purpose of praising the struggle and achievements of Animal Farm. At the designated time, everyone would immediately leave their work, form ranks, starting with the pigs, followed by the horses, cows, sheep, and finally the chickens and ducks, and march around the farm. Napoleon's black rooster always led the way, while the dogs flanked the parade. Warrior and Fat Lady carried the green flag with the horn and hoof emblem and the slogan "Long live Comrade Napoleon." The rallies always ended with the recitation of a poem praising Napoleon and a report from the Pointer on the achievements in production increases over the past period; celebrations often included gun salutes as well. The sheep particularly enjoyed the parades, and if any of them complained (especially when the dogs and pigs were absent) that the parades were just cold and a waste of time, they would immediately chant their eternal prayer: "Four legs good, two legs bad," so loudly that it drowned out all (even any) complaints and grumbles. But generally, the majority liked such ceremonies. They felt somewhat comforted because such gatherings reminded them that they were truly the owners of the farm and everything they did was for themselves alone. The songs, the parades, the Pointer's statistics, the gun salutes, the rooster's crowing, and the flag fluttering in the wind helped them forget, even if just for a moment, the gnawing hunger that tormented them.
tr: Although the difficulties never ceased, the animals consoled themselves to some extent by thinking that they now lived much more honorably than before. More songs were sung, more speeches were made, and more ceremonies were held. Napoleon had ordered Spontaneous Demonstrations to be held once a week to celebrate the struggles and victories achieved on Animal Farm. At the designated time, the animals would stop working and march around the farm in military formation: pigs at the front, followed by horses, then cows, sheep, and finally poultry at the back... The dogs would walk on either side of the parade, and Napoleon's black rooster would lead the way. Boxer and Clover always carried a flag bearing the image of a hoof and horn, with the words "Long live Comrade Napoleon!" Afterwards, poems written in honor of Napoleon were read, followed by Squealer giving a speech detailing the latest increases in food production, and occasionally a gun would be fired. The greatest enthusiasts of the Spontaneous Demonstrations were the sheep; if any animal tried to complain that they were wasting time and doing nothing but standing in the cold (some animals did indeed complain when the pigs and dogs were not around), the sheep would immediately silence them by bleating "Four legs good, two legs bad!" at the top of their lungs. But generally, the animals enjoyed these ceremonies. After all, the reminder that they were their own masters and worked only for their own benefit was heartening. Thus, with the songs, parades, Squealer's statistics, the gun's roar, the rooster's crowing, and the flag's fluttering, they could occasionally forget their hunger.
es: But although there were no shortages of hardships to endure, they were partly compensated by the fact that life had greater dignity than before. There were more songs, more speeches, more parades. Napoleon ordered that once a week something called a Spontaneous Demonstration be held, the purpose of which was to celebrate the struggles and triumphs of "Animal Farm." At the appointed time, the animals would abandon their tasks and march around the farm's boundaries in military formation, with the pigs at the head, followed by the horses, cows, sheep, and then the birds. The dogs marched on the sides and at the very front, Napoleon's black rooster. Boxer and Clover always carried a green flag marked with the hoof and horn and the slogan: "Long live Comrade Napoleon!" Then came recitals of poems composed in honor of Napoleon and a speech by Squealer giving details of the latest increases in food production, and on some occasions, a shotgun would be fired. The sheep were the most enthusiastic about the Spontaneous Demonstrations, and if anyone complained (as some animals did sometimes when there were no pigs or dogs around) saying that it was a waste of time and involved standing around in the open for a long time, the sheep would invariably silence them with a loud: "Four legs good, two legs bad!" But, in the end, the animals liked these celebrations. It was satisfying to remember that, after all, they were really their own masters and that all the work they did was for the common benefit. And so, with the songs, the parades, Squealer's lists of figures, the thunder of the shotgun, the rooster's crowing, and the waving of the flag, they could forget for a while that their bellies were almost empty.

en: In April, Animal Farm was proclaimed a Republic, and it became necessary to elect a President. There was only one candidate, Napoleon, who was elected unanimously. On the same day it was given out that fresh documents had been discovered which revealed further details about Snowball’s complicity with Jones. It now appeared that Snowball had not, as the animals had previously imagined, merely attempted to lose the Battle of the Cowshed by means of a stratagem, but had been openly fighting on Jones’s side. In fact, it was he who had actually been the leader of the human forces, and had charged into battle with the words “Long live Humanity!” on his lips. The wounds on Snowball’s back, which a few of the animals still remembered to have seen, had been inflicted by Napoleon’s teeth.
vi: In April, Animal Farm declared itself a Republic, necessitating the election of a President. There was only one candidate. Napoleon was elected with one hundred percent of the vote. That very day, news came that new documents had been found proving that Snowball had been collaborating with Mr. Jones from the beginning. It turned out that Snowball not only used clever tactics to sabotage the Battle of the Cowshed, as previously thought, but had also fully sided with Mr. Jones. Snowball had led the human invasion, shouting loudly: "Long live humanity!". As for the wounds on his back, some animals still alive had seen those wounds and remembered clearly that they were indeed Napoleon's bite marks.
tr: In April, a Republic was declared at Animal Farm. It was necessary to elect a president. Napoleon, the only candidate, was unanimously elected president. On the same day, it was announced that new documents had been found revealing detailed information about Snowball being an accomplice of Jones. The documents showed that Snowball not only resorted to war tricks to lose the Battle of the Cowshed, as the animals initially thought, but also openly It revealed that he fought on Jones's side. Moreover, he had taken command of the Human forces and launched an attack, shouting "Long live Humanity!" Those who remembered seeing the wounds on Snowball's back with their own eyes were learning something entirely new: It turned out that Napoleon had inflicted those wounds with his teeth.
es: In April, "Animal Farm" was proclaimed a Republic, and it became necessary to elect a President. There was only one candidate: Napoleon, who was unanimously elected. The same day it was revealed that new documents had been discovered giving more details regarding Snowball's complicity with Jones. According to them, it seemed that Snowball not only tried to lose the "Battle of the Cowshed" through a stratagem, as the animals had supposed, but he was openly fighting in favor of Jones. In fact, it was he who led the human forces and charged into battle with the words "Long live Humanity!". The wounds on Snowball's back, which several animals still remembered seeing, were inflicted by Napoleon's teeth.

en: In the middle of the summer Moses the raven suddenly reappeared on the farm, after an absence of several years. He was quite unchanged, still did no work, and talked in the same strain as ever about Sugarcandy Mountain. He would perch on a stump, flap his black wings, and talk by the hour to anyone who would listen. “Up there, comrades,” he would say solemnly, pointing to the sky with his large beak —“up there, just on the other side of that dark cloud that you can see — there it lies, Sugarcandy Mountain, that happy country where we poor animals shall rest for ever from our labours!” He even claimed to have been there on one of his higher flights, and to have seen the everlasting fields of clover and the linseed cake and lump sugar growing on the hedges. Many of the animals believed him. Their lives now, they reasoned, were hungry and laborious; was it not right and just that a better world should exist somewhere else? A thing that was difficult to determine was the attitude of the pigs towards Moses. They all declared contemptuously that his stories about Sugarcandy Mountain were lies, and yet they allowed him to remain on the farm, not working, with an allowance of a gill of beer a day.
vi: After many years of absence, Moses suddenly reappeared in the middle of last summer. He had hardly changed, still refusing to do anything and spending all day telling fanciful stories about Sugarcandy Mountain. He often perched on a tree branch, flapping his black wings and talking for hours on end, as long as there was someone willing to listen. "Up there, comrades," It said while pointing its beak towards the sky, "above those black clouds is Mount Rice, where we, the wretched animals, will rest forever." It also said that it had once flown there, had seen clover fields lush all year round, and had seen gardens full of flaxseed cakes and sugar cubes. Yet there were many hostages. They thought they were starving, suffering, and struggling; so the idea of a more peaceful world somewhere else seemed only fair. But what they couldn't understand was the pigs' attitude towards Moses. The pigs scorned the idea that Sugar Mountain was just a fabrication, but Moses was not only not driven away but was also given a pint of beer each day.
tr: The raven Moses, who had not been seen for years, suddenly returned to the farm in the middle of summer. He had hardly changed; he did not lift a finger, and as before, he kept telling tales of the Sugarcandy Mountain. He perched on a stump, flapped his black wings, and if he found someone to listen, he would talk for hours. Pointing to the sky with his big beak, he would say in a very serious voice, "It's there, comrades." "Sugarcandy Mountain, the land where we poor animals shall be free from all our troubles and live in peace forever, is there, just behind that black cloud you see!" Moreover, he claimed that one day, while flying very high, he had passed by it and seen with his own eyes the clover fields stretching as far as the eye could see, and the hedges covered with linseed cakes and lumps of sugar. Many of the animals believed him. They lived in hunger and deprivation in this world; what could be more true or understandable than the existence of a better world elsewhere? The real puzzle was the pigs' attitude towards Moses. They both ridiculed him, saying that his tales of Sugarcandy Mountain were lies, and yet they allowed him to stay on the farm without working, even letting him drink beer every day.
es: In the middle of summer, Moses, the raven, suddenly reappeared on the farm after an absence of several years. He hadn't changed at all; he still did no work and spoke the same as always about Sugar Mountain. He would often perch on a post, flap his black wings, and talk for hours to anyone who would listen. “Up there, comrades,” he would say, solemnly pointing to the sky with his long beak, “up there, just behind that dark cloud you can see, lies Sugar Mountain, that happy land where we poor animals will rest forever from our labors.” He even claimed to have been there on one of his high flights and to have seen the perennial fields of clover and the linseed cake and sugar lumps growing in the hedges. Many of the animals believed him. Nowadays, they reasoned, their lives were nothing but hunger and work; wasn't it right and just, then, that a better world should exist somewhere? One difficult thing to determine was the pigs' attitude towards Moses. They all disdainfully declared that his tales about Sugar Mountain were lies, yet they allowed him to stay on the farm without working, with a small ration of beer per day.

en: After his hoof had healed up, Boxer worked harder than ever. Indeed, all the animals worked like slaves that year. Apart from the regular work of the farm, and the rebuilding of the windmill, there was the schoolhouse for the young pigs, which was started in March. Sometimes the long hours on insufficient food were hard to bear, but Boxer never faltered. In nothing that he said or did was there any sign that his strength was not what it had been. It was only his appearance that was a little altered; his hide was less shiny than it had used to be, and his great haunches seemed to have shrunken. The others said, “Boxer will pick up when the spring grass comes on”; but the spring came and Boxer grew no fatter. Sometimes on the slope leading to the top of the quarry, when he braced his muscles against the weight of some vast boulder, it seemed that nothing kept him on his feet except the will to continue. At such times his lips were seen to form the words, “I will work harder”; he had no voice left. Once again Clover and Benjamin warned him to take care of his health, but Boxer paid no attention. His twelfth birthday was approaching. He did not care what happened so long as a good store of stone was accumulated before he went on pension.
vi: Finally, Warrior's hoof healed, and it threw itself into work more enthusiastically than ever. The other animals also had to work no differently than hard labor prisoners. Besides the regular farm tasks and restoring the windmill, there was also the job of building a school for the piglets. The school construction began in March. Sometimes it seemed impossible to endure the time and intensity of the labor with an empty stomach, but Warrior never lost heart. There was no sign, either in words or actions, that its strength was not what it used to be. However, its appearance had changed a bit; its skin was no longer as glossy, and its hips looked smaller. Everyone said, "With fresh grass, Warrior will recover immediately," but spring had come, the grass was green, and Warrior hadn't gained any weight. When watching it strain to pull stones up the slope, it seemed as if its strength was exhausted, and only a steely will kept it standing. Looking at its lips, a keen observer could see it was trying to say, "I will try harder," but it couldn't utter the words. Mrs. Fat and Benjamin reminded it to take care of its health, but it ignored them. Its twelfth birthday was approaching. It only cared about one thing: gathering as many stones as possible before retiring, and whatever happened after that didn't matter.
tr: After Boxer’s leg healed, he began to work harder than ever. In fact, that year, all the animals were working like slaves. Besides the daily farm work and the rebuilding of the windmill, a classroom for the young pigs had also begun to be built in March. Eating less and working more was unbearable, but Boxer never gave up. It was impossible to tell from his speech or his work that he was no longer as strong as he used to be. Only his appearance had changed a bit; his coat was no longer as shiny, and his massive haunches had sunken in. Everyone was saying, "Once the spring grass grows, Boxer will recover." The spring grass grew, but Boxer did not recover. Sometimes, on the slope leading to the quarry, when his muscles trembled under a large piece of rock, the only thing keeping him standing was his determination. In such situations, despite having completely lost his voice, the words "I will work harder" could be read from his lips. Clover and Benjamin constantly warned him to take care of his health, but Boxer did not listen. His twelfth birthday was approaching. He did not care about his health; his only wish was to gather enough stones for the windmill before he retired.
es: After his hoof was healed, Boxer worked harder than ever. Indeed, all the animals worked like slaves that year. Apart from the usual farm chores and the rebuilding of the windmill, there was the school for the piglets, which began in March. Sometimes, the long hours of work with insufficient food were hard to endure, but Boxer never wavered. In nothing he said or did was there any sign that his strength was no longer what it used to be. Only his appearance had changed a little. His coat was less shiny and his haunches seemed to have shrunken. The others said that Boxer would recover when the spring grass appeared; but spring came and Boxer did not gain weight. Sometimes, on the slope leading to the top of the quarry, when he strained his tense muscles under the weight of some huge stone, it seemed that nothing kept him standing except his will to continue. At these moments, one could guess that his lips were forming the words: "I will work harder" because he had no voice left. Again Clover and Benjamin warned him to take care of his health, but Boxer paid no attention. His twelfth birthday was approaching. He did not care what happened, as long as a good amount of stone had been accumulated before he retired.

en: Late one evening in the summer, a sudden rumour ran round the farm that something had happened to Boxer. He had gone out alone to drag a load of stone down to the windmill. And sure enough, the rumour was true. A few minutes later two pigeons came racing in with the news; “Boxer has fallen! He is lying on his side and can’t get up!”
vi: One night, when it was already quite late, there was suddenly news that Chiến Sĩ had met with an accident. It turned out that he had gone to pull the stone cart alone. It was no longer a rumor, it was the truth; a few minutes later, two pigeons flew back. "The Warrior has fallen! It fell and is lying on its side, it can't get up anymore!", the two pigeons reported.
tr: One summer evening, a rumor suddenly spread on the farm: Something had happened to Boxer. He had tried to carry a load of stones for the windmill all by himself. The rumor was undoubtedly true. Soon after, two pigeons hurriedly brought the news: "Boxer has collapsed! He can't get up!"
es: One summer day, at dusk, the rumor quickly spread across the farm that something had happened to Boxer. He had gone alone to drag a pile of stones to the mill. And, indeed, the rumor was true. A few minutes later, two pigeons came flying in with the news: "Boxer has fallen! He is lying on his side and cannot get up!"

en: About half the animals on the farm rushed out to the knoll where the windmill stood. There lay Boxer, between the shafts of the cart, his neck stretched out, unable even to raise his head. His eyes were glazed, his sides matted with sweat. A thin stream of blood had trickled out of his mouth. Clover dropped to her knees at his side.
vi: Almost half of the animals on the farm rushed towards the mound. Warrior lay there, between the two cart shafts, his neck stretched out, but too weak to lift his head. His back was drenched in sweat, and his eyes looked wild. A small stream of blood was oozing from his mouth. Fat Lady knelt down beside him.
tr: Almost half of the animals on the farm ran to the small hill where the windmill was located. Boxer was there, lying between the shafts of the cart, stretching his neck, unable to even lift his head. His eyes were glassy, and his body was drenched in sweat from head to toe. A thin stream of blood was oozing from his mouth. Clover knelt down beside him.
es: Approximately half of the farm animals ran towards the hill where the windmill was. There lay Boxer, between the shafts of the cart, his neck stretched out, unable to lift his head. His eyes were glassy, and his flanks were covered in sweat. A trickle of blood was coming out of his mouth. Clover fell to her knees beside him.

en: “Boxer!” she cried, “how are you?”
vi: "Warrior!", it asked, "What happened to you?"
tr: "Boxer!" he shouted. "What happened to you?"
es: —Boxer! —he shouted—, how are you?

en: “It is my lung,” said Boxer in a weak voice. “It does not matter. I think you will be able to finish the windmill without me. There is a pretty good store of stone accumulated. I had only another month to go in any case. To tell you the truth, I had been looking forward to my retirement. And perhaps, as Benjamin is growing old too, they will let him retire at the same time and be a companion to me.”
vi: "I can't breathe anymore," Soldier whispered, "But it's okay. I think you all will be able to rebuild the windmill. There are plenty of stones already. Anyway, it's only one more month until I retire. To be honest, I'm really looking forward to retirement. Benjamin is old too, if he could retire at the same time as me to keep me company, that would be wonderful."
tr: Boxer, in a barely audible voice, said, "My lungs gave out." "No matter. You can finish the windmill without me." A lot of stones have been collected. And I only had a month left. Honestly, I was eagerly looking forward to my retirement. Benjamin has aged too; maybe they'll retire him as well, and he can keep me company."
es: —It's my lung —said Boxer weakly—. It doesn't matter. I believe they can finish the windmill without me. There is a good amount of stone accumulated. Anyway, I only had one more month left. To tell the truth, I was looking forward to retirement. And since Benjamin is also getting old, maybe they'll let him retire at the same time, and he could keep me company.

en: “We must get help at once,” said Clover. “Run, somebody, and tell Squealer what has happened.”
vi: "Go inform Chỉ Điểm immediately," Mrs. Mập said.
tr: Clover said, "We must ask for help immediately." "Run, inform Squealer."" The animals all ran together to the farmhouse to tell Squealer what had happened.
es: —We must get help immediately —demanded Clover—. Someone should run to inform Squealer about what has happened.

en: All the other animals immediately raced back to the farmhouse to give Squealer the news. Only Clover remained, and Benjamin who lay down at Boxer’s side, and, without speaking, kept the flies off him with his long tail. After about a quarter of an hour Squealer appeared, full of sympathy and concern. He said that Comrade Napoleon had learned with the very deepest distress of this misfortune to one of the most loyal workers on the farm, and was already making arrangements to send Boxer to be treated in the hospital at Willingdon. The animals felt a little uneasy at this. Except for Mollie and Snowball, no other animal had ever left the farm, and they did not like to think of their sick comrade in the hands of human beings. However, Squealer easily convinced them that the veterinary surgeon in Willingdon could treat Boxer’s case more satisfactorily than could be done on the farm. And about half an hour later, when Boxer had somewhat recovered, he was with difficulty got on to his feet, and managed to limp back to his stall, where Clover and Benjamin had prepared a good bed of straw for him.
vi: Everyone immediately ran to the main house to find Chỉ Điểm. Only Bà Mập and Benjamin stayed behind. Benjamin quietly lay down next to Chiến Sĩ and used his tail to swat flies away from him. About fifteen minutes later, Chỉ Điểm arrived, his face showing full of sympathy and eagerness. He said that comrade Napoleon was very sad to hear that an accident had happened to one of the farm's most loyal workers and was arranging to take Chiến Sĩ to be treated at the hospital in Willingdon. But the animals felt uneasy because, until now, apart from Mollie and Tuyết Tròn, no one had ever left the farm, and they also didn't like the idea of handing over a sick comrade to humans. However, Chỉ Điểm easily convinced them that the veterinarians in Willingdon would treat Chiến Sĩ better than just letting him lie in the farm. About half an hour later, Chiến Sĩ managed to stand up and slowly made his way back to the barn. Bà Mập and Benjamin spread straw to make him a rather thick bed.
tr: The animals all ran together to the farmhouse to tell Squealer what had happened. Only Clover and Benjamin stayed behind; Benjamin lay down beside Boxer, swatting flies away with his long tail. About fifteen minutes later, Squealer appeared; he looked sad and worried. He said that Comrade Napoleon had learned with great sorrow what had happened to one of the farm's most loyal workers and was trying to arrange for Boxer to be sent to the hospital in Willingdon for treatment. The animals felt a bit uneasy. Until that day, no animal except Mollie and Snowball had ever left the farm; they did not like the idea of their sick comrade being handed over to humans. But Squealer did not delay in calming them down: the veterinarian in Willingdon could treat Boxer much better. About half an hour later, Boxer recovered a bit and got up with difficulty; he hobbled to his stall and lay down on the straw bed that Clover and Benjamin had prepared.
es: All the animals immediately ran towards the house to give the news to Squealer. Only Clover and Benjamin stayed, who lay down next to Boxer and, without saying a word, shooed away the flies with his long tail. A quarter of an hour later, Squealer appeared, alarmed and full of interest. He said that comrade Napoleon, greatly distressed by the misfortune that had befallen one of the farm's most loyal workers, was making arrangements to send Boxer to a hospital in Willingdon for treatment. The animals felt a bit uneasy upon hearing this. Except for Mollie and Snowball, no other animal had ever left the farm, and they did not like the idea of leaving their sick comrade in the hands of human beings. However, Squealer easily convinced them that the veterinarian in Willingdon could treat Boxer's case more satisfactorily than on the farm. And half an hour later, when Boxer recovered a little, they laboriously lifted him, and thus he managed to limp back to his stable where Clover and Benjamin had quickly prepared a very large and comfortable straw bed for him.

en: For the next two days Boxer remained in his stall. The pigs had sent out a large bottle of pink medicine which they had found in the medicine chest in the bathroom, and Clover administered it to Boxer twice a day after meals. In the evenings she lay in his stall and talked to him, while Benjamin kept the flies off him. Boxer professed not to be sorry for what had happened. If he made a good recovery, he might expect to live another three years, and he looked forward to the peaceful days that he would spend in the corner of the big pasture. It would be the first time that he had had leisure to study and improve his mind. He intended, he said, to devote the rest of his life to learning the remaining twenty-two letters of the alphabet.
vi: The Warrior lay in the pen for two consecutive days. The pigs found a rather large bottle of pink medicine in the medicine cabinet in the bathroom and brought it to him. Mrs. Fat made him take it twice a day, right after meals. In the evening, Mrs. Fat went into the Warrior's pen to chat, while Benjamin shooed away the flies for him. The Warrior said he had nothing to complain about. If he recovered this time, he could live for another three years, and he hoped to spend his remaining peaceful days in the corner of the large meadow reserved for retirees. He would devote all his free time to studying and improving his skills. He said he would spend the rest of his life learning to master the twenty-two letters of the alphabet.
tr: Boxer stayed in his stable for two days. The pigs had sent a large medicine bottle they found in the bathroom medicine cabinet. Clover was giving Boxer the pink medicine from the bottle twice a day after meals. In the evenings, Clover stayed in Boxer's stable and talked with him, while Benjamin shooed away the flies. Boxer said he was not upset about what had happened to him. If he could recover, he could live at least three more years and spend peaceful days in a corner of the large pasture. Perhaps for the first time in his life, he would be able to take time to read and learn something. He was thinking of dedicating his final years to learning the entire alphabet.
es: During the following two days, Boxer remained in his stable. The pigs had sent a large bottle of the pink medicine they found in the bathroom cabinet, and Clover administered it to Boxer twice a day after meals. In the afternoons, she stayed in the stable talking with him, while Benjamin shooed away the flies. Boxer stated that he did not regret what had happened. If he recovered, he could live for about three more years, and he thought about the peaceful days he would spend in the corner of the large meadow. It would be the first time he would have free time to study and improve himself. He intended, he said, to dedicate the rest of his life to learning the remaining twenty-two letters of the alphabet.

en: However, Benjamin and Clover could only be with Boxer after working hours, and it was in the middle of the day when the van came to take him away. The animals were all at work weeding turnips under the supervision of a pig, when they were astonished to see Benjamin come galloping from the direction of the farm buildings, braying at the top of his voice. It was the first time that they had ever seen Benjamin excited — indeed, it was the first time that anyone had ever seen him gallop. “Quick, quick!” he shouted. “Come at once! They’re taking Boxer away!” Without waiting for orders from the pig, the animals broke off work and raced back to the farm buildings. Sure enough, there in the yard was a large closed van, drawn by two horses, with lettering on its side and a sly-looking man in a low-crowned bowler hat sitting on the driver’s seat. And Boxer’s stall was empty.
vi: Benjamin and Mrs. Fat could only take care of Warrior after working hours, yet the vehicle to take him away appeared around noon. The pigs were commanding the group to sow mustard seeds in the field when suddenly they saw Benjamin galloping from the farm, shouting until his voice was hoarse. This was the first time they had seen Benjamin so emotional, and also the first time they had seen him gallop. "Hurry up! Hurry up!", he screamed, "Come here quickly! They have taken the Warrior away!" The whole group immediately dropped what they were doing and ran towards the main house, not waiting for the pigs' permission. Indeed, in the yard, there was a closed two-horse carriage, with large letters written on its side, and the coachman wore a fedora that made him look quite cunning. Warrior was no longer in the pen.
tr: However, Benjamin and Clover could only look after Boxer after working hours. When a covered cart came to take Boxer away, it was noon. The animals, who were weeding the turnip field under the supervision of a pig, were very surprised to see Benjamin galloping from the direction of the farm buildings, braying at the top of his lungs. They were seeing Benjamin agitated for the first time in their lives; in fact, no one had ever seen him gallop until that day. "Quick! Quick!" shouted Benjamin. "Come at once! They're taking Boxer away!" The animals, disregarding the pig, left their work and ran towards the farm buildings. Indeed, in the yard, there was a large covered cart with two horses. On the side of the cart, there was a writing, and on the driver's seat sat a man with a bowler hat and a devilish look. Boxer's stall was empty.
es: However, Benjamin and Clover could only be with Boxer after working hours, and at noon a van arrived to take him away. The animals were working under the supervision of a pig, weeding the turnips, when they were surprised to see Benjamin coming at a gallop from the house, braying with all his might. They had never seen Benjamin so excited; indeed, it was the first time anyone had seen him gallop. “Quick, quick! —he shouted—. Come at once! They're taking Boxer away!” Without waiting for orders from the pig, the animals abandoned their work and ran towards the farm buildings. Indeed, in the yard there was a large closed van, with signs on the sides, pulled by two horses, and a sly-looking man wearing a crushed bowler hat on the driver's seat. Boxer's stall was empty.

en: The animals crowded round the van. “Good-bye, Boxer!” they chorused, “good-bye!”
vi: The animals gathered around the vehicle. "Travel safely, Warrior!", They shouted in unison, "Goodbye!"
tr: The animals had surrounded the car and were all shouting together, "Goodbye, Boxer!" "Safe travels!"
es: The animals crowded around the cart. —Goodbye, Boxer! —they shouted in unison—, goodbye! —Idiots!

en: “Fools! Fools!” shouted Benjamin, prancing round them and stamping the earth with his small hoofs. “Fools! Do you not see what is written on the side of that van?”
vi: "Stupid, so stupid," Benjamin screamed while running around, his feet thudding on the ground, "Stupid, can't you see any letters?"
tr: But Benjamin was leaping around them and stamping the earth with his small hoofs. "Fools! Fools!" he shouted. "Do you not see what is written on the side of that van? Do you not see what they are doing?"
es: Idiots! —exclaimed Benjamin, jumping around them and kicking the ground with his small hooves—. Idiots! Don't you see what is written on the signs of that van?

en: That gave the animals pause, and there was a hush. Muriel began to spell out the words. But Benjamin pushed her aside and in the midst of a deadly silence he read:
vi: The whole group seemed to awaken, silently looking at each other. The donkey Muriel began to spell out, but Benjamin pushed her aside and read:
tr: The animals who heard Benjamin paused; a silence enveloped the surroundings. Muriel was trying to decipher the writing. Benjamin pushed her aside and read the writing in the midst of the deathly silence:
es: That pacified the animals, and silence fell. Muriel began to spell out the words. But Benjamin pushed her aside and, in the midst of a sepulchral silence, read:

en: “‘Alfred Simmonds, Horse Slaughterer and Glue Boiler, Willingdon. Dealer in Hides and Bone-Meal. Kennels Supplied.’ Do you not understand what that means? They are taking Boxer to the knacker’s!”
vi: "Alfred Simmond's slaughterhouse, Willingdon. Buying and selling meat, bones, horse hides. Providing dog kennels. Do you understand? They are taking Warrior to be slaughtered!"
tr: "Alfred Simmonds, Horse Slaughterer and Glue Boiler, Willingdon. Dealer in Hides and Bone-Meal. Dog Kennels Supplied. Do you understand now? They're taking Boxer to the horse slaughterer, they're going to make dog food out of him!"
es: —"Alfredo Simmonds, horse slaughterer and glue manufacturer, Willingdon. Dealer in hides and bone meal. Supplies kennels." Don't you understand what that means? They're taking him to the knacker!

en: A cry of horror burst from all the animals. At this moment the man on the box whipped up his horses and the van moved out of the yard at a smart trot. All the animals followed, crying out at the tops of their voices. Clover forced her way to the front. The van began to gather speed. Clover tried to stir her stout limbs to a gallop, and achieved a canter. “Boxer!” she cried. “Boxer! Boxer! Boxer!” And just at this moment, as though he had heard the uproar outside, Boxer’s face, with the white stripe down his nose, appeared at the small window at the back of the van.
vi: A terrifying scream erupted from every chest. At that moment, the coachman cracked his whip, and the two horses began to trot. The carriage slowly moved out of the yard. The whole group ran after it, crying like a storm. Fat Lady rushed forward. The carriage also sped up. Fat Lady tried to leap forward, but she was exhausted and couldn't keep up with the other two. "Warrior!", he screamed, "Warrior! Warrior! Warrior!" It is unknown whether Chiến Sĩ heard the call from outside or not, but its snout with a white streak running along its nose was peeking inside the small window at the back of the vehicle.
tr: The animals screamed in terror. At that moment, the man sitting in the driver's seat whipped the horses, and the carriage, pulled by the trotting horses, exited the courtyard. All the animals, making a tremendous noise, followed behind the carriage. Clover was leading the way with all her might. The carriage began to speed up. Although Clover tried to break into a gallop with her strong legs, she could only manage a canter. "Boxer!" she was shouting. "Boxer! Boxer! Boxer!" Just then, as if he had heard the commotion outside, Boxer's face appeared in the small window at the back of the carriage.
es: The animals let out a cry of horror. At that moment, the driver whipped the horses and the van left the yard at a light trot. All the animals followed it, shouting. Clover moved forward. The van began to pick up speed. Clover tried to gallop, but her heavy hooves only managed a half-gallop. —Boxer! —she shouted—. Boxer! Boxer! At that moment, as if he had heard the commotion, Boxer's face, with the white stripe on his muzzle, appeared in the rear window of the cart.

en: “Boxer!” cried Clover in a terrible voice. “Boxer! Get out! Get out quickly! They’re taking you to your death!”
vi: "Warrior!", Mrs. Fat shouted until her voice was hoarse, "Run! Run! Run quickly! They will kill you!"
tr: Clover cried out, "Boxer!" in a heart-wrenching voice. "Boxer! Get out of there! Get out quickly! They're taking you to be slaughtered!"
es: —Boxer! —shouted Clover in a terrible voice—. Boxer! Get out of there! Get out quickly! They are taking you to your death!

en: All the animals took up the cry of “Get out, Boxer, get out!” But the van was already gathering speed and drawing away from them. It was uncertain whether Boxer had understood what Clover had said. But a moment later his face disappeared from the window and there was the sound of a tremendous drumming of hoofs inside the van. He was trying to kick his way out. The time had been when a few kicks from Boxer’s hoofs would have smashed the van to matchwood. But alas! his strength had left him; and in a few moments the sound of drumming hoofs grew fainter and died away. In desperation the animals began appealing to the two horses which drew the van to stop. “Comrades, comrades!” they shouted. “Don’t take your own brother to his death! “But the stupid brutes, too ignorant to realise what was happening, merely set back their ears and quickened their pace. Boxer’s face did not reappear at the window. Too late, someone thought of racing ahead and shutting the five-barred gate; but in another moment the van was through it and rapidly disappearing down the road. Boxer was never seen again.
vi: Everyone shouted in unison: "Run, Warrior, Run!" But the two horses had increased their speed, and the cart was getting farther away. It was unclear whether Chiến Sĩ had heard what Bà Mập said or not, but his muzzle was no longer visible inside the window, and at the same time, one could hear his paws hitting the side of the cart rhythmically and loudly, much like the sound of a drum. That was Chiến Sĩ kicking the side of the cart to find a way out. In the past, just a few kicks like that would have been enough to turn this cart into firewood. But oh my God! His strength was gone now, and the sound of his kicks grew fainter and fainter until it stopped completely. Not knowing what else to do, the animals turned to the two pulling horses for help, begging them to stop running. "Comrades! Comrades!", They shouted in unison again, "Do you know where you are taking your brother?" But the two dim-witted animals did not understand; they only perked up their ears slightly and ran even faster. Warrior was no longer visible through the small window. Some thought about running out to close the large gate, but it was too late; the vehicle had already reached the main road and was getting farther away. From then on, no one saw Warrior again.
tr: The animals were also shouting, "Get out of there, Boxer! Throw yourself out!" But the cart had picked up speed and was getting farther away. It was unclear whether Boxer understood what Clover was saying. But soon his face disappeared from the window, and terrible thumping sounds were heard from inside the cart. He was trying to kick open the door. In the past, he would have shattered the cart door with a few kicks. But not anymore! The strength he once had was long gone. After a while, the thumping gradually weakened and finally stopped altogether. Desperate, the animals this time called out to the horses pulling the cart: "Comrades! Comrades! Don't take your brother to his death!" But the stupid horses, not understanding what was happening, laid their ears back and sped up a little more. Boxer's face did not appear at the window again. One of them thought of running ahead to close the farm gate, but it was too late; the cart passed through the gate and quickly disappeared from sight. They never saw Boxer again.
es: All the animals began to shout: “Get out of there, Boxer, get out of there!” but the van had already picked up speed and was moving away from them. It was not known if Boxer understood what Clover said. But a moment later, his face disappeared from the window and the sound of hooves kicking was heard inside the van. He was trying to kick his way out. In earlier times, a few kicks from Boxer’s hooves would have shattered the van. But, unfortunately, his strength had left him; and soon the sound of hooves grew weaker and died away. In their desperation, the animals began to appeal to the two horses pulling the van to stop. “Comrades, comrades!” they shouted. “Don’t take your own brother to his death!” But the stupid beasts, too ignorant to realize what was happening, laid back their ears and quickened their trot. Boxer’s face did not appear at the window again. It was too late when someone thought to run ahead to close the gate; in an instant, the van was gone and disappeared down the road. Boxer was never seen again.

en: Three days later it was announced that he had died in the hospital at Willingdon, in spite of receiving every attention a horse could have. Squealer came to announce the news to the others. He had, he said, been present during Boxer’s last hours.
vi: Three days later, there was an announcement that Warrior had passed away at the hospital in Willingdon, despite receiving very attentive care. It was Squealer who made the announcement. He also said that he had been by Warrior's side during his final moments.
tr: The news came three days later that Boxer had died in the hospital at Willingdon despite all the care shown. Squealer, who announced the news, said he was with Boxer in his final moments.
es: Three days later, it was announced that he had died in the hospital at Willingdon, despite receiving all the care that could be given to a horse. Squealer announced the news to the others. He had been present, he said, during Boxer’s last hours.

en: “It was the most affecting sight I have ever seen!” said Squealer, lifting his trotter and wiping away a tear. “I was at his bedside at the very last. And at the end, almost too weak to speak, he whispered in my ear that his sole sorrow was to have passed on before the windmill was finished. ‘Forward, comrades!’ he whispered. ‘Forward in the name of the Rebellion. Long live Animal Farm! Long live Comrade Napoleon! Napoleon is always right.’ Those were his very last words, comrades.”
vi: "It was incredibly moving," Chỉ Điểm said while wiping away tears, "I sat beside Chiến Sĩ as he took his last breath. Before he died, he was very weak, unable to speak, but he still tried to whisper that he regretted not being able to attend the windmill's inauguration. "Forward, comrades - he said - For the cause of the Rebellion, march forward! Long live Animal Farm! Long live Comrade Napoleon! Comrade Napoleon is always right!" - Those were his last words."
tr: Squealer, lifting his foreleg to wipe away his tears, said, "I have never seen such a touching scene!" "I was by his side until the very end. He no longer had the strength to speak. With his last breath, he whispered in my ear that his only regret was not being able to see the windmill completed. 'Forward, comrades!' he said with difficulty. 'Forward in the name of the Rebellion! Long live Animal Farm! Long live Comrade Napoleon! Napoleon is always right!' These were his last words, comrades."
es: —It was the most moving scene I have ever witnessed! —expressed Squealer, raising his paw to wipe away a tear—. I was by his bedside until the very last moment, and in the end, almost too weak to speak, he whispered to me that his only regret was dying before the windmill was finished. «Onward, comrades —he murmured—. Onward in the name of the Rebellion. Long live "Animal Farm"! Long live Comrade Napoleon! Napoleon is always right!» Those were his last words, comrades.

en: Here Squealer’s demeanour suddenly changed. He fell silent for a moment, and his little eyes darted suspicious glances from side to side before he proceeded.
vi: At that moment, Chỉ Điểm's attitude suddenly changed. He sat still for a while, then looked around before continuing the story.
tr: Then, Squealer's demeanor suddenly changed. He paused for a moment, cast suspicious glances around with his tiny eyes, and then began to speak.
es: Here Squealer's demeanor changed suddenly. He remained silent for a moment, and his little eyes darted suspicious glances from side to side before continuing.

en: It had come to his knowledge, he said, that a foolish and wicked rumour had been circulated at the time of Boxer’s removal. Some of the animals had noticed that the van which took Boxer away was marked “Horse Slaughterer,” and had actually jumped to the conclusion that Boxer was being sent to the knacker’s. It was almost unbelievable, said Squealer, that any animal could be so stupid. Surely, he cried indignantly, whisking his tail and skipping from side to side, surely they knew their beloved Leader, Comrade Napoleon, better than that? But the explanation was really very simple. The van had previously been the property of the knacker, and had been bought by the veterinary surgeon, who had not yet painted the old name out. That was how the mistake had arisen.
vi: It said that since Chiến Sỹ was taken away, unfounded rumors had been spreading in the camp. Some animals, upon seeing the words "Slaughterhouse" on the side of the truck, hastily concluded that Chiến Sỹ was taken away to be slaughtered. Chỉ Điểm said that it couldn't believe that the animals in the camp were that foolish. Unbelievable, Chỉ Điểm said while wagging its tail and jumping around, that the animals in the camp could think of their beloved leader, think of comrade Napoleon in such a way! Things were much simpler. The fact was that the veterinarian had bought the truck from the slaughterhouse, but he hadn't had the chance to remove the old owner's name yet. That was the only reason.
tr: After Boxer was taken away, he had heard that a ridiculous and vile rumor had spread on the farm. According to the rumor, some animals had seen "Horse Slaughterer" written on the cart that took Boxer away and immediately concluded that Boxer was being sent to be slaughtered. It was unbelievable that an animal could be so stupid. He was pacing back and forth, shouting angrily. Did they not know their beloved Leader Comrade Napoleon at all? Would Comrade Napoleon ever allow such a thing? Yet the truth was very simple. The cart, which had once been used by a horse slaughterer, had been bought by the veterinarian a short while ago, but the veterinarian had not had time to erase the writing on the cart. This was where the problem stemmed from.
es: It had come to his attention —he said— that a ridiculous and malicious rumor circulated when Boxer was taken away. Some animals noticed that the van that transported Boxer had the inscription: "Horse Slaughterer," and hastily concluded that this was indeed Boxer's fate. It was almost unbelievable, said Squealer, that an animal could be so stupid.
